The stock market headed lower early Tuesday following three-day Memorial Day weekend. The S&P 500 index and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively, while the Nasdaq dipped nearly 0.1%.Among the Dow industrials, Verizon (VZ) paced the advancers with a 1.1% rise. Fast-food chain McDonald's (MCD) fell 0.2% despite having its price target hiked at Barclay's to 164 from 155. The firm maintained its outperform rating amid its raised expectations for the company's digital and delivery efforts.In early trading, the blue chip's laggards include financial component Goldman Sachs (GS) and energy components Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM). The global investment bank fell 1.9%, while the oil giants fell 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively, as oil prices slipped more than 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate just above $49 a barrel.On the S&P 500, computer security firm Symantec (SYMC) rose 2% after being upgraded to overweight from equal-weight at Barclay's. Shares were attempting to reclaim their 50-day line after piercing it on May 17.On the downside, energy names found themselves at the bottom of the S&P 500's performers amid a 1.4% decline in the price of crude oil. Devon Energy (DVN) and Valero Energy (VLO) fell 3.1% and 1.3%, respectively.Among other leading stocks, Micron Technology (MU) jumped more than 2% as it surged above a 29.97 flat-base buy point. Fellow data storage firms Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) rose 2.3% and 1.5%, respectively.Nvidia (NVDA) rose 2.8% as it set a fresh record high, while e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) briefly broke above the vaunted 1000 price level, rising 0.3%.Among analyst actions, former highflier Ambarella (AMBA) fell 6.5% after being downgraded to sector weight from overweight at Pacific Crest. Over the last eight weeks, the stock has made a strong comeback on its way to building the right side of a potential cup-base. Meanwhile, Tesla (TSLA) was initiated at hold by Independent Research. Shares of the electric automaker soared over 2% to reach a new high, extending its three-day winning streak.Action in the IBD 50 was mostly positive after the open, but several leaders found themselves under pressure early Tuesday. China education stocks New Oriental Education (EDU) and TAL Education (TAL) fell 3.5% each.On the upside, Match Group (MTCH) and Ichor (ICHR) moved up 2.9% and 3.4%, respectively.RELATED:Analysts Tout McDonald's, Yum But Cut Ambarella, AutoZoneSnap Seeks Support, But These 3 Hot IPOs Are Near Buy ZonesDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisWeek In Review: Stocks Hit Highs On FANGs; Oil Dives After OPEC; Best Buy, Ulta Shine

When putting together your watch list, focus on stocks with an 80 or higher RS rating. BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) now meets that criteria, with a jump from 79 to 82 Thursday.IBD's proprietary RS Rating tracks market leadership by using a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score that shows how a stock's price performance over the trailing 52 weeks matches up against other publicly traded companies.History reveals that the market's biggest winners typically have an RS Rating of above 80 as they launch their biggest price moves.The stock is building a cup with handle with a 47.65 buy point. See if the stock can clear the breakout price in heavy trade.Fellow members of the Retail-Restaurant industry group Starbucks (SBUX), McDonald's (MCD) and Red Robin Gourmet Burgers (RRGB) have already served up recent breakouts.BJ's Restaurants reported -11% growth in the latest quarterly report. Sales gains came in at 6%.BJ's Restaurants earns the No. 12 rank among its peers in the Retail-Restaurants industry group. Habit Restaurants (HABT), Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) and Panera Bread (PNRA) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.RELATED:Stocks With Rising Relative Strength RatingsWhy Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

X Major stock indexes showed modest gains in afternoon trading Wednesday ahead of the release of the minutes from the May 2-3 Fed meeting at 2 p.m. ET.The market is expecting another rate hike at the June meeting, but Wall Street could get more color on the Fed's plans to shrink its $4.5 trillion balance sheet. Liquidating holdings would be another form of a rate hike.The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite were up by 0.1% to 0.2%. Volume on the Nasdaq in the stock market today was tracking about 10% lower than Tuesday's level. NYSE volume was tracking close to Tuesday.Goldman Sachs (GS) and McDonald's (MCD) outperformed in the Dow with gains of more than 1%.Western Digital (WDC) was a solid gainer in the Nasdaq 100, up nearly 3%, after published reports said the company offered to buy Toshiba's chip unit for $17.8 billion. Western Digital is testing support at the 10-week moving average for the first time after a base breakout in late March.Oil eased 0.5% to $51.21 a barrel Wednesday despite data from the Energy Information Administration showing the seventh straight weekly drop in U.S. crude supplies. That news was offset by a recommendation by a joint OPEC and non-OPEC committee on Wednesday to extend output cuts agreed upon in December for nine months.Inside the IBD 50, Stamps.com (STMP) continued work on the right side of a cup-shaped base as shares jumped 5%. It reset its base count last year when shares hit a low of 68.82 in July. That means its current base is first stage.Also in the IBD 50, China-based YY (YY) also outperformed, rising 3%. It's still in buy range from a 56.31 cup-with-handle buy point, although a lagging relative strength line raises some concern about the viability of the breakout.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) gave up its 50-day moving average ahead of its earnings report Thursday after the close. Shares slumped nearly 4% after Edward Jones downgraded the beauty retailer to hold from buy.Chipmaker Marvell Technology Group (MRVL) also reports Thursday after the close. Despite several quarters in a row of declining sales, it's a reasonable candidate for a call-option trade ahead of earnings as it works on a base with a 16.82 buy point.When shares were trading around 16.25, a weekly call option with a 16.50 strike price (May 26 expiration) came with a premium of 50 cents, offering a trade with downside risk of just 3%. The right, but not the obligation, to buy 100 shares of Marvell at 16.50 came at a cost of just $50. You can learn more about IBD's option strategy to use around earnings here.RELATED:U.S. Steel, Nucor Upgraded; Shake Shack Started At Buy; Ciena DowngradedA 9-Month Extension To OPEC's Oil Output Cut Just Cleared A Key HurdleHow The Fed Could Spook Markets, Bank Stocks Today

Shares of Grubhub (GRUB) slid on Friday, apparently after a TechCrunch report detailed how Facebook (FB) was stepping up the competition in food delivery.The report said Facebook has made an "Order Food" option available to some of its users. That option lets users order and pay for food, for pickup or delivery, entirely on Facebook, and works with restaurants that use the ordering services Delivery.com or Slice, the report said.Grubhub fell 1.6% to close at 43.37 on the stock market today. Facebook ticked up 0.3% to 148.06. Facebook first made food ordering available in October.Those plans come as Facebook aims for deeper community involvement and as more fast-food restaurants start to experiment with delivery, roll out mobile order and pay options, and try to figure out how best to approach the rise of companies like Grubhub.McDonald's (MCD) this week said it would expand its delivery service through its partnership with UberEats. Jack in the Box (JACK) also hopes its own delivery service, through Doordash, can give it an edge in late-night dining. Panera Bread (PNRA) also delivers.IBD'S TAKE: Even Domino's Pizza — a veteran at delivery whose own mobile order and pay platform has been successful — has tried to figure out how best to engage companies like Grubhub. Read IBD's interview with CEO Patrick Doyle here. Restaurants are hoping that delivery and mobile order and pay will eventually become the norm for the industry, whose last major technological disruption came from the drive-thru decades ago.But in the short term, investments in technology could weigh on margins and prompt other adjustments in things like packaging. Pizza, for instance, holds up well inside a cardboard box. French fries, meanwhile, are often the first casualty once they go into a takeout bag.McDonald's, Jack in the Box and Panera Bread were all up marginally at the close.RELATED:McDonald's Delivers Beefy Earnings; Execs Talk Deliveries, Digital StoresJack In The Box Beats Views, Eyes 'Potential Alternatives' For Qdoba

X Jack in the Box (JACK) topped fiscal second-quarter forecasts after the close Tuesday, and said it is looking at options for its Qdoba Mexican chain."At our investor meeting last May, we said one of the factors that would cause us to reconsider our strategy with respect to Qdoba was valuation," said Chairman and CEO Lenny Comma in a statement. "It has become more apparent since then that the overall valuation of the company is being impacted by having two different business models. As a result, we've retained Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC to assist the Board in its evaluation of potential alternatives with respect to Qdoba, as well as other ways to enhance shareholder value.Estimates: Earnings per share of 91 cents, up 7%, on revenue up 2% to $369.2 million. As of Friday, system same-store sales were expected to fall 0.8%.Results: EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $369.39 million. System-wide same-store sales at Jack in the Box fell 0.8%, and system-wide comp sales at Qdoba fell 3.2%.Outlook: Q3 same-store sales down 1% to up 1% at Jack in the Box and Qdoba system wide. Full-year comps sales are now seen up 1% at Jack in the Box vs. prior views for a 2% gain. Management narrowed its Qdoba comps view to a 1%-2% decline vs. a 1%-3% drop."After a sluggish start to the quarter, which we believe was attributable to delayed tax refunds and record rainfall in California, Jack in the Box system same-store sales improved to positive territory as these transitory issues passed and we pivoted our advertising towards value messages," Comma said. "However, same-store sales at Qdoba company restaurants worsened in the latter two months of the quarter, as we lapped more aggressive discounting in last year's second quarter."But he added that Qdoba's margins improved in the final month of fiscal Q2 as it managed labor and food costs better, and Qdoba's comps have improved so far in Q3.Stock: Jack in the Box jumped 10% late, indicating an open Wednesday near a 113.40 buy point. Shares closed up 2.3% at 101.89 on the stock market today. McDonald's (MCD) rose 0.7% at 147.29 to a fresh record high, as did Wendy's (WEN) with a 1.8% gain to 16.41. Both stocks are above buying territory. Burger King parent Restaurant Brands (QSR) ticked 0.1% to 59.65, still in buy zone.Jack in the Box has said its sales growth comes from limited-time offerings, breakfast and late night more than the value deals being pushed by rivals.But McDonald's all-day breakfast service has at times hurt Jack in the Box's sales, and McDonald's drink promos and higher-end offerings represent a threat as well. McDonald's has also outperformed the quick-service sandwich category for calendar Q1, Cowen said in a research note on Friday.Jack in the Box's results come after California — where many of its restaurants are located — raised its minimum wage in January. The drought-ridden state also suffered an unusual amount of rain, potentially keeping more customers indoors.Last week, Wendy's topped Q1 estimates, helped by advertising around fresher ingredients and its 4 for $4 value meal.Last month, Restaurant Brands also beat views, but same-store sales declined at both its Burger King and Tim Hortons chains.RELATED:McDonald's Delivers Beefy Earnings; Execs Talk Deliveries, Digital StoresRestaurant Brands Swallows The Competition To Find Growth

XThe stock market traded lower through morning trading Tuesday as corporate earnings mostly disappointed and data showed new-home construction in the U.S. missed estimates. Residential housing starts in March came in at 1.22 million vs. the 1.25 million predicted.The Nasdaq moved 0.3% lower, the S&P 500 fell 0.4%, and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.7%. Volume rose solidly on the NYSE and Nasdaq vs. the same time on Monday. Among the Dow industrials, Goldman Sachs (GS) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) dragged the Dow lower after reporting Q1 earnings and sales early Tuesday. Goldman missed the Street's earnings and revenue expectations, while blaming weak trading revenue on political uncertainty and low market volatility. Shares dropped 4.6%. Johnson and Johnson reported earnings that beat targets, but revenue came up short on weaker pharmaceutical sales. Shares fell 3.5% to pierce the 50-day.On the upside, Coca-Cola (KO) and McDonald's (MCD) paced the advancers with gains of 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. Shares of Coca-Cola are building the right side of a base after getting back above the 200-day two weeks ago, while McDonald's is within buy range from a 130.10 cup-with-handle buy point. McDonald's was upgraded to outperform at Bernstein. Among other companies reporting earnings, Bank of America (BAC) topped Q1 earnings expectations, causing shares to rise initially, but fell 1.3% in midday trading as the financial sector moved lower. Netflix (NFLX) lost 1.6% after releasing its Q1 earnings late Monday. The video streaming company missed forecasts for subscriber growth. The stock remains above its 50-day line.Snap (SNAP) jumped 2.7% after releasing new lenses for its Snapchat users. Its new augmented-reality overlay can create a 3D experience on a photo. Snap is in a heated battle with Instagram, which is owned by Facebook (FB). Last week, Facebook said that its Instagram Stories feature has more daily users than Snapchat. Snap shares remain near their post-IPO lows. Facebook traded 0.3% higher and remains about 1% off its all-time highs. Among leading growth stocks, Dycom (DY) advanced 3.6% to lead the IBD 50. The telecom stock was breaking out of a cup-shaped base with a 98.57 entry. Volume surged nearly 150% above average. Quarterly earnings grew 52% in the most recent quarter vs. the same quarter in the prior year.On the downside, China-based Momo (MOMO), the fast-growing video platform for social networking, dropped 3.9%, while TAL Education (TAL) moved down almost 2%.RELATED:Goldman Sachs Blames Weak Trading Revenue On Politics; BofA TopsJohnson & Johnson Earnings Top, But Drug Sales Are A DragNetflix To Top 100 Million Subscribers On Adam Sandler, Original ShowsStock Market Today: When Can Snap Turn Profitable?

X The stock market moved lower but recovered from intraday lows ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later today. The Fed's decision, which will be announced around 2 p.m. ET, is expected to leave rates unchanged.The Nasdaq dropped 0.5%, spurred lower by weakness throughout large-cap tech stocks. Stocks opened higher Monday, despite a weak reading on New York manufacturing activity in April.The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq climbed 0.3% while the S&P 500 was up 0.2%.Banks and financials remain a big piece of the week's reporting news, with quarterly results due out this week from Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS), Visa (V) and others.M&T Bank (MTB) rolled out one of Monday's early earnings reports and rose more than 1%. Results easily topped analysts' first-quarter expectations. The company repurchased $523 million in shares during the quarter and raised its annual dividend to 75 cents, from 70 cents.McDonald's (MCD) rose 0.5% and Apple (AAPL) 0.4% on the Dow. Wells Fargo upgraded McDonald's to outperform from market perform. Apple gained after RBC Capital raised its price target to 157, from 155 and maintained its outperform rating. But Pacific Crest Securities raised concerns about difficulties with fingerprint sensors on Apple's upcoming iPhone 8.Pfizer (PFE), Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Abbvie (ABBV) all rose as Incyte (INCY) dropped more than 10% in early action. The Wilmingon, Del.-based biotech reported Friday the Food and Drug Administration denied the application for the Incyte-Eli Lilly (LLY) rheumatoid arthritis treatment baricitinib. Some estimates had put the annual value of the drug near $2 billion. Incyte shares plunged below the 50-day moving average in heavy volume, triggering a sell signal. Eli Lilly shares dropped 4%. It also broke below the 50-day line but remains about 1% below a 83.34 buy point.Gilead gained 0.5%, Abbvie jumped 1%. Pfizer was flat. Pfizer, Gilead and Abbvie all compete in the market for rheumatoid arthritic treatments.

China's Alibaba Group Holding (BABA) climbed 1% at the open after its financial unit, Ant Financial, raised its offer for global payment service MoneyGram International (MGI) to $1.2 billion. Ant's initial offer of $880 million was topped by Euronet Worldwide (EEFT), which placed a $955 million offer in March. Moneygram shares rose 6% at the open. Euronet shares rose 1%.IBD Leaderboard stock Alibaba is in a buy range above an alternative handle buy point of 110.55.Medical diagnostics product maker Alere (ALR) swept up 17% at the open. The Waltham, Mass.-based company announced Friday it and Abbott Laboratories (ABT) had mutually dismissed competing lawsuits, and Abbott had reduced its takeover offer to 51, from 56 a share. The deal now values Alere at $5.3 billion and is expected to close during the third quarter. Abbott dropped 0.3% at the open.Manufacturing slowed sharply in the New York region in April, sending the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey to a reading of 5.2. The reading was still positive, but down from 16.4 in March and far below economists expectations for 15, although well above levels posted through nearly all of 2015 and 2016. New orders retreated and unfilled orders slowed and delivery times lengthened, but shipments edged up and gauges of both employment and hours worked remained firm.The National Association of Home Builders' releases its builder confidence survey at 10 a.m. ET. The gauge is for April.Internationally, the readout on the global stock market today was spotty due to the holiday schedule. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 posted a 0.1% gain Monday, held back by a dollar weakened against the yen by concerns over North Korea.China's Shanghai Composite ended down 0.7% after a top regulator pledged a resolute crackdown on risky market action. The Hong Kong stock exchange remained closed on holiday. In Europe, exchanges in London, Paris and Frankfurt all remained closed for the holiday.RELATED:Big Week For Dow Stock Earnings: Investing Action PlanInvestors Unfazed By North Korea; Netflix, United Continental Earnings On Tap

Stocks held solid gains in quiet trade early Monday as earnings season picks up with big banks due to report this week. Apple (AAPL) and McDonald's (MCD) initially led the Dow Jones industrial average on analyst rating and price-target changes.The Nasdaq composite rallied 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.4% each. Volume was lower across the board in the stock market today vs. the same time in Thursday's preholiday session.Telecom services, metal ores miners and movie-related stocks led the upside, thanks to a 2% gain in Netflix (NFLX), which reports earnings after the close. Hospitals, automakers and drugmakers lagged.Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT) were the top gainers on the Dow, climbing about 1% each. Apple and McDonald's were up 0.2% and 0.4% respectively after paring earlier gains.Apple shares are just above a 141.12 four-weeks-tight follow-on entry and are well extended past a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point cleared in January. RBC Capital maintained an outperform rating on the iPhone maker, boosted its price target to 157 from 155 and raised its 2018 EPS forecast by 9 cents a share to $9.67.McDonald's remains in buy range from a 130.10 handle entry. Wells Fargo upgraded the burger giant to outperform from market perform and lifted its price target to a 145-150 range from 125-130.MoneyGram International (MGI) popped 8% after Alibaba Group's (BABA) Ant Financial unit sweetened its bid for the global payment service by 36% to $1.2 billion. Its prior offer was topped by Euronet Worldwide (EEFT). Alibaba advanced nearly 1%; Euronet was fractionally lower.On the downside, Incyte (INCY) plunged 10% in massive volume, gapping down to undercut its 50-day line for the first time in over five months. The FDA on Friday failed to approve the biotech's baricitinib rheumatoid arthritis drug, saying more clinical data are needed. Goldman lowered its Incyte price target to 136 from 149.Partner Eli Lilly (LLY) gapped down and fell 4%, also breaching its 50-day line. BMO Capital downgraded the drugmaker to underperform from market perform, but Cowen raised its price target to 95 from 85.RELATED:Apple, Facebook Get Price-Target Hikes; McDonald's A BuyEli Lilly, Incyte Stocks Set To Break Key Levels After FDA SetbackAlibaba's Ant Financial Hikes MoneyGram Bid By 36% To $1.2 Billion

XAnalyst actions on Monday included price-target hikes for Apple (AAPL) and Facebook (FB), an upgrade for McDonald's (MCD), and a downgrade for Eli Lilly (LLY).RBC Capital raised its price target for Apple to 157 from 155, keeping an outperform rating. Analyst Amit Daryanani cited the iPhone8 cycle, an acceleration in services revenue, and potential for an increase in after-tax profits, dividends and share buybacks from Trump administration tax cuts, including a change in taxation for profits held overseas. He bumped up his 2018 EPS estimate by 9 cents a share to $9.67.Shares of Apple rose 0.5% to 141.80 on the stock market today, moving back above a 141.12 buy point lost on Friday.Credit Suisse hiked its price target for the social media leader to 175 from 170, keeping an outperforming rating. Meanwhile, Aegis Capital lifted its Facebook target to 160 from 155 with a buy rating. Aegis analyst Victor Anthony said he expects Facebook to unveil new camera and video innovations at its annual developer conference this week, "which should help increase engagement and monetization." Anthony also predicted solid quarterly earnings based on "strong advertiser checks."Shares of Facebook rose 1.5% to 141.42.IBD'S TAKE: Check out which 3 "FANG+" stocks are facing a big technical test this week as they try to rise above their 10-week moving average and which stocks have outperformed.Wells Fargo upgraded the fast-food giant to outperform from market perform, raising its target range for McDonald's to 145-150 from 125-130. Analyst Jeff Farmer expects market-share gains driven by the company recent adoption of mobile ordering and payment, which give it first-mover advantage among burger chains.Consumers, Farmer says, are "aggressively gravitating toward concepts that offer the greatest level of convenience and control across ordering, payment and distribution."Shares of McDonald's added 0.45% to 131.35, still in range from a 130.10 buy point.BMO Capital downgraded Eli Lilly to underperform from market perform after the FDA said more clinical data are needed to clarify dosage levels and safety concerns before approval of its rheumatoid arthritis drug baricitinib in partnership with Incyte (INCY).Still, Cowen & Co. raised  its price target for Eli Lilly to 95 from 85, citing momentum in other parts of its business, including other late-stage drug candidates.Goldman lowered its price target for Incyte to 136 from 149, keeping a buy rating. Analyst Salveen Richter cut Goldman's 2017 EPS estimate to a loss of 30 cents from a gain of 38 cents, but cited the potential of Incyte's 17-drug pipeline.Shares of Eli Lilly slid 4.1% to 82.38, while Incyte sank 10.5% to 126.07.RELATED:Apple Is Largest Western Seller Of Software In China: ReportApple Gets Price-Target Hike On Expectations For Huge iPhone 8 LaunchInstagram Stories Passes Snapchat As Facebook Assault ContinuesMcDonald's Will Serve Fresh-Beef Quarter Pounders; Stock Nears Buy PointEli Lilly, Incyte Stocks Break Key Levels After FDA Drug Setback

X McDonald's (MCD) on Wednesday said it will widen its new delivery service to restaurants in Los Angeles, Chicago, Phoenix and Columbus, Ohio — the latest industrywide effort to tap a growing population that does business via their smartphones.Customers can order food on a mobile app or through UberEats, which McDonald's has partnered with for deliveries. The expansion now means that delivery is offered at some 1,000 U.S. McDonald's restaurants, including 300 in LA."We are bringing a new level of convenience to more of our customers as we continue to transform the McDonald's experience," CEO Steve Easterbrook said in a statement.McDonald's, a member of the Dow Jones industrial average, last month said it would expand deliveries from its trial run in Florida, which began this year, to other cities in the U.S. during this quarter. Jack in the Box (JACK) has also expanded delivery to Los Angeles and Phoenix via its delivery partner DoorDash.McDonald's has also said it would launch a mobile order and pay platform in 20,000 restaurants in the U.S. and other areas by the end of the year. The burger chain is also rolling out its new restaurant format, called "Experience of the Future," which will have digital ordering kiosks and table service.Wendy's (WEN), which also has self-order kiosks at some restaurants, is also rolling out a mobile order and pay system. Restaurant Brands International's (QSR) Burger King wants to expand a mobile platform of its own.The digital expansion has the potential to make ordering food easier than ever, and analysts have said smartphone ordering marks the biggest change to the way people buy fast food since the drive-thru.But the technology raises questions about how restaurants will manage margins as they spend on technology and how they handle traffic-flow through their restaurants.IBD'S TAKE: Even as restaurants race to expand delivery, Restaurant Brands International has been growing by acquisitions.Starbucks (SBUX), which has its own mobile order and pay platform, had reported some knots in in-store customer traffic after launching the system.McDonald's, which is already testing fresh, cooked-to-order hamburger patties at some restaurants, reported minor slowdowns at the drive-thru that were later corrected.McDonald's edged down 0.6% to 146.41 in the stock market today after hitting a record high Tuesday.Wendy's fell 3.4% after setting a fresh decade high on Tuesday. Restaurant Brands retreated 1.1% from an all-time best. Starbucks dipped 0.4% to 59.73, holding just above a 59.64 buy point. Jack in the Box, which late Tuesday topped earnings views and said it would explore "alternatives" for its Qdoba Mexican Eats chain, rose 5.6%.The industry's delivery expansion also raises questions about competition for driver's. Domino's Pizza (DPZ), whose mobile-ordering technology has fit in well with its decades-old delivery service, is currently testing GPS technology. CEO Patrick Doyle, during the Domino's earnings call last month, also said his company was a better place for drivers to work." ... for those drivers who are listening to this call," he said, "my pitch is you're going to be more consistently busy and receiving tips at Domino's than working somewhere else, and that is ultimately what keeps drivers happy is that they're busy."RELATED:Jack In The Box Finds A 'Forgiving' Late-Night-Delivery CustomerJack In The Box Beats Views, Eyes 'Potential Alternatives' For Qdoba

Being in the American restaurant business is tough, as cheaper groceries, heightened competition and never-ending searches for growth abound.Growth by novelty is one way to prosper. Take two recent limited-offer efforts from a couple of industry giants: Starbucks' (SBUX) recent unleashing of the rainbow-colored Unicorn Frappuccino and Yum Brands' (YUM) debut of the Taco Bell Naked Chicken Chalupa — featuring a shell made out of fried chicken."(In a) saturated market, you've got to make your brand stand out," Morningstar's restaurant analyst, R.J. Hottovy, told Investor's Business Daily. "You maybe have to push the envelope a little bit more in terms of menu innovation, and get people talking about your brand. I think that that's what you're seeing more and more of."Another way to grow is to simply swallow another company whole, as in the case of Restaurant Brands International (QSR).The parent of Burger King and Canada's Tim Hortons outlets, Restaurant Brands is growing by acquisition, recently closing the buyout of Popeye's Chicken and adding the fried-chicken chain to its portfolio of burgers, coffee and doughnuts. The decision was broadly well-received."I think it gives (Restaurant Brands) an interesting growth vehicle down the road," said Hottovy, adding that demand for fried chicken could be particularly appealing to the company's franchising partners abroad.Following a quarter of weaker-than-expected same-store sales growth in North America, Restaurant Brands' management sounded bullish on expanding Popeye's abroad."One of the reasons we get really excited is the ability to accelerate the pace of growth, both in the U.S. and Canada, and all around the world," said Restaurant Brands Chief Executive Daniel Schwartz about the deal, on the April 26 call to discuss first-quarter earnings.For the quarter, profit of 36 cents a share marked 20% year-over-year growth and topped consensus by 2 cents. Revenue rose 9% to $1 billion, exceeding estimates for $990.3 million. But weak year-ago sales comparisons, including a 2.2% decline at Burger King's U.S. restaurants and a 0.2% dip at Tim Hortons' Canadian locations, marred the consensus beat.A certain Big Mac maker might have been to blame for the same-store-sales slips. In a world filled with artisanal burgers and trendy Shake Shack (SHAK)-type eateries, McDonald's (MCD) ubiquity still provides enormous power."The comps were a little bit softer than what people were expecting, and I think probably you can trace a good portion of that back to McDonald's success," said Hottovy. "A comp point for McDonald's has a much more disproportionate impact on the rest of the industry, just given its size and scale."But it's worth keeping in mind that for Restaurant Brands, same-store sales growth isn't necessarily the most significant metric."In a virtually 100% highly franchised business model like (Restaurant Brands), unit openings drive more operating leverage than comps," Cowen analyst Andrew Charles noted the day after earnings were released. He has a market-perform rating on the restaurateur with a 54 price target. And Piper Jaffray's Nicole Miller Regan reiterated her overweight rating and 66 price target."Continued execution against the company's strategic blueprint as well as cash flows being returned to shareholders at an increasing rate (i.e., recently raised dividend now yielding 1.3%) remains the key catalyst," she wrote in late April.To be a fast-food giant in 2017 almost seems quaint, given the trends toward customized meals, natural and organic fare, and millennial-friendly experiences. But Burger King, the Pepsi to McDonald's Coca-Cola, remains engaged in a heated rivalry with the Golden Arches as both attempt to align their technology with modern customers.Burger King is reportedly debuting mobile payments soon. That feature is currently in test mode in the Miami area, according to Bloomberg, citing Burger King head Jose Cil on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: Restaurant Brands tried to break out of a two-month-long flat base on April 25, immediately retreated the next day and then mounted another breakout on May 5 and hasn't looked back since. Shares continue to reach new highs. The company is currently ranked fourth in IBD's Retail-Restaurants Group, behind Dave & Buster's (PLAY).There's no national release date yet, but no doubt the Whopper maker is eyeing McDonald's plans to debut a mobile-order-and-pay platform in 20,000 locations by the end of 2017. Both lag behind Starbucks' robust mobile-order-and-pay system, an app feature that has become so popular, so quickly, that it actually wound up creating congestion in many locations a couple of quarters ago.Hottovy considers all three big foodie names winners, despite the macro pressures."Some of the efforts McDonald's has done has put them in the winners' camp, and I think that's had a halo effect over probably Restaurant Brands as well as Dunkin' (DNKN) at this point," said Hottovy, adding that Starbucks would still be considered a winner despite not being at the top of its game.Both the BK parent and McDonald's have performed well in recent months. After struggling to break out of a flat base with 58.08 entry point, Restaurant Brands shares rose decisively into buy range on May 5. Its Relative Strength rating, which pits its performance against the S&P 500, is a solid 87.McDonald's recent ascent has been even sharper, gapping up 5.6% on its April 25 earnings report.As far as growth is concerned, McDonald's might have to contend with an ever-larger rival. After all, Restaurant Brands was born of a 2014 merger between 3G Capital-backed Burger King and Tim Hortons.The company will "probably continue to look for more acquisitions in the future," said Hottovy.  "Tough to say exactly where, but I think it gives them nice new growth and cost-cutting opportunities at the same time."And Restaurant Brands is not totally immune to the charms of novelty items. Burger King took the time Tuesday to remind its Twitter followers of its newest treat: a milkshake based on Froot Loops cereal.We have a Froot Loops Shake in case you were wondering if childhood dreams come true.— Burger King (@BurgerKing) May 9, 2017RELATED:Shake Shack Shakes Off Same-Store Shock As Starbucks Hunts More UnicornsWhere Does Starbucks Go From Here? More Unicorn Frappuccinos?McDonald's Delivers Beefy Earnings; Execs Talk Deliveries, Digital StoresHappy Meals On Wheels: McDonald's Touts '3-Mile' Delivery Advantage

Shares of Wendy's (WEN) jumped on Wednesday to their best level in nearly 10 years after the burger chain's first-quarter earnings came in above analyst estimates, likely helped by advertising around fresher ingredients and its 4 for $4 value meal.Wendy's North America same-store sales rose 1.6% — the 17th straight time the company has turned out an increase for the key industry metric — topping consensus expectations for 1.1% growth.Earnings per share fell 18% to 9 cents, but that was a penny above what Wall Street had forecast. Revenue fell 24.6% to $285.8 million, beating estimates for $282.56 million.Wendy's attributed the steep sales decline to 301 fewer company-operated restaurants.Shares jumped 5.1% to 15.87 in the stock market today, hitting its best level since late 2007. The stock is now extended from a 14.57 buy point.Rival McDonald's (MCD) climbed 0.1% to 144.52, near all-time highs. Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) rose 1.2% to 59.92, holding above a 58.08 buy point."We would note that these (Wendy's) results likely came on the continued success of its value news (rotation within the 4 for $4) and increased brand marketing around fresh beef, which we believe has helped to drive awareness/re-trial of core items," Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh said in a research note.Wendy's also signaled that food costs could rise more than it had expected this year, potentially helping to discourage the discount wars that have attracted customers looking for cheap fast food but wilted industry sales.The company hiked its commodity inflation forecast to 1.5% to 2% from an earlier outlook of flat, "which reaffirms our view of an inflationary (second half of 2017)," RBC analyst David Palmer said in a research note.The decline in grocery prices has been steeper than that at restaurants, however, making eating in a more attractive option and compounding restaurants' sales difficulties.However, in a research note last month, SunTrust analyst Jake Bartlett said the pricing gap between restaurants and grocery stores narrowed "meaningfully" in March. Earlier this year, he said poultry and hamburger prices could rise this year, which would also help narrow that gap, and that restaurant sales could pick back up again starting in Q2 as the industry enters more forgiving comparisons.RELATED:McDonald's Delivers Beefy Earnings; Execs Talk Deliveries, Digital StoresCheesecake Factory Misses, Habit Profit Tops After Yum, Papa John's Beat

Shares then solidly entered the buy zone on April 5, but fell back below the entry on Friday.Microsoft (MSFT) is hitting resistance at a buy point. Shares have been trading just under a 66.01 flat base entry since March 30, closing just below that level in each of the past seven sessions in lighter-than-average volume. See if this Dow stock can clear the entry in heavy volume, which indicates institutional support.After being mentioned in last week's "Stocks To Watch," Tesla (TSLA) has now cleared the 287.49 cup-with-handle entry. The maker of luxury electric cars edged above the upper bound of the 5% buy range on Friday. In order to maximize your gains, it's best not to chase a stock too far after it clears a proper entry point.Along with the major indexes, Netflix (NFLX) is looking for support at its own 50-day moving average. In late March, the video streaming service was successfully able to rebound higher after touching the line, providing a secondary buying opportunity. See if Netflix can find the same supporting action again.Fellow "FANG" member Alphabet (GOOGL), which owns Google, has breached support at its 50-day line for a second time in the past several weeks. The action comes after an attempted breakout past an entry at 867.10 in mid-March failed.

The Dow Jones industrial average held its lead on gains from McDonald's (MCD),  Caterpillar (CAT) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH).The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5% and the Nasdaq composite added 0.4%. Despite today's market sell-off, the Retail-Restaurants industry group has been holding up well — and some of its members are even moving higher. This type of positive action is exactly what burgeoning leaders will do on days of general market weakness. Relative strength lines, the blue lines painted on daily and weekly IBD Charts, will start to perk up, signifying outperformance.…

Stock indexes posted a second day of small changes as volume kicked higher because of the expiration of options and futures. The Nasdaq hit an all-time high but closed virtually flat, while the S&P 500 and blue chip Dow Jones industrial average each inched down 0.1%. The small-cap Russell 2000 added 0.4%, outperforming the market. Volume rose on both major exchanges. Friday…

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index failed to close higher Friday, but Dow and S&P 500 component McDonald's (MCD) advanced, nearly breaking out on a report of stronger same-store sales. Darden Restaurants (DRI) also is approaching a buy point too as Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) retakes an entry area.Shares of McDonald's rolled higher on Friday after Credit Suisse boosted its first-quarter U.S. same-store sales forecast for the burger chain on signs its coffee and McCafe promo, extra Big Mac offerings and McPick value deals could be paying off.Following conversations with franchisees, Credit Suisse raised its U.S. same-store sales forecast for McDonald's to a 0.5% gain, up from a 2% drop. Wall Street expects same-store sales to fall 1.3%, according to Consensus Metrix."Key sales drivers cited by franchisees incl.: (1) expansion of Big Mac platform (launched nationwide in ~late Jan.), (2) $1 drip coffee/$2 McCafe promo and (3) local McPick 2 deals," Credit Suisse analyst Jason West wrote in a research note on Friday.He said he believed that McDonald's U.S. same-store sales were "flattish" in January, but picked up in February and the first half of this month prior to Winter Storm Stella.That storm, which this week disrupted air travelers' plans, forced some store closures and likely hurt McDonald's sales in parts of the Northeast, West wrote. But its impact on the chain's U.S. same-store sales overall might be only around 15 to 20 basis points for the first quarter.The apparent gains from McDonald's cheaper coffee and drinks deals would come as Starbucks (SBUX) showed signs of losing foot-traffic share in the U.S. in January.McDonald's has said it is testing out food delivery and will launch a mobile order and pay system by the end of the year. It's reported begun testing mobile order and pay  in some markets. That technology is among the biggest breakthroughs for convenience in generations for the restaurant industry. But it has also resulted in problems managing the flow of people in and out of restaurants, as Starbucks has found.McDonald's rose as high as 129.98 in the stock market today, just below a 130.10 cup-with-handle buy point. Shares closed up 0.5% at 128.64.Starbucks (SBUX) rose 1.8% to 55.78, closing just below its 200-day moving average and topping that key level intraday. Starbucks is working its way through a flat base.Dunkin' Brands, whose coffee service could be threatened by McDonald's price cuts, climbed 1.6% to 56.53, barely retaking a 56.23 buy point from a cup base. But volume is light.Olive Garden parent Darden Restaurants climbed 1.7% to 76.66, rising to 77.07 intraday. Darden was close to breaking out of a cup-with-handle base with a 77.21 buy point.RELATED:Jack In The Box Finds A 'Forgiving' Late-Night-Delivery CustomerMcDonald's Stock Tests Key Support Levels Amid Turnaround Doubts

The major market averages gave up early gains and turned slightly lower Friday morning. The Dow Jones industrial average got a lift from McDonald's (MCD) and Boeing (BA).The Dow Jones industrials and S&P 500 index fell 0.1% while the Nasdaq composite lost nearly 0.2%. The small-cap Russell 2000 held a fractional loss. Volume was tracking higher across the board in the stock market today vs. the same time Thursday.McDonald's led blue chips with a 1.2% gain, with Boeing adding nearly 1%. The fast-food giant is close to a 130.10 buy point of a cup with handle; the jet maker is far extended from a 160.17 flat-base entry cleared Jan. 24.Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose more than 5% to a new high. Shares are well extended past a 111.19 buy point cleared Jan. 24 in above-average trade. After the close Thursday, the digital media and software company announced better-than-expected fiscal Q1 results on both the top and bottom lines. It guided for Q2 adjusted EPS of 94 cents on $1.73 billion in sales, above views for 91 cents on $1.72 billion.Tiffany & Co. (TIF) gapped up and rose 3% after reporting Q4 earnings that beat views and guiding its fiscal 2018 earnings outlook above forecasts. Shares are extended past an 85.54 flat-base buy point cleared Feb. 17 in brisk trade. MuleSoft (MULE) opened at 24.25, a 43% spike. Its initial public offering was priced late Thursday at $17 a share, above an upwardly revised $14-$16 range, for an initial valuation of $2.9 billion.ProPetro (PUMP), which sold 25 million shares at $14 each, raising $350 million, surged 8% in its debut. The oilfield services provider had planned to offer 20 million shares at $16-$19.Outdoor apparel maker Canada Goose (GOOS), which came public Thursday, leapt 7% Friday morning. On Thursday, it closed near session lows but still soared 26% in its first day of trade.On the downside, Amgen (AMGN) gapped down and sank nearly 7% in fast turnover after announcing disappointing results for its Repatha cholesterol drug. Shares are still slightly extended from a 161.10 cup-with-handle buy point.Rival The Medicines Co. (MDCO) gapped down and plunged 21%, while Esperion Therapeutics (ESPR) sank 17%.RELATED:Adobe Beats On Earnings, Sales; Shares Hit New High After CloseAmgen Tanks On Heart Study; Shares Of Other Drugmakers TumbleMuleSoft IPO Packs A Punch As Stock Pops On Market DebutTiffany Shines On Q4 Beat, Guidance For 'Meaningful Growth'

Stocks opened flat Friday, as company news and a mixed dollar drove early trading.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were up a fraction while the Nasdaq inched lower. The small-cap Russell 2000 rose 0.2%.The Dow industrial stocks head into Friday's session up 0.2% for the week, hanging 0.3% below the 21,000 mark and a bit more than 1% below the index's March 1 high. The S&P 500 is ahead 0.4% and the Nasdaq has a 0.7% gain so far for the week, with both indexes holding well above their 50-day moving averages.Small caps have run a little hotter, putting the Russell 2000 ahead 1.5% through Thursday. But the index is rebounding from the prior week's 2.1% drop, ending Thursday narrowly back above its 50-day line.Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 0.2% and McDonald's (MCD) added 0.9% on the Dow.Boeing (BA) added 0.4% after confirming late Thursday it had inked a $3.4 billion contract to supply the U.S. Army and "a customer outside the U.S." with Apache attack helicopters.Outside the Dow, Adobe Systems (ADBE) surged 6% after reporting a solid fiscal first-quarter win lat Thursday. A 22% revenue increase and 42% jump in earnings easily topped analysts' targets, while management's second-quarter earnings and revenue guidance was above expectations. Adobe shares are working on their 10th gain in the past 11 weeks, and are extended after a January breakout from a cup-with-handle base.Tiffany & Co. (TIF) gapped up more than 3% after its fourth-quarter results. Earnings were flat but above expectations, and a 1% rise in revenue met forecasts. But management's full-year earnings guidance was above the consensus estimate. Tiffany shares are extended from a flat base cleared in February.Steel Dynamics (STLD) rumbled ahead 2.5% in early trading. The Fort Wayne, Ind.-based steel producer provided preliminary first-quarter guidance late Thursday, steering earnings expectations well above the 138% advance in the consensus estimate. The stock is forming a base with a 40.27 buy point and an alternative buy point at 38.35.Biotech drug maker Avexis (AVXS) bolted 14% at the open. The Bannockburn, Ill.-based outfit reported weaker-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings late Thursday. But the company reported positive clinical trial results, pending milestone payments and an upcoming meeting with the Food & Drug Administration. The stock is now extended from a 72.82 buy point in a four month cup-base.Among IBD 50 stocks, NetEase (NTES) pushed up nearly more than 1% at the open. The China-based video games provider is extended above a 257.78 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.IBD 50 peer Veeva Systems (VEEV) rose 03% at the open. Veeva is extended above a 45.95 buy point.February industrial production and capacity utilization estimates from the Federal Reserve are lined up for release at 9:15 a.m. ET.At 10 a.m. ET,  the Conference Board delivers its leading economic indicators index for February and the University of Michigan's March Consumer Sentiment Index is due.Oil prices added nearly 1%, with West Texas Intermediate back above $49 per barrel and up a little more than 1% for the week.  Gold traded slightly higher to just below $1,230 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro and down against the yen. The 10-year yield lost 3 basis points to trade at 2.52%.Europe's markets remained up in afternoon trade — London's FTSE 100 held a 0.3% gain, Frankfurt's DAX added 0.2% and the CAC 40 in Paris defended its 0.4% advance.In Japan's Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slumped 0.4% and took a 0.4% loss for the week. In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index added 0.1% Friday, landing a 3.1% advance in its strongest week since September. The Shanghai Composite dropped 1%, leaving it with a 0.8% gain for the week.RELATED: This News Suggests Apple iPhone Supercycle Is BrewingA Second Top Steelmaker In 2 Days Just Gave Blowout Earnings Guidance

The stock market continued to slip gently from record highs in midday trading.All three major indexes, the Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average, traded down about 0.1%. Volume surged on both exchanges vs. the same time Thursday, which is typical of quadruple witching days, when index options, index futures, stock options and single stock futures all expire.Among the Dow industrials, McDonald's (MCD) and Boeing (BA) were the clear leaders, while financials set the pace on the downside. McDonald's gained 1.1% as it approached a 130.10 cup-with-handle entry. Credit Suisse raised the restaurant's Q1 same-store sales outlook early Friday. Boeing traded up 0.8% as it remained well-extended from a 160.17 flat-base buy point.Within the lagging financials, Goldman Sachs (GS) dropped 1.6%. Shares were approaching the 50-day line. This is the second test of the 50-day line since the stock's strong move from a 172.52 flat-base entry last October.Among companies that reported earnings, Adobe Systems (ADBE) jumped almost 6% after besting Q1 earnings and sales estimates late Thursday. Shares are about 16% above a 111.19 flat-base entry.Amgen (AMGN) investors hit the eject button on Friday after the company announced its cholesterol drug Repatha disappointed in its recent heart study. The drug reduced the risk of heart attack, stroke and cardiovascular death by 20%; expectations were for a 24% reduction.New issue Snap (SNAP) fell 4% despite a neutral rating issued by Mizuho Securities. Another market debutante, MuleSoft (MULE), soared 43% in its first day of trading. The San Francisco-based software developer raised $221 million in the IPO.Among stocks breaking out today, Carnival (CCL) was on its way above a 57.89 flat-base buy point. Earnings rose 34% in the latest quarter vs. the same quarter last year.Within the IBD 50, a screen of leading growth stocks, NetEase (NTES) moved up 2.5%, snapping a three-day losing streak. The No. 6-ranked IBD 50 member remained about 13% above a 257.78 cup-with-handle entry but has been drifting lower.On the downside, Autohome (ATHM) cracked 4% as it looked to test its 10-week moving average.RELATED:These 3 Big Restaurant Stocks Are Closing In On Buy PointsAdobe Stock Soars On Q1 Beat-And-Raise ReportAmgen Tanks On Heart Study; Shares Of Other Drugmakers TumbleMuleSoft IPO Packs A Punch As Stock Pops On Market Debut

Stocks plotted out thin losses at the starting bell Friday, despite a surprise increase in Midwest manufacturing, as the market headed into the final session of March and of the first quarter.The Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq Composite and the S&P 500 all opened down 0.2%.The opening trimmed the Dow's gain for the week to 0.5%, the S&P 500 shows a 0.9% gain, while the Nasdaq remains up 1.3%. All three indexes met support at their 50-day moving averages and the Nasdaq notched a new closing high on Thursday, ending just below its March 21 intraday peak.For March, the Dow went into Friday's session down 0.4%, tracking toward its first down month since before the presidential election in October. For the quarter, the index is up 4.8%, vs. its 7.9% gain in Q4.The S&P 500 is ahead 0.2% for March, working on a fifth straight up month, and shows a 5.8% quarterly gain, up from a 3.2% advance in the fourth quarter. The Nasdaq has easily outpaced, rising 1.5% so far in March and 9.9% since the start of the year.Small caps have posted a non-committal quarter, leaving the Russell 2000 down 0.3% in March and up 1.8% since Dec. 30.McDonald's (MCD) jumped to the top of the Dow, up 0.6%. ExxonMobil (XOM) brought up the rear, down 1.1%.

Nike (NKE) slipped 0.4%. Nike shares ended Thursday 4% below a 58.52 buy point, after falling more than 8% below that buy marker and triggering an automatic sell rule on March 22.Among the FANG stocks: Amazon.com (AMZN) jumped 1% at the open. Loop Capital launched coverage on the sotck with a buy rating and a 1,100 price target. Loop also initiated coverage on Alphabet (GOOGL), with a hold rating and an 800 price target. Shares slipped 0.1% in early trade.Herbicide and insecticide maker FMC (FMC) soared 15% after DuPont (DD) announced FMC would acquire DuPont's crop protection products business for $1.2 billion in exchange for FMC's health and nutrition unit. The gain put shares well above a a 62.13 buy point in a cup-with-handle base, but the gap up breakout establishes a new buy range, starting at 69.72.The FMC sale was the first divestiture aimed at meeting regulatory requirements for the planned $77 billion merger between DuPont and Dow Chemical (DOW). The two companies today said they expect to close the deal in August. DuPont traded down 1% and Dow shares were off 0.5%.On the IBD 50 list, savings and loan Bofi Holding (BOFI) dropped 3% at the open. The company released a statement claiming allegations raised in a "tabloid" story circulated Friday — apparently revisiting claims of falsified company financial statements — were inaccurate. Shares ended Thursday with a slight gain for the week and high in the week's trading range, after diving almost to their 40-week moving average in heavy trade on Wednesday.Personal incomes increased 0.4% in February, the Commerce Department estimated, equal to January's revised estimate and in line with consensus projections. Consumer spending eked up 0.1%, below January's 0.2% gain and estimates for a 0.2% improvement.Overall price inflation slipped back into line, rising 0.1%, down from January's 0.4% jump and also in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus energy and food, gained 0.2%, as expected, and vs. a 0.3% increase the prior month.Expansion of Midwest regional manufacturing accelerated in March, lifting  Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index to 57.7, up from 57.4 in Februaryand above expectations for a dip to 57.The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, also for March, comes out at 10 a.m.Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari speaks at 10 a.m., and the St. Louis Fed's James Bullard follows at 10:30 a.m.International markets traded generally lower on Friday. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 0.8% apiece. Europe's markets were mixed, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.5%, the CAC 40 in Paris off 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX defending a fractional gain in afternoon trade.RELATED:These 5 Stocks Are Near Buy Points: Investing Action Plan

Stocks clocked out with healthy gains Tuesday, in a second session cut from the bullish weak-start/strong-finish pattern.The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.7% and broke an eight-session pullback, its longest string of daily declines in a half-decade. The S&P 500 chiseled a 0.7% gain and the Nasdaq climbed 0.6%. Small caps kept pace with the general action, leaving the Russell 2000 up 0.7%.Tuesday's moves showed the Dow and the S&P 500 finding support at their 50-day moving averages, although trading volume in both cases was weak. The Nasdaq rebounded from its 50-day line Monday and extended that gain Tuesday.Shipping fleets took the day's largest gain among industries, with Star Bulk Carriers (SBLK), Safe Bulkers (SB) and Golden Ocean Group (GOGL) all surging more than 9% on upgrades to overweight from Morgan Stanley.Seven Dow industrial stocks booked gains better than 1%. Apple (AAPL) led the group, popping 2% to a new high but remaining in a buy range above a 141.12 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. Caterpillar (CAT), JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) were next in line.Amazon.com (AMZN) rose more than 1% during the session, as Stifel Nicolaus raised the stock's price target, to 1025, from 912, after the company reached a deal to buy Souq.com, reportedly one of the largest e-commerce operations in the Middle East. Amazon shares continue to trade below a four-weeks-tight buy point of 860.96.Darden Restaurants (DRI) and Red Hat (RHT) carried the strongest gains among S&P 500 stocks, both opening strong after reporting quarterly results.Darden gapped up and gained 9% to clear a cup-with-handle base in huge volume. The cup with handle is a common bullish pattern. Darden topped the Street's estimate on quarterly earnings and raised guidance.Red Hat scored a 5% gain after reporting a solid fourth-quarter beat late Monday. The stock is testing 10-week support in the fifth week of a shallow consolidation.Charles Schwab (SCHW) topped the IBD 50 list, rising nearly 3% in weak trade. The stock is battling to recover support at its 50-day moving average after dropping almost 14% from its March 17 high.Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) posted a 2% gain and Ollie's Discount Outlet (OLLI) added 1% during the regular session. Both were scheduled to report quarterly results after the close.Tuesday's losses were generally moderate. Seasonings maker McCormick (MKC) took the S&P 500's hardest hit, down 3% in strong trade. The stock is shaping a possible handle on an eight-month cup base. McDonald's (MCD) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) were the only two decliners on the Dow, down a fraction each.RELATED:Steel Stocks Rebound On Trump Infrastructure Plans

XAnalysts were upbeat on Snap (SNAP), Apple (AAPL), Starbucks (SBUX) and Micron (MU) Monday, while signaling more caution on Chipotle (CMG).Multiple analysts initiated coverage on Snap with buy ratings after the Snapchat parent got a slew of bearish ratings in the weeks immediately following its IPO.Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald gave Snap a buy rating and price target of 30, saying Snap "looks well positioned for growth as advertisers clamor to serve ads to its large audience of deeply-engaged users, many of whom are in the attractive millennial demographic and are located in high-value ad markets." He added, "We believe Snap has all the ingredients to build a robust advertising business."Goldman Sachs set a price target of 27, while Morgan Stanley's price target on Snap is 28.Snap stock jumped 4.8% to close at 23.83 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: While Snap has now received several buy ratings and is said to have replaced Twitter as the No. 2 social networking platform among advertisers, it faces a formidable rival in Facebook and the low Accumulation/Distribution rating on Snap's stock indicates selling by institutional investors. JPMorgan added Apple to its "Focus List" and raised its price target to 165 from 142, saying there is high pent-up replacement demand at the same time Apple is gearing up to launch its new iPhone.But shares edged up 0.2% to finish at 140.88.Special Report: IBD Best Mutual Fund AwardsCoverage was initiated on Starbucks with an outperform rating and a price target of 66 at Telsey Advisory Group, which cited the coffee giant's growth plans.China is the next big frontier for Starbucks as it plans to rapidly expand its store count there. But meanwhile in the U.S., McDonald's (MCD) is planning to offer $2 McCafe drinks and $1 sodas in April, as well as a mobile ordering platform later this year, as Starbucks may be showing signs of losing ground to rivals.Starbucks shares rose 0.7% to 57.23.Deutsche Bank reiterated a buy rating on Micron Technology and raised its price target to 35 from 30, which analyst Sidney Ho based on favorable supply-demand and solid execution.Micron stock rallied 1.2% to 28.76.Wedbush analyst Nick Setyan reiterated a neutral rating and a price target of 400 on Chipotle. He wrote that recent checks indicate continued momentum during the first quarter but with a limited view on profitability."We believe current valuation appropriately reflects an improving top-line trajectory, offset by limited visibility into Chipotle's near-term margin trajectory," Setyan wrote.Chipotle stock ticked 0.2% higher to 414.96.

U.S. stock indexes refused to roll over Monday afternoon as the indexes found support at their 50-day moving average lines.The Nasdaq composite staged a positive reversal, turning a 1% loss in the first 45 minutes of trade into a nearly 0.3% gain with less than 15 minutes remaining in Monday's wild session. The S&P 500 was down less than 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average trimmed its loss to 0.2%.Volume in the stock market today was running sharply higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq compared to the previous session's pace.The Nasdaq, Dow and the S&P 500 each tested and then bounced up from their 50-day lines (please see a daily chart at Investors.com or IBD's premium charting service Marketsmith). The action is considered bullish because it suggests funds are moving in to scoop up apparent bargains.Stocks appeared to be reacting to Friday's failure to repeal and replace ObamaCare. The hospital stock group popped 2% as it headed toward its fourth consecutive gain. Hospitals benefit from the expanded coverage of ObamaCare because it means fewer uninsured patients will be walking away from unpaid bills.Meanwhile, HealthEquity (HQY) dived 7%, touching its 200-day line and then rebounding to erase all of the loss. HealthEquity, a provider of health savings accounts, was expected to benefit from a Republican replacement of ObamaCare. HealthEquity lost 3% Thursday and slid 5% Friday.Banks struggled Monday afternoon, though they did trim some of their losses. Chips were mostly up, but volume was soft.One group that has stayed calm amid the sell-off that began Tuesday is the restaurant group. Panera Bread (PNRA) hit a new high Monday and rallied 1.4% to 253 as it headed toward its seventh daily gain in a row. Analysts expect Panera to grow quarterly earnings 17% in Q1, which would be the best growth in 17 quarters.Other restaurant stocks showing strength: Domino's Pizza (DPZ) held up at its 50-day line; McDonald's (MCD) flirted with a 130.10 buy point; Bob Evans Farms (BOBE) stood firm in a buy zone; Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) also remains in its 5% buy zone; and Starbucks (SBUX) continued to sketch a flat base that is tighter and shallower than the larger consolidation that began forming almost a year and a half ago.Dave & Busters, a former Leaderboard stock, will report Q4 results after the close on Tuesday. Analysts see profit rising 11% to 59 cents a share, following gains of 51%, 57%, 25% and 108% in the prior four quarters.Another group little damaged in the recent sell-off was the homebuilder group. The group was on track Monday afternoon for its third gain in a row.The put call/volume ratio closed at 1.1 Friday, near the area that sometimes points to a short-term market bottom. But the put call eased to 1.01 Monday afternoon.RELATED:Stocks To Watch In A Tough MarketWhich Stocks Are Hitting New Highs Despite Market Pressure?Stock Market Today: Should Snap Get A Spot On Your Watch List?

X U.S. stocks pivoted twice Friday, staging a negative reversal to wipe out morning gains and then a positive reversal when House Speaker Paul Ryan canceled a vote on the health care bill. The Nasdaq settled for a 0.2% gain. It was the second day in a row that it closed near session lows, and the composite's action Friday…

Tense, late-stage maneuvering at the White House and the Capitol kept markets on edge straight to Friday's close, with major indexes ending mixed and the Dow Jones industrial average chalking up its worst week since the Nov. 8 presidential election.The Dow lost 0.3% Friday and 1.3% for the week. Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) took what were far-and-away the Dow's worst losses for the week, down 6.5% and 4%, respectively.Also in the Dow 30, Apple (AAPL) and McDonald's (MCD) each managed modest gains for the week and Nike (NKE), which on Wednesday dived more than 7% after a weak earnings report, on Friday trimmed its decline for the week to less than 3%.The S&P 500 sagged 0.1%, ending the week with a 1.3% loss — also its worst week since just before the election. Heavy engineering, steel and suppliers of construction materials took the S&P 500's heaviest hits on Friday. Vulcan Materials (VMC), Martin Marietta (MLM), Fluor (FLR) and Nucor (NUE) each dumped more than 2% in Friday's session. It's well-worth noting that all of those losses occurred in light trade.Micron Technology (MU) and Under Armour (UA) pegged the S&P 500's best gains.Micron spiked 7% as earnings rose to 90 cents a share, up from a penny in the year-ago quarter. Revenue soared 58%. But the industry took particular heart in Micron's Q3 outlook, which placed the midpoint of earnings guidance 61% above consensus views. Micron shares ended the week up 11% and at a new high, extended from a February rebound from 10-week support.Under Armour popped 4% following an upgrade to buy, from hold, by Jefferies. The stock suffered a 63% sell-off over the past 11 months, but the Jefferies note diagnosed the correction as having formed a bottom and, given market circumstances, "an inflection has formed and the buying (opportunity) is now." CAN SLIM investors can minimize risk by waiting for a proper base to form.The Nasdaq composite held its loss Friday to less than 0.1%, ending off 1.2% in its sharpest weekly slip since December. Micron topped the Nasdaq 100, with Western Digital (WDC), Tesla (TSLA), Cerner (CERN) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) all advancing 2% or more.Tesla chairman Elon Musk teased investors with tweets revealing new details regarding the company's upcoming Model 3, and more distant Model Y and Roadster vehicles. Tesla shares are five weeks into a consolidation — holding nice support at the stock's 10-week moving average, but it's slightly too deep to qualify as a flat base.Among IBD 50 stocks, China's TAL Education Group (TAL) jumped 3% Friday in its eighth straight daily advance. Shares are taking out new highs and are well-extended above a three-weeks-tight buy point of 83.97.BioTelemetry (BEAT) also gained 2%, narrowing its loss for the week to less than 3%. The stock bounced off its 10-week moving average on Thursday, but week volume nullified the move as a buying opportunity.RELATED:ObamaCare Repeal Vote Failure Threatens Tax Cuts — And Stock RallyChip Gear Makers Rise On Upbeat Micron OutlookStock Market Today: Do These 6 Chip Names Have A Shot At Big Gains In 2017?

McDonald's (MCD) plans to offer $2 McCafe drinks and $1 sodas in April, as well as a mobile ordering platform later this year, could come at an opportune time for the burger chain and Dow Jones industrial average component, as Starbucks (SBUX) may be showing signs of losing ground to rivals.Starbucks' U.S. share of foot traffic last month slipped to 11%, from 12% in January, according to restaurant-related data analyzed by marketing firm xAd.In an email, xAd said it was unclear why the slip in foot-traffic share occurred, but said that it may have been due to "inclement weather or the overall issues with online ordering," among other potential factors. The trends were first reported by Bloomberg.The coffee chain has tried to find ways to unknot the longer lines and congestion that it says have resulted from its own mobile order-and-pay program, raising the possibility of logistical challenges to other restaurants that adopt a mobile platform.The McCafe and soda promotion could help McDonald's compete not just with Starbucks but with convenience stores, which account for more than half of restaurant-industry coffee service, according to an RBC Capital Markets research note last month, citing data from the NPD Group."In our previous notes, we highlighted beverage value as one of the three reasons that we believe McDonald's US same store sales trends can accelerate as the company competes against the expansion of convenience store foodservice and fast casual," analyst David Palmer wrote.At a presentation last week, McDonald's said it would launch a mobile order and pay platform in 20,000 restaurants in the U.S. by the end of the year. McDonald's also sees a massive opportunity in delivery, and is exploring its prospects with companies like UberEats and GrubHub (GRUB).Shares of McDonald's rose 5 cents to 128.14 in the stock market today. The stock has recently formed a handle in a cup base, with a buy point of 130.10.Starbucks fell 1% to 55.19, its sixth straight decline. Starbucks undercut its 200-day moving average on Wednesday. Its relative strength line is the weakest in nearly two years, showing how Starbucks has lagged the S&P 500 index.Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) fell 0.8% to 53.61, drifting further away from a 56.23 entry. GrubHub rose 0.6% to 33.57 after falling intraday to its lowest level since late July. Panera Bread (PNRA) rose 0.9% to 235.86, but closed below a 236.35 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern after rising intraday to an all-time high.IBD'S TAKE: Domino's Pizza's online ordering platforms have worked so well for the company, and while burgers and fries don't travel as well as pizza does, Jack in the Box customers that get delivery don't seem to be too bothered. The tougher competition comes as discounting efforts appear likely to shift toward drinks. While value deals remained abundant last year amid a slump in food costs, some analysts expect those prices to rebound this year. Restaurants have also struggled with cheaper groceries at grocery stores, which have encouraged people to eat in.But it's still too early to tell if Starbucks is seeing just a blip or something more persistent. From Q3 to Q4, xAd said foot traffic at Starbucks rose 1.3%.Since then, other factors may have contributed to last month's weakness.Starbucks' plan to hire 10,000 refugees over the next five years — announced Jan. 29 after President Trump's attempts to temporarily bar the entry of refugees into the U.S. — appears to have also briefly annoyed some customers.Credit Suisse said in a note Wednesday that "net sentiment" data from NetBase showed the coffee chain's hiring decision "could have upset some customers, perhaps negatively impacting sales trends." While sentiment remained lethargic for 10 days from late January to early February, it has rebounded but "seen significant volatility in recent weeks."RELATED:McDonald's Stock Tests Key Support Levels Amid Turnaround DoubtsWhy It May Be Time To Sell Apple, Tesla; Starbucks Nears Buy PointToo Much Of A Good Thing? This Weighed On Starbucks' U.S. Performance

Sometimes a small prod is all it takes to make a hot investment idea go cold in no time — as small as a quarter-point bump in a benchmark rate in the case of low volatility and dividend stock ETFs.As the era of zero ends and interest rates rise, investors in exchange traded funds have turned away from certain high dividend and low volatility strategies this year. Instead, they favored more cyclical exposures that benefit from a tick up in rates — banks and transporters, for example."Yet, thanks to product innovation, there are now strong smart-beta strategies that combine defensive and cyclical components," Todd Rosenbluth, director of ETF research at CFRA, wrote in a March note. Smart beta ETFs seek to achieve better returns or lower risk vs. cap-weighted counterparts.As examples of "next-generation products" for a rising rate environment, Rosenbluth offered these two names:As relatively new products without a three-year history, both ETFs should be traded with care. However, Rosenbluth considers them worthy choices for large-cap stock exposure in light of the March rate hike and the Fed's signals of more gradual rate hikes this year.XRLV is the younger sibling of PowerShares S&P 500 Low Volatility (SPLV), an ETF that aims to give investors a smoother ride in the stock market. SPLV invests in the 100 least volatile stocks in the S&P 500 and surged in popularity during 2016's choppy markets. So did iShares Edge MSCI Minimum Volatility (USMV).But this year through March 21, SPLV and USMV saw net outflow of $1.238 billion combined, according to FactSet data — a big chunk of their total assets, which now stand at roughly $19 billion.Hefty stakes in defensive, high-yielding sectors could be hurting them.Those equity sectors, such as consumer staples, real estate and utilities, are seen as "bond proxies" because of their higher yields. They have historically lagged the S&P 500 when bond yields are rising.As the Federal Reserve seems inclined to keep raising rates this year, more pain may lie in store for SPLV and USMV, in Rosenbluth's view.XRLV has little to fear in this context. It boots out the 100 most rate-sensitive stocks from the S&P 500 and so has virtually no exposure to utilities and real estate. Gas and electric companies such as Dominion Resources (D) and Southern Co. (SO), which belong in the older sibling's portfolio, are missing here.Instead, it skews heavily toward financials, technology and industrials, such as JB Hunt Transport Services (JBHT). Those economically sensitive sectors tend to perform well amid rising interest rates.Basically, XRLV is defensive — but not too much."It's a middle ground for investors who are expecting more choppiness in the marketplace but also wish to participate in an improving economy," said Rosenbluth.XRLV has gained 10.3% since the Nov. 8 election, roughly in line with the S&P 500 and outpacing the 9.2% advance of the low volatility heavyweights, SPLV and USMV.While the Fidelity dividend ETF also holds stocks that perform well when rates are rising, it avoids big sector bets.It is up 4.8% year to date and has a 30-day SEC yield of 3.05%.RELATED:The Best Lage-Cap Growth ETF For 10 Years, But Is It Best For You?

Verizon Communications (VZ) has joined AT&T (T) in freezing all advertising on Google except for search ads, adding to the backlash from global companies objecting to their ads appearing next to controversial content on YouTube.The move is significant because phone companies AT&T, Sprint (S), T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Verizon are among the biggest advertisers in corporate America. AT&T first announced its plans earlier on Wednesday, then it was learned Verizon was doing the same."We've taken appropriate steps with our digital advertising partners to remedy the issue by suspending this type of ad placement," said Sanette Chao, a Verizon spokeswoman. "We are working with all of our partners to understand the weak links so we can prevent this from happening in the future."Chao added that Verizon has frozen "digital nonsearch advertising inventory to be exact."In a written statement, AT&T said: "We are deeply concerned that our ads may have appeared alongside YouTube content promoting terrorism and hate. Until Google can ensure this won't happen again, we are removing our ads from Google's nonsearch platforms."Sprint and T-Mobile could not be reached for comment on the moves by AT&T and Verizon.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) has been at odds with AT&T and Verizon over many regulatory issues, especially broadband and data privacy. And, Google has invested in fiber-optic broadband and wireless technologies to increase competition.IBD'S TAKE: Though shares of Google parent Alphabet are pushing 850 apiece, the company isn't leading IBD's Internet-Content Group. The top spot goes to Chinese social networking company Momo (MOMO). More information can be found here.Google last week promised to step up enforcement of advertising policies aimed at preventing ad placement next to inappropriate content after an uproar in the U.K. over government and branded ads appearing on video-sharing website YouTube.Google's announcement came after the U.K. government and the Guardian newspaper stepped up pressure on YouTube to police content on its platform. Daimler's (DDAIF) Mercedes-Benz division and McDonald's (MCD) are among companies that have complained.Google has said it will expand safeguards for advertisers, giving them more control over where and when their ads appear.Alphabet shares were down marginally at the close Wednesday to 849.80. AT&T slipped 1% to 41.65 while Verizon was off 0.9% to 49.71.RELATED:Google Faces 'Global Repercussions' From U.K. Advertising Flap: Analyst

Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP) continued to get a cold reception from Wall Street analysts Friday, McDonald's (MCD) received a price-target increase, while off-price apparel retailer Burlington Stores (BURL) and online travel booking service Expedia (EXPE) got stock ratings upgrades.Susquehanna Financial Group initiated coverage of Snap at neutral with a price target of 22. Also Friday, Morningstar started coverage of Snap with a fair value on the stock of 15.On Thursday, Aegis Capital initiated coverage of Snap at hold with a price target of 22. Nomura started coverage at reduce and a price target of 16. Pivotal Research Group hit Snap with a sell rating and price target of 10.Snap rose 10.7% to 27.09 on the stock market today. That's follows Thursday's 44% pop to 24.28 in its trading debut from its IPO price of 17RELATED:Snap Soars In Debut, But Analyst Expects Snapchat Parent To Dive 59%Telsey Advisory Group reiterated its outperform rating on McDonald's and raised its price target to 136 from 130.Shares of Oakbrook, Ill.-based McDonald's fell 0.3% to 127.90. On Thursday, McDonald's stock fell 0.6% to 128.23.McDonald's stock has been forming a cup base with a 132.06 buy point for the past 43 weeks.RELATED:Happy Meals On Wheels: McDonald's Touts '3-Mile' Delivery AdvantageTelsey Advisory Group upgraded Burlington Stores stock to outperform from market perform and raised its price target to 110 from 91. RBC Capital Markets hiked its price target on Burlington to 97 from 91 and reiterated its outperform rating.Burlington stock rose 1.6% to 96.07 on Friday. On Thursday, Burlington shares soared 6.7% to 94.59 after the company posted better-than-expected fiscal fourth quarter sales and earnings.RELATED:Off-Price Retailers Trade At A Premium As Burlington Stores Hits High On Earnings, OutlookCitigroup upgraded Expedia stock to neutral from sell, citing increased confidence that the company can grow its hotel booking business.Expedia was up 1% to 120.12 on Friday. On Thursday, it fell 1.3% to 118.92.RELATED:Expedia Earnings Miss Estimates, Revenue Barely Beats, Stock FallsGoldman Sachs maintained its buy rating on Kroger, but took the grocery chain off its Conviction List after the company reported Q4 results."Kroger's Q4 update demonstrated that its competitive edge has eroded a bit," Goldman Sachs analyst Stephen Tanal said in a report. Kroger appears to be losing market share to key competitor Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), he said.Goldman Sachs has a price target of 35 on Kroger stock. Kroger fell 3.4% to 29.63 on Friday. On Thursday, Kroger fell 4.3% to 30.67.RELATED:Kroger Expects Grocery Woes To Continue After Same-Store Sales Fall

President Trump's renewed call for tax cuts and infrastructure spending pushed the Dow Jones industrial average and other stocks sharply higher to all-time highs. Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP) soared in its IPO debut. The Federal Reserve seems poised to raise rates, McDonald's (MCD) is ready to deliver while Charles Schwab (SCHW) and other online brokers slashed stock trading fees.Trump gave few details in his Tuesday night speech to Congress, but stocks had their best day of 2017 the next day, soaring to record highs following his call for "massive" tax cuts and $1 trillion in infrastructure spending. The Dow industrials, which broke a 12-day winning streak on Tuesday, rallied 0.9% for the week, crossing 21,000 for the first time. The S&P 500 finished the week up 0.7% and the Nasdaq composite 0.4%. Bank stocks, including Dow components JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), rallied as hawkish Fed comments pushed up bond yields and the odds of a March rate hike.
