Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook vowed Tuesday to appeal a European Commission ruling that would force the company to pay about $14.5 billion in back taxes plus interest to Ireland, where it has its European headquarters.The European Union's executive arm claims Apple received special tax treatment to lower its tax burden. In a letter responding to the ruling, Cook denied getting special treatment in Ireland and harshly criticized the EU's actions.Apple has been a "responsible corporate citizen," working with Irish tax authorities to comply correctly with Irish tax law, Cook said."The commission's move is unprecedented, and it has serious, wide-reaching implications," Cook said. "It is effectively proposing to replace Irish tax laws with a view of what the commission thinks the law should have been. This would strike a devastating blow to the sovereignty of EU member states over their own tax matters and to the principle of certainty of law in Europe."Apple and Ireland both plan to appeal the commission's ruling and are confident it will be reversed, Cook said.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has an IBD Composite Rating of just 34, meaning it has been outperformed by 66% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For a deep dive into Apple, check out the IBD Stock Checkup."Using the commission's theory, every company in Ireland and across Europe is suddenly at risk of being subjected to taxes under laws that never existed," Cook said.Ireland Finance Minister Michael Noonan told Reuters that he "disagrees profoundly" with the EU tax ruling. Ireland's finance ministry said the full amount of tax was paid by Apple, and no state aid was provided.Cook said the EU specifically targeted Apple, which ended the June quarter with $231.5 billion in cash and securities.The EU's case against Apple is part of a broader crackdown on tax treatment of multinationals by EU member nations. The EU is still investigating Amazon (AMZN) and McDonald's (MCD). And the EU has also had longtime tax battles with Alphabet (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB).Last year, Starbucks (SBUX) was ordered to pay 30 million euros ($33.4 million) in taxes back to the Netherlands. In January, Belgium was ordered to recover 700 million euros in taxes from 35 companies, including from BP (BP) and Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD), among others.Apple stock ended trading down 0.8% to 106 on the stock market today."The ruling is disappointing, and while Apple is confident in an appeal, the process may take several years and may have a near-term sentiment overhang on the stock," Wells Fargo analyst Maynard Um said in a research report Tuesday. He rates Apple stock as outperform with a valuation range of 115 to 125.RELATED:Apple Schedules Sept. 7 Event For iPhone 7 RevealApple Should Buy Sirius XM Satellite Radio, CNBC's Jim Cramer Says.

McDonald's (MCD) agreed to sell a controlling stake in its China and Hong Kong operations to a group of investors for about $1.7 billion, a key component of the fast-food giant's reorganization in a market where it's striving to catch up with more nimble rivals.Chinese state-backed conglomerate Citic Ltd., Citic Capital Holdings and U.S. private-equity firm Carlyle Group LP will acquire an 80% holding in a deal valuing the business at as much as $2.08 billion, according to a statement Monday. Oak Brook, Illinois-based McDonald's will keep the remaining stake. The new owners plan to add more than 1,500 restaurants over the next five years in smaller Chinese cities.McDonald's and rival Yum China Holdings (YUMC), which operates the KFC and Pizza Hut brands in the mainland, are among retailers that are trying to fend off domestic competition and attract middle-class Chinese consumers who increasingly demand high-quality and healthier dining options. As McDonald's streamlines its sprawling global operations, the fast-food giant is also looking at further deals in markets such as South Korea, Japan and Southeast Asia.Under the agreement, Citic Ltd. and Citic Capital Partners will jointly take a 52% stake, while Carlyle will hold 28%."Citic and Carlyle's resources will allow McDonald's to expand rapidly and refurbish old restaurants, which is expensive to do," said Ben Cavender, a Shanghai-based analyst at China Market Research Group. "Given that McDonald's lags behind KFC in terms of store count in China, we can expect them to expand aggressively and invest heavily."McDonald's currently operates or franchises more than 2,400 outlets in mainland China. Its five-year target means about 300 stores will be added annually. That compares with 600 stores for Yum China Holdings, which was spun off late last year by Yum Brands (YUM), and 500 restaurants for Starbucks (SBUX), according to the companies.While Citic and Carlyle are paying a "substantial price" for 20-year franchise rights, the food and beverage chains are "cash machines," Cavender said. In contrast, Yum China licensed the KFC and Pizza Hut brands from Yum Brands for 50 years, with automatic renewals that could make it possibly indefinite.The McDonald's transaction is Carlyle's second-biggest deal in China, trailing only its investments in China Pacific Insurance Group Co., according to a person with knowledge of the matter. The U.S. private-equity firm invested a total of more than $700 million in China Pacific Insurance in 2005 and 2007, the person said, asking not to be identified because the information is private. A spokeswoman for Carlyle declined to comment.McDonald's CEO  Steve Easterbrook is pursuing a turnaround plan to revive the company as it faces the fourth consecutive year of traffic declines in the U.S., its largest market. The China deal combines McDonald's with partners "who have an unmatched understanding of the local markets and bring enhanced capabilities and new partnerships," the CEO said in the statement.The new partnership will also focus on areas such as menu innovation, retail digital leadership and delivery, the statement said.McDonald's, which said in March it's seeking strategic partners in Asia, has committed to re-franchising 4,000 restaurants by the end of 2018, and has set a long-term target to have 95% of its outlets owned by franchisees.U.S. restaurant chains have seen their market lead in China challenged by a growing lineup of Asian competitors such as Ting Hsin International Group's Dicos eateries. The seller of Big Macs is also playing catch-up to Yum China. Since the spinoff from its U.S. parent, that company has a carte blanche opportunity to pursue growth, its Chief Executive Officer Micky Pant has said.The monthslong auction process drew interest from international private-equity funds and local companies. In October, people with knowledge of the matter said TPG Capital had exited the race, leaving its erstwhile partner, Chinese grocery operator Wumart Stores Inc., to compete against Carlyle and Citic. Bain Capital had also teamed up with Chinese hotelier GreenTree Hospitality for a bid, the people said at the time.

U.S. stock indexes moved into record territory Friday afternoon, as the Nasdaq headed for its fourth day of outperformance vs. the S&P 500.The Nasdaq popped 0.8% and the S&P 500 0.55%, both all-time highs. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5% after coming within 1 point of 20,000. The small cap Russell 2000 edged higher. Volume in the stock market today was running lower on both major exchanges.Two former IBD leaders showed strength. Priceline Group (PCLN) was on track for a 1% gain and its fourth straight up day. The stock is completing the eighth week of a flat base. The potential buy point is 1601.03, but an early entry could come at 1566.73.Priceline's earnings growth has faded from its glory years of 2003-2014, when annual growth ranged from 118% to 28%. In 2015, earnings growth eased to 9%. The Street expects 11% for the full year 2016 and then 17% this year. Priceline's margins show no slippage. In Q3, margin after tax was 42.5%, the best in at least 18 quarters.Illumina (ILMN), also a former leader, gapped up about 4% in heavy volume. The gene-sequencing big cap is still under its 200-day moving average line.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, the No. 1 ranked Banks-Super Regional rose 1.1%. Within the group, SVB Financial (SIVB) notched the best gain, up 2% in subdued volume.Blue chips were mostly down. Dow components Apple (AAPL), McDonald's (MCD) and Intel (INTC) are trading within a handle and could trigger buy points if they break out in heavy volume.RELATED:Disney Turns Tide, But GoPro, McDonald's DowngradedHow To Build An Earnings Season Action Plan

Apple (AAPL) has set up a court battle with European Union competition watchdogs who ordered Ireland to claw back a record $13.6 billion in unpaid taxes from the iPhone maker.The U.S. tech giant said Monday it formally appealed the EU's August decision to the EU's General Court in Luxembourg, as the European Commission and Ireland separately published details of their own arguments in the case.In an order that reverberated across the Atlantic, the EU slapped Apple with the multibillion-dollar bill, saying Ireland granted unfair deals that reduced the company's effective corporate tax rate. The U.S. Treasury said the EU was making itself a "supranational tax authority" that could threaten global tax reform efforts.The EU "took unilateral action and retroactively changed the rules, disregarding decades of Irish tax law, U.S. tax law, as well as global consensus on tax policy, that everyone has relied on," Apple said in a statement after filing its court appeal.Ireland already has asked the court to strike down the EU's decision from August. In a separate filing on Monday, the Brussels-based commission published details of its two-year probe, attacking the way Irish authorities taxed profits attributed to two of Apple's Irish units.The EU also took aim at Irish tax practices, saying they were "too inconsistent" to set firm rules for profit allocation.The Apple investigation and others probing arrangements for Amazon.com (AMZN) and McDonald's (MCD) in Luxembourg are the cornerstone of an EU attack on national practices it claims help multinational companies avoid taxation.EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager has repeatedly argued that special tax treatment harms companies that don't get such advantages.According to Monday's EU filing, regulators shrugged off claims that they weren't fair to Ireland and Apple during the probe. They argued that they always respected their procedural rights and the subject matter of the investigation — profit allocation methods used in tax rulings — never changed.Ireland had "ample opportunity" to express its views and "made use of that opportunity on multiple occasions," the EU said. While Apple only had the right to submit observations, it "was given and has effectively made use of the opportunity to submit" views to regulators on numerous occasions, according to the text of the EU decision.The EU's competition arm said it doubted that the methods used to produce taxable profit for Apple units complied with the so-called arm's-length principle for transfers between parts of a company.Ireland said the EU exceeded its powers by ruling on its tax jurisdiction, according to an Irish finance ministry statement on Monday.Ireland also challenges the EU's determination that Apple allocated almost all its European sales profits to what the EU said were "head offices" not subject to tax by virtue of their tax status in Ireland. Apple argues the units, Apple Sales International and Apple Operations Europe, were never exempt from taxation — and that under the law they are subject to deferred U.S. taxation."These branches carried out routine functions, but all important decisions within ASI and AOE were made in the U.S., and the profits deriving from these decisions were not properly attributable to the Irish branches of ASI and AOE," the Irish finance ministry said.The court appeals filed by Apple and Ireland follow those already pending by Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Belgium concerning tax arrangements the nations granted to units of other multinationals, including Starbucks Corp. (SBUX)Though Apple will have to pay its tax bill within weeks, the money will be held in escrow. A final ruling from the EU courts may take several years.

As has been the norm, Apple (AAPL) led the S&P 500 in stock buybacks in the third quarter as the information technology sector overall led the field, says a report by FactSet Research.Firms in the S&P 500 overall spent $115.6 billion on share buybacks in Q3, but that was down 28% year over year and the smallest quarterly total since Q1 2013.Top spender Apple repurchased $7.2 billion worth of shares in Q3. Following Apple for second place was General Electric (GE) at $4.3 billion, then Microsoft (MSFT) at $3.55 billion, Allergan (AGN) at $3.2 billion and McDonald's (MCD) at $2.77 billion.Apple, General Electric and Microsoft led the S&P 500 in stock buybacks in Q2 as well. Three months ago Microsoft said its directors had authorized a new stock buyback program of as much as $40 billion, and the company reaffirmed that it is on track to complete its current $40 billion buyback authorization by year-end.IBD'S TAKE: Share repurchases are a popular way to return capital to shareholders, tending to boost a stock and per-share earnings by reducing the number of shares outstanding. It's also a move that companies make when they begin to transition from rapid growth into middle age.As has been the norm for the S&P 500 index, the information technology sector was the top spending group in terms of buybacks at $27 billion, but that was down 41% year over year. Several major contributors were the smaller repurchases from Oracle (ORCL), Intuit (INTU), and Apple. The financials sector was the second top spending group, with $25 billion worth of stock being repurchased in Q3.Apple shares rose 0.1% to 117.06 on the stock market today.RELATED:Apple, Exxon Mobil Lead S&P 500 In Q2 Dividends PaidApple, Alphabet, Microsoft, Cisco Are Kings Of Cash

The European Union's executive arm on Tuesday ordered Apple (AAPL) to repay 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion) in back taxes plus interest to Ireland, part of a broader crackdown into EU member nations' special tax treatments for big multinationals.The European Commission ruled that Ireland's tax benefits to Apple amounted to illegal state aid under EU rules.The executive arm of the European Union Tuesday concluded that Ireland granted undue tax benefits to the U.S. tech giant - which is illegal under EU state aid rules."The Commission's investigation concluded that Ireland granted illegal tax benefits to Apple, which enabled it to pay substantially less tax than other businesses over many years," said EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager in a statement.Vestager said this let Apple pay "an effective corporate tax rate of 1% on its European profits in 2003 down to 0.005% in 2014."The adverse ruling was widely expected. Apple shares fell 0.8% to 106 at the close on the stock market today, its fifth straight loss.Both Apple and Dublin have said they'll fight the ruling, with the U.S. Treasury Department also objecting. Apple said the ruling will affect investment in Europe.The case, stemming back to initial EU charges vs. Ireland in 2014, will likely send a chill through boardrooms of multinational corporations. Vestager said the EU is still investigating Amazon (AMZN) and McDonald's (MCD).Last year, Starbucks (SBUX) was ordered to pay 30 million euros in taxes back to the Netherlands. Belgium in January was ordered to recover back 700 million euros in taxes from 35 companies, including from BP (BP), Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) and others.RELATED:Apple CEO Tim Cook Slams 'Unprecedented' EU Tax RulingApple Schedules Sept. 7 Event For iPhone 7 Reveal

Stocks ended mixed Friday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled that interest rates were set to go higher.The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.3%, dragged down by Verizon (VZ) and McDonald's (MCD), and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%. Olive Garden parent Darden Restaurants (DRI) reported fiscal second-quarter earnings that were in line with analyst forecasts, while revenue just missed.Estimates: EPS up 18.5% to 64 cents on a 2.5% revenue gain to $1.648 billion.Results: EPS of 64 cents, revenue from continuing operations edged up to $1.643 billion. Same-store sales rose 1.7%, but 2.6% at its Olive Garden locations. Olive Garden revenue rose 2.5% to $915 million, above some estimates.Outlook: Darden Restaurants still expects full-year EPS of $3.87-$3.97 with same-store sales growth of 1%-2%. Analysts forecast $3.93.Stock: Shares rose 0.1% to 75.73 in the stock market today. Darden stock edged up Monday but had been pulling back following its postelection climb from a cup base to an all-time high on Dec. 9.IBD'S TAKE: Darden Restaurants has tried to draw more customers by offering a better dining experience, and analysts see potential in its to-go offerings and digital platform. Meanwhile, Domino's Pizza is keeping an eye on the potential for drones and self-driving cars. McDonald's (MCD) rose 0.3%. Chipotle Mexican Grill (MCD) just dipped while Restaurant Brands International (QSR), which operates Burger King and doughnut shop Tim Hortons, edged up 0.1%.As for top-performing restaurant stocks, Domino's Pizza (DPZ) fell 0.1%, Dave & Buster's (PLAY) rose 0.25% while Wingstop (WING) climbed 0.5%.A broad swath of restaurant stocks suffered earlier this year amid food deflation, tougher competition, consumer anxieties and uncertainty from global affairs.But the election lifted restaurant shares amid expectations of an income tax cut, a hefty infrastructure spending bill and the easing of labor and healthcare regulations that affect the industry.Meanwhile, continued economic growth has tightened the job market, forcing income gains to finally pick up.RELATED:Darden Earnings Top But Restaurant Slump ContinuesChipotle Names Four New Directors In Nod To Investor Ackman

Even as the restaurant industry has struggled this year due to a litany of factors — cheaper groceries, discounting, rising labor costs — Domino's Pizza (DPZ) has thrived.Domino's overall ingredient costs tend to be lower than other restaurants, and a single pizza is generally affordable and feeds more people than other takeout fare. More importantly, the pizza giant was made for the smartphone, and its mobile-friendly ordering system has helped propel it above its peers.Domino's earnings and sales growth has been accelerating, while its stock has climbed 44% year to date. That compares to a 12% gain for IBD's Retail-Restaurant group, with nearly all of those gains coming after Donald Trump won the presidential election.Domino's CEO Patrick Doyle says the industry is undergoing its most "profound" transformation in decades, and expects Domino's to benefit from other restaurants' attempts to enhance their own technology. Further out, he sees pizzas that are still handmade, but not necessarily hand-delivered. Doyle also spoke about what the incoming Trump administration might mean for restaurants.An edited version of IBD's interview with Doyle follows.IBD: What do you see being the main themes that will define the coming year for the restaurant industry and Domino's Pizza?Doyle: Well, the industry overall has been relatively flat the last year or two. One factor is always the relative value of restaurant meals to grocery. Over the last couple of years that hasn't been as good for the industry. At Domino's we've had a pretty terrific last couple of years. And we think there are a lot of things that we got right that made that value equation better for our customers, in terms of getting food right, the service right and, recently, the use of digital. And we've gotten better-than-average growth as a result.If you look ahead to 2017, you're still looking at a pretty benign commodity-cost environment. You're going to continue to see from us and from the industry ongoing investment into technology. While we've been doing it for a while, you're seeing a lot of the restaurant industry putting more and more focus on that — whether or not it's dine-in restaurants and bringing ordering and payments into the stores. You're continuing to see a real split between the concepts that are, I think, doing things right and kind of modernizing their offerings and continuing to improve what they're doing and some that, frankly, have been struggling a little bit, maybe because the pace of change hasn't been what it's needed to be.IBD: If more restaurants are stepping up their technology investments, how concerned are you?Doyle: The more that digital technology becomes the default way that people are going to access brands, and it is already the majority of our business, I think that is going to continue to play to our strength. The pizza category is very fragmented. It is difficult for the regional chains to get their digital technology and experience to the same level that Domino's and some of the other national players are able to do just because of our scale. A lot of our growth over the past couple of years has really been market-share growth. So to the extent to which more digital investment is made across the industry, I think that means that customers become more and more accustomed to doing business that way with restaurant brands.IBD: Netflix has made it easier to stay in. Domino's has made it easier to order and eat in. How much do you think Domino's, indirectly, might be a streaming-media play?Doyle: Consumption of media and number of screens in front of people has gone up over the years, but I don't know that that's particularly accelerated over the past couple of years. You've just seen market share shift in terms of Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) Prime and DirecTV and others.What you've seen broadly in the restaurant industry is a split between dine-in and off-premise. If people are dining in, they are expecting a special experience. And you've seen some categories that have struggled because the experience hasn't been special. For years you've actually seen pretty significant growth in fine dining, though that has slowed a bit recently. But if people are going out, they want it to be a terrific experience. And I think the convenience of off-premise, whether it is delivery or carry-out, has continued to be pretty compelling.IBD: How does Domino's see technology changing its business going forward?Doyle: I think that when you look forward, the days of interacting with your technology through your phones are going to look quaint. We launched full voice ordering a few years back on our app, one of the very first, if not the first, commercial ordering applications with natural voice. We launched with Alexa (Amazon) earlier this year. What you're seeing with Alexa and Google Home (Alphabet (GOOGL)) — voice is probably a far more natural way for people to interact with technology over time, and you're starting to see that accelerate.As a delivery company we're looking very carefully at what's happening with autonomous and connected vehicles and drones and all of that. I think there's going to be a really significant evolution in the business model over the next decade.IBD: What does that look like when all this technology comes together? Is there a legitimate possibility of an Uber-ized form of delivery, where I yell to a device that I want to order pizza, it connects with a connected oven, bakes a pizza in a couple minutes, sends it to a self-driving, oven-equipped car?Doyle: It's all very "Jetsons," isn't it? Absolutely those things are possible. And the pace of change has been dramatic. If you look at the restaurant industry broadly, the last big, really disruptive innovation was a few decades back, when people put in drive-thru windows. You are now seeing a pace of change through technology that is, I think, dramatically more profound.IBD: Elsewhere in the fast-food space, McDonald's (MCD) and Wendy's (WEN) this year have adopted or considered moving more toward self-ordering kiosks either to, ostensibly, supplement or save on labor. Do you see your technology eliminating jobs or supplementing them and, if so, to what extent?Doyle: With the growth that we've had over the last few years, even as technology might make us more efficient in the stores, we certainly employ more people today than we did a couple of years ago. They're going to be more efficient because of technology but technology, for us, has only allowed us to grow.IBD: So you see technology as labor-enhancing, as opposed to labor-saving?Doyle: At some level, yes. First of all, hand-made pizza is a very important thing to our customers. That's why, with the redesign of our restaurants, we're taking out the wall. We refer to it as "Pizza Theater." But we fundamentally do three things in our stores: we take orders, we make pizzas and we get them to our customers, whether or not it's a delivery or it's in store. And the pizza-making part of that, and that being done by hand, has some real magic around it with our customers. But certainly the order-taking process is now majority digital, and as we discussed, we're certainly looking at new and different ways in terms of how you deliver the pizzas.IBD: What does a Trump presidency mean for your industry and Domino's Pizza?Doyle: Employed people buy a lot more pizza than unemployed people. So it really comes down to whether or not overall employment levels are going to go up. I'll let the experts opine on whether we're going to drive more employment in the near term as a result of the new administration. But that's certainly what we watch as being the most important factor.IBD: Are there any particular opportunities that you see from a Trump administration?Doyle: One of the most interesting things out there is a lot of discussion around tax reform. A revenue-neutral approach that simplifies and broadens the tax base but decreases the marginal tax rate, I think, is potentially a real positive. All economic theory says that's a good thing for growth.IBD: Trump plans to nominate CKE Restaurants CEO Andrew Puzder as labor secretary. Puzder has opposed minimum wage increases, the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare) and the Labor Department rule that would expand overtime eligibility (which was delayed after a federal judge blocked it last month). What would you look for from him if he is confirmed?Doyle: I'm not going to get into all the specifics — it's obviously very, very early. But I know Andy, and having somebody that understands our industry has to be a positive overall.IBD: So if he laid off a minimum wage hike, if the Affordable Care Act were scaled back, those would be favorable things?Doyle: Our job is to thrive in every environment. We operate in over 80 countries around the world and have an awful lot of different approaches to health care, and to wages and all the rest of it. We have a lot of success in all of them.IBD: What's one of the bigger, newer things that you learned about the restaurant industry in 2016?Doyle: It is very interesting seeing the evolving approach of aggregators, both in terms of order-taking and delivery services — sites like Uber Eats and GrubHub (GRUB), where you're going in and ordering off of multiple restaurant platforms. There's been a lot of activity on that front over the last year or two. I don't know that we've learned anything yet, because it's still quite early for a lot of those different businesses, but certainly something fairly new and interesting that has been taking place. And some of those are more developed outside of the U.S. than they are inside. It's actually quite developed in China.IBD: Could you expand on what's happening with aggregators in China?Doyle: We're taking orders over our own platform, so it's not necessarily that I like it, but it's interesting. And they've built some scale in some markets, so we're certainly watching that carefully and understanding the implications for the category and for our business. Again, no real conclusions yet.

Facing criticism that it was slow to respond to an E. coli outbreak last year, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), on Friday announced four new directors to its board in a long-anticipated shake-up supported by activist investor Bill Ackman.The new members — Paul Cappuccio, Robin Hickenlooper, Ali Namvar and Matthew Paull — actually joined the board on Wednesday. The move brings the current number of directors to 12, the burrito chain said in a statement Friday."Chipotle has taken the important step of refreshing its board, which will position the company for continued growth and long-term success," Ackman said in the statement.The overhaul addresses concerns that Chipotle's board was too insular and lacked diversity. The changes also add restaurant-industry experience in the form of Paull, previously chief financial officer of McDonald's (MCD). Following a series of foodborne-illness outbreaks last year, Chipotle drew flak for lacking the operational expertise of larger fast-food chains.The revamped board "gives us the oversight, accountability and leadership we need," Chief Executive Steve Ells said in the statement.Namvar is an executive at Ackman's firm, Pershing Square Capital Management, Chipotle's largest investor. He joined Pershing Square in 2006 and helped oversee its investments in McDonald's, Wendy's International (WEN) and other food companies. Paull, who previously served on Chipotle's board when the company was owned by McDonald's, is also on the advisory board at Pershing Square.Pershing Square disclosed a stake of almost 10% in Chipotle in September. If the holdings fall below 5%, Namvar will resign from the restaurant chain's board, Pershing Square said in a separate filing Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Chipotle shares are well off their peak of 758.61, reached just as disclosures over E coli outbreaks hit the restaurant chain, and now are below 400 a share. It's now ranked 48th among those in IBD's restaurant stocks group, with Jack In The Box (JACK) at the top of the list. Hickenlooper, meanwhile, is a former investment banker at Thomas Weisel Partners who serves in senior executive roles at both Liberty Global (LBTYA) and Liberty Media (LMCA) — two pieces of billionaire John Malone's cable and media empire. She married Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper, earlier this year.Cappuccio, a former U.S. Supreme Court clerk and associate deputy attorney general at the Department of Justice, rounds out the new additions. He has been general counsel at Time Warner (TWX) since 2001.The stock was up 2.1% in recent action. It had been down 20% this year through Thursday's close, hurt by Chipotle's food-safety crisis. The chain suffered a series of foodborne-illness outbreaks in 2015 and then struggled to repair its image, bringing massive sales declines.The reshuffle follows a CEO change on Monday, when Ells retook the role on a solo basis. He had served as co-leader with Monty Moran, but the board felt the arrangement made the chain harder to operate. Ells started the Denver-based company more than 23 years ago and ran it until 2009, when he assumed the shared role with Moran.Paull's involvement, meanwhile, extends a complicated relationship with McDonald's. Chipotle was a subsidiary of the burger giant before holding an initial public offering in 2006.Since then, Chipotle's executives have railed against traditional fast food and the burrito company has taken pains to distance itself from its former owner. Now, as Chipotle struggles with restaurant operations and new food-safety protocols, it's seeking advice from a veteran of the world's largest fast-food chain.Now, the question is how much difference the board changes will make, said Michael Halen, an analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence. It's a positive sign that Pershing and Chipotle are working together constructively, but the new board members alone aren't enough to jump-start the troubled chain's recovery, he said."It's really about people trusting the brand again, and ultimately that's going to take time," he said.

A year after the European Commission began formally investigating Luxembourg's tax treatment of McDonald's (MCD), the global fast-food restaurant is reportedly moving its overseas tax base to the U.K.The move comes just months after Brexit, the U.K.'s decision to leave the European Union.The Happy Meal maker chose the U.K. because of the "significant number of staff based in London working on our international business, language and connections to other markets," according to a McDonald's statement sent to Bloomberg.In December of last year, EU regulators set out to determine whether Luxembourg officials had given McDonald's an unfair tax advantage, alleging that McDonald's Europe Franchising had "virtually not paid any corporate tax in Luxembourg nor in the U.S. on its profits since 2009."In a statement to Bloomberg that echoes previous statements to other outlets, McDonald's said that it pays a "significant amount" of corporate taxes.McDonald's is not the only company currently being investigated. Amazon's (AMZN) tax arrangement in Luxembourg is also in the midst of an ongoing probe by the European Commission. That investigation began in 2014.In August, the commission concluded that Apple (AAPL) had received up to 13 billion euros of unfair tax benefits from Ireland.McDonald's shares climbed 0.4% to 120.45 in the stock market today. Amazon shares fell 0.4%. Apple shares climbed 1%.RELATED:EU: Apple Must Pay Ireland $14.5 Billion In TaxesTrump Taps Fast-Food CEO, Big ObamaCare Foe, To Head Labor Department

Facebook (FB) has transformed how people communicate. But from an investor standpoint, what's impressive is how the social network, despite its reach, is still adding users and finding ways to rapidly increase revenue per users.Facebook is among five stocks on the elite IBD 50 list that boast the fastest true revenue growth. (Companies such as Apple supplier Broadcom (AVGO) enjoying huge sales gains largely due to recent acquisitions were excluded).Apple (AAPL), which once awed Wall Street with its ability to generate huge growth despite its size, has reported lower sales in the last two quarters. McDonald's (MCD), Ford (F) and Salesforce (CRM) have reported "softening" in U.S. demand. So finding top-rated companies that can deliver on the top line is even important.Acacia Communications is a provider of high-speed fiber-optic communications gear. It's one of the brightest lights in the fiber-optic "supercycle" as telecoms and cloud-computing firms in the U.S. and China ramp up network spending.Sales growth: Sales rose 101% vs. a year earlier in the latest quarter, the third straight quarter of accelerating growth.Stock: Acacia priced its May IPO at 23 a share. The stock shot up 9.1% to 123.44 on the stock market today, rocketing to a new high of 127.20 intraday.RELATED:Acacia, Twilio, Line IPOs Prime Market For Post-Labor Day PickupIBD'S TAKE: For a deep dive into the fiber-optic boom, check out this Industry Snapshot on the gigabahn's last mile.NetEase develops and operates some of China's most popular PC and mobile games and provides advertising services, email services and e-commerce platforms. NetEase, is benefiting from serving the world's largest internet market that's still growing rapidly.Sales: NetEase revenue rose 89% vs. a year earlier. That actually was a slowdown from the 100%-plus gains in the prior three quarters.Stock: NetEase cleared a 179.20 buy point on June 29. Since then the stock has continued to climb. Shares rose 3.3% to 222, hitting a fresh high. There is no potential buy point.RELATED:Tencent, Alibaba Lead Chinese Internet Stock Rally3 Top China Stocks Handily Beating The MarketNetEase Beats Earnings Estimates On China Gaming GainsFacebook is the leading social network, boasting more than 1.7 billion monthly active users at the end of the second quarter, including 1 billion mobile MAUs. Facebook has adapted to mobile and is embracing video as it continues to find ways to better-monetize its users. That includes its photo- and video-sharing site Instagram.Sales: Facebook revenue rose 59% vs. a year earlier, the best gain in seven quarters. Meanwhile, earnings growth has accelerated for the last four quarters.Stock: Facebook cleared a 121.18 buy point in late July. After weeks of moving sideways, Facebook rose 2.55% to 129.73 Tuesday, hitting an all-time high and becoming extended from that original buy point. But Facebook has now topped a new buy point at 128.43.RELATED: Facebook Adds Pinch-To-Zoom On Instagram As Monetization Stays HotFacebook's Action Has Been Frustrating: Is That About To Change?Mobileye makes driver-assistance systems that are in high demand from automakers as they work on autonomous vehicles. Mobileye and Tesla (TSLA) recently agreed to wind down their relationship. But Mobileye has an alliance with auto parts maker Delphi (DLPH) to create a turnkey autonomous system for carmakers by 2019. Mobileye also is working with Intel (INTC) and BMW (BMWYY) to have a self-driving vehicle on the market by 2021.Sales: Mobileye sales rose 58% in the latest period, though that represents the third straight quarter of decelerating growth.Stock: Mobileye has been forming a handle in a yearlong consolidation with a buy point of 50.28. Mobileye briefly crossed the pivot on Aug. 23, on the Delphi news, but closed below that level. Mobileye fell 0.35% to 48.93 Tuesday.RELATED:Mobileye Accelerates Self-Driving Car Technology With Delphi DealPaycom Software offers employers cloud-based records-management programs running from job application through retirement.Sales: Paycom revenue rose 51% in the latest quarters. Sales growth has ranged from 45% to 63% over the last seven quarters.Stock: Paycom shares fell 0.2% to 52 on Tuesday after rising 1.5% Friday to 52.10, hitting a new high. That cleared a short, four-week consolidation after a strong prior run-up. Volume was only slightly above average, but significantly higher than in recent sessions.RELATED:3 Software Makers Highlight Top Tech Stocks

Five big-name stocks are making notable moves as the market continues to climb higher, including two IBD 50 members, Facebook (FB) and LendingTree (TREE), and two Olympics sponsors, Nike (NKE) and McDonald's (MCD).Nike is trading well below its all-time high reached last December, but it has been rallying since hitting a 10-month low in July. Shares are now nearing the critical 200-day line, boosted by a quick-turnover rise on Friday in sympathy with Foot Locker's (FL) view-topping quarterly results. The athletic footwear and apparel giant's chart has suffered much technical damage, but retaking the 200-day line would be bullish.McDonald's is still feeling the pain from its announcement last month of weaker-than-expected U.S. same store sales in Q2, with shares dropping below their late June low to hit their worst level in five months on Friday. The stock is now 12% below its all-time high, reached on May 10.IBD 50 member Facebook continues to trade within buy range after clearing a 121.18 buy point, a sluggish breakout amid the recent new highs reached by the major indexes. Though the stock has been fading in recent sessions -- it's now 3% below its all-time peak reached on July 28 -- its uptrend remains intact.LendingTree, another IBD 50 name, is in danger of hitting the 5%-8% sell territory. The stock is now 4% below a 106.92 cup buy point. For those who bought the stock after it cleared that level, make sure to keep an eye out for any further losses.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 is a ranking of leading growth stocks based on key measures such as earnings and sales growth, profit margins, return on equity and relative price performance during the past 12 months. To see which names join Facebook and LendingTree on that list, plus up-to-date chart analysis, check out the IBD 50 on our Leaderboard platform.And financial software firm Guidewire (GWRE) is building a base ahead of its quarterly earnings report in a few weeks. After a failed breakout past a cup-with-handle base in late June, Guidewire is forming a flat base with a 64.10 buy point. It's trading 3% below that level as it looks for support at its 50-day line.RELATED:

McDonald's (MCD) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) showed bearish action on the stock market Friday, as investors remained somewhat squeamish about restaurant trends generally.McDonald's fell 1.8% to 115.01 on Friday, hitting the lowest level in six months. It was the weakest close since early December. McDonald's is still struggling from reporting weaker-than-expected Q2 U.S. comps, partly due to broader consumer weakness. The all-day breakfast menu introduced late last year had fueled a turnaround, but investors are worried about growth drivers as comparisons get tougher.Meanwhile, McDonald's faces rising labor costs due to minimum-wage hikes and the company's own wage increases. Rising costs and weaker comps will squeeze margins, said Argus Research last week as it downgraded McDonald's.IBD'S TAKE: Rising labor costs are a problem for fast-food chains generally. Fast-food prices have never risen so fast vs. the cost of eating at home.  Chipotle Mexican Grill retreated 1.6% to 388.50, a three-year closing low. Chipotle is still trying to recover from last year's food-borne illness outbreaks. It's introduced a new menu item -- chorizo sausage -- and introduced its first loyalty program, Chiptopia. Chipotia is generous but complicated, so it's unclear how many people will use it aggressively and whether they'll keep dining at Chipotle in October.Starbucks (SBUX) fell 1.1% to its lowest level in nearly two months. Like McDonald's, Starbucks reported weak U.S. comps for its latest quarter but said that was an anomaly, vowing improvement. Still, a few days after the earnings report Starbucks stock met resistance at the 200-day line and began retreating, falling through its 50-day average as well.On the upside, Domino's Pizza (PZZA) and Papa John's (PZZA) have delivered strong results, sending shares to highs.Jack in the Box (JACK) spiked after its earnings report earlier this month and is now trading just below its all-time high of 99.99 set in March 2015. Notably, Jack in the Box owns Qdoba Mexican Eats, a rival chain to Chipotle.RELATED:

Homebuilders unexpectedly broke ground on more homes last month while industrial production rose by the most in over a year, suggesting the economy is more in line with the solid July jobs report than recent tepid retail sales data. Meanwhile, consumer prices were flat.Housing starts rose 2.1% in July to an annual rate of 1.21 million, the Commerce Department said, defying forecasts for a dip to 1.18 million. That's just below January's post-recession peak, but starts remain far below the 2-million-plus levels in the years before the crash.Building permits fell 0.1% to a 1.152 million rate. Economists expected a slight rise to a 1.16 million pace.Multifamily starts led the way, rising 8.3% to 433,000, the best since September. New construction on single-family homes inched up 0.5%.On Monday morning, the NAHB Housing Market Index showed a gain of 2 points to 60, as builders expressed stronger confidence in the buying outlook. Yet the question is whether they are putting their money where their mouths are or unsure if introducing more supply to the market could hurt pricing and weigh on margins.The July consumer price index was unchanged, as expected, thanks to lower gas prices. Core prices rose 0.1%, just below views for a 0.2% rise, as the price of medical care and other services continues to outpace goods prices.Core inflation was 2.2%, down from June's 2.3%.Bottom line: July's data show that housing continues to be a tailwind for the economy, while the prospect of Fed rate hikes still isn't much of a headwind.IBD'S TAKE: Should investors care about Fed rate increases? Because there's no simple answer, investors would be better off focusing on overall stock market conditions to know whether the time is right to buy shares. Visit IBD University to learn proven rules about timing stock purchases.Lately, grocery prices have been falling while prices for food away from home have been rising, and that continued in July. Fast-food chains like McDonald's (MCD) and Wendy's (WEN) have cited that divergence as a headwind to sales.Industrial production rose 0.7% in July, the best monthly gain since November 2014 and beating views for a 0.3% rise. June's gain was revised down modestly. Manufacturing output climbed 0.5%, the best in a year.Industrial activity has been rising modestly in recent months. General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) reported lower U.S. sales in July. Still, output of motor vehicles and parts rose 1.9% in July, the Fed data showed.There's reason to doubt whether the solid manufacturing gain is an emerging trend. Analysts think U.S. auto sales are approaching a long-term peak, and summer production is subject to seasonal volatility as auto plants retool.On Monday morning, the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Index unexpectedly fell to negative 4.51 in August from July's positive 0.55.

McDonald's (MCD) and Best Buy (BBY) were downgraded Monday, while Lululemon (LULU) and JCPenney (JCP) saw their price targets raised, and Valeant (VRX) was upgraded to buy.McDonald's was downgraded to hold from buy at Argus. The fast-food giant's profit margins are likely to be squeezed by rising labor costs and slowing same-store growth over the coming quarters. McDonald's last month posted weaker-than-expected U.S. comps, something several other restaurants have also reported.McDonald's stock lost 0.8% to 118.52 at the close on the stock market today.Telsey Advisory Group raised Lululemon's price target to 92 from 82 and kept its outperform rating on the yoga-wear retailer's stock.Lululemon shares rose 1.2% to 80.27 at the close, hitting a three-year high.Best Buy was downgraded to hold with a 36 price target at Jefferies. The analysts said that the electronics store will see weaker same-store sales and margins due to a "maturing" 4K TV cycle.Best Buy shares fell 1% to 34.51. The stock is at a resistance area around 35.Nordstrom's (JWN) price target was raised to 47 from 38 at RBC Capital Markets. Late Thursday, the upscale department store reported better-than-expected profit in Q2, but revenue came in light. Still, Nordstrom rose 8% on Friday and was up 18% for the week.Telsey Advisory hiked JCPenney's price target to 13 from 12. On Friday, JCPenney reported a smaller-than-expected Q2 loss, as same-store sales rose 2.2%. JCPenney was the bright spot among department stores in Q2, according to Cowen analysts. JCPenney shares rose 6% on Friday and 12% for the week.Nordstrom shares rose 3.1% to 52.96 intraday. JCPenney stock jumped 7% to 11.29.IBD'S TAKE: Nordstrom and JCPenney are rebounding, but they are still working on bases while their fundamentals are mixed. Meanwhile, Home Depot and Lowe's are holding at or near buy points, as their profit and sales have held up. For more on the home improvement chains, which both report earnings this week, click here.The drugmaker was upgraded to neutral by Mizuho Securities. Valeant is still dealing with a scandal with now-defunct pharmacy Philidor.On Monday, billionaire investor David Tepper's Appaloosa hedge fund disclosed it sold off all its shares of Valeant in Q2.Valeant shares leapt 6.7% to 26.59 at the close.

The biggest problem for the fast-food industry just got worse. As rough as the burger wars are, fast food chains are facing even more heat from an increasingly tough competitor: eating in.While Wendy's (WEN) says it's picking up market share in the hamburger segment of the fast-food industry, industrywide demand has been flat.Wendy's CEO Todd Penegor explained why on an earnings call last week: "It's gotten a lot cheaper, relatively speaking, to go get fresh beef at your local butcher and go home and grill it," he said, according to a SeekingAlpha.com transcript.Prices for uncooked ground beef are down 10.2% from a year ago, the Labor Department said Tuesday, in a reversal aided by cheaper corn for feeding cattle. Poultry prices for home consumption are down just over 3% from a year ago.Overall, the cost of food consumed at home fell 0.2% in July, while the cost of food away from home rose 0.2%. That continues a trend which has moved into uncharted territory.Over the past two years, prices of limited service meals and snacks are up 6.0%, while food-at-home costs 0.7% less than it did two years ago. That's the biggest gap since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began breaking out fast-food prices in the late 1990s. The shift has accelerated over the past year, in which food-at-home costs have fallen 1.6%, while fast-food purchases cost 2.9% more.On Monday, Argus Research analyst John Staszak downgraded shares of McDonald's (MCD) from buy to hold, saying that a difficult combination of upward pressure on labor costs and the relatively cheap cost of eating at home could be a negative for restaurant traffic and sales in coming quarters.McDonald's Chief Financial Officer Kevin Ozan said on a July 26 conference call, "While we are benefiting from favorable commodity costs around the world, we are facing rising labor costs in many of our markets. As a result, we are carefully balancing price increases with a focus on maintaining our strong value proposition."He noted that menu prices were up about 3% from a year ago in the second quarter.IBD'S TAKE: If rising labor costs already are a concern for the fast-food industry, can low-cost chains live with a $15 minimum wage? To understand why a high minimum wage will be so difficult for fast-food franchises to digest, check out this Industry Snapshot.Jack in the Box (JACK) reported a 3.7% decline in transactions in the second quarter, citing a "migration (of business) from our industry to supermarkets."Still, margins at Jack in the Box brand restaurants increased 0.5 percentage point to 22.5% "as favorable commodity costs more than offset wage inflation," said Jerry Rebel, Jack's chief financial officer.Potbelly (PBPB) said commodity deflation had lowered its cost of goods sold to 27.3% in the second quarter, down 1.2 percentage point from a year ago. But labor costs are rising, from 28.5% a year ago to a range of 29% to 30%. "We remain extremely focused on managing our labor expense through continued efforts and investments to improve our labor productivity as well as through targeted price increases," Potbelly CFO Michael Coyne said.In addition to labor costs, different industry dynamics have kept restaurant chains from trying to keep pace with grocery stores in cutting prices.Food-at-home deflation also is a big issue for fast-casual chains. But Brinker International (EAT), which owns the Chili's and Maggiano's Little Italy chains, says it's staying on plan to raise prices 1.5% to 2% a year, amid labor-cost increases and doubts that food-at-home prices will keep falling."It's a little different in retail where you just resticker the product every day, but for us, we believe that it makes more sense to be more consistent in your pricing," CEO Wyman Roberts said.Another consideration for franchises is that for McDonald's, the Restaurant Brands International (QSR) Burger King chain and others, franchise fees and rent, in some cases, is a fixed percentage of sales. That means lower prices would directly cut into franchise royalties, a cash cow.

The restaurant industry did not have what you would call an amazing quarter. A muddling economy that has left many behind, ISIS-inspired violence that has become harder to anticipate, a U.S. election that finds new ways each day to insult our intelligence -- all of these factors have made spending on restaurants less enticing. Other issues, like discounting and cheaper groceries, have also dragged sales lower.But pizza chains like Domino's Pizza (DPZ) and Papa John's (PZZA) are way up in the wake of their second-quarter results, unlike McDonald's (MCD), Starbucks (SBUX), Wendy's (WEN) and others.In fact, Domino's Pizza stock is up 31% so far this year, and Papa John's is up 33%, while IBD's Retail-Restaurants group is up just 5%. Starbucks has lost 7%, and McDonald's has advanced just 1%.Domino's and McDonald's shares rose 0.1% on the stock market today, while Starbucks was flat. Papa John's slid 0.65%.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Domino's Pizza broke out of a cup-with-handle base following the company's most recent quarterly results. Learn more about the basics of how and when to buy stocks here.While pizza stocks weren't the only strong performers in the industry this quarter, Domino's was the only one of the 25 largest restaurant concepts in America to turn out at least 5% same-store sales growth in the second quarter, Nomura analyst Mark Kalinowski said.What happened? Analysts cite value -- for both customers and the businesses themselves -- convenience, and a digital ordering platform that isn't just lip service to technology.KeyBanc said in a recent research note that the pizza sector stood to benefit from the uncertainty as more people opt to order in. On the value front, you can feed a few people for not that much money, and pizza's main ingredients are cheaper, helping pad margins.What's more, pizza has been delivered to household doors for decades. For Domino's and Papa John's, that facilitates the transition to digital ordering -- over a mobile device -- which for many is far more pleasant and convenient than ordering via a phone call."When you look at the model for pizza delivery," Kalinowski said, "that lends itself to digital ordering that most other parts of the restaurant industry don't."While he said that digital ordering platforms will become more prevalent over time, some restaurants are more mobile-friendly than others. Starbucks, for instance, has a customer frequency that other restaurants don't, he said, so mobile ordering makes sense. For other restaurants, the returns on investing in mobile have been less certain."It's almost like a keeping up with the Joneses problem," Kalinowski said.Pizza is also more mobile-order-friendly because of the way people eat it -- a single pie serves more people; that means less time ordering a bunch of individual items for each person in a group."The thought process of ordering a pizza is relatively limited, other than a couple different toppings and a couple different pies," Tigress analyst Ivan Feinseth said. "For the most part, the majority will agree on what to get on pizza. Ordering Chinese food (is) much more difficult. Ordering Italian food (is) much more difficult."

Like other restaurant chains this earnings season, Shake Shack (SHAK) said on its second-quarter earnings call that Brexit, terrorism abroad and global economic strains could remain troubling, even though the fast-casual burger chain said it remained upbeat about the future."Internationally, we are not immune to global economic and political uncertainty," Shake Shack CEO Randy Garutti said on the call Wednesday.He added that "recent terrorism in Istanbul" would continue to hurt business at its four locations there. A shooting and suicide bombing in June at Istanbul's Ataturk Airport, Turkey's largest, killed 45 people. Then, last month, a failed coup attempt by a faction in the military resulted in a massive government purge from the nation's military, legal system, education system and media.Garutti also said that the company's Middle East business -- its website lists 26 locations in the region -- "continues to experience headwinds, given the regional challenges, and the volatility of the oil market."The U.K.'s vote in June to leave the European Union, he said, also "brings new uncertainty" that could keep the pound weak against the dollar. Garutti said Shake Shack would "temper our near-term expectations."McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX) also described a less-certain consumer during their earnings calls.Shares sank 6.2% to 38.35 in the stock market today, though they are currently holding above their 50-day and 200-day moving averages.That followed weaker-than-expected Q2 same-store sales growth. However, Shake Shack's Q2 earnings per share and overall revenue beat Street estimates, and the company raised full-year revenue guidance above views.Shake Shack also said it expected to open 18 domestic company-run locations this year, up from 16.IBD'S TAKE: While people might have been more reluctant to dine out during the second quarter, stocks like Domino's Pizza, Papa John's and GrubHub -- which lean more on digital ordering, delivery and takeout -- are way up comparatively. Read more about the fast-food and burger wars here. The sight of more empty tables at restaurants "may be the result of consumers eating more at home amid the current political/social backdrop, which we believe could last through the November election," according to a KeyBanc analyst report cited by MarketWatch.Stocks like Papa John's (PZZA), whose business depends more on pickup and delivery, stand to benefit as a result, the note said.Papa John's and Domino's Pizza (DPZ) are among the minority of restaurants to report strong earnings reports. Domino's is slightly extended from a breakout last month following quarterly results. Papa John's is consolidating near highs, forming a handle with a 78.19 buy point.Lower grocery-store prices and some harsh weather in some parts of the U.S. also weighed on second-quarter restaurant sales.Shake Shack's play for a higher-end fast-food consumer, however, means it doesn't have to worry as much about competing on value meals, the way traditional fast-food chains do.The company, SunTrust analyst Jake Bartlett said in a note, "is largely immune to the current industry slowdown given its differentiation." And Cowen analyst Andrew Charles said that the firm viewed Shake Shack's "softness as temporary". Others felt it was a good time to buy the stock, saying that even though its valuation has fallen its long-term potential remains strong.Newer menu items and limited-time offerings also helped, management said. The Chick'n Shack sandwich accounted for 8.4% of Q2 sales. Its Bacon Cheddar Shack "has been the best performing LTO (limited time offering) we've run since we launched the LTO program last year." The company has also tried out breakfast menu items in a handful of spots.Those menu adjustments come as restaurants try to draw new customers without cluttering up their menus and losing their identity. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), another fast-casual chain often praised for its concise menu, also said that the addition of chorizo to its menus had helped draw customers.Shake Shack also said it had higher labor costs during the quarter, but that the impact was cushioned by its sales growth. Management said on the call that they "still expect labor pressure" this year, following a recent wage increase."But as we get to the second half of the year, we're going to continue to invest in our teams, in this competitive environment, to get the right people, in order to get the people that we need, in order to continue to execute the way that we have," CFO Jeff Uttz said on the call.McDonald's rose 0.5% Thursday, while Domino's Pizza gained 0.7% and Papa John's 0.9%. Starbucks fell 0.3%.

The Summer Games aren't just a noble gathering of the world's athletic elite: The event is also a marketing gold mine for official brand partners and sponsors of individual athletes.And perhaps more so in 2016 than in prior Olympic years, trying to harness the life force of the internet can lead to unpredictable results, thanks to an often-rowdy digital commentariat on Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR), Snapchat and elsewhere. Brands can emerge from the melee as social-media stars or as sore losers.So here's a glimpse at how Coca-Cola (KO), McDonald's (MCD), Nike (NKE) and others are performing in Rio so far:Not Coke's fault, but the soft drink giant got mixed up in a PR debacle when an Olympian from Egypt told NPR that there was no coffee in the Olympic Village, because it was a Coca-Cola-only zone.The story went semi-viral. The New York Daily News, Business Insider, Fusion and others picked up on the NPR segment -- Cosmopolitan even grouped it under a listicle called "11 Rio Olympic Village Horror Stories."Spokespeople from Coca-Cola, an official worldwide sponsor of the Games, told several of those outlets that no, the athletes aren't limited to Coke products and yes, there is coffee in Olympic Village, but the damage had been done.That's probably not what gold feels like.Shares rose 0.3% to 43.75 on the stock market today. Coca-Cola stock has been trading below its 200-day average since reporting Q2 results late last month.The Big Mac maker is doing lots of feel-good stuff around the Olympics -- it sent kids to the opening ceremony! Its McNuggets are pink-slime-free! -- but you can trust hungry, tired reporters to weed out the real news: there's no McDonald's in Olympic Park.According to USA Today, Olympiads of years past have prominently featured a McD's in the press center. But McDonald's told the paper that it wanted to get into the local spirit and feature dessert stands instead, of which there are 2,500 in Brazil.There is, however, a full-service McDonald's in Olympic Village. And it is very, very popular with the athletes.Line out the door at McDonald's in Olympic Athletes Village (via @JohnBranchNYT) pic.twitter.com/HJQrxqcP2k— Darren Rovell (@darrenrovell) August 9, 2016Shares rose 0.5% to 119.38 Thursday. McDonald's is moving sideways since reporting weaker-than-expected U.S. same-store sales on July 26.Serena Williams may be out of Olympic contention, but Nike still has a massive number of high-profile athletes competing in Rio, like track and field star Allyson Felix and soccer player and Twitter darling Alex Morgan.
GAME DAY! Game face on. #USAvFRA pic.twitter.com/skS6kHAz6Z— Alex Morgan (@alexmorgan13) August 6, 2016

Brand synergy is everything. Deliberate or not, the Swoosh is probably pretty happy that both Serena and Allyson appear to be buds, even if they are wearing Ralph Lauren (RL) in this Snapchat.Me & @serenawilliams getting ready to walk! Snapchat✨Allyson_Felix pic.twitter.com/PauK4kn6sH— Allyson Felix (@allysonfelix) August 5, 2016Nike is one of 28 official domestic sponsors of the Games, although the recent loosening of IOC rules may make such a partnership less valuable, NPD Group analyst Matt Powell has told IBD.IBD's TAKE: A change in Olympic rules opened up the playing field to non-sponsor brands that have athlete endorsements. Does that mean Nike is wasting its money by sponsoring the Games? Read on for more: "How Under Armour Hopes To Steal Nike's Thunder At The Rio Olympics."And this new ad, which dropped Wednesday, is a moving, lyrical piece featuring Chance the Rapper waxing patriotic and sampling anthem lyrics. It's already getting rave reviews. Score one, Nike.Shares climbed 2.9% to 56.73, regaining its 50-day line after closing below that support on Wednesday.Click here tuned for part 2 of the Brand Olympics -- featuring Apple (AAPL), Under Armour (UA), Visa (V).

The smash hit smartphone video game "Pokemon Go" is on an annual revenue run rate of more than $1 billion, Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said Wednesday."We think the game is currently operating at meaningfully north of a $1 billion annual revenue run rate," Creutz said in a research report."Pokemon Go" is a joint venture of the Pokemon Company and video game publisher Niantic. Nintendo (NTDOY) is a shareholder in both of the two companies and also owns the trademarks to Pokemon and the Pokemon character names."Pokemon Go," a free-to-play, location-based augmented reality game, has been the No. 1 most-downloaded game on the Apple (AAPL) App Store and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Play store since its July 6 launch.While the game is free to play, it sells in-game items that enhance the experience and help players advance. Apple and Google get a 30% share of in-game sales sold through their respective app stores.Nintendo stock rose 1.25% to 28.27 in the stock market today, though well off its five-year high above 38, touched July 18. Alphabet stock climbed 0.1%, while Apple stock was down 0.7%.IBD'S TAKE: Two video game companies are among the top-performing companies on the IBD 50: NetEase and Activision Blizzard. IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group currently ranks No. 56 out of 197 groups.The popularity of "Pokemon Go" has benefited a host of other companies. Some retailers like GameStop (GME) and McDonald's (MCD) have become stops for "Pokemon Go" players looking for digital creatures and in-game items and have seen a corresponding sales boost."Pokemon Go" has also spurred sales of smartphone battery packs because the game is a notorious power hog. The NPD Group reported that portable power pack sales were up 101% year over year in the two-week period in July following the introduction of "Pokemon Go." Makers of mobile power packs include Best Buy (BBY), Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB)-owned Duracell, Energizer (ENR) and Zagg (ZAGG)."Pokemon Go" does not appear to be affecting sales for other top mobile game companies, Creutz said."Multiple gaming companies that we cover have … said that they haven't seen much impact on their revenue from the launch of the game, suggesting that 'Pokemon Go' has largely been additive to the market," he said.The success of "Pokemon Go" demonstrates the importance of major franchises to game publishers, he said."Companies with significant franchises and quality (intellectual property) are likely to increasingly dominate the space," he said. Another prime example is King Digital Entertainment, now owned by Activision Blizzard (ATVI), which has the "Candy Crush" game series.Electronic Arts (EA) has been successful in the mobile games space with versions of its popular consoles sports franchises. They include "Madden NFL Mobile," "NBA Live Mobile" and "FIFA Mobile."RELATED:Nintendo Tanks On News It Won't Benefit Much From 'Pokemon Go''Pokemon Go' Fires Starting Gun For Augmented RealityApple Could Reap Billions From 'Pokemon Go'

Shake Shack (SHAK) sank after-hours Wednesday after reporting weak same-store sales, while Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) rose after topping second-quarter estimates. Silver Wheaton (SLW) was also set to report quarterly results after the close.Estimates: Analysts expected the upscale fast-casual burger chain to report second-quarter earnings per share of 13 cents, a 44% jump from a year earlier. Revenue is seen rising 30% to $63.15 million.Results: Shake Shack earned 14 cents, up 56%. Revenue climbed 37% to $66.5 million. Same-store sales rose 4.5%, below forecasts of 4.9% or more.Shake Shack sees full-year revenue of $253 million to $256 million, up from its prior target of $245 million to $249 million. It sees full-year comps up 4%-5%.Analysts forecast 2016 revenue of $252.09 million, though that was before the $3 million beat in Q2.Shake Shack's stock dived 8% in after-hours action. Shares closed down 1.4% to 40.99 on the stock market today. Shake Shack has been trading sideways in 2016 after plunging in the second half of last year. But the stock has been trading recently above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Performance in the restaurant industry has also slowed recently, with violence, civil unrest and economic anxieties making many people more reluctant to eat out.Since customers expect to pay more when they go there, Shake Shack has largely been able to stay out of the hornets' nest of value-meal competition that has sucked in McDonald's (MCD) and others. But the better-burger outlet faces no shortage of competition.Estimates: Wall Street expects Silver Wheaton to report second-quarter EPS of 14 cents, up 7.7%. Revenue is seen rising 22% to $200.82 million.Results: Silver Wheaton earned 14 cents, in line, while revenue was $212.35 million.Silver Wheaton reported 7.6 million ounces in silver production, up 28% and 70.2 million ounces of gold, up 16%. The company substantially raised its full-year gold production target while slightly trimming its silver output goal.Silver Wheaton shares were little changed in late trading. The stock closed up 1.4% to 30.17 Wednesday as a weaker dollar lifted precious metals. That's up from 12.42 at the end of last year.Silver Wheaton is a "silver streaming" company, making upfront payment to miners for the right to buy a fixed percentage of their production.Gold and silver stocks, often seen as safer investments, have risen as many investors try to play defense amid what executives this earnings season have repeatedly characterized as a "challenging environment." Silver Wheaton's purchase agreements with miners help it avoid some mining-industry risks.Royal Gold (RGLD), which owns and manages royalty interests in gold mines, reported EPS of 32 cents and revenue of $94.1 million, below views for 33 cents and $100.6 million. Royal Gold dipped after closing up 1.25%.Estimates: Analysts expected Q2 EPS of 17 cents on sales of $280.93 million.Results: EPS rose 45.2% to 19 cents on net sales of $287 million, up 12.9%.Blue Buffalo raised its full-year adjusted EPS forecast to 74-76 cents, and also hiked its revenue guidance for the year to $1.14 billion to $1.15 billion. Analysts expected EPS of 75 cents and $1.143 billion in sales.The appeal of Blue Buffalo, which purports to make higher-quality pet food, has strengthened as more people put more money into caring for their pets.Shares rose 2% in after-hours action. The stock closed closed 1.2% higher to 26.84 in heavy volume, just above a 26.79 buy point. On June 8, Blue Buffalo hit 27.37, the highest since August 2015.

U.S. stock indexes clung to small losses Friday afternoon on a day expected to show higher volume due to options expirations.The Nasdaq sanded off 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average shaved 0.3% each. Volume in the stock market today was running higher on both major exchanges.The Dow Jones utility average dropped 1.6% on further signs that the Federal Reserve may be preparing to raise interest rates. CME Group's Fed Watch Tool sees an 18% chance of a rate hike in September, but a 43% chance of one in December. Higher rates could make the dividends of utilities look less attractive.Most utilities have recently lost their 50-day moving average line. Southern Company (SO), for example, shows typical action -- losing the line Aug. 11 and since unable to reclaim it.One stock that is comfortably above its 50-day line and that shows no signs of weakness is retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA). The stock rose 0.6% and notched another new high. Ulta Beauty is slated to report quarterly results after the close Thursday. Wall Street expects earnings to advance 21% to $1.39 a share. That would be the slowest quarterly growth in nine quarters. However, Ulta beat views last time around by 12%.Among the blue chips, losers led winners by a 9-4 ratio in the Dow. The biggest percentage losers were Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), down 1.5%, and McDonald's (MCD), down 1.3%. The best performer was Nike (NKE), up 3%.Of the 197 industry groups followed by IBD, farm machinery was the day's No. 1 winner, up about 5%. The worst performer was the metal products distributor group, down 6%, but that was chiefly because of one stock: Olympic Steel (ZEUS) plunged 16%. Analysts at KeyBanc Capital Markets downgraded the stock from sector weight to underweight. KeyBanc also downgraded other steel-related stocks, saying they expect a weak supply-demand balance.

At first blush, analysis suggests the big stock winners related to the Olympics Games in Brazil are U.S.-based companies such as Nike (NKE) and Under Armour (UA), and also including McDonald's (MCD), Coca-Cola (KO) and Visa (V). But playing Brazil's market more directly in the form of exchange traded funds might be a more effective way to bank on the…

Nonfarm payrolls rose by 255,000 in July, the Labor Department said Friday morning, much better than expected for a second straight month, and reviving sentiment about the U.S. economy. But while the Federal Reserve will take notice, markets aren't expecting Fed action for several months.The jobless rate held at 4.9%, while hourly earnings rose 0.3% and the workweek nudged higher.Economists expected nonfarm payrolls up 185,000, the jobless rate dipping to 4.8% and average hourly earnings 0.3% higher.Also, June's strong figure was revised up by 5,000 to 292,000. May's weak hiring was revised up by 13,000 to 24,000."Maybe it's not morning in America, but the coffee is brewing and jobs are being created," said Joel Naroff, president and chief economist of Naroff Economic Advisors.Professional services, hospitality, retail and government sectors were key contributors. Manufacturing also rose in a broad-based gain. Mining, which includes oil drilling, showed further declines.The labor force participation rate rose 0.1 point for a second straight month to 62.8% as the labor force climbed by 407,000. The household survey, from which the unemployment rate is derived, showed an employment gain 0f 420,000."The July jobs report was uniformly positive and strong," said IHS Chief Economist Nariman Behravesh in statement. He said the strong labor force gain "signals greater confidence among US workers about job prospects."Behravesh did note that "as the economy approaches and reaches full employment, the pace of jobs gains is likely to slow."Stocks soared on the jobs report, with the S&P 500 hitting a fresh high and the Nasdaq composite rising to within 1% of its all-time best.Normally, back-to-back strong jobs reports and bullish markets would raise the specter of a Federal Reserve rate hike. But with other economic reports looking less robust -- and other central banks such as the Bank of England and Bank of Japan increasing monetary stimulus --- U.S. policymakers are still seen on hold for the foreseeable future.Fed funds futures peg the odds of a September or November meeting hike below 20%, vs. below 10% before the jobs report. The odds don't top 50% until next March, though investors see a reasonable chance of a December move."Given the unevenness of the data and still-present imbalance in the economy across sectors with a relatively solid consumer and markedly weak business investment, policy makers are likely to wait for further information regarding the longer-term trajectory of activity," wrote Stifel Fixed Income chief economist Lindsey Piegza.Strong hiring and solid wage gains --  holding at post-recession high of 2.6% vs. a year earlier -- should underpin consumer spending, which the economy has relied on even more in recent months. Consumer spending rose at a brisk 4.2% annual rate in the second quarter, even as the overall economy grew about 1% for a third straight quarter.But recent corporate reports have raised doubts about consumer-related stocks and perhaps the broader economy.Apple (AAPL) reported a second straight quarter of declining earnings and revenue. Apple shares have rallied as per-share earnings and iPhone sales topped weak forecasts, but they reflect weak demand.IBD'S TAKE: For a more detailed look at consumer-related stocks' recent woes, click here.Ford Motor (F) last week missed second-quarter earnings estimates, citing sluggish U.S. sales and higher incentive spending climbed. Ford predicted domestic industry sales would fall in 2016 and 2017. On Tuesday, Ford and General Motors (GM) reported declining sales vs. a year earlier. Other automakers generally reported weaker-than-expected results.Meanwhile, McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX) also have reported weaker-than-expected U.S. comps, both citing consumer unease in part. Several analysts see restaurant stocks in trouble generally, though pizza chains are doing well.Delta Air Lines (DAL) on Tuesday reported weak July unit revenue, hitting airline stocks that day.Despite retailers' headwinds, the sector added 25,000 jobs last month.Manufacturing added 15,000, the best since January. Auto production had been a manufacturing driver for several years. If Ford, General Motors and others see flat to lower sales for the foreseeable future, that could hurt factory output and jobs. And with oil prices well off midyear highs, any hoped-for revival in energy-related jobs may also be short-lived.

Stocks opened modestly lower Wednesday after positive earnings news countered the early impact from the firing of the FBI chief.President Trump fired embattled FBI Director James Comey late Tuesday on recommendations from Attorney General Jeff Sessions. FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe was named acting head of the agency.The news sent stock futures to early losses, but futures for the Nasdaq 100 later rebounded. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were down 0.1% at the open while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%.Among blue chips, Walt Disney (DIS) dropped 3% after reporting narrowly mixed fiscal second-quarter results late Tuesday. Earnings topped targets but a 3% revenue advance stopped just short of estimates.  Disney shares have been finding resistance at their 10-week moving average.

A number of tech names climbed on positive earnings news, helping to bolster the Nasdaq. Electronic Arts (EA) scored a 10% gain at the open. TripAdvisor (TRIP) trekked 6% higher.  Microchip Technology (MCHP) climbed 4% and is now extended above a buy point of 75.Graphics chip developer Nvidia (NVDA) scorched ahead 13% after an 85% earnings increase and a 45% rise in revenue easily topped analysts' first-quarter expectations. Management also lifted its second-quarter revenue guidance to above the consensus estimate. Nvidia shares are forming the right side of a consolidation.Netherlands-based aircraft lessor AerCap Holdings (AER) took an 8% advance, after reporting late Tuesday flat earnings and a 6% drop in revenue, both better than expected, in its first quarter. The company reported a fleet utilization rate of 99.7%, and launched a new $300 million share repurchase program. The stock on Tuesday closed 8% below a 49.76 buy point in a three-month flat base.On the downside, a number of stocks lodged big losses following their quarterly reports. Worst hit was Yelp (YELP), which collapsed 20% after its first-quarter earnings topped expectations, but revenue stopped short of targets. Further, its second-quarter and full-year guidance was below the consensus view.Priceline Group (PCLN) nosed down 4% after delivering mixed first-quarter results late Tuesday. Earnings rose 7% and topped views.  Revenue climbed 13%, just short of the consensus target.  Priceline shares remain extended from an April rebound from their 10-week moving average.Oil prices reversed early losses, with the West Texas Intermediate benchmark jumping 1.1% and back above $46 a barrel. Gold climbed 0.7% to above $1,224 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro and up against the yen. Bonds were in motion, trending higher and trimming the 10-year yield by 3 basis points to 2.37%.Import prices rose 0.5% and exports gained 0.2% in April, according to Labor Department estimates, up from respective gains of 0.1% and 0.2% in March. Economists projected both figures up 0.1% in April.The Energy Information Administration offers up its weekly oil inventories report at 10:30 a.m. ET. Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren speaks at 12 p.m. ET.
