The Street expects earnings to rise 15% to 45 cents a share. Revenue is expected to increase 8.4% to $5.41 billion. Starbucks, in buy range, edged higher.RELATED:Cold Pizza? Not At All. Domino's Delivers Hot Results

This earnings season, companies like Starbucks (SBUX) and McDonald's (MCD) have been more candid about mounting global dread, going beyond euphemisms like "challenging environment," as other giants like Apple (AAPL) and General Electric (GE) grapple with China's slowing economy and the Brexit vote.The remarks offer brief insights into management's thinking about an array of issues that have cropped up in earnings conference calls more recently, including the U.S. presidential election, the failed coup in Turkey and its fallout, mass shootings at home, and ISIS-inspired attacks worldwide.The CEOs of McDonald's and Starbucks -- whose sales depend on people going to their restaurants without worrying about their paychecks or safety -- both weighed in on the unease, according to Seeking Alpha transcripts."I think we have a situation where you have a very uncertain election," Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz said. "You have domestic civil unrest with regard to race. And I think the issues around terror have created a level of anxiety. And so, we're no longer looking at just an economic downturn."Schultz said conditions were "quite unusual." But he also said that the needs which the ubiquitous coffee chain appeals to -- "the sense of community, the longing for human connection, a safe place, an affordable luxury" -- would benefit the company overall.While cheaper grocery prices may encourage more people to eat at home, McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook said, "there's just a broader level of uncertainty in consumers' minds at the moment, both trying to gauge their financial security going forward, you know, whether through elections or through global events, people are slightly mindful of an unsettled world."The company benefits from "people moving around, going to the malls, driving around, going on vacations," he continued. "And if people are reining in their (spending) across broader categories, that will have a little bit of a flow-through to us as well."That sentiment also lines up with a recent note from KeyBanc Capital Markets, which upgraded Papa John's (PZZA), saying that civil unrest and a heated political environment may keep people at home -- and keep them ordering pizza -- instead of going out.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Papa John's and rival Domino's Pizza cleared buy points recently despite the overall restaurant sector facing a slowdown amid wage pressure and tougher price competition.The Brexit vote also has come up a lot during earnings calls, but its impact is not yet clear, while other global events and the outcome of the U.S. presidential vote are adding another layer of complexity, according to comments gleaned from Seeking Alpha transcripts.Michael DeWalt, a vice president at Caterpillar (CAT), said the U.K. vote to leave the European Union, the upheaval in Turkey and "all the negative rhetoric around the U.S. elections" added to the risks the construction firm was facing.Big banks generally turned out solid second-quarter results, but Goldman Sachs (GS) and Citigroup (C) commented on the "unique" course of the U.S. campaigns, which have turned banks into the favorite punching bags of both Democrats and Republicans.Goldman CFO Harvey Schwartz said he felt "this cycle will have unique aspects to it vs. other presidential cycles," but that he didn't foresee any short-term damage.But Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat said world tensions could further stall any Federal Reserve interest rate increases. "While the U.K. has a new leader," he said, "the U.S. is still in the midst of a unique presidential campaign, and such geopolitical and economic uncertainty doesn't create a clear picture for potential interest rate increases."McDonald's said Brexit had not significantly affected U.K. demand and that the vote was unlikely to harm commodity prices there in the near term. But the company shaved a few cents off its profit-per-share forecast in part because the vote caused the pound to plummet. Starbucks said Brexit had piled on to already existing worries in Europe.And General Electric CEO Jeff Immelt said, "Brexit is just another point of volatility. It wasn't the outcome we hoped for, but we were plenty ready for that as just another point of volatility."It's difficult to gauge the state of China's economy through executives' commentary, which came in mixed.Apple CEO Tim Cook remained optimistic. Apple's fiscal Q3 results topped expectations, and iPhone sales were better than expected amid concerns the market was saturated.But while he said that "switchers and first-time smartphone buyers" made up most of the company's quarterly iPhone sales in Greater China, he conceded that the region's economy has cooled."This is reflected in consumer confidence and retail spending, and the Chinese yuan has depreciated by 7% relative to the U.S. dollar since August of last year," he said. "Hong Kong's tourism and retail businesses also continue to be significantly impacted by the stronger Hong Kong dollar relative to other Asian currencies."United Technologies (UTX), a conglomerate that owns the elevator and escalator-maker Otis, offered a glimpse into China's real estate market. Transactions, management said, had picked up some steam, but the gains hadn't translated into more money from elevator sales."In China, while the number of property transactions and home prices -- particularly in the tier 1 cities -- show growth year-to-date, the elevator new equipment market is down, and price pressure has increased," CFO Akhil Johri said on the company's earnings call.Meanwhile, GE said China was "getting better." Starbucks touted its own performance in the region, while McDonald's said comps in China rose.Those gains, McDonald's said, came "despite a challenging environment."

JCPenney (JCP) reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings, providing further evidence that consumer spending isn't as bad as investors had feared.The department store reported a 5 cent per-share loss minus one-time items, narrowing from a 41 cent loss in the same quarter a year earlier, as JCPenney pushed ahead with a reorganization. Analysts expected a 15 cent loss. Revenue grew 1.4% to $2.92 billion, a bit below consensus for $2.93 billion. Comparable-store sales increased 2.2%.Cowen analyst Oliver Chen said in a client note after JCPenney earnings that it was "the only positive comp" among reporting department stores. Cowen has a market perform rating on JCPenney with a 10 price target.JCPenney Chairman and CEO Marvin Ellison, credited 60 more Sephora store-within-a-store cosmetics and beauty stops, center core refreshes and the rollout of "buy online, pick up in store same day" for lifting results. JCPenney stock has climbed 69% since hitting a 2016 low at 6 per share on Jan. 20, including an 8.6% gain Thursday. JCPenney rose 6% to 10.54 in the stock market today, a four-month high.On Thursday, Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) also beat on earnings, providing what Retail Metrics analyst Ken Perkins called "rays of hope" that the struggling retail sector may be bottoming. Macy's skyrocketed 17%, and Kohl's jumped 16% on Thursday, rebounding from recent and longer-term downtrends. On Friday, Macy's rose 2 cents to 39.83, while Kohl's climbed 1.7% to 44.95.Nordstrom (JWN) late Thursday reported better-than-expected profit, but revenue was a bit light. Still, Nordstrom rose 8.1% to 51.40 -- back above its 200-day line -- after soaring 7.5% Thursday.The upbeat reports are seen as part of a relief rally after many consumer-related companies, from General Motors (GM) to Ford (F) to McDonald's (MCD), reported sluggish U.S. demand.IBD'S TAKE: JCPenney shares are climbing the right side of a cup base with a 12.09 entry point. Cup and cup-with-handle bases are among the most common patterns stocks form. For more on how to spot winning bases, see the IBD University.Overall retail sales were flat in July, with non-auto sales down 0.3%, the Commerce Department said Friday. July's total was well under estimates of a 0.4% gain. However, June's gain was revised up to 0.8% from the initial 0.6% reading.

Even with Amazon (AMZN) Prime Day, retail sales were merely flat in July, with non-auto sales down 0.3%, the Commerce Department said Friday.While July's totals came in well below expectations for an overall 0.4% gain, and a 0.2% rise outside the auto sector, the disappointment was softened by an upward revision to June numbers. The overall gain was revised to 0.8% from 0.6%, with sales outside autos rising 0.9%, up from 0.7%.Still, the year-over-year gain in retail sales slowed to 2.3%, which may slightly ding confidence in the strength of the American consumer. While a 2.7% drop in gas station sales held down July spending, consumers didn't put the money to work elsewhere.Non-store retailers continued to stand out, with sales rising 1.3% on the month and 14.1% on the year. That was surely helped by Amazon's 24-hour sales event for Prime members. Amazon said Prime orders in the U.S. surged 50% from the company's inaugural event in 2015, but it didn't reveal its sales tally.But efforts by Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and others to piggyback or cut into Amazon's big day may have fallen flat. General merchandise store sales dipped 0.1%, while department stores saw sales continue to decline, off 0.5% on the month and down 4.0% from a year earlier.Both Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) slightly beat modest revenue expectations on Thursday, while Nordstrom (JWN) saw a much smaller drop in same-store sales than analysts expected. All three companies saw sales drop from a year earlier. JCPenney (JCP), a relative bright spot, said on Friday that same-store sales rose 2.2% from a year before, about as expected.IBD'S TAKE: While the consumer continues to be the main driver of U.S. economic growth, most retailers have underperformed the stock market because the retail sector is overbuilt and online competition is intense. Watch this IBD Video for tips on how to quickly identify and research leading stocks that may be ready to be bought.July is typically a slow month for retail before the back-to-school season kicks in, so it's possible the sales push could lead to an upside surprise. Two unknowns: Will Prime Day sales by Amazon and competitors eat into back-to-school shopping, and how will July sales look on a seasonally adjusted basis? The latter may depend on how much the Commerce Department has adjusted its seasonal models after last year's Prime Day.Building-materials and garden-equipment retailers like Home Depot (HD) saw sales ease 0.5% after an upwardly revised 4.2% surge in June. Home Depot and rival Lowe's (LOW) will report quarterly earnings next week.Sales at food services and drinking places continued to be soft, falling 0.2% after an upwardly revised 0.3% rise in June. The problem cited by McDonald's (MCD) and multiple industry players is that food at home is looking like an unusually good deal relative to the cost of food away from home. On Wednesday, Wendy's (WEN) scaled back same-store sales growth guidance for 2016 from 3% to a range of 1%-2%.

Stocks moved sideways at all-time highs this week, but the week was packed with market-moving news. Alibaba (BABA) broke out as growth accelerated, while Acacia Communications (ACIA) exploded as fiber optic and IPO growth names sparked. Macy's (M) triggered a huge relief rally, and Wal-Mart (WMT) bought Jet.com to better compete vs. Amazon (AMZN). Oil prices rebounded, but solar stocks crashed.After weeks of the S&P 500 and Dow industrials hitting all-time highs, the Nasdaq eclipsed its 2015 peak. All three major indexes rose fractionally for the week -- the Nasdaq and Dow closed up 0.2% while the S&P 500 climbed 1 point. More quality breakouts appeared. Retailers, energy plays and some hot growth stocks led the market amid earnings reports and higher oil prices. But solar stocks tumbled on weak SunPower (SPWR) guidance. REITs struggled as investors sought growth names -- and worried about store closures.Alibaba reported revenue of $4.84 billion, beating the Wall Street consensus estimate of $4.53 billion. Revenue rose 59% in local-currency terms, the best gain since Alibaba's September 2014 IPO. EPS rose 33% to 74 cents, beating the consensus of 63 cents.JD.com reported revenue of $9.8 billion, slightly above the consensus and up 42% in local currency. It reported earnings per share of 4 cents, double the 2 cent consensus, but its Q3 revenue estimate fell short of projections. Both companies showed strong growth in mobile users.Alibaba stock soared 16% for the week, breaking out of a base to their highest level since January 2015. JD.com leapt nearly 13%.Next week, messaging giant Tencent (TCEHY), perhaps Alibaba's biggest Chinese rival, reports earnings. So do mobile gaming portal NetEase (NTES) and flash e-commerce seller Vipshop (VIPS).IBD'S TAKE: With the market at record highs, many growth names large and small are breaking out. To get an in-depth look at Alibaba, Acacia and other top-rated stocks -- and how they fare vs. rivals -- go to IBD Stock Checkup to develop your watch list.Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih hinted at a production freeze, which could come at a meeting on the sidelines of the International Energy Forum next month. But Russia's energy minister said he didn't see a reason for renewing talks. The International Energy Agency said the oil glut has disappeared, but it warned of weaker demand on a "dimmer macroeconomic outlook" in 2017. OPEC said Saudi Arabia pumped a record amount of crude oil in July, and the cartel left its 2017 demand outlook unchanged at 95.41 million barrels per day. The Energy Information Administration said that U.S. stockpiles rose by 1.1 million barrels to 523.6 million for the week ended Aug 5. And U.S. production fell by 0.2% to 8.44 million barrels, a second straight week of declines.U.S. oil rigs in operation rose by 15 to 396 in the week ended Aug. 12, Baker Hughes said. That's the seventh straight weekly gain and the highest level since late February.Still, U.S. crude oil prices closed the week at $44.49 a barrel, up 4.4%.Wal-Mart Stores, looking to keep pace with Amazon, agreed to buy Jet.com for $3.3 billion. Wal-Mart has sizable online sales, but growth has been decelerating. Wal-Mart also will put Jet.com CEO Marc Lore in charge of all of Wal-Mart's e-commerce operations, though Jet.com will remain separately. Lore previously founded Quidsi, parent of Diapers.com, before Amazon bought it.Wal-Mart stock rose 0.2%, hitting a 14-month high during the week.Solar stocks after SunPower cut its 2016 guidance and inverter-supplier SolarEdge (SEDG) cited a slowdown at U.S. installers. For Q2, SunPower's Q2 revenue growth and adjusted loss topped estimates. But SunPower sees Q3 revenue of just $700 million to $800 million vs. the consensus for $1.13 billion, as demand for utility-scale solar projects tumbles. And SunPower also cut its 2016 view to $2.8 billion-$3 billion, missing analysts' view for $3.3 billion.SolarEdge's $124.8 million in fiscal Q4 sales missed analysts' expectations for $129.4 million, but 44 cents EPS minus items beat by a nickel. The midpoint of current-quarter sales guidance for $130 million-$139 million trailed the consensus at $137 million, and EPS missed by a penny.SolarCity (SCTY), which has agreed to a takeover deal by Tesla (TSLA), topped analysts' Q2 projections for adjusted loss and revenue. But its current-quarter view for $155 million-$168 million in revenue lagged the consensus for $174.6 million.SunPower stock crashed 28% to a 3-year low.Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), involved in everything from gaming to autonomous driving and AI, rose 8.3% for the week to a fresh high after the Tesla partner reported $1.43 billion in sales and 40 cents earnings per share. That topped the consensus for $1.35 billion and 37 cents, and was up 24% and 700%, respectively, vs. last year. Nvidia sees current-quarter sales at $1.68 billion, plus or minus 2%, beating analysts' model for $1.45 billion.With China, telecoms and data centers spending heavily for higher-speed connections, makers of fiber optic components are seeing huge demand.Hot IPO Acacia Communications said Q2 revenue rose 101% to $116 million, and adjusted earnings soared 305%. Lumentum (LITE) and Inphi (IPHI) also reported stronger-than-expected figures. NeoPhotonics (NPTN) sales growth fell short due to sluggish demand for older parts, but production of 100-gigabit gear is ramping up. IBD's 14-company Telecom-Fiber Optics industry group hit a 15-year high Thursday and ranks No. 10 out of 197 groups.Acacia rose 41% Friday and nearly 50% for the week, blasting to new highs. Lumentum rose more than 4% and Inphi 16%, also to new highs. NeoPhotonics climbed 2.6% to 14.01, clearing a 13.85 buy point on Friday.Related:IBD'S TAKE: Acacia Communications is among several tech leaders that have risen 20% past a buy point, putting them in profit-taking zone. But when you should you sell these top stocks? IBD's latest Tech Leaders column explains when to hold onto winning stocks, and how those rules apply to Acacia, Weibo and others right now.Recent IPO Twilio (TWLO), a communications software firm, reported a narrower than-expected non-GAAP loss. Q2 revenue jumped 70% to $64.5 million, vs. Wall Street estimates of $58.2 million, although sales from its top customer, Facebook (FB)-owned WhatsApp, fell 8% year over year. Twilio's full-year guidance edged consensus estimates.Twilio shares surged 28% for the week, hitting a new high.Medpace Holdings (MEDP) soared 20% to 27.79 in Thursday's debut after pricing at 23, the high end of its expected IPO range. Shares edged up 0.9% to 28.04 on Friday. Medpace provides outsourced clinical development services for drug and medical device companies.Specialty drugmakers ended what had been a strong Q2 season for the drug industry on a more ambiguous note. Allergan (AGN), freshly divested of its generics business, beat expectations slightly but trimmed its sales guidance. Shares fell 1.7% for the week. Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) missed Q2 numbers but affirmed its guidance as it reorganized. It said its deal with Walgreens (WBA) was finally turning profitable and that it was willing to sell $8 billion worth of non-core assets. The stock soared 25% Tuesday, but pared weekly gains to 13.5% on a report that Valeant could face criminal charges of defrauding insurers.Medivation (MDVN) reported a ho-hum quarter, but profit will likely be flat until an expected market expansion for its drug Xtandi in Q4. Shares rose 4.4% to 66.02, a 14-month high and just barely in buy range from a 63.04 entry. Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) missed EPS estimates and lowered guidance, partly due to a change in tax reporting and partly due to higher costs. Its stock dropped 9.3%. Mylan (MYL) beat its profit estimate slightly and affirmed its guidance, with its controversially high-priced EpiPen making up for light generic drug sales. Mylan closed the week unchanged.Walt Disney (DIS) topped Wall Street estimates late Tuesday and said it had bought a 33% stake in streaming company BAMTech. As it vies to remain competitive in digital, the media conglomerate plans to launch an ESPN-branded over-the-top service, but it will not include current ESPN content. Q3 EPS rose 12% to $1.62 on 9% revenue growth to $14.28 billion. Shares were up about 1% for the week, but failed to hold above their 50-day line.Southwest (LUV) cut its third-quarter unit revenue outlook and said it expected higher unit costs due to 2,000-plus flight cancellations in July after a single router failure blacked out much of its technological infrastructure. The guidance came as Delta Air Lines (DAL) spent much of the week trying to recover from some 2,000 of its own flight cancellations caused by an outage early Monday. American Airlines (AAL), meanwhile, forecast an improvement in its Q3 unit revenue.Southwest and Delta shares fell 3.5% while American Air climbed 1.4%.Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) reported lower sales, while Macy's also had declining earnings and said it would cut 100 stores. But they both topped forecasts after weeks of bad news from consumer stocks such as Ford (F) and McDonald's (MCD). So Macy's and Kohl's skyrocketed 16.7% and 14.3%, respectively for the week. Nordstrom (JWN) and JCPenney (JCP) topped on earnings and missed on revenue, with their shares also soaring for the week. But overall, retail sales were flat in July -- and down 0.3% excluding autos -- according to the Commerce Department. Home Depot (HD), Lowe's (LOW), Wal-Mart and Ross Stores (ROST) are among the retailers reporting this coming week.The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index rose to a 14-month high in August, climbing 2.9 points to 48.4. That's still below the neutral 50 level.

A new Burger King TV commercial is designed to trigger voice-controlled speakers from Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google in viewers' homes, adding a wrinkle to the debate over whether such devices have become too invasive.In the 15-second ad, a Burger King employee says, "OK, Google. What is the Whopper burger?"If viewers are watching the commercial near a Google Home gadget, the "OK Google" prompt will cause the device to read the Wikipedia entry for the sandwich. The TV spots are airing nationally starting Wednesday on networks such as Spike, MTV and Comedy Central.The commercial extends Burger King's record of trying to push the envelope with its marketing.In 2015, the restaurant chain sought a "truce" with rival and Dow component McDonald's (MCD) by offering to create a peace burger called the McWhopper. It also brought back its deliberately creepy King mascot in recent years. The character loomed in the background during the much-hyped boxing match of Floyd Mayweather-Manny Pacquiao in 2015.The Google stunt could renew concerns about whether voice-activated technology has unintended consequences. Amazon.com's (AMZN) Echo devices and Samsung Electronics Co.'s smart televisions have faced criticism from privacy groups over the extent of the conversations and data that they track. The Echo, which answers to "Alexa," also lets consumers buy products with quick voice commands — creating the potential for accidental orders.Burger King, owned by Restaurant Brands International (QSR), said it's not collaborating with Google on the ads. But the plug could give a boost to a device that is playing catch-up with the Echo. Analysts estimate that Google shipped about 500,000 units in the first quarter after the Home product debuted late last year.IBD'S TAKE: Despite questions over whether Burger King is making the right move by speaking directly to home devices, shares of parent Restaurant Brands International are in high standing. It holds an Investor's Business Daily Composite Rating of 94, good enough for second place among the Retail-Restaurants Group, just behind Dave & Buster's (PLAY)."It's a cool way, and a bold way, to surprise our guests," said Jose Cil, president of the Burger King brand. The company believes the interaction will be "very positive," he said.A broader U.S. restaurant slump is forcing restaurant chains like Burger King to vie more fiercely for customers. Some have introduced new menu items and value deals, while others have increased advertising to boost customer traffic.McDonald's began offering $1 and $2 drink specials this month, while Wendy's (WEN) has been remodeling stores and touting its fresh beef.Burger King also rolled out a new version of its chicken sandwich last month, and it enlisted "haters" — people who criticized the old sandwich on social media — to market the revamped item."Burger King has been doing creative, innovative things for a long time," Cil said. "It's something that we feel strongly about."RELATED:This Dow Stock Is Now In Buy Range, Nears New High As Restaurants RallyPanera Bread Hits New High On Buyout Buzz; Restaurant Stocks Back On Menu

McDonald's (MCD) on Tuesday said it expected foreign-exchange rates to hit earnings per share harder than anticipated this year, partly due to the U.K.'s vote last month to leave the European Union. Meanwhile, its shares tumbled on weaker-than-expected U.S. same-store sales.CFO Kevin Ozan said on the burger chain's second-quarter earnings call Tuesday that it expected the tougher foreign-exchange environment to shave 2 to 4 cents off third-quarter EPS estimates and 9 to 11 cents off its full-year EPS target. The pound plunged against the dollar following the "Brexit" vote, and currencies elsewhere have weakened amid economic anxieties.Still, McDonald's said it had not seen any significant change in demand in the U.K. following the vote, and it did not expect the vote to affect food costs in the near term. McDonald's also said it expected U.S. food costs to "remain favorable" and stay relatively flat internationally.The company warned that labor costs were rising in many of its markets. Management also said on the call that the company's sponsorship of the Rio Olympic Games next month would keep third-quarter general and administrative costs higher, but without having much effect on general business trends.The burger chain also reported weaker-than-expected second-quarter revenue and U.S. same-store sales on Tuesday.Total revenue fell 3.6% vs. a year earlier to $6.265 billion. Analysts had expected $6.27 billion. Global same-store sales, excluding currency effects, rose 3.1% vs. estimates for about 3.6%. International comps were in line, but U.S. comps rose just 1.8% vs. targets for about 3.2%.McDonald's earned $1.45 a share, beating analysts' expectations for $1.38.Shares of McDonald's fell 4.5% to 121.71 on the stock market today. That undercuts a 124.18 buy point cleared on July 19 and puts the stock just below its 50-day moving average.IBD'S TAKE: McDonald's is the world's largest restaurant operator, but it's No. 21 in IBD's Retail-Restaurant group. To see how MCD stacks up against the top eateries in objective criteria, go to IBD Stock Checkup.McDonald's said its All Day Breakfast menu and McPick 2 offerings remained strong, but it noted "softening industry growth." CEO Steve Easterbrook on the call also discussed a "broader level of uncertainty" in consumers' minds, saying that global turmoil and the election season has made diners more cautious.But analysts have been concerned that All Day Breakfast had been doing a bit too much of the hard work in improving sales. SunTrust Robinson analyst Jake Bartlett said that McDonald's results "demonstrate that it is not immune to slowing industry trends." Jefferies analyst Andy Barish said Tuesday that softer comps and higher labor costs mean "at least 18 months of challenges" for the restaurant sector.Easterbrook said its planned additions to its All Day Breakfast menu, set for September, would help "reinforce the baseline momentum" in the fourth quarter, which could be particularly difficult to lap on a year-over-year basis. The company's launch of All Day Breakfast last October drove sales improvement during that period, after struggling to compete with fast-casual restaurants.But Easterbrook said the company was focused on longer-term sustainability."We are playing the long game," he said on the call, later adding, "We're not going to manage it by quarter."Stifel Nicolaus on Tuesday downgraded a slew of restaurant stocks, betting that the U.S. will enter a recession within nine months. Stifel analyst Paul Westra downgraded a number of eateries to hold from buy, including highly rated Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) and Dave & Buster's (PLAY). Texas Roadhouse plunged 5.9%, but found support intraday around its 50-day line. Dave & Buster's sank 3.4%.Stifel cut Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) to sell from hold. Chipotle was off 2.4%.Not all was awful, however. Easterbrook touted McDonald's recent agreement to incorporate its Japan restaurants into the augmented reality game Pokemon Go, saying McDonald's was "enjoying what it's doing for our business in Japan." However, the company would not say whether it planned to expand that arrangement to other markets.

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 indicated little change at Tuesday's opening bell. But Apple (AAPL), Walt Disney (DIS) and McDonald's (MCD), touted by teens in a new survey, are all Dow industrials components that are in or near buy range. Nike (NKE), another Dow stock, may be losing some teen steam.Dow Jones industrial average futures rose a fraction vs. fair value.  So did Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures. Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said late Monday that she does not want inflation to "linger" above 2%, but didn't seem concerned about short-term moves above the Fed's price target.The Dow industrials, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite closed with fractional gains Monday after an up-and-down session amid geopolitical concerns and new tax reform doubts. The Dow and S&P 500 have been trending slightly lower since their early March peaks and are currently trying to find support at their 50-day moving averages. The Nasdaq composite, which has moved sideways in recent weeks, is about 1% over its 50-day line. FANG stock Netflix (NFLX) rebounded above that support area Monday after an intraday drop threatened Netflix's first close below that line since late September.Crude oil futures were steady overnight. U.S. crude oil has risen for the past five sessions, their longest win streak of the year. U.S. crude rose 1.6% on Monday to $53.08 a barrel, a one-month high, as Libya's biggest oil field shut down after an unknown group blocked a key pipeline.Savvy investors know to make the trend their friend. So perhaps it's not surprising that Apple, Walt Disney and McDonald's, Dow consumer stocks that are trendy with teens, are also faring well on Wall Street.According to Piper Jaffray's semiannual teen survey, "81% of teens expect their next phone to be an iPhone," a record high. The share of teens (75%) who have an iPhone edge up from last fall.Apple fell 0.1% to 143.17 in Monday stock market trading. Apple, which is on IBD's Leaderboard premium service, is still in range from a 141.12 buy point from a three-weeks-tight base. It's the top-performing stock on the Dow Jones industrial average in 2017 by far.RELATED:The Strongest Evidence Yet For An iPhone 'Supercycle'?Walt Disney dominates the films that teens want to see this year, including the next "Star Wars" entry and more Marvel superhero films. Disney's blockbuster formula is helping offset ongoing erosion in ESPN subscribers, as more Americans cut the cord on traditional pay-TV.Walt Disney shares fell 0.1% to 112.43 on Monday. Disney cleared a 112.09 buy point last month.RELATED:Walt Disney Is In Buy Range, And You Can Thank TeensTeens' enthusiasm is more muted for McDonald's, but it's still the No. 1 burger chain. Piper Jaffray cited "culinary and technology initiatives" as reasons to buy McDonald's shares.McDonald's rose 2 cents on Monday to 129.98, just below a 130.10 buy point. McDonald's closed above that entry on April 5. It's traded above the buy point in each of the last three sessions, but hasn't been able to end above it.Nike remains the dominant athletic apparel brand for teens. But there are signs of gradual erosion. Adidas (ADDYY), which has made a big new push into America, is now the No. 1 new brand worn by teenage boys, according to the Piper Jaffray survey.Nike is up in 2017, but it's the Dow's worst performer over the last 12 months. Nike fell 0.4% to 54.90, below its 50-day line. Nike tried to break out in late March, but has struggled since reporting weaker-than-expected sales, margins and futures orders.RELATED:Nike Is No Longer The Top New Apparel Brand For Teen Boys: Piper Jaffray SurveyIn Asian trading, Japan's Nikkei fell 0.3% in Tuesday trading and Hong Kong's Hang Seng sank 0.8%. South Korea's Kospi slid 0.4%, its sixth straight loss amid North Korea tensions. But China's Shanghai composite rose 0.6% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index advanced 0.3%.In european trading, the U.K.'s FTSE climbed 0.6% and France's CAC edged up 0.2%. Germany's Dax dipped a fraction.

Stocks opened lower Tuesday, as commodities were generally quiet and overseas markets booked mixed sessions.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite lost 0.3%.Walt Disney (DIS) jumped 1%. Disney's live-action fairy tale "Beauty & the Beast" took second place at the box office over the weekend, earning $25 million domestically over the three days, and bringing its four-week global take to nearly $1 billion. Disney shares have been trading tightly and above the 10-week moving average.Another Dow component, McDonald's (MCD), popped 0.6% at the open. The burger chain's stock is trying to clear a 130.10 buy point.Elsewhere, RetailMeNot (SALE) soared 49%. The online coupon aggregator announced late Monday it would be taken private by MacAndrews & Forbes for $11.60 a share, 50% above Monday's closing price. The company valued the deal at $630 million. Yelp (YELP) rose more than 3%, possibly feeling some sympathy interest from investors.Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) fell 1% its first-quarter earnings narrowly topped analyst targets.  Shares are consolidating below an early March high.United Airlines (UAL) fell 2% as the story of a passenger being forcibly removed from a flight to make room for United employees gathered online momentum, particularly in China. United shares on Monday were testing resistance at their 10-week moving average, trying to climb the right side of a base.At the head of both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, Western Digital (WDC) swung up nearly 3% on an upgrade to overweight from neutral by JPMorgan, which gave a new 116 price target. Western Digital shares were nearing the top of a buy range after clearing a flat base buy point of 81.77 in heavy trade on March 30. Data storage peer Seagate Technology (STX) rose 3%.Qualcomm (QCOM) dropped nearly 2% and Apple (AAPL) dipped 0.1% on reports that Qualcomm late Monday filed counter-claims against Apple, alleging the larger company of a series of unethical practices. Apple sued Qualcomm in January, alleging the chipmaker owed it $1 billion in what it called "rebates."  Apple shares are trading tightly near highs. Qualcomm has been consolidating since October.The Labor Department's Job Openings And Labor Turnover Survey — the JOLTS report — for February is due out at 10 a.m. ET. Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari speaks at 1:45 p.m. ET.Oil traded flat, gold rose 0.5% to above $1,260 an ounce. The dollar sifted lower and bonds rose, sending the 10-year yield down 3 basis points to 2.33%.In Europe, benchmark indexes in Paris and Frankfurt remained mixed in afternoon trade, while the FTSE 100 in London rose 0.7%. China's leading benchmarks booked a mixed session, with the Shanghai Composite ending up 0.6% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng down 0.7%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 0.3%.RELATED:Futures Steady: 3 Dow Stocks Show The Trend Is Your Friend, TwiceThese 5 Shale Stocks Form Bases As Oil Rebound: Investing Action Plan

Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) first better-burger location, called Tasty Made, will apply its focus on higher-quality ingredients and menu minimalism to the ultracompetitive burger business.The menu for Tasty Made, which will open in Lancaster, Ohio, this fall, will consist only of burgers, fries and milkshakes made from "high quality ingredients that are grown and raised with respect for the animals, the land, and the farmers who produce them," according to company statement."Early fast food burger restaurants generally had focused menus," Steve Ells, Chipotle's co-CEO, said in the statement."We think there's great strength in that original fast food model and wanted to create a restaurant built around that," he added. "Making only burgers, fries and shakes with really great ingredients, we think we can appeal to peoples' timeless love of burgers, but in a way that is consistent with our long-term vision."But the opening, and Chipotle's attempts to diversify and tap better-burger nostalgia, would come amid heavy competition among burger chains. Traditional fast-food giants like McDonald's (MCD) and Restaurant Brands International's (QSR) Burger King are likely to compete on value, while better-burger rivals like Shake Shack (SHAK), Habit Restaurants (HABT) and In-N-Out are trying to compete more on quality.Shares of Chipotle finished trading up 1.1% to 430.55 on the stock market today. McDonald's shaved off 6 cents to 119.42, Restaurant Brands rose 1.9% to 44.67, Shake Shack lost 0.3% to 40.22 and Habit climbed 1.9% to 16.44.IBD'S TAKE: While parts of the restaurant sector struggled during the second quarter, companies that have more focus on digital ordering -- like Domino's Pizza, Papa John's and GrubHub -- are up. Compare and contrast restaurant stocks at IBD's Stock Checkup. Reports of Chipotle's interest in opening a burger restaurants first surfaced several months ago. The company has also opened an Asian restaurant and backed a fast-casual pizza restaurant.But sales in the restaurant sector overall also appeared to slow during the second quarter due to aggressive value offerings and consumers' economic uncertainty.Chipotle's plans also come as the company tries to revive sales and customer sentiment following a foodborne-illness outbreak last year. The chain's second-quarter results showed struggles on that front, but its limited-time loyalty program, Chiptopia, has provided some relief on that front.Expanding its menu has also helped. Chipotle recently added chorizo to its menu in some restaurants, with plans to bring the item to all Chipotle locations by the end of the year.Ells noted during the company's earnings call last week that such a move was "unusual" for a chain that has kept its menu simple."But we have never ruled out additions or changes to the menu, and chorizo is one of the few changes that we have made to the menu in 23 years," he said then.

XExchange traded funds tracking major stock indexes rose on Tuesday as investors digested a raft of first-quarter earnings reports, including more wins for closely watched blue chip stocks.SDPR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) bolted 1.1% higher shortly after the open, outpacing a 0.6% gain for SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) and a 0.5% gain for the tech-heavy PowerShares QQQ (QQQ).A small-cap surge also fueled a 1.0% gain for iShares Russell 2000 (IWM).The Dow ETF rose on the stock market today amid a resounding earnings beat for heavy equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT). The industrial giant saw its shares surge almost 7%, breaking out of a multimonth consolidation, after smashing views on both the top and bottom lines.Shares of McDonald's (MCD), a top 10 stock in the price-weighted Dow portfolio, also topped Q1 forecasts. Shares rallied 4% in morning trade.The ETF's second-largest stock holding, 3M (MMM), was lower despite an across-the-board Q1 beat.The SPDR Dow ETF is eyeing a breakout from an 8-week flat base with a 211.69 buy point.A potential catalyst for the ETF is the fiscal second-quarter earnings report from Apple (AAPL), scheduled for May 2 after the market close.The iPhone maker is the top-performing stock in the Dow Jones industrial average year to date through Monday, with a 24.5% gain.The chart pattern for DIA mirrors the moves in stock holdings such as Caterpillar and fellow heavy equipment maker Deere (DE).DIA rose 6% from a flat base buy point in late January and advanced 7% from another flat base buy point in mid-November to mid-December.IBD'S TAKE: Apple is on IBD's Leaderboard list of actionable stocks with the potential for big gains.RELATED:What Is Going On In The ETF Market?

Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) reported better-than-feared second strong quarter earnings, boosting shares of both department store chains and the broader retail sector. Nordstrom (JWN) late Thursday reported better-than-expected earnings.JCPenney (JCP) is queued for early Friday. Retail groups dominated the top-performing industries Thursday on the stock market today.The department stores offered some relief after a procession of consumer-oriented companies -- aside from e-commerce giant Amazon (AMZN) -- reported sluggish demand, from Ford Motor (F) to McDonald's (MCD), that fueled sector sell-offs often led by department store stocks.Macy's reported a 16% drop in earnings per share minus one-time items to 54 cents, beating estimates for 45 cents. Revenue slid 3.8% to $5.87 billion, the sixth straight quarter of year-over-year declines, but still topping consensus for $5.75 billion.Macy's said overall same-store sales fell 2% vs. a year earlier.The Cincinnati-based company plans to close 100 Macy's full-line locations, or 14%. Most of them will close in early 2017. Coach (COH) said on Tuesday it will shutter some 250 locations -- known as "doors" -- or about 25% of the total it has within North America, as part of "the strategic decision to elevate the Coach brand's positioning."Macy's said it's still seeing lower-than-normal store spending, but left its full-year guidance intact. The company sees EPS of $3.15-$3.40, with the midpoint slightly above consensus.Kohl's Q2 EPS rose 14% to $1.22, easily topping views for $1.03. Sales fell 2.1% to $4.18 billion, better than the expected $4.16 billion.Kevin Mansell, Kohl's chairman and CEO, said in a statement, "Our sales improved over our first-quarter results but were below our expectations." As a result, the company cut its full-year earnings guidance to $3.80-$4, down from $4.05-$4.25 previously but still above analysts' consensus for $3.83 at the midpoint.Macy's stock spiked 17.1% to 39.81 Thursday, the highest since the beginning of May. Macy's is trading above 200-day line for the first time in a year, as it tries to break a long downtrend.Kohl's rose 16.2% to 44.19. It's still well below below its 2016 high of 52.06, set on Jan. 7.Retails Metrics analyst Ken Perkins said in a report that for Macy's and Kohl's earnings provided "rays of hope" as inventories and margins improved. Still, he noted that "both retailers guided FY16 earnings below the current consensus."IBD'S TAKE: Traditional department stores such as Macy's, Kohl's and Nordstrom are getting beaten down by online retailers like Amazon. Giant Wal-Mart is trying to stem the tidy by buying a strong online presence.Retailers are under pressure due to a confluence of negatives. Fashion houses Kate Spade (KATE) and Michael Kors (KORS) noted in their reports that tourists visiting certain key cities have cut back on spending at their stores. The strong dollar is seen as the culprit, making some affordable luxury items too pricey for tourists.Spade and Kors also cited less foot traffic in malls. Consumers continue to opt for online bargains shipped to their home, for free if they're members of a service like Amazon's $99 a year Amazon Prime free shipping and video streaming.Brick-and-mortar retailers may continue to lose share in the crucial holiday buying season, while Amazon and other online retailers continue growing.Nordstrom jumped 7.5% at the close, then spiked after hours after reporting stronger-than-expected earnings. JCPenney climbed 8.6%, with analysts expecting a smaller loss Friday morning.The Commerce Department's July retail sales report, due Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET, is expected to show a 0.4% rise, or a 0.2% increase when excluding autos. There could also be an Amazon Prime Day effect in the data.

U.S. stock indexes started on a positive note Tuesday, as the market tried to follow up on the previous session's big gains.The Dow Jones industrial average leapt 1.2%, leading the way. The small cap Russell 2000 jumped 1%, joining the Nasdaq composite in new-high ground. The Nasdaq itself added 0.6% to clear the 6,000 level for the first time. The S&P 500 index advanced 0.6%. Volume was running faster on both major exchanges.Monday's 1.2% gain in the Nasdaq was only the third time this year that the Nasdaq rose 1% or more in a session. In the previous two instances, the next session was either flat or down.Blue chips were mostly up. Caterpillar (CAT), a Dow Jones industrial average component, surged nearly 7% after quarterly results beat the Street's estimates on the top and bottom lines. Caterpillar leapt out of a 12-week consolidation, hitting its best levels since late 2014Other Dow components lodging big gains included McDonald's (MCD), up nearly 5% to a record high, and DuPont (DD), up 3%. Both companies reported sales and earnings that topped expectations.In the S&P 500, construction products supplier Masco (MAS) gapped up nearly 5% in red-hot volume. The company reported quarterly results that exceeded expectations on the top and bottom lines.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, advancers outpaced declining groups by a 10-1 ratio. The biggest gainers included construction equipment makers, telecom services and specialty steel. The morning's laggards included medical services, gold miners and homebuilders.RELATED:McDonald's Tops Q1 Forecast As U.S. Comps Show Surprise StrengthCaterpillar Breaks Out, Steamrolls Earnings Estimates

XChipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Stryker (SYK), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Arconic (ARNC) topped analysts' estimates late Tuesday, while Illumina (ILMN) met profit views and gave weak Q2 earnings guidance.Estimates: Per-share earnings of $1.27, swinging from a year-ago per-share loss of 88 cents. Shares of the performance metals maker, which spun off Alcoa (AA) late last year, rallied 3.4% to 26.98, remaining below their 50-day moving average. Shares had popped 3.1% on April 17 after its CEO, Klaus Kleinfeld, abruptly resigned amid a public scuffle with Elliott Management that led to Arconic's board seeking his resignation.RELATED:Arconic Jumps As CEO Kleinfeld Exits Amid Proxy FightTop Stocks In Buy Zone Ahead Of Results: Investing Action PlanTech, Industrial Giants To Report As Euro Rallies: Investing Action Plan
