Despite market losses Monday, the new-high list dished up some interesting charts. In the technology space, Cray (CRAY) gapped up and cleared a 36.03 buy point . Shares jumped 3.42 to 36.49 after the maker of high-performance computing systems received a $36 million upgrade contract from a customer in Europe. Cray is set to replace Curtiss-Wright (CW) in the S&P…

McDonald's (MCD) defied the broad yet generally shallow decline among the major indexes following better-than-expected same-store results in the final quarter of last year. The Dow Jones industrials fell 0.6%, yet Dow 30 component McDonald's held on to a 1%-plus gain. The S&P 500 lost nearly 0.7%; the Nasdaq composite, supported by a small gain by Facebook (FB), still was…

Stocks kicked off the week with modest losses Monday on the heels of three straight constructive sessions to close out the week last week. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 lost 0.3% each. The Nasdaq fell 0.2%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking lower than Friday's levels in the stock market today. Crude oil fell…

Stock futures were moderately lower Monday, as earnings reports start to pour in this week.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were indicated lower 0.3%.The market appeared to be following crude prices, as it often has the past few months. Oil fell 3% after Iraq announced record oil production, compounding a glut of global supply.Reflecting the industry's woes, Halliburton (HAL) was down 1% after the oilfield service company posted an adjusted profit of 31 cents a share  for the quarter, above views of 24 cents. The company, whose shares last week touched the lowest level since 2012, warned it faces another difficult year.Monday is the start of what will be a busy week of quarterly reports.McDonald's (MCD) rallied nearly 4% in premarket trading after the fast-food company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.31 a share, an increase of 16% or 26% after currency adjustments. Sales increased 4%.Worldwide, same-store sales jumped 5%. In the U.S., that figure increased 5.7%. Management cited "the October launch of All Day Breakfast and, to a lesser extent, unseasonably mild weather." The stock is finding support at the 10-week moving average.D.R. Horton (DHI) was down 1% despite the homebuilder reporting a profit of 42 cents a share, a penny above the consensus estimate. Homebuilding revenue for the first quarter of fiscal 2016 increased 5% to $2.4 billion as the backlog grew 16% in value to $3.2 billion and 15% in number of homes to 10,665.In Europe, the FTSE 100 was down 0.4% while the German DAX and Paris' CAC 40 were down 0.5%. That was in sharp contrast to Asia, where the Nikkei rose 0.9%, the Hong Kong Hang Seng rallied 1.4% and the Shanghai composite added 0.8%.

Apple (AAPL) got its price target lowered Wednesday as did Polaris Industries (PII), while Fitbit (FIT) got a new call and McDonald's (MCD) got an upgrade.Apple received a few price cuts on Wednesday after the consumer electronics giant posted disappointing Q1 revenue and weak guidance amid weaker-than-expected iPhone sales.Stifel lowered Apple's price target to 120 from 140 while keeping its buy rating, FBR Capital cut Apple's  price target to 130 from 150 while reiterating its outperform rating and Maxim Group lowered its price target to 162 from a previous price target of 167 while keeping its buy rating.Apple's stock price was down 4% in midday trading Wednesday in the stock market today.Citigroup initiated coverage on Fitbit with a buy rating, saying the maker of fitness trackers should get a lift from new products later this year.Fitbit's shares were up 1.6%.Argus upgraded its rating on McDonald's to buy from hold after the fast-food giant served up a beat on both its top and bottom lines for the fourth quarter on Monday, signaling that its strategy to compete with newer alternatives hit the spot with consumers.Shares of McDonald's rallied 0.9%.RBC Capital Markets lowered its price target on Polaris Industries to 80 from 88 while keeping its outperform rating after the off-road vehicle maker Tuesday posted its first decline in quarterly profit growth in more than five years.BTIG downgraded Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) to neutral from buy ahead of the sports bar and eatery's Q4 earnings report on Feb. 3.Shares of Buffalo Wild Wings ticked 0.4% higher.

Stocks sold off into the close Monday to start out the week on a bad note as oil resumed its slide.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each slumped 1.6% while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.3%. Volume was lighter across the board, according to preliminary data. Losers trumped winners by a 5-to-1 margin on the NYSE and 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Oil stocks led the decline, with West Texas intermediate prices plunging 6%, back to the $30 level. Banks and hotel stocks also got hammered. The scant list of gainers included defensive stocks such as gold miners, food and beverage makers.Only three stocks bucked the decline on the Dow: Coca-Cola (KO), McDonald's (MCD) and Wal-Mart (WMT). The biggest losers included Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM), down 3% each, followed by Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which each lost more than 2%.The two oil giants are trading 20% or more off their 52-week highs. Nomura lowered its rating on JPMorgan to neutral from buy, though it lifted the price target to 71 from 70.McDonald's (MCD) continued to heat up, adding 1% in robust trade for a third straight advance. The fast-food chain early Monday reported Q4 results that topped views on both the top and bottom lines, thanks partly to its breakfast-all-day offering. U.S. same-store sales grew 5.7% while global comps rose 5%.On the IBD 50, NetEase (NTES) defied the sell-off with a 3% gain. Arista Networks (ANET), Signature Bank (SBNY) and Phillips 66 (PSX) led the downside, giving up 7%, 5% and 5% each.Economic data on tap for Tuesday include the S&P/Case-Shiller home price index for November and consumer confidence for January, which is expected to dip slightly to 96 from 96.5 in December.Apple (AAPL), AT&T (T), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and Procter & Gamble (PG) are among big companies reporting earnings Tuesday.

Losses can be tough to swallow. Stocks that can hold up well in a market downturn, while offering a dividend, can be like a little dessert with your meal. McDonald's (MCD) stock was in a three-year slump before Steve Easterbrook took the helm as CEO in March 2015. A strong earnings report in October delivered evidence that his turnaround initiatives…

Google, the main subsidiary of Alphabet (GOOGL), has reached a tax settlement with the U.K., the Financial Times first reported last Friday. Google will pay 130 million British pounds ($185 million) in back taxes and higher taxes in the future, said the FT, which quoted a Google executive and an official with HMRC, Britain's revenue service. A Google spokesperson told…

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon said Tuesday that the bank would hike its minimum hourly wage to $12-$16.50 for 18,000 employees, many of them bank tellers or other customer service employees, arguing that wages for many in the U.S. "have gone nowhere for too long."The increase, which comes as bank branches face potential disruption from new technology, will take hold over the next three years, Dimon said in an op-ed in the New York Times. The bank's current minimum hourly wage for U.S. staff is $10.15, he said.Dimon's announcement also comes amid calls nationwide for higher pay from restaurant and retail employees who have struggled to make ends meet and complained of difficult or reduced schedule hours. A day earlier, coffee giant Starbucks (SBUX) said that it would institute a minimum 5% pay hike for store managers and other employees in U.S. company-operated stores as of Oct. 3. Wal-Mart (WMT) said it would give a raise to more than 1.2 million store employees earlier this year.But wage increases could mean higher prices for customers, as well as  the arrival other "labor saving" measures. Starbucks raised coffee drink prices Tuesday, a day after its wage-hike announcement. Wendy's (WEN) has said it would make self-ordering kiosks available to its restaurants. But McDonald's (MCD), which has announced its own base pay hikes, has said such technology would be unlikely to result in lost jobs.Dimon said JPMorgan would also put more than $200 million this year toward training thousands of its entry-level consumer banking employees. The pay increase and the training investment would help retain and develop talent.In the coming years, however, bank branches could be overhauled due to the rise of financial tech startups, which could move many of the services provided at a local branch to one's smartphone. The fintech industry in recent months has had its own problems with loan volume growth and the possibility of increased regulatory scrutiny, but its technology could result in lost jobs.JPMorgan, which reports Q2 earnings on Thursday, closed up 1.5% in the stock market today, pushing above its 50-day moving average. Starbucks climbed 2.1%, while Wal-Mart fell 1.1%.McDonald's edged up 0.2%, while Wendy's ended flat.

U.S. stocks opened higher Tuesday as markets in Europe defending wide gains.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 rose 1% and the Nasdaq climbed 1.3%.Leaders in early trade included JPMorgan (JPM), Chesapeake Energy (CHK), Prudential (PUK) and Micron Technology (MU).European markets added to their early gains as they headed into afternoon trade. The CAC-40 in Paris traded up 3.2%; while the DAX in Frankfurt, Germany, was ahead 2.8%; and the FTSE 100 in London showed a 2.8% gain.The Commerce Department gave the stock market today an additional boost, revising its third estimate of first-quarter GDP growth upward to 1.1%, vs. its prior 0.8% growth estimate. Its inflation gauge, the GDP Price Index, eased to a 0.4% gain -- down from the previous 0.6% figure.Home prices rose 0.5% in April vs. March, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller 20 City Composite Home Price Index. That was down from a 0.9% month-over-month increase in March. On a year-over-year basis, prices were up 5.4%, effectively flat with March's (upwardly revised) 5.5% gain.The Conference Board is on deck, set to release it consumer confidence numbers for June at 10 a.m. ET.All of the Dow's stocks were positive. JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs (GS) led, adding to early gains and up more than 2% apiece just before the open.Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) spiked 5%; Chesapeake Energy rose 4% at the open, Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) 7% and Devon Energy (DVN) 4%.Chipmakers were higher; Micron Technology rallied 5%.Among U.K.-based issues trading in the U.S., life insurer Prudential bounced 11% after swooning 17% Monday. Lloyds Banking Group (LYG) jumped 8%. Wireless services provider Vodafone Group (VOD) popped 4.5%.Quarterly reports due out after today's close include Nike (NKE) and Aerovironment (AVAV).Oil prices bounced hard, with West Texas Intermediate jumping nearly 3% to just below $49 a barrel. Europe's Brent crude added more than 2% and was back above $48 a barrel. Gold backed off almost 1%, to near $1,314 an ounce. The dollar was down against the euro but up sharply vs. the yen. The 10-year Treasury yield added 3% basis points to 1.73%.Both the British pound and the euro rebounded somewhat off Monday's lows, possibly buoyed by discussions of coordinated intervention by Europe's central banks, according to Bloomberg.China's markets notched a mixed session: The Shanghai composite ended down 0.3%, but Hong Kong's Hang Seng index was up 0.6%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ticked up 0.1%.

Cooking-equipment maker Middleby (MIDD) spent a good part of last year trying to address a troubling situation: 75 reports that gas ranges made by Viking, the high-end oven maker it bought some three years ago, were turning on by themselves. Viking recalled around 60,000 ovens due to those reports, and Middleby -- which makes cooking appliances for homes and restaurants -- stresses those ovens were made prior to the acquisition. But the recall heightened problems within Viking that weighed on Middleby's finances. Among them: Delays in refrigeration products Middleby had been trying to make more energy-efficient, concerns about Viking's residential products and questions over whether the $380 million Middleby paid was too much for a company seen as lacking new ideas or sufficient margins.For Middleby officials, quality concerns of this magnitude are not what they're used to encountering."Papa John's (PZZA) runs our oven almost 18 to 20 hours a day -- especially on weekends," Chief Executive Selim Bassoul told IBD. "And it cannot break down. It is not allowed to break down."Yet shares of Middleby are up around 32% since February as the company turns out sales growth that outpaces competitors and works aggressively -- and to a large extent effectively, some analysts say -- to turn Viking around. The company has a 98 Composite Rating out of a best-possible 99. That sales growth has been led by an array of kitchen items that cater to more selective home chefs and a competitive restaurant industry, which has been set on international expansion and on serving food in a way that's quicker, fresher and more cost-effective.Roth Capital analyst Tony Brenner wrote in a research note last month that new product introductions addressing increased speed, energy and labor saving "should continue to play a key role in increasing sales and margins." Those gains would also come as the bar rises for service, even within fast food.  An array of big restaurant chains are customers of Middleby -- Starbucks (SBUX), McDonald's (MCD), Wendy's (WEN), Domino's Pizza (DPZ) and Yum Brands' (YUM) KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell -- along with higher-end chains. Want an oven that can cook a pizza in 90 seconds or a steamer that saves water by utilizing the food's moisture? Middleby has those. Need an oven that can make a steak look and taste like it was fussed over by a chef, or an oven system that can do the work of a line cook or two? Middleby has some of those too.Middleby has a lot of those things in no small part because of acquisitions. It has made more than 40 since 2000, according to the Great Lakes Review stock-picking service, with most of those deals coming during Bassoul's tenure. "He never sits on his laurels," Elliott Schlang, Great Lakes' founder, said of Bassoul. "He's always doing something new and innovative, to broaden his product line and to give the restauranteur what he needs."Restaurants, Bassoul said, face greater demand for breakfast, potentially requiring adjustments to space in the kitchen and on the grill. Greater demand for delivery and analytics, he said, will necessitate more connected, automated cooking equipment. And higher employee wages -- as have been demanded industrywide -- are inevitable."It's going to happen," he said. After reaching an intraday high of 127 on June 8, shares slipped below their 50-day moving average Friday in light of the U.K. Brexit selloff. Shares ended Monday trading around 110. That means restaurants will likely seek technology in place of people. The company's Kitchen of the Future, a conveyor-oven system with an infrared broiler and warming cabinet, helps restaurants get more usage out of each square foot. The system also uses technology that cuts usage of oven burners when not in use.    "This array replaces convection ovens, fryers, microwaves, grills, charbroilers and salamanders (broiler units), prepares food faster and with greater consistency and can eliminate two or three line cooks from the kitchen," Brenner wrote. Profit margins on such projects, he said, "reportedly exceed 50%."Middleby's ventless cooking equipment saves energy -- and a lot of money -- because it doesn't require a large, bolted-down ventilation system. Since much of a kitchen's layout hinges on where ventilation is located, ventless technology helps kitchens become more flexible with floor space and menus. The company's holding trays can also control for moisture and heat, enabling restaurants to keep items fresher for longer and served quickly."People have a tendency to think this stuff tastes like airplane food," BB&T analyst Schon Williams said of machine-prepared items. "I've done a lot of taste tests -- and it's improved the taste concept among customers."The company's food and beverage equipment has also helped some restaurants with an international presence to step up their breakfast game, although Middleby wouldn't say who."We have a number of key executives throughout our organization that literally know how to build a store, build a restaurant, build a small-box retail operation, that know how to lay out a kitchen, that actually have done that," COO David Brewer told IBD.And as more people aspire toward the artisanal in their homes, the sophistication in Middleby's commercial operations has made its way into its residential products. Viking plans to launch an oven that, it says, can cook a rack of lamb in four minutes and a 12-pound turkey in 42 minutes.The company could also use design elements from AGA Rangemaster, a U.K. company it acquired that's known for its rustic-chic ovens and cast iron cookers, to make fancy home products even fancier.Management's experience in cooking equipment has also helped during the company's rare moments of difficulty, as with the Viking acquisition.After that acquisition, the company deployed scores of engineers to Viking to assess potential problems. In quality tests, they hung weights off of refrigerator doors, which could sometimes fall off, Williams said, and in one instance Bassoul slammed an oven door over and over until it broke.The company strengthened Viking's packaging materials. Following the recall, Middleby has sued former senior staff at Viking, and Middleby's salesforce has worked to reclaim goodwill among dealers and made the wiring of Viking ovens less complicated."That's a hallmark of Middleby, just in terms of reducing the number of parts, reducing complexity whenever possible," Williams said. He later added: "Time and time again they've proven they can restructure all these businesses."Almost all Viking dealers have resumed buying the company's products, Middleby says. As restaurants expand internationally, so will Middleby, and Bassoul hopes to make its Viking residential platform a more global entity.Steel prices, Schlang noted, risk hurting the bottom line if they rise, and the company's food-processing business still lives project to project, analysts say. Brenner also said that Middleby's main competitors are bigger and have deep pockets. Manitowoc (MTW) is among its biggest rivals, but its focus isn't exclusive to food service.Restaurant same-store sales were also sluggish in the second quarter and could lag through the year. But as they try to keep costs down and investors happy, equipment could play just as much of a role as the food in improving what they offer to customers."You can do that in a simple way," Brewer said. "You can put the ketchup on top of the meat patty, you can put ketchup underneath the meat patty, add a pickle -- that maybe gets you a quarter. But eventually you have to bring in a new bread and toast it a different way."

Stocks surrendered most of their early-morning advance by mid-afternoon on Wednesday, as the U.K. referendum on retaining or rejecting membership in the European Union grew closer.Meanwhile, Emergent BioSolutions (EBS) plunged nearly 19% to about 32 to 31.05 as volume soared approached 8 million shares vs. its float of 33 million. The anthrax vaccine firm's average daily volume over the past 50 sessions is 451,000 shares.The Nasdaq composite let an early 0.7% wither to a fractional gain. The S&P 500 faded to trade just a hair positive, while the small-cap S&P 600 traded lower.The Dow Jones industrial average also shed early gains and was 0.1% lower, led by McDonald's (MCD), the only member of the 30-stock average to fall nearly 2%. The world's largest burger chain gapped down at the open and was testing buying support at 120, a psychologically key round number.Notice how on a daily chart, the stock was beginning to live beneath its 50-day moving average, which flattened out in May.McDonald's is expected to grow Q2 profit by 11% to $1.40 a share, which would mark a fourth straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth. But sales continue to wither, and Wall Street sees Q2 sales slimming by 3% to $6.29 billion.Emergent, a leader in vaccines against the bioterrorism agent anthrax, is falling after news that the U.S. government has issued two solicitation notices for the development of vaccines for its strategic stockpile. Reports noted that the Department of Health & Human Services does not specifically state the number of vaccine doses to be procured each year.The stock had formed a somewhat sloppy base that began with its Dec. 30, 2015, peak at 40.49. The four-month base featured a triple-bottom look, which is generally a flaw. Still, Emergent staged a breakout past a 38.69 early buy point on April 6 in big volume. That eventually led to a 14.7% gain through its peak of 44.38 in early June.Amid the current choppy market, a good sell rule these days is to sell more quickly on the way up; so rather than wait for a 20%-to-25% gain to emerge, an investor can take at least partial profits in a position at 10% to 15%. In the case of Emergent, a second key sell signal emerged on June 17, as the stock sliced sharply below its 50-day moving average in volume 47% above average. In the following two sessions before Wednesday's big spill, the stock barely rebounded in light volume, a subtle sign that its character had changed.Among IBD 50 names in the stock market today, top-ranking stocks Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Dycom (DY) fell mildly in ultra-light trade -- that's the right combination of price-and-volume action you want to see when a good stock takes a break. Dycom, a solid play in the telecom infrastructure space, is still in buy range from a recent new handle buy point of 86.14.As seen in Tuesday's Big Picture column and Market Pulse table, the market's current outlook was downgraded from "confirmed uptrend" to "uptrend under pressure." This means an investor can still buy stocks that break out from properly formed bases, but the probability of making money is lower, given the increased intensity of professional selling. The S&P 500 recently saw its distribution day count (denoting heavy selling) rise back to 5, while the Nasdaq composite's count is currently at 4.Is your stock is best in class within its industry group in terms of profit growth, margins, sales, return on equity, institutional fund sponsorship and relative price strength? Check it out at Investors.com's exclusive tool, IBD Stock Checkup.

Stocks capped a volatile week with big gains Friday, boosted by positive housing and manufacturing U.S. data and bullish comments out of Europe.The Nasdaq soared 2.7%, the S&P 500 rose 2% and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 1.3%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. the prior session, according to preliminary figures. Winners trounced losers by an 8-to-1 margin on the NYSE and 4-to-2 on the Nasdaq.The key indexes closed higher for the week, with the Nasdaq up 2%, and the S&P 500 and Dow 1% higher.Oil and gas stocks led in the stock market today, as both Brent crude and West Texas intermediate surged more than 8% to above $31 a barrel. Internet and bank stocks were also big gainers in the broad rally.Apple (AAPL) gapped up and soared 5% in robust trade to lead the blue chips. Piper Jaffray said in a Thursday report Apple stock could rise more than 50% from current levels on its iPhone 7 launch, expected in September: "We are buyers of AAPL going into next week's earnings (Jan. 26) and over the next month ... ." Piper rates Apple at overweight with a 179 price target.Microsoft (MSFT) weighed in with a 4% gain. Shares are below their 50-day line and 8% off their high. Analysts expect to see profit and sales dip 8% and 5%, respectively, when the Surface tablet maker reports fiscal Q2 results Thursday.Other Dow stocks scoring big moves included Disney (DIS), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Exxon Mobil (XOM), each with a 3% or better advance.On the IBD 50 , oil refiner Phillips 66 (PSX) surged 5% as it attempts to retake its 200-day moving average, which sits below its 50-day line. Centene (CNC) and Ellie Mae (ELLI) rallied 6% and 7%, respectively.A light economic data schedule Monday includes the Dallas Fed Manufacturing Survey for January. Among notable companies reporting during a busy week for earnings are Amazon.com (AMZN), eBay (EBAY) Facebook, McDonald's (MCD) and Microsoft.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo and on Facebook.

Analyst upgrades Tuesday sent shares of McDonald's (MCD), AstraZeneca (AZN) and Procter & Gamble (PG) up, while battered bank stock Citigroup (C) rose slightly.Meanwhile, Fitbit (FIT) got its PT cut by SunTrust to 30 from 48, while Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Skyworks (SWKS) was raised from hold to buy by Needham, with a PT of 73.Fitbit closed down 1.3% on the stock market today. After rallying earlier in the day, Skyworks fell 0.5% at the close. Apple also fell 0.5%.Chipmaker Micron Technology (MU), which has agreed to buy DRAM chip supplier Newell Rubbermaid (NWL), dropped 2.5% after Mizuho cut its price target from 15 to 12.Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley upgraded Microchip Technology (MCHP) to overweight and a PT of 55. Shares climbed 2.9%.McDonald's was upgraded to buy by BTIG Research; shares rose 2%. Barclays upgraded British drugmaker AstraZeneca to equal weight, with a PT of 50. Shares finished up 0.8%.Citigroup, which has been in free fall this month, dipped another 1.3% even after Keefe, Bruyette & Woods maintained an outperform on the stock, with a PT of 51.Stifel Nicolaus raised Procter & Gamble to buy from hold and a PT of 85. Shares climbed 2.3%. But it cut Disney's (DIS) PT from 130 to 110. Even so, Disney shares rose a fraction.Follow Marilyn Alva on Twitter @IBD_MAlva.

Dunkin’ Brands (DNKN) reported an unexpected decline in U.S. same-store sales at Dunkin’ Donuts outlets, which might be hurt by increased competition from McDonald’s (MCD) as well as continued strength from Starbucks (SBUX). Dunkin’ logged fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of 52 cents a share, up 13% from the prior year and 2 cents above consensus analyst views. Revenue climbed 5.5% to…

The Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) brand has taken a beating due to several food-safety scandals, but analysts appear mostly positive on the fast-casual eatery's ability to engineer a turnaround -- eventually.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Monday ended its food-safety probe of Chipotle. But perceptions can take longer to change, and Chipotle late Tuesday warned of a "very difficult" 2016 after reporting sharply weaker fourth-quarter earnings. The company also disclosed it received a new government subpoena as a criminal probe expands.Wedbush analyst Nick Setyan told IBD that the earliest he sees Chipotle sales returning to a pre-food-crisis level is in 2017."Even when they do, we may see a different Chipotle" than the one investors knew before the outbreaks hit, he said, given permanent supply chain changes and food-safety measures. Plus, labor inflation and food cost inflation aren't going to stay static, and the company "is not in a position to take prices up over the next year and a half, two years."Restaurant-level margin percentages have ranged from the mid- to high-20s over the last few years, but Chipotle recorded a 19.6% margin in Q4."Margins look closer to 20% than what they've looked historically, and that makes Chipotle not exceptional where they have been exceptional in the past," said Setyan. He said that brings its valuation into question."Arguably, it now no longer deserves a premium to its restaurant peers," he said.Sales growth already was stalling before the food illness news slammed business. But investors were taken aback by Chipotle's January sales news and forecasts for no profit in the current quarter.Shares fell 2.9% to 461.74 in the stock market today after trading as low as 440.41 intraday.Several other analysts see the light at the end of the tunnel."We are optimistic that margins can begin to recover in 2017, particularly if food-cost inflation remains benign, as we expect," RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer wrote in a Wednesday note. "Chipotle's restaurant-level economics remain best-in-class despite recent brand damage."Palmer cited improving throughput, new menu items, catering, mobile ordering and strategic marketing as reasons to believe that Chipotle can return to mid-single-digit comps and 20% earnings growth in the wake of its food-safety issues.Bob Derrington of the Telsey Group projects that same-store sales will turn positive in Q4 of this year. The bar is low for lapping comps, however, as Chipotle posted a 14.6% same-store sales decline for Q4. Wedbush's Setyan also sees positive comps "no sooner than Q4."January comps crashed 36%, Chipotle said late Tuesday.Credit Suisse analysts Jason West and James O'Brien "continue to believe the brand will fully recover," according to a report Wednesday. The bank maintains an outperform rating but lowered its price target to 475 from 530.Bank of America boosted Chipotle's rating to neutral from underperform, citing poll results in which almost one-third of respondents said they still ate at the restaurant as often as they used to. Only about one-tenth had stopped visiting Chipotle.During Tuesday's post-earnings call, Chipotle management said it would be "really hard to predict" a recovery timeline."When we looked at other events, other companies that have gone through something like this. The recovery typically takes four or five quarters or so," Chipotle CFO John Hartung said during the call. But he added that the company won't know until the recovery starts.Yum Brands (YUM) and McDonald's (MCD) restaurants in China were several years ago rocked by food-safety scandals, which pressured sales for a number of quarters. Yum Brands reported a 2% same-store sales gain at its China division late Wednesday as Q4 earnings topped views. Shares fell late after closing fractionally higher.Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) rose slightly late despite reporting weaker-than-expected earnings and sales as well as offering light 2016 guidance. Buffalo Wild Wings already closed down 4.2% Wednesday amid reports of a norovirus outbreak at a Kansas location.In the near term, Chipotle has work to do before it gets back on track.Chipotle's Hartung said during the earnings call late Tuesday that it is "likely we will post an EPS that is around break-even for the (first) quarter." Wall Street had expected about $2.08, but analysts were racing to slash targets Wednesday.The beleaguered fast-casual chain, struggling to resuscitate its image after a series of E. coli and norovirus incidents that affected around 200 people total, topped analysts' Q4 earnings views with a 43.5% plunge to $2.17 a share, but revenue fell almost 7% to $997.5 million. Estimates were for $1.01 billion.Chipotle is aggressively ramping up marketing and promotion spending in a bid to win back customers."Near-term, I think they're doing the right thing," said Setyan, "communicating the message that they're sorry for what happened, they're making changes."RELATED:Chipotle Warns Of ‘Very Difficult’ 2016, Sees No Profit In Q1

A year ago, you would have been hard pressed to make a case that fast-food restaurant chains such as McDonald's and Wendy's were better bets for investors than trendy fast-casual outlets like Chipotle Mexican Grill. That's a much easier sell today, given the beating Chipotle has taken, following E. coli and norovirus outbreaks at a number of its eateries, as…

Walk down Seventh Avenue in downtown Seattle and you can't miss them: three gigantic spheres resembling melted-together Milk Duds rising in the shadow of Amazon.com's (AMZN) new 500-foot-tall office tower. The architectural oddity has already become a tourist attraction and social media phenomenon. Passers-by snap photographs and watch construction crews attach glass panes to the steel frames. Images stream through Instagram and Twitter.When they open in 2018, the 100-foot-tall orbs -- Amazon calls them Biospheres -- will host more than 300 plant species from around the world, creating what the company sees as the workplace of the future. Amazonians will be able to break from their daily labors to walk amid the greenery along suspension bridges and climb into meeting spaces resembling bird nests perched in mature trees, where the company expects them to brainstorm -- and perhaps even invent the next billion-dollar opportunity.Amazon's new headquarters was designed to project a forward-thinking company eager to help employees be more productive, creative and happy by providing a connection to nature. But the most trendsetting and appealing feature of the new complex is most likely its location: plopped between glass and steel high-rises on a busy street in downtown Seattle where food trucks are abundant, apartments are within walking distance and Happy Hour greets employees at quitting time.Over the years, founder and Chief Executive Officer Jeff Bezos has made clear his disdain for the free lunches, massages and other perks commonplace in the suburban enclaves of Alphabet (GOOGL), Apple (AAPL) and Facebook (FB). His big advantage in the amenities arms race is a commitment to preserving an urban campus, no matter how big his company gets.Other tech companies are following his lead by squeezing new offices into cities where millennials prefer to live. LinkedIn (LNKD) consolidated staff scattered around San Francisco into a 26-story tower in March. Salesforce.com (CRM) will be the anchor tenant in a 61-story skyscraper a few miles away that will be the city's tallest upon completion in 2018. Uber has plans for a new headquarters in San Francisco's Mission Bay. Industrial-age leviathans are doing it, too. General Electric (GE) is shifting from suburban Connecticut to Boston, while McDonald's (MCD) is moving from Oak Brook, Ill., to Chicago.Amazon's is the most ambitious gambit of them all. When its spheres and three surrounding towers are completed, the company will have 10 million square feet of office space in Seattle, more than 15% of the city's inventory, on a campus that occupies more than 10 square blocks. That will provide space for Amazon to more than double in size, to 50,000 Seattle workers in the next decade. "How big can Amazon get and stay in Seattle? That's what they're trying to find out," says Glenn Kelman, the CEO of online real estate company Redfin. "Can you create a massive company in the middle of a city?"Amazon's commitment to Seattle began long before the spheres were conceived. In 2010, the company moved to South Lake Union from leased space it was outgrowing in an old medical building. Amazon leased retail space on the ground floor of its office buildings to hand-picked bars, restaurants and coffee shops, speeding the neighborhood's transformation from a hodgepodge of car dealerships and secondhand stores into a vibrant business district where people could work, live and hang out.Veteran fine-dining restaurateur Tom Douglas was among the businesses lured by a growing concentration of well-paid tech workers. His survey of Amazon workers indicated they wanted cheap burgers and beer, which encouraged him to break from his traditional model and open the Brave Horse Tavern with a wide assortment of local brews, pub fare and long tables for family-style seating. "I'm sure glad we did that survey, because we might not have gone with this concept otherwise," Douglas said. "At the time, none of us realized how big and fast Amazon would grow." The economic ripples from Amazon have since pushed beyond burger joints and cafes. Yellow cranes mark the skyline where new office towers, hotels and luxury apartments are rising.Just six years after relocating, Amazon has outgrown South Lake Union and is marching toward the city's urban core. The spheres, designed by architecture firm NBBJ, are Amazon's boldest statement yet in the first project it's building from the ground up.They were inspired by Amazon research indicating that a key thing missing from typical work environments is a link to the natural world, said John Schoettler, the company's global real estate director. The challenge was creating an environment conducive to plants without being hot and muggy like a greenhouse; the spheres had to be comfortable for humans.A staff horticulturist scoured the globe for species that can thrive in a cool, dry environment. Many of the plants are endangered species, meaning that the spheres double as a conservation project. Schoettler said the design was chosen to be an architectural focal point in the city, similar to the iconic Space Needle. "We wanted to create a place employees would be proud of and proud to bring their families," he said.Inevitably, the company's growing presence is making it a scapegoat for common urban woes such as traffic jams and rising rents. New, luxury, one-bedroom apartments packed with amenities that appeal to young urban tech workers fetch upward of $4,000 a month, putting them out of reach of the Starbucks barista.To some longtime Seattleites, the new South Lake Union feels sterile, like an open-air mall. Wide sidewalks are devoid of cigarette butts and shattered beer bottles. Street people banging bongos and strumming acoustic guitars with mangy dogs in tow, a common sight in Seattle's retail and financial districts, are conspicuously absent. South Lake Union has become "a dormitory for Amazon and now Facebook and Google," said Jeff Reifman, a tech consultant.Meanwhile, the Space Needle's owners have complained that all the towers being thrown up by Amazon and developers hoping to house its workers are crowding out views of the aging tourist attraction.For now, Amazon's growth seems unstoppable, and it will continue to redefine Seattle, one of the nation's fastest-growing cities. Nathan Wilhite, 36, helped fuel that growth when he moved from Chicago to Seattle four years ago. He rides his bike to work, parks it in an Amazon bike locker and showers before starting at about 8 a.m. He'll break for a spinach, avocado and almond milk smoothie while catching some sun in a courtyard where other Amazonians congregate to eat lunch.Wilhite is glad he picked the Amazon job over opportunities he considered in Silicon Valley that would have required long commutes by car. The way he sees it, "one of the best recruiting tools Amazon has is if people come interview on a nice day, and people are sitting outside having lunch from a food truck."Related:Chic Co-Working Spaces Now Drawing A Corporate CrowdL.A. Creative Offices Become The Norm And Get SmarterWarehouse Space At A Premium As Retailers Race Against Amazon

Shares of McDonald's (MCD) and Wendy's (WEN) fell Wednesday after Nomura downgraded both stocks to neutral, saying the burger business overall was no longer "a beacon of brightness for the industry.""With the U.S. restaurant industry looking like it could remain sluggish for the remainder of 2016, and McDonald's starting to lap tougher comparisons in Q4 . . . , we believe MCD stock is more likely to be range-bound for the rest of this year," Nomura analyst Mark Kalinowski said in a research note, in which he cut McDonald's price target to 129 from 142."While we applaud changes that management continues to make (e.g., testing of fresh beef and actions to reduce costs), we believe that a neutral rating is more appropriate at this time," Kalinowski said.mcdThe McDonald's downgrade echoes concerns from some other analysts that the burger chain's sales rebound last year depended a little too much on All Day Breakfast, which was launched nationwide in October. RBC last month said the improved sales showed the "heavy lifting" done by All Day Breakfast.Meanwhile, same-store sales industrywide have weakened in the second quarter, possibly due to growing consumer anxiety, bad weather or an abundance of competitive discount offerings spurred by cheap food costs.Also, burger chains like McDonald's and Wendy's, in general, face more competition from the likes of Shake Shack (SHAK), Five Guys, In-N-Out and others who put more of a focus on higher-quality ingredients.Kalinowski estimated that comps for burger chains were just "barely positive" in the second quarter. "No longer is the burger segment a beacon of brightness for the industry, as it was in Q1."He added that a data breach affecting more than 300 Wendy's restaurants could hurt also hurt its same-store sales. He cut his price target on the stock to 11 from 12.50.McDonald's closed 1.6% lower at to 120.62 on the stock market today, nearing the low end of the flat base it is forming with a 132.06 buy point. Wendy's fell 1.8% to 9.81. Yum Brands (YUM), now Kalinowski's top stock pick, lost 0.5% 83.89 but is still near an 85.89 buy point.Kalinowski also brought the pain to the pizza industry on Wednesday, downgrading Papa John's (PZZA) and Domino's Pizza (DPZ), citing slower industry trends and more competition from Yum's Pizza Hut.Papa John's fell 0.35%, while Domino's slipped 1.6%.

Tesla Motors (TSLA), Solar City (SCTY) and McDonald's (MCD) were downgraded Wednesday, while Nike (NKE) had its price target cut.Analysts weighed in on Tesla and SolarCity after the electric-car maker late Tuesday made a surprise offer to buy the solar energy company in a stock swap valued at roughly $2.7 billion. Tesla offered stock that values SolarCity stock at 26.50 to 28.50 per share. SolarCity shares closed near 21 on Tuesday.Oppenheimer downgraded Tesla to perform from outperform, while Stifel Nicolaus downgraded SolarCity to hold from buy, and Barclays downgraded SolarCity to underweight.

Tesla stock tumbled 10.45% -- its worst loss since May 2014 -- to 196.66, the lowest in more than three months. SolarCity closed up 3.3%, retreating from steeper, early gains. Tesla CEO Elon Musk is also chairman of SolarCity and a top shareholder in the solar power company.Analysts question if Tesla shareholders will support the deal, especially with Musk announcing that he willMcDonald's was downgraded to neutral by Nomura, even though the fast-food chain has received more than six bids for the planned sale of 2,800 restaurants in Hong Kong and mainland China.The bids are valued at about $3 billion, according to Reuters. Normura's top pick in the fast-food field is Yum Brands (YUM), which received a price target boost to 95 from 92.Shares of McDonald's dropped 1.6%, undercutting recent lows to 120.62.Telsey Advisory Group dropped its price target on Nike to 69 from 72. Nike shares -- which ended Tuesday near 55 -- have been steadily falling since the company missed quarterly revenue estimates and issued disappointing guidance in March.Nike reports quarterly results again next Tuesday. Earnings are expected to fall 2%, while revenue is seen rising 6%.Shares fell 0.4% to 54.57.FedEx (FDX) received a price target increase from RBC Capital Markets to 175 from 158 after reporting earnings late Tuesday that beat estimates. The stock had finished near 164 Tuesday.The No. 2 U.S. package shipper earned $3.30 a share, up 24% year over year, as revenue rose 7% to $13 billion. But it sees adjusted EPS for fiscal 2017 of $11.75-$12.25, with the midpoint light vs. consensus estimates for $12.05.Shares gapped down 4.5%, in part because FedEx didn't give guidance that included its just-completed acquisition of European delivery firm TNT Express.

Stocks groaned lower Wednesday, as sliding oil prices and British pound exchange rates, as well as analyst downgrades all factored into early trade.The sterling dipped to a new 31-year low, off 14% from pre-Brexit vote levels. Bonds trudged higher, yet again trimming the 10-year Treasury yield -- this time by 4 basis points, to 1.33%.The Nasdaq opened 0.5% lower while the Dow industrials and S&P 500 fell 0.4%. Oil prices and European markets fell, while analyst downgrades fueled early action.The Nasdaq 100 felt some downward pull from American Airlines (AAL) (down 5% at the open), Netflix (NFLX) and Vodafone Group (VOD) (down 4% and 3% respectively). Credit Suisse downgraded American to underperform from outperform. Jefferies initiated coverage on Netflix with an underperform rating and an 80 price target, forecasting flattening subscriber growth.On the Dow, Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) each traded 1% lower. McDonald's (MCD) slipped 1.2%.Railcar manufacturing and leasing operation Greenbrier (GBX) erased a premarket 4% gain to open 5% lower after reporting solid fiscal third-quarter results, although management eased its full-year EPS and railcar deliveries guidance.Pharmacy giant Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) slipped almost 1% after beating fiscal third-quarter earnings views, but reporting revenue growth narrowly below expectations. Management said it expects the company's acquisition of Rite Aid (RAD) to close before the end of the year.Gold mining stocks scrambled higher. Sibanye Gold (SBGL) popped 5% at the open. AngloGold Ashanti (AU) jumped 5%. Newmont Mining (NEM) rose 2%. Sibanye is forming a cup base with a 16.73 buy point. AngloGold and Newmont were extended, and both sketching out new highs.U.K. and eurozone banks were under heavy, early pressure in U.S. premarket trade. Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) tumbled 7%. Deutsche Bank (DB) slid 5%, and Lloyds Banking Group (LYG) dropped 6%.This afternoon's release of minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's June 15 meeting, set for 2 p.m. ET., is likely to provide a focal point for the stock market today. There may also be news out of a meeting of the European Central Bank governors in Frankfurt, Germany.The U.S. trade deficit widened slightly in May, to $41.1 billion, the Commerce Department reported. That was up from April's $37.7 billion gap and wider than the $40 billion forecast by economist consensus.Researcher Markit reports its June services Purchasing Managers' Index at 9:45 a.m. The Institute for Supply Management drops its June non-manufacturing index at 10 a.m. The Energy Information Administration pushed its normal Wednesday release of oil inventories data to Thursday, due to the July Fourth holiday.New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley spoke at a local business roundtable in Binghamton, N.Y., before the open. Fed governor Daniel Tarullo is also scheduled to speak before the start of regular trade.Oil futures leaned lower. West Texas Intermediate dropped 1%, holding just above $46 a barrel. Crude prices toppled 5% on Tuesday on a combination of rising U.S. drilling activity, a stronger dollar and further Brexit concerns. Gold continued higher, pressing ahead more than 1% to above $1,373 an ounce. The dollar was steady vs. the euro, but it fell hard against the yen.China markets were once again mixed: Shanghai was up, and Hong Kong was down. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 plunged 1.9% in its second straight decline.Sellers were driving European and U.K. markets in afternoon trade, with London's FTSE 100 down 1.5% and benchmarks in Paris and Frankfurt off earlier lows and down a bit less than 2% each.

Microsoft's (MSFT) $26.2 billion purchase of LinkedIn (LNKD) is a big joke, at least to the nation's comedians.Late-night comics poked fun at Microsoft for paying such a hefty price for the professional social network, derided by many for its pestering emails from strangers wanting to connect.Seth Meyers, host of NBC's "Late Night," had this to say: "Microsoft has announced it will buy the professional networking site LinkedIn for $26.2 billion. This also marks the first time anyone has ever accepted a LinkedIn invitation."Chris Hardwick, host of "@midnight" on Comedy Central, also took some shots at the Microsoft-LinkedIn deal this week."Microsoft has announced plans to acquire LinkedIn for $26.2 billion, making history as the most anyone has ever paid for a list of people without jobs," Hardwick said.Hardwick said he hopes Microsoft does something about all the bleeping emails he gets from LinkedIn."I imagine Microsoft just bought them so they can f---ing stop getting emails from LinkedIn as well," he said.Microsoft and LinkedIn aren't the only companies getting mocked by comics lately. Other targets recently have included Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), McDonald's (MCD) and Apollo Education Group's (APOL) University of Phoenix.Among the comedians delivering zingers on tech-related subjects were Meyers, Jimmy Fallon, Conan O'Brien and James Corden.Fallon: The New York Post reports that more people check their Facebook feed than read the Bible each week. Which explains that new commandment: Thou shalt not 'like' a bikini pic of thy neighbor's wife.Fallon: A new study found that students who learn without any shoes on get better grades than students who wear shoes. Then the University of Phoenix Online said, "Just think how well you'd learn without PANTS on!"Fallon: The company that makes products for Apple and Samsung in Asia has reportedly replaced 60,000 factory workers with robots. Just to keep it authentic, they're all child robots.Meyers: X-rated website Pornhub has released a new fitness app that claims to help couples get in shape by recommending physically intense sex positions. It's a fun way to get in shape, but the other people at the gym really hate it.Conan: Two thieves stole $16,000 worth of iPhones from a New York Apple store by dressing as Apple "Geniuses." Police are on the lookout for two "Actual Geniuses."Conan: In Virginia recently, a computer crash wiped out a decade's worth of U.S. military data. However, this morning the Chinese government called and said, "No problem, we backed it up."Conan:  The FDA has approved a device for weight loss that sucks the food out of your stomach through an abdominal incision. Or you could just try a salad sometime.Conan: A former CEO of McDonald's is warning that robots could take over jobs of fast food workers. Which begs the question, where are they going to find a slow-moving robot with acne?Corden: The electronics company LG identified a new phenomenon called low-battery anxiety. People become nervous, distracted, and frustrated when their phones are about to die. If you are not familiar with low-battery anxiety, it's a real condition that primarily affects people with no actual problems.Corden: According to a survey, a third of people will drop everything to go and charge their phone. Like what, is there a doctor in the middle of surgery and he's like, "I need to split, guys, I'm at 5 percent. Ted, where you at, at 20? Cool, can you put a heart in this guy?"

McDonald's (MCD) is moving its headquarters about 20 miles east to Chicago, following General Electric (GE) in the shift to urban centers where the global giants hope to attract younger talent.McDonald's said Monday it had signed a lease in the West Loop neighborhood of Chicago and would move its headquarters there from its current location in Oak Brook, Ill., by the spring of 2018. The fast-food company had previously been headquartered in Chicago from 1955 to 1971.Shares rose 0.5% to 122.99 in the stock market today."This world-class environment will continue to drive business momentum by getting us even closer to customers, encouraging innovation and ensuring great talent is excited about where they work," McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook said in the release.In January, General Electric (GE) said it will move its corporate headquarters from Fairfield, Conn., to Boston due to the higher corporate taxes in Connecticut, as well as to attract tech-focused and younger employees that prefer to work in major cities.General Electric stock dipped 0.7% Monday.In 2001, then Seattle-based Boeing (BA) picked Chicago over Dallas and Denver to relocate its headquarters on promises of tax breaks of up to $60 million over 20 years. Boeing shares fell 0.9% Monday.
An early jab of optimism quickly gave way to deepening losses in the first half-hour of trade Thursday. The Nasdaq fell 1%. The S&P 500 backed off 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.3%.
Volume ticked up 13% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.

James Bullard, St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank president, softened his recently bullish stance in a Memphis, Tenn., speech this morning. Continued declines in oil prices have led to an associated decline in market-based inflation expectation measures and are "becoming worrisome," Bullard said. Further declines could delay the forecast return of inflation, possibly delaying the Fed's rate hike scheme.

The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro and up against the yen. Bonds slipped. Oil prices were steady, up about 1% and hovering at $30 to $31 a barrel. Overseas, Europe's markets largely held their early losses. The DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris each traded down more than 2% in afternoon action.

Two-thirds of the Dow's stocks moved higher in the stock market today. Procter & Gamble (PG), Exxon Mobil (XOM) and McDonald's (MCD) led, up about 1%. Home Depot (HD) and DuPont (DD) fell more than 1% apiece.

Best Buy (BBY) posted the S&P 500's widest loss, down nearly 10% after reporting its Christmas season revenue declined 0.8%. Cellphones seemed to be the problem category. Minus phones, the company said domestic revenue increased year over year.
Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) fell 7%. Ore miner Freeport-McMoran (FCX) surged 7% to lead the S&P 500.

Among IBD 50 stocks, WebMD (WBMD) strode to an early lead, up more than 7% after news reports said the company was discussing a possible takeover with bidders Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH). The gain sent WebMD easily to new highs and 24% past a 46.01 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
Hawaiian (HA) jumped nearly 3%, taking back a bit of its 7% loss from Wednesday. Shares were still down 4.4% for the week.

Universal Display (OLED) rose more than 2%. The maker of image-enhancing organic LED chips used in TV and computer screens is finding support at its 50-day moving average after triggering a sell rule by falling more than 8% below a 55.93 cup base buy point.

At the list's low end, Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) tumbled more than 3%. The light-trade loss put shares below their 50-day moving average in the eighth week of a possible base-on-base pattern.An early jab of optimism quickly gave way to deepening losses in the first half-hour of trade Thursday. The Nasdaq fell 1%. The S&P 500 backed off 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.3%.Volume ticked up 13% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.James Bullard, St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank president, softened his recently bullish stance in a Memphis, Tenn., speech this morning. Continued declines in oil prices have led to an associated decline in market-based inflation expectation measures and are "becoming worrisome," Bullard said. Further declines could delay the forecast return of inflation, possibly delaying the Fed's rate hike scheme.The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro and up against the yen. Bonds slipped. McDonald's (MCD) has imposed ultra-high rents and restrictive contracts on its European franchisees, ultimately harming their competitive position by forcing them to pass on costs to consumers, according to an antitrust complaint filed with the European Commission by three Italian consumer groups.The complaint could add to the fast-food chain's difficulties in the European Union. Authorities last month began investigating whether the company received illegal tax breaks in Luxembourg.McDonald's shares closed down 0.6% in the stock market today.The European Commission said it would review the consumer groups' complaint, which alleges that McDonald's made franchisees pay rents that were 10 times normal market value. It also says one- to two-year noncompete clauses in franchise contracts prevent franchisees from changing brands.McDonald's stood by its franchise system, saying in a statement that it "helped create the best business opportunities for our franchisees and the best overall experience for our customers."If the company were found in violation of the law, it could face penalties of as much as 10% of its international revenue, according to the Wall Street Journal.EU lawmakers in recent months have tried to crack down on multinationals who have allegedly used their size — and some creative accounting — to work out favorable tax arrangements.In October, the EU ordered Starbucks (SBUX) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) to pay unpaid taxes after ruling that their tax arrangements in the Netherlands and Luxembourg, respectively, broke the law. Amazon (AMZN) and Apple (AAPL) have also been in the Continent's cross hairs over their tax deals there.Apple shares rose 1.5% Tuesday. Amazon was flat. Starbucks climbed 2.8%, and Fiat Chrysler was up nearly 1%.And on Monday, the European Commission determined that tax exemptions, which had given dozens of multinationals some $760 million in tax breaks on Belgian profits, ran afoul of the law.AB InBev (BUD) and BP (BP) were among the companies that benefited, the Journal reported.Follow Bill Peters on Twitter @IBD_BPeters.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) further cut its fourth-quarter guidance Wednesday and disclosed a subpoena in connection with a federal criminal investigation into a restaurant hit by norovirus in August.The fast-casual burrito chain said December comparable restaurant sales plunged by 30%, and it now expects Q4 comps to sink by 14.6%, with earnings per share coming in at $1.70-$1.90. That's far worse than the 8%-11% quarterly comp decline and EPS outlook of $2.45-$2.85 that the company forecast last month.Chipotle said in a regulatory filing that a separate norovirus incident last month at a restaurant in Brighton, Mass., had compounded the company's problems following an E. coli outbreak at some of its locations during the fall.The restaurant chain also anticipates one-time Q4 expenses of $14 million-$16 million to cover food replacement, food safety, inspection, marketing and other costs. That's a higher estimate than the $6 million-$8 million estimate offered in December.And Chipotle sees restaurant-level operating margins shrinking to 20%-21%, compared to the 22%-24% projected last month. The company is due to report full Q4 results Feb. 2.Shares closed down nearly 5% in the stock market today. The stock has nose-dived 39.5% since the company's last earnings report on Oct. 20.Other restaurant chains also moved lower Wednesday. McDonald's (MCD) dipped 0.7%, Wendy's (WEN) gapped down 2.3%, Jack In The Box (JACK) lost 0.8%, and Sonic (SONC) sank 6.6% despite reporting strong quarterly results late Tuesday.Chipotle said it received the subpoena last month from the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California requiring the company to turn over "a broad range of documents" related to a restaurant in Simi Valley, Calif. The investigation is being led by federal prosecutors and the FDA."We intend to fully cooperate in the investigation," Chipotle said, adding that it was unable to assess the investigation's full impact.Chipotle in recent weeks has vowed to improve safety standards, with its co-CEO issuing a televised apology.The company on Wednesday also said it had OK'd $300 million in share repurchases. Those buybacks are in addition to the $300 million in buybacks approved last month, the company said.Follow Bill Peters on Twitter @IBD_BPeters.

Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Apple (AAPL) led the S&P 500 with the largest amount spent on stock buybacks in the first quarter, which in total set a nine-year high as companies sought to boost their stock price in a slumping market, according to the S&P Dow Jones Indices.Gilead spent $8 billion, up from the $3.1 billion it spent in the prior quarter. Apple spent $6.7 billion, slightly down from its prior quarter's $6.9 billion.Companies in the S&P 500 spent a total of $161.4 billion in stock buybacks in Q1, up 12% from Q1 2015. It was the second-largest expenditure on record, following the $172 billion spent in Q3 2007, as reported by the S&P Dow Jones Indices.The information technology sector continued to dominate buybacks. Following Apple in the IT sector were Microsoft (MSFT), Oracle (ORCL) and Alphabet (GOOGL). Microsoft spent $3.85 billion, with Oracle at $2.2 billion and Alphabet at $2 billion.Following Gilead and Apple as the biggest spenders, General Electric (GE) was No. 3 at $6.3 billion, then came Pfizer (PFE) at $5 billion and McDonalds (MCD) at $4.3 billion. Microsoft was No. 6 overall.For the ninth consecutive quarter, more than 20% of the S&P 500 companies reduced their year-over-year diluted share count by at least 4%, thereby boosting their earnings per share by at least 4%."The pace of buybacks was partially driven by companies supporting their stock during the opening downturn of the year, which coincidentally started in early February when many earnings lock-ups ended," said Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices, in a statement announcing the Q1 tally."The upswing in both expenditures and participation appears to persist in the market, meaning that the upturn in Q4 was not a single-shot," he saidAccording to Silverblatt, cash reserves set a record, increasing 1.6% to $1.347 trillion. That topped the prior record $1.333 trillion set at the end of 2014. Silverblatt adds that the current cash level is 86 weeks of expected 2016 operating income, giving corporations leeway in their expenditures.Among the two buyback leaders, Apple stock rose 3% in Q1, ending the quarter at 108.99, Apple stock was down a fraction to 95.55 at the close on the stock market today.Gilead shrank 9% in Q1, ending the quarter at 91.86. Gilead stock ended trading Wednesday at 82.45, up 0.8%.

Under the glare of the fight-for-$15 movement, McDonald's (MCD) CEO Steve Easterbrook told a shareholders meeting on Thursday that self-service kiosks and automation might change jobs but won’t eliminate them"It may change the nature of the jobs in the restaurant, because frankly technology is something that our customers are embracing, whether it’s through their phone or whether through self-order kiosks -- that is a societal trend," he said. "We want to adapt to that, but it’s not actually meant as a labor replacement. We can just re-apportion that labor into more service-orientated roles."Vilified by Big Labor as a symbol of low wages, it's easy to understand why Easterbrook would want to soft-pedal the truth about how the fast-food industry is likely to respond to a much higher minimum wage. Yet the economics of operating a fast-food franchise with thin profit margins points to a harsher reality.When Easterbrook talks about how McDonald's will respond to minimum wage hikes, it's worth remembering what he said when the company hiked its average hourly wage to just above $10 an hour last year -- but only for employees at the roughly 10% of 14,500 U.S. restaurants operated by the company.The franchisees who operate the vast majority of McDonald's "make their own decisions about how they run their business and pay their employees."To the extent that the highly publicized wage hike put pressure on those franchisees to follow suit, they were none too happy about it, because a big wage hike squeezes franchisees in multiple ways:First, their labor costs go up, which puts pressure on them to raise prices. Higher prices could translate to lost sales.Second, assuming that higher prices generate enough extra revenue to pay for the higher labor costs, franchisees have an added burden: The fees they pay to the companies behind franchises like McDonald’s and Burger King (owned by Restaurant Brands International (QSR)) are a fixed percentage of sales — a 10% revenue increase means a 10% hike in franchise fees.Chains such as McDonald’s and Burger King charge franchisees a royalty of around 4%-5% of sales and a similar-size  marketing fee. On top of that, a number of chains, including McDonald’s, Burger King, Tim Horton’s, Wendy’s (WEN) and Jack in the Box (JACK), generally lease out their restaurant locations to franchisees for an additional percentage of sales.Between marketing fees, royalties and rent, a franchisee can owe McDonald's an amount equal to 20% of sales or more.Some simple math illustrates the challenge for a McDonald’s franchisee facing a big wage hike. Assuming a franchisee earns a 2% profit margin, then a 10% price hike that’s just enough to cover extra labor costs would, all else being equal, erase its profitability.A survey conducted for the Employment Policies Institute found that franchise businesses would be more likely than non-franchise businesses to cut jobs (65% vs. 51%) and turn to automation (54% vs. 37%) in response to a $15 wage. While the group advocates against minimum-wage hikes, the notion that franchisees would be less able to manage higher labor costs jibes with the reality that labor costs passed through as price increases would also raise the cost of royalties, marketing and rent.Wendy's said recently that it will make self-service ordering kiosks available across its 6,000-plus mostly franchise-operated restaurants in the second half of the year, as minimum wage hikes and a tight labor market push up wages.For quick-service chains with few company-operated stores, a much higher minimum wage won’t have much of a direct effect, but a deterioration in the financial health of their franchisees would bode ill for the company’s future.Further, one of the growth strategies for fast-food chains is modernizing their restaurants, which requires investments of several hundred thousand dollars per restaurant for each franchisee. Such investments will be harder to make if profits are being squeezed by higher wages.Advocates of a $15 wage argue that companies will save from lower turnover, while many customers will have more money to spend. Yet few operators will be willing to take a leap of faith that they can pass along big price increases without losing customers to higher-end competitors or to eating at home.Wendy's CEO Todd Penegor said the company is "working so hard to find efficiencies" so it can deliver "a new QSR experience but at traditional QSR prices."Former McDonald's USA CEO Ed Rensi, for one, isn't nearly so sanguine about a $15 wage as Easterbrook sounded on Thursday: "It will mean wiping out thousands of entry-level opportunities for people without many other options," Rensi wrote last month.

After an hour of talking about refranchising and earnings accretion, Jack In The Box (JACK) said Wednesday it will try to become a higher-end burger chain by tapping into two parallel trends that have developed over the last 20 years.The first: the evolution in diners' preferences away from deep-frozen chicken patties with abstract shapes to fresher, better-tasting fast-food items. The second: a shift within popular culture from cheeky to earnest.When Jack Box, the burger chain's balloon-headed, wise-cracking mascot, was created in 1995, the company was trying to tap into a pop culture then defined by ironic, adversarial posturing. But the company suggested Wednesday at its 2016 investor day that the irony once employed in some of its advertising -- the very device that makes many ads seem pointless, too clever, or halfheartedly mean to many older consumers -- no longer jibes with the culture or the chain's more recent focus on quality."As we started to really shift the quality of our product and the service that we provide to our customers, it was no longer the right way for us to communicate our brand by letting humor dominate the messaging around our food," Richard Cran, vice president, marketing communications, said at the conference."When Jack was created, the No. 1 reigning sitcom ... was 'Seinfeld,' " Cran added. "If you think back to how the finale of 'Seinfeld' ended, it ended with the four friends being put in jail for basically just being unpleasant people -- a little bitter, a little bit too sarcastic. And at times, Jack shifted toward that part of his persona too much."A slide from the company's investor presentation further detailed the cultural changes. Pop culture, Jack In The Box said, had moved from being "disenfranchised" to "empowered," from "sarcasm" to "optimism", or, say, from "Pulp Fiction" to "The Hunger Games."So after years of ads in which Jack Box materialized in stoners' dark, TV-lit basements offering food that either cured or helped them explore their loneliness, viewers might now be more likely to see the mascot embark on a what the company called a "heroic but silent quest for better ingredients and better burgers."Fast food's flight to quality comes even as the cheap, commodity-induced discounts that have also characterized the industry show no signs of easing. But Frances Allen, Jack In The Box's brand president, said the company's opportunity "is not to stay in the very value-driven QSR space," referring to quick-service restaurants.And she said the company's goal, by 2020, was to move beyond QSR to become a "top QSR-plus burger destination," referring quick-service restaurants branded as higher quality like In-N-Out and Chick-fil-A but aren't as high-quality as fast-casual restaurants like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).Those ambitions could raise more questions about whether Jack In The Box might spin off Qdoba Mexican Eats, the fast-casual chain that the company acquired in 2003. Jack In The Box at the conference said it had a "firm commitment" to growing Qdoba but that it could consider alternatives if those plans didn't work out.Offering up a specific deadline by which to make that decision would be "extremely irresponsible" and distracting to leadership, the company said.Jack In The Box jumped 5.5% in the stock market today to 83.39. McDonald's (MCD), which held its annual shareholder meeting Thursday, inched up 0.4% to 123.79. Chipotle lost 1.3% to 452.03.

Temple Grandin had trouble relating to people. But she sure could relate to animals. By dealing with her autism, she developed a unique understanding of creatures to build humane facilities for farms and slaughterhouses.Grandin has built many animal handling facilities for slaughterhouses, feed yards and ranches in the U.S., Canada and Europe.She has also created animal welfare guidelines for the meat industry, advised McDonald's (MCD), Tyson Foods (TSN) and other firms on animal welfare, written articles for a maze of publications and become a professor of livestock behavior at Colorado State University.Now 68, she's aiming to help give children the same social awareness that her life has imbedded in her.Grandin's autism helped her decode animals' behavior and understand why they think the way they do, says Teresa Corey, a conference director for Future Horizons, a group based in Arlington, Texas, that hosts conferences and publishes information on autism and Asperger's syndrome.Autism and Asperger's are developmental disabilities that cause people difficulties with social interaction and communication. Signs are typically first noticed during a child's first two years.Good Feeling"Temple would watch how cows became calm in the squeeze chute as they went in for vaccines," said Corey. "With her autism, she didn't like to be touched, and marveled at how cows would be calmed down with a squeeze and built her own squeezing machine."Grandin has become so successful in improving handling facilities and speaking on autism, HBO made a movie of her life starring Claire Danes in 2010.Early life wasn't easy for Grandin. Born in Boston in 1947, she displayed classic symptoms of autism, such as the inability to speak and an aversion to physical contact.Doctors at Boston Children's Hospital labeled her brain damaged. The diagnosis of autism was still new, having been recognized just a few years before her birth.Autism now affects 1 in 68 American children and is one of the fastest-growing developmental disorders in the country, according to Autism Speaks, a nonprofit science and advocacy organization.Grandin's mother, Eustacia Cutler, sent her to a speech therapy school and hired a nanny; they teamed up to give her a traditional upbringing. They taught her table manners, how to interact with her mother's guests and not to spend much time in front of the TV."You have to stretch (mentally to overcome autism)," Grandin told IBD. "My mother knew how to stretch me when I was a young child. She knew how to get me partly outside my comfort zone."Grandin had trouble with speech and making friends, and didn't like going into crowded rooms. But her mother made her socialize with people at parties and work outside the home. The push paid off, with Grandin now speaking in front of thousands of people about autism awareness and animal science.Still, Grandin says, her adolescence and high school days were rough. Students picked on her, and she moved to Hampshire Country School in Rindge, N.H. The boarding school took gifted students with behavioral issues.The vibe was positive, with Temple working in a horse barn and gaining a strong work ethic."A problem I'm seeing today are kids getting coddled too much and aren't learning how to work," she said. "I'm seeing kids graduating from high school without ever having a job, and for kids that are quirky or different, that is causing big, big problems."Grandin credits her old-school upbringing and exposure to work as part of her path upward.She grew interested in cattle and animals when she met them at her aunt's ranch in Arizona and credits her aunt as a crucial mentor.Grandin also lauds a high school science teacher for motivating her to study with hands-on projects.She liked such classes, which went beyond textbooks, and encourages that style of learning: "My ability in art was always encouraged, and that became the basis of my career in industrial design."Grandin turned her love of animals, science and art into a career, riding education to the hilt. She received a bachelor's degree in psychology from Franklin Pierce College (now University) in New Hampshire, then landed a master's in animal science at Arizona State University and a Ph.D. in that subject from the University of Illinois.Grandin took what she learned in school and her grasp of what causes animals stress, and went to work designing more humane facilities across the world. She points to hard work over a sustained period as the top key to her advancement.Meanwhile, she leapt at opportunities — such as when she built a better dip vat in Arizona for John Wayne's Red River feed yard in the 1970s on orders from the Agriculture Department after an outbreak of scabies, a contagious skin disease caused by mites, among cattle."Lucky breaks gave me a lot of jobs," she said, "but I still had to do work after that."International ReachEquipment that Grandin designed handles 50% of all cattle in the U.S. and Canada.Her 2005 book, "Animals in Translation: Using the Mysteries of Autism to Decode Animal Behavior," was a New York Times best-seller; several hundred industry publications printed excerpts.Corey says that Grandin solved problems by exploring and refusing to deliver pat answers for her professors in college.As for entering the rancher workforce, autism made it especially hard. It helped that an engineer, Jim Uhl of Agate Construction in Scottsdale, Ariz., explained how to get along with co-workers."There are a lot of talented people out there, and bosses need to learn how to work with them," Grandin said of hiring people with special needs. "Being blunt helps; don't be subtle. And work with a clear goal; don't be vague."Despite rising in industrial design, Grandin had her setbacks.In the 1980s, the Kahn slaughterhouse and meatpacking plant in Cincinnati hired her to build a conveyer belt to transport pigs too sick or weak to walk up to the third story to be slaughtered.The problem with her design: The belt just pushed the pigs on their backs and was ineffective."What I learned from that project is that I treated the symptom, not the root cause," she said.After collecting the ID tags of the sick pigs, she found they all came from the same farm. The slaughterhouse could have saved money by buying the farm new boars to produce healthier offspring that could walk to the top of the facility instead of paying for the conveyer belt.Down, Not OutGrandin says that she went into a six-month depression after the project failure, but she learned that not everything could be solved by "throwing engineering at things."Just as engineering didn't magically solve the problem at the slaughterhouse, Grandin thinks some people expect quick fixes to complicated problems."Too many times, people look for a magic fix like putting iPads in schools," she said, "but that's not going to fix everything."She stresses the need for good management in business and good teachers in schools, especially to inspire those who need extra guidance to realize their abilities."I'm worried that today, too many kids are being labeled as dyslexic, with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autistic, and they are becoming those labels," Grandin said. "Some of those talented people whom we need to fix the problems of tomorrow are getting that handicapped mentality."She points to Nikola Tesla, the great inventor of a century ago. If he had stayed out of futuristic findings because of his autism, the world would've been slow to develop alternating current generators.For someone who had trouble socializing in high school, she sure has no problem finding pals in the animal science and autism communities. "She has friends from ranchers in Montana to Claire Danes in Los Angeles to the students she works with to people in the autism field," said Corey. "She takes people for who they are, and social status doesn't even enter into the picture."Corey likes Grandin's approach and marvels at how they haven't had a disagreement in their long friendship. "Empathy goes a lot further than sympathy," Corey said of Grandin's ability to interact with others who have autism or parents with autistic children.Grandin says that she lives by this philosophy: Stop looking for all sorts of complicated meanings in life, and just focus on things you can do to improve the world.One way she does it is using the money she's earned from speaking engagements to support autistic students in reaching their full potential.
