Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Markets will keep close tabs on what Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen says, while presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump appears at an oil industry event attended by General Electric (GE) and Halliburton (HAL), among others. Meanwhile, Exxon Mobil (XOM) shareholders will have…

The Federal Reserve convinced markets that a June rate hike is on the table. Warren Buffett disclosed a big Apple (AAPL) stake. Home Depot (HD), Lowe's (LOW) and Wal-Mart (WMT) reported strong results, but Target (TGT), Gap (GPS) and Ross Stores (ROST) were among those with weak results or outlooks. Cisco (CSCO) and Salesforce (CRM) had upbeat reports that were good news for IT spending. General Motors (GM) and Uber tested self-driving cars on the road, joining Alphabet (GOOGL) Google cars, while Google held a major developers conference.The major averages continued to move sideways in a choppy fashion as the market remains under pressure. The Nasdaq rose 1.1% for the week after falling for the prior four weeks. The S&P 500 eked out a 0.3% rise while the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2%, its fourth straight weekly decline. The S&P 500 and Dow moved back above their 50-day moving averages on Monday as Apple rose on Buffett's stake, but then fell back as near-term Fed rate hike buzz took hold, pushing up the dollar. Thanks to Friday gains, the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq are slightly higher for the week.While some stocks broke out -- Salesforce and Lowe's -- older breakouts struggled. Facebook (FB) closed just below a buy point Thursday, though it regained its entry point on Friday. McDonald's (MCD) fell below its late March entry area.Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s April meeting showed policymakers are close to raising benchmark interest rates again next month, surprising Fed watchers who priced in an increase later in the year. But before raise rates for a second time, the Fed wants to see signs growth is picking up in Q2, along with stronger labor markets and inflation heading for the 2% target.New York Fed President William Dudley said the next day a rate hike in the June-July timeframe is reasonable, unless the economy stumbles. He said a June rate hike is "definitely live." Other policymakers made similar comments. The next meeting will be held June 14-15, followed by another on July 26-27.April consumer prices had their biggest monthly gain in three years. Weekly jobless claims fell sharply after spiking to the highest since February 2015 in the prior week. Industrial production was strong in April, but manufacturing surveys for May from the New York Fed and Philly Fed showed unexpected deterioration.Existing-home sales and housing starts rose for April, while builder sentiment was steady in May.Mega-investors piled into Apple. Warren Buffett disclosed on Monday May 13 that Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) bought 9.8 million shares of Apple last quarter, valued at about $1.07 billion at quarter’s end. Midweek, Greenlight Capital disclosed it raised its stake in Apple 30.7% to 8.2 million shares, and billionaire George Soros' Soros Fund Management said it took a 3,100-share stake in Apple. Buffett's investment reflects confidence in Apple's pipeline of products, including future iPhones or even a rumored Apple Car. But it also suggests a shift in Apple's lifecycle from a growth company to a value play.Apple stock rose 5.2% for the week after hitting a 23-month low in the prior week.Playing catch-up, Alphabet's Google introduced a voice-activated Wi-Fi speaker system with built-in search. Google Home, expected to ship in 2016, will compete with the Amazon.com (AMZN) Echo. Google’s new “Allo” messaging app features artificial intelligence, like Facebook's new “chat bot.” Google’s upcoming Android N upgrade to its mobile operating system will feature a virtual reality mode. However, Google did not unveil a VR competitor to Facebook’s Oculus Rift. Apple rival Xiaomi plans to ship its Android-based TV set-top box to the U.S. in 2016.Both home improvement chains topped estimates on strong housing market growth and favorable spring weather, raising guidance. But Home Depot fell 2.5% on Tuesday and 1% for the week, as same-store sales growth cooled from 10.2% in Feb. to 6.7% in March and 4.3% in April. Meanwhile, Lowe’s shares climbed 6.4% to an all-time high, breaking out of a nearly four-month long consolidation.Salesforce.com reported Q1 EPS and revenue that topped views as the business software provider signed more big deals with enterprise customers. Billings rose 31% year over year, accelerating from 28% in Q4. Salesforce.com increased its full-year revenue guidance slightly to $8.2 billion. On its earnings call, management touted a new cloud alliance with Amazon Web Services. Salesforce stock jumped 6.1% for the week, breaking out of a base and nearly hitting an all-time high.Cisco Systems reported a 6% adjusted EPS gain for its fiscal Q3, with revenue up 3%, both edging past analyst forecasts. Profit and sales guidance was also bullish. Analysts had lowered expectations ahead of Cisco earnings due to the growing number of companies outsourcing to cloud computing service providers such as Amazon Web Services, reducing demand for Cisco’s networking gear. The lowered expectations also reflected lower spending on information technology overall.Well aware of the trends, Cisco is diversifying into newer, higher-growth segments such as software, data centers, security, wireless and the Internet of Things market.Cisco stock rose 5.4% for the week.The Energy Information Administration reported a domestic stockpile increase of 1.3 million barrels vs. a 3 million barrel decline expected by analysts. The American Petroleum Institute reported a drawdown of 1.14 million barrels. U.S. production continues to fall while gasoline demand ramps up.Oil prices hit fresh seven-month highs during the week. U.S. futures closed the week at $47.75 a barrel, up 3.3%.Goldman Sachs said that oil could hit $50 per barrel later this year as the market “likely shifted into deficit in May,” earlier than Goldman expected. But the supply deficit will be short-lived and will swing back to surplus next year.FMC Technologies (FTI) and France’ Technip announced a merger that would rival oilfield service giants Schlumberger (SLB) and Halliburton (HAL).Occidental Petroleum (OXY) reportedly offered to buy Apache (APA). But Oxy said it didn’t “have any knowledge” about an offer. In November, Anadarko (APC) withdrew a bid to buy Apache, which had rejected the offer.Wal-Mart and Target moved in opposite directions after issuing their quarterly earnings reports.Target’s Q1 EPS increased 17% to $1.29, beating views for $1.19. But sales dropped 5% to $16.2 billion, missing estimates. Same-store sales grew 1.2%, short of predictions for a 1.6% gain. Target’s Q2 EPS guidance of $1 to $1.20 widely missed expectations for $1.36.Shares plunged 7.1%, hitting their lowest levels since late 2014.Wal-Mart’s Q1 profit fell 5 cents to 98 cents a share but beat estimates by 10 cents. Sales rose 0.9% to $115.9 billion vs. forecasts for a drop to $113.2 billion. U.S. same-store sales climbed 1%, the seventh straight gain. For Q2, Wal-Mart sees EPS of 95 cents to $1.08, with the midpoint above estimates for 98 cents.Shares popped 7.6% for the week, retaking their 200-day and 50-day lines after gapping down in sympathy with Target on Wednesday.Outshining its ailing department store peers, TJX (TJX) Q1 EPS and sales rose 10% to 76 cents and $7.54 billion, comfortably topping. Comps rose 7%. The off-price retailer guided full-year EPS up to $3.35-$3.42, still shy of estimates. Off-price peer Ross Stores edged past Q1 EPS views with a 6% gain, but revenue's 5% gain to $3.09 billion missed. Comps grew 2%. Q2 and full-year EPS guidance fell short of consensus. Ross Stores fell 3.4% for the week, while TJX climbed 3.7%.General Motors acquisition Cruise Automation confirmed that its self-driving technology was being tested on Chevy Bolts after photos of the all-electric cars surfaced online. Uber on Thursday also posted a photo of a hybrid Ford (F) Fusion outfitted with self-driving technology that it said would be undergoing testing.GM and Lyft plan to road-test autonomous Bolt taxis in the coming months, and Ford has established a subsidiary focused on autonomous-car technology and ride-sharing. But the carmakers face stiff competition from the likes of Toyota (TM), Tesla (TSLA) and Alphabet, which recently inked a tech deal with Fiat Chrysler (FCAU).Red Robin Gourmet Burgers (RRGB) plunged 21% this week to a 3-year low on weak sales and slashed revenue guidance. Sonic (SONC) said it would miss its own fiscal Q3 same-store sales target, triggering an 8.65% weekly stock loss. The reports, which followed a weak May 11 sales outlook from Wendy’s (WEN), intensified fears about burger competition as both value and upscale offerings spread. Wendy’s stock fell 2.8%. Shake Shack (SHAK), which popped on solid results earlier this month, slid 6.9%. McDonald’s lost 4.9%.Campbell Soup (CPB) and Hormel (HRL) reported disappointing quarterly results, perhaps indicating that sluggish consumer spending is spilling over into the foods group. Hormel, the parent of Spam lunch meat, Skippy peanut butter and other leading brands, plunged xx% for the week to a 2016 low. Q2 earnings growth was strong as sales in 4 of 5 product groups rose, Hormel also raised guidance. But its Q2 profit margin shrank to 11.9% before interest and taxes, down from 14.4% in the prior quarter. Campbell said fiscal Q3 EPS rose 5% to 65 cents, beating by a penny. But sales fell 1.6% to $1.87 bil, missing Wall Street’s target. Shares fell 6.4% Friday and 9.4% for the week, falling to a 3-month low.

Stocks extended their gains in early afternoon trade after a sluggish start, despite lower-than-expected U.S. manufacturing data.The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.5% advance, the S&P 500 was up 0.4% and the Nasdaq climbed 0.3%. Volume was tracking lighter across the board vs. the same time Friday.The ISM manufacturing index eased to 50.8 in April, down from 51.8 in March and below economist forecasts for 51.5. But it remained positive for the second consecutive month; a reading above 50 indicates expansion.Food, internet retail and steel stocks led the upside in the stock market today. Amazon.com (AMZN) added 3% in heavy trade. Shares are now extended from a 603.34 buy point and from an alternate handle entry of 638.11. The stock gapped up and soared 10% Friday, after its earnings report late Thursday crushed views. Nomura on Monday set a price target of 775, which represents about 15% upside from Amazon's current level.Goldman Sachs (GS) and McDonald's (MCD) outperformed among blue chips, with respective gains of 1.6% and 1.3%. McDonald's shares are in buy range from a 124.93 flat-base buy point cleared in late March. The fast-food giant has served up robust double-digit profit gains the past three quarters.But Apple (AAPL), down 1% in above-average volume, was the biggest loser on the Dow. The stock is working on its eighth straight loss and has given up 11% since the iPad maker's quarterly results disappointed late Tuesday and it reported a year-over-year iPhone sales decline for the first time. Apple is close to undercutting its late January low.Solar, automakers and oil stocks lagged. West Texas intermediate crude slid more than 2% to $44.82 a barrel. Among oil stocks, Baker Hughes (BHI) reversed from a 5% early spike and sank 3% in massive volume. The oilfield service provider and Halliburton (HAL) called off their $28 billion merger amid antitrust concerns. Halliburton rose 2% in fast trade, on track for a fifth straight advance.Tesla Motors (TSLA) pulled back 1% ahead of its Q1 earnings report due Wednesday after the close. Analysts expect a loss of 58 cents a share on a 45% sales jump to $1.60 billion. Shares have eased following a recent rally but are holding above their 10-week and 40-week lines.

Equity-income mutual funds almost matched the performance by the broad market in the form of the S&P 500 over the past 10 years.The S&P 500 index outperformed equity-income funds as a group over the past decade by averaging a 7.07% yearly gain. That topped the 6.22% average annual gain by equity-income funds.Equity-income funds outperformed during most of the Great Recession. They had better quarterly returns as a group from the fourth quarter of 2007 through Q1 2009. And they were close during the rest of 2009.That's what you expect from equity-income funds. In a market downturn, the income they generate can cushion the blow to investors from declines in stock share prices or at least slower growth of shares.But the broad market bogey came roaring back after the financial crisis. And it outperformed equity-income funds from Q2 2014 through Q4 2015.Look how that adds up. It can give a nice little boost to your overall portfolio or to your retirement nest egg in particular.If you had invested $10,000 in the S&P 500 on March 31, 2006, after 10 years your money would have grown into $20,047.If you had invested the same amount in a cross-section of equity-income funds, it would have swelled to $18,531.In that decade, the now-$520 million Nicholas Equity Income Fund (NSEIX) was the best-performing equity-income fund. It racked up a 9.70% average annual gain in that period.Its 12-month yield is 2.16%. The big-cap bogey's yield is 2.10%.Managed by Albert Nicholas since late 1993 and Michael Shelton since early 2011, the fund had 84% of its shareholders' money in U.S. stocks as of March 31. It had another 8.5% in foreign stocks, and the balance in cash and other types of assets.Consumer cyclicals comprised the fund's largest sector, with a 26% weighting. Health care and technology were the next largest sectors, with weightings of about 14% and 15% respectively.Six Flags Entertainment (SIX), a theme-park operator, is a recent holding that has helped the fund outperform despite a broad market that has been on a roller-coaster ride of its own for nearly six months.Six Flags fell Thursday and Friday amid a broad market pullback. Even so, the stock is up 27% over the past 12 months. Its dividend yield is 3.8%.The average 12-month dividend yield for all equity income funds is 1.94%.On Wednesday the company reported a loss of 51 cents a share for Q1. Still, the outcome was better than seven analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research expected. Their consensus was for a 64 cent loss. And even with the loss, the results were better than the year-earlier quarter, when the company lost 75 cents a share.Six Flag's Q1 revenue of $115.4 million also topped analysts' expectations.EPS grew 52% 105% and 32% the past three quarters.The stock has IBD's Composite Rating of 95. The Composite Rating combines IBD's five performance ratings, including EPS and Relative Strength ratings. Stocks poised to move higher often have a high Comp Rating.AT&T (T) has been another nice performer for the fund. The telecommunication giant's shares are up 11% over the past 12 months.EPS grew 11%, 14%, 15% and 11% the past four stanzas.The stock has a 97 Comp Rating. Its dividend yield is 5%.The company is in the midst of a push into Mexico's wireless phone market. America Movil (AMX) is the incumbent there. Analysts say AT&T's campaign is gaining traction.McDonald's (MCD) (IBD) is up 32% in the past 12 months.EPS rose 28%, 16% and 22% the past three quarters. That reversed four frames in a row of declining EPS. Still, revenue has fallen seven straight quarters.The latest results, which came out last week, showed that the fast-food giant beat quarterly earnings and sales expectations as it continued to benefit from its all-day breakfast and McPick initiatives.McDonald's has an 76 Comp Rating. Its dividend yield is 2.8%.

Monster Beverage said Thursday that it plans to make its highly anticipated entrance in China during the first half of 2016, as a distribution deal with Coca-Cola pushes its energy drinks to more markets around the world.

So far, Monster (MNST) has an agreement with Coca-Cola (KO) for distribution across 28 countries, with a launch in Russia expected by the end of this year, Monster CEO Rodney Sacks said in a conference call.
But the company may not see an immediate pop as it introduces itself to Chinese consumers.
"It is unlikely we will have some massive national launch with TV," Sacks said. "We like to go into a country and focus on that and roll it out. It may mean it takes some time."
Monster is still figuring out how it will launch in China and in what cities, he added.
Sacks also said that Monster has grown its market share over the past three months, and in cases and units, the company is now ahead of rival Red Bull.
Monster stock climbed 8% in extended trading after closing the regular session down 0.4%. Coca-Cola finished 0.9% higher.

In June, Monster closed a deal with Coca-Cola in which it made the soft drink giant Monster's preferred global distribution partner. They also swapped several brands, and Coke took a 17% stake in Monster.

The deal caused problems in Q2, when disruptions related to the distribution shift to Coke hurt Monster's sales growth. Monster cited lower inventories maintained by bottlers in the transitioned territories, plus uncertainties with certain international distributors outside of Coke's network.
But on Thursday, Monster said that distribution is now going more smoothly.
"We are pleased to report good progress on the implementation of our strategic alignment with Coca-Cola bottlers," Sacks said in a statement.
The news helped boost third-quarter results. Adjusted earnings per share jumped 20% to 84 cents, beating analyst consensus by 3 cents. Gross margin widened to 61.5% from 53.8%.
Net revenue climbed 19% to $756.6 million, topping estimates of $735.5 million. Unfavorable currency rates reduced net sales by about $28.6 million in the quarter.

Net sales to customers outside the U.S. grew 25% to $170.6 million. Asia-Pacific sales jumped 43% in dollars, and management said that the Europe-Middle East-Africa market is operating well with improvements in increasing distribution.

Monster is also looking to a recent deal with McDonald's (MCD), which is selling Monster beverages in about 20 of its U.S. restaurants in a trial that could open up a new market for Monster drinks.Monster Beverage said Thursday that it plans to make its highly anticipated entrance in China during the first half of 2016, as a distribution deal with Coca-Cola pushes its energy drinks to more markets around the world.So far, Monster (MNST) has an agreement with Coca-Cola (KO) for distribution across 28 countries, with a launch in Russia expected by the end of this year, Monster CEO Rodney Sacks said in a conference call.But the company may not see an immediate pop as it introduces itself to Chinese consumers."It is unlikely we will have some massive national launch with TV," Sacks said. "We like to go into a country and focus on that and roll it out. It may mean it takes some time."Monster is still figuring out how it will launch in China and in what cities, he added.Sacks also said that Monster has grown its market share over the past three months, and in cases and units, the company is now ahead of rival Red Bull.Monster stock climbed 8% in extended trading after closing the regular session down 0.4%. Coca-Cola finished 0.9% higher.In June, Monster closed a deal with Coca-Cola in which it made the soft drink giant Monster's preferred global distribution partner. They also swapped several brands, and Coke took a 17% stake in Monster.The deal caused problems in Q2, when disruptions related to the distribution shift to Coke hurt Monster's sales growth. Monster cited lower inventories maintained by bottlers in the transitioned territories, plus uncertainties with certain international distributors outside of Coke's network.But on Thursday, Monster said that distribution is now going more smoothly."We are pleased to report good progress on the implementation of our strategic alignment with Coca-Cola bottlers," Sacks said in a statement.The news helped boost third-quarter results. Gross margin widened to 61.5% from 53.8%.Net revenue climbed 19% to $756.6 million, topping estimates of $735.5 million. Unfavorable currency rates reduced net sales by about $28.6 million in the quarter.Net sales to customers outside the U.S. grew 25% to $170.6 million. Asia-Pacific sales jumped 43% in dollars, and management said that the Europe-Middle East-Africa market is operating well with improvements in increasing distribution.Monster is also looking to a recent deal with McDonald's (MCD), which is selling Monster beverages in about 20 of its U.S. restaurants in a trial that could open up a new market for Monster drinks.

McDonald's (MCD) held its annual investor/analyst day Tuesday on the same day that thousands of fast-food workers nationwide held protests calling for higher pay, but the company chose to focus on its growth strategies.The meeting took place as McDonald's eyes ways to better compete against fast-food rivals such as Yum Brands (YUM) — owner of the KFC and Taco Bell chains — as well as fast-casual chains like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Shake Shack (SHAK).During the first hour of the scheduled four-hour meeting, McDonald's Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook and other officials outlined several new goals that the company looks to achieve in coming months."My priorities for McDonald's as a modern, progressive burger company are threefold: driving operational growth, creating brand excitement and enhancing financial value," Easterbrook said. "We are taking bold, urgent action to reset the business and prepare the company for the next chapter of its history."McDonald's constant-currency financial targets for 2016 include systemwide sales growth of 3% to 5% and operating income growth of 5% to 7%, excluding potential charges associated with its refranchising strategy and cost-saving initiatives.More Franchises, Fewer CostsIn terms of refranchising, the company raised its target to 4,000 restaurants from an earlier target of 3,500. This accelerates the pace and increases the global franchised percentage from the current 81% to about 93% by the end of 2018. McDonald's long-term goal is to become 95% franchised.McDonald's also raised its net annual general and administration cost-savings target to $500 million, most of which will be realized by the end of 2017. This reflects a $200 million increase from the previously announced target. The new target excludes the impact of foreign currency changes.In addition, Easterbrook said McDonald's has no plans to spin off its properties into real estate investment trusts, as had been speculated."We have given REITs serious consideration, but we don't believe it serves best the interests of shareholders to pursue REITS at this time," he said.Easterbrook also mentioned plans to grow its store count internationally and improve McDonald's level of efficiency and customer service. It looks to add more restaurants along Germany's Autobahn, for example. Meanwhile, it is looking to change the way it toasts buns and grills meat."We were not executing to our standards," he said. "We were missing customer expectations in too many places. For too long we've asked customers to adapt to us. A big part of turning that around is giving customers more choice and always adapting to meet their needs."Meanwhile, McDonald's board declared a quarterly cash dividend of 89 cents per share of common stock, payable on Dec. 15 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Dec. 1. This represents a 5% increase over its previous quarterly dividend.Protests NationwideWhile the meeting was taking place, fast-food workers in hundreds of U.S. cities held strikes and demonstrations calling for higher wages. It was the largest collection of rallies yet in a cause that seeks to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.The demonstrations began around dawn at McDonald's locations in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities. The protests are expected to continue throughout the U.S. for the remainder of the day and culminate in a rally at the Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee.Earlier this year McDonald's said it would raise wages by more than 10% for workers at U.S. restaurants that it operates, and pay at least $1 more per hour than the local minimum wage for workers at U.S. restaurants.Financially, though, the company has been in a bit of a funk of late. It has logged five straight quarters of lower sales. Year-over-year earnings have declined in four of the last five quarters, though its most recent quarter showed a 28% EPS gain. That kind of performance compares unfavorably to other stocks in IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, including Starbucks (SBUX), Chipotle and Shake Shack.Even so, McDonald's stock price has been on a nice roll lately. Shares hit a fresh high of 113.96 on Oct. 26 and are up more than 10% since Oct. 21.Growth DriversIn a Monday morning note, RBC analyst David Palmer said McDonald's stock price has mainly been driven by gains in return on invested capital as well as recent earnings growth and earnings-per-share revisions.EPS growth has been driven in part by same-store sales gains in international markets, he said.On the downside, U.S. comps "(have) dramatically slowed," Palmer noted. "The company's struggles inside the U.S. have been the most troubling since declining same-store sales have been the result of significant share losses in an otherwise healthy U.S. fast food market in 2015."On a more positive note, McDonald's recent decision to offer an all-day breakfast menu has been a success."We believe that McDonald's consumer base is broader at breakfast, so increased availability of breakfast items could inspire trial of other core items and day parts," Palmer said.McDonald's shares rose 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks added 1.4%, while Chipotle climbed 3.2% and Yum lost 0.3%.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.
Stocks flirted with positive territory, but dipped back into the red with just over an hour left to go in Tuesday's regular session.

The S&P 500 was fractionally lower and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq continued to lag with a 0.5% loss. Volume was mixed, tracking sharply higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq vs. the same time Monday.

Solar, video game software and automakers were among the biggest decliners in the stock market today. Tesla Motors (TSLA) skidded 3% in fast trade as the stock remains below its 50-day moving average, where it's been stuck for over a month.

Morgan Stanley said in a note that it expects Q4 and 2016 deliveries to be lower than Tesla's forecasts and that the company will burn up to $1 billon in cash over the next 12 months. It maintained a 450 price target. Tesla is now trading around 218.

Tech stocks weighed on the Dow, as Apple (AAPL) gapped down and fell 4% and Microsoft (MSFT) shed 1.4%, both in above-average volume. Credit Suisse said Apple cut production orders for its iPhone 6s by up to 10%, which sent its supplier stocks down too.
Avago Technologies (AVGO) led IBD 50 losers with a 4% drop. The Apple chip supplier fell below the 50-day moving average, which it had regained on Friday.

CyberArk Software (CYBR) sank 8% in heavy trade, extending its losing streak to four. Bank of America downgraded the security software company to neutral from buy and cut its price target to 48 from 80.

On the upside, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gained nearly 3%. The fast-casual restaurant operator said it will reopen in a few days 43 stores in the Seattle and Portland, Ore., areas that it had voluntarily closed due to an E. coli outbreak. The stock is 18% off its Aug. 5 peak.

McDonald's (MCD), which spun off Chipotle in 2006, reversed higher. The fast-food giant said it will not spin off its real estate assets. It upped the number of restaurants that it plans to franchise to 4,000 from 3,500.

Investors are hopped up on Starbucks' (SBUX) stock ahead of the coffee giant's next earnings report late Thursday. Analysts expect the coffee giant's earnings in its fiscal Q4 ending in September to climb 17% over last year to 43 cents a share. It would be the 15th straight quarter of double-digit gains but a slowdown from Q3's 24% rise, which analyst Jeffrey Bernstein of Barclays dubbed one of the "strongest and most remarkable quarters" in its history.

Revenue in the quarter is seen growing 17% as well, to $4.897 billion, according to Thomson Reuters' analyst poll. Blended revenue estimates for the consumer discretionary sector in the September ending quarter pegs growth at 4.1%. Blended earnings growth in the consumer discretionary sector is seen rising 13.2%.
Analysts expect Q4 comparable store sales growth of 6.7%.
Shares closed up 1.3% to 63.43, a new high, on the stock market today.

Investors and analysts will be watching for commentary on Starbucks' relatively new, line-skipping mobile order and pay app, which has been ramping up in stores at a faster pace than expected. Analysts say the order-ahead app is helping to grow mobile usage and membership in the company's rewards program.

"There's no question that mobile order and pay is the major initiative that's capturing consumer and analysts' imagination," analyst David Palmer of RBC Capital Markets told IBD earlier this month. "They are leading the industry in this initiative."

Meanwhile, coffee prices declined further in the last month of the quarter and in late September were 38% lower than a year earlier, according to Goldman Sachs, which also noted that Starbucks' "aggressive pricing" in ground-coffee single-serve and packaged coffee was translating into share gains.

Among restaurant companies, Starbucks is second only to McDonald's (MCD) in sales and market capitalization. Last week McDonald's, which is in the midst of turnaround efforts, reported that Q3 same-store sales in the U.S. rose for the first time in two years, up 0.9%, while global comps grew 4%. Earnings jumped 28% from the earlier year to $1.40, beating views by 13 cents.

McDonald shares jumped 8% after last week's quarterly report to a new high. Tesla (TSLA), McDonald’s (MCD) and General Electric (GE) all got higher price targets Monday, while media/entertainment giants 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and CBS (CBS) also saw analyst action.Goldman Sachs raised its price target on Tesla to 245 from 230 and maintained its neutral rating on the stock. The electric car maker’s stock price is up about 80% since touching a more than two-year low of 141.05 on Feb. 9.Shares of Tesla rose early but closed down 0.8% to 251.62 on the stock market today.General Electric’s stock price was hiked to 35 from 33 at RBC Capital Markets, which maintained its outperform rating on the stock. On Friday, GE topped quarterly earnings views but reported sluggish organic revenue growth.Shares of GE dipped 0.3% to 30.66 after losing 0.7% Friday. So far GE stock is finding support at the 50-day line.McDonald’s stock price target was raised to 140 from 135 at RBC Capital Markets, which rates the stock an outperform. Cowen & Co. also raised its price target on McDonald’s to 127 from 125 and maintained its market perform rating.On Friday, the fast-food giant beat quarterly earnings and sales views as it continued to benefit from its all-day breakfast and McPick initiatives. McDonald's rose 1.6% Monday to 127.46 after falling intraday to 125.01, nearly undercutting its 124.93 buy point.Wedbush raised its price target on 21st Century Fox to 34 from 33 and its price target on CBS to 63 from 60. 21st Century Fox rose 0.4% and CBS fell 0.35%.Honeywell (HON) got a couple of price target hikes following Friday’s better-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings results. Stifel raised its price target on the stock to 129 from 127 and maintained its buy rating on the stock. RBC Capital Markets raised its price target to 122 from 121 and maintained its outperform rating on the stock. Honeywell, which announced a $5 billion stock buyback Monday morning, fell 0.8% to 113.25.LinkedIn (LNKD) saw its price target lowered to 130 from 200 at Wedbush, which has a neutral rating on the stock. LinkedIn, which reports earnings on Thursday, rose 0.9% to 120.48.

Macy's (M) dismal first-quarter results and guidance Wednesday bolstered views of Amazon's (AMZN) unrelenting dominance, sending shares of the department store chain -- and most stocks in the retail and consumer sectors -- down.Companies ranging from Wal-Mart (WMT) to Michael Kors (KORS) to Nike (NKE) to Tiffany (TIF) to Williams-Sonoma (WSM), sold off. But Amazon stock rose 1.45%, hitting a fresh high.Macy's report followed Gap's (GPS) forecast late Monday of a 5% drop in Q1 same-store sales and weak earnings. The chain also noted a "tepid macro environment for apparel retail.""In light of AMZN and M's recent results, we feel more confident that AMZN will displace M as the #1 US Apparel retailer by '17," wrote Cowen analyst John Blackledge in a Wednesday note, doubling down on his assessment from last year.Macy's earnings fell 29% to 40 cents a share, 4 cents above views, on a 7% revenue decline to $5.77 billion that fell short of estimates for $5.93 billion.Same-store sales -- sales at facilities open more than a year -- at both Macy's-owned outlets and licensed operators dropped 5.6%. For Macy's-owned stores only, comps fell 6.1%.Shares plunged 15.2% on the stock market today to the lowest since December 2011. Kohl's (KSS) and Nordstrom (JWN), which report Thursday, fell 6% and 7%, respectively. JCPenney (JCP), which reports Friday, lost 1.85%. On Monday, it said it topped its own goal for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization.IBD's Take: Is Macy's a premium or discount stock? And how does it compare to retail rivals? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupMacy's is still in the best position among its department store peers, said Retail Metrics' Ken Perkins, despite Macy's recent struggles, although "Amazon is doing so many things that a retailer like a Macy's, Target (TGT), Wal-Mart . . . just aren’t able or willing to do."Adding to the sell-off was Macy's warning on weak consumer spending. Shares of companies not in direct competition with Amazon dropped as well, including McDonald's (MCD) and Panera (PNRA)."We are seeing continued weakness in consumer spending levels for apparel and related categories," Macy's Chief Executive Terry Lundgren said in a statement. "In particular, our sales trend relative to expectations meaningfully slowed beginning in mid-March, and first-quarter results are below our original outlook."The company now sees full-year per-share profit of $3.15-$3.40, down from its previous outlook of $3.80-$3.90 and far below Wall Street estimates for $3.80 a share. It also expects 2016 same-store sales on an owned-plus-licensed basis to fall 3%-4%, vs. prior outlook for a 1% decline."We are not counting on the consumer to spend more," Lundgren said, so the department store is "working harder to give customers more reasons to buy from us by delivering outstanding style, quality and value."For the second straight year, tourist spending is falling in the double digits, he said, and noted a slowdown in some "center core" categories. But he also said that the first quarter is a "relatively small portion of the total year" and sees a chance to play catch-up over the next three quarters.Still, Macy's isn't exactly the next Sears Holdings (SHLD), which has seen years of falling sales and store closures."That's a leap," laughed Perkins, though he also said the department store's current struggles are more than just a bump in the road.But like Sears, Macy's is evaluating real-estate proposals for joint ventures or similar arrangements. Macy's has been under pressure to spin off its real estate holdings to raise cash.

Shares of McDonald’s (MCD) rose Friday after the fast-food giant delivered another robust quarter, driven by the continued success of its all-day breakfast menu, as well as positive results from its McPick initiative.McDonald’s earned $1.23 a share in the first quarter, up 22% vs. a year earlier and 7 cents above consensus analyst views. It was the third straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth -- the first time that’s happened in five years.Quarterly revenue dipped 1% to $5.9 billion but still topped estimates for $5.8 billion. It was the sixth straight year-over-year revenue decline but the smallest drop in that string. Sales would have risen 3% excluding the strong dollar.U.S. same-store sales rose 5.4% year over year, which also beat consensus. Global comps rose 6.2% excluding currency shifts, helped by an extra day due to the leap year.McDonald’s shares rose 2% shortly after the opening bell on the stock market today but soon erased their gains and closed down 0.2%. The stock touched a new intraday high of 129.80 on Wednesday but fell nearly 3% Thursday. Shares broke out of a consolidation to a new high on March 30, but in weak volume.Can McDonald's, Other Quick-Service Franchises Digest $15 Minimum Wage?Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook said in a prepared statement that the turnaround plan McDonald's announced last year is "taking hold." That plan includes the all-day breakfast menu launched in the fall, as well as this year’s McPick 2 for $5 promotion."The ongoing investments we’re making in running great restaurants and delivering what matters most to our customers are beginning to yield sustained positive results," Easterbrook said. "For the quarter, we generated higher sales, revenues and operating income in constant currencies across all business segments."Another element of the turnaround plan has been an aggressive move to refranchise restaurants. Over the past five quarters McDonald’s has refranchised about 700 restaurants, JPMorgan analyst Virginia Chambless noted in a report. That figures includes 200 restaurants during the first quarter.McDonald’s recently announced plans to start selling Johnsonville Brats again after a seven-year hiatus, perhaps in response to a recent move by rival Burger King to sell hot dogs at its restaurants. Starting April 25, brats will return to menus at 125 McDonald’s locations in southeast Wisconsin.Another potential growth driver is McDonald’s expansion in Asia. The company recently said it will add more than 1,500 locations in China, including Hong Kong and South Korea over the next five years. It already has more than 2,800 locations in those markets, most of which are company-owned. This time McDonald’s is looking for "strategic partners" to help in its Asia expansion."This will allow McDonald's to accelerate our growth and scale faster across diverse markets, placing us closer to our customers and the communities we serve," Easterbrook said. "We're in the midst of transforming our business and taking a strategic and thoughtful approach to enhance our ability to grow around the world. These actions build on our turnaround efforts and will advance local ownership, enable faster decision-making and achieve restaurant growth."It might take awhile for McDonald’s ambitious Asia expansion to be completed, however."The company continues to search for a strategic partner in Asia but cautioned the process could take 12 to 18 months," Chambless noted.McDonald’s isn’t the only fast-food chain to enjoy a rebound on Wall Street. Shares of Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) is up 10%, edging higher Friday morning.Shares of Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) have risen about 12% this year. But Yum suffered a reversal Thursday: Shares jumped as much as 4%, breaking out to an eight-month high on strong Q1 earnings and raised guidance. But shares closed down 1% on that day. They fell 0.6% Friday.

McDonald's (MCD) won few plaudits a year ago when, under fire from the Fight for $15 movement, it hiked the starting wage in its company-owned stores to $1 over the minimum. Union organizers were far from satisfied. The hike upped the company’s average hourly wage to just above $10 an hour, and it only applied to workers at the roughly 1,500…

Apple (AAPL) shares moved higher Friday after the iPhone maker was upgraded, while McDonald's (MCD) and Amazon (AMZN) got price-target hikes but Biogen's (BIIB) price target was cut.

Maxim Group upgraded Apple to buy from hold and also raised its price target on the stock to 167 from 144. Through a recent partnership with Cisco Systems (CSCO), Apple looks to sell more iPads and iPhones to business customers and to enable those devices to run Cisco's videoconferencing and other products.
Apple shares closed up 3.1% on thestock market today. Cisco climbed 1.2%.
Amazon's stock increased 6.2% after its price target was raised to 775 from 705 by RBC Capital Markets, which has an outperform rating on the stock.
On Thursday, Amazon topped Q3 earnings and revenue views, driven by a top-line lift from its Prime Day promotion, as well as a strong performance from its cloud offerings.

Another Internet giant, Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), shot up 5.6% after scoring price-target hikes from FBR Capital and RBC Capital Markets. FBR raised the target to 809 from 749, while RBC raised it to 880 from 750.
Late Thursday, Alphabet topped quarterly earnings and revenue estimates and OK'd a $5 billion share repurchase.

McDonald's shares added 1.55% after its price target was raised to 120 from 110 by RBC Capital Markets. The fast-food giant's stock price rose 8% to a new high on Thursday following strong Q3 earnings and sales.
Leading biotech Biogen rose less than 0.1% despite having its price target cut to 360 from 380 by H.C. Wainwright.

Microsoft (MSFT) soared 10% after its price target was raised to 57 from 54 at RBC Capital Markets, which has an outperform rating on the name. Late Thursday, the software giant posted much better-than-expected September quarter results.
Dunkin Brands (DNKN) added 3.3% even though it was downgraded to neutral by Piper Jaffray. On Thursday, the doughnut chain topped quarterly EPS and revenue views, but the stock lost 3.6%.
Wells Fargo resumed coverage on Visa (V) with an outperform rating. Visa shares rose 0.85% Friday.

Stock ETFs ended the week mixed amid a steady drumbeat of lackluster corporate results, but with investor  sentiment getting a boost from a third week of gains for oil.SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) rose modestly on the stock market today for a weekly gain of 0.7%.The ETF holds all of the Dow's 30 industrial leaders. Three key stock holdings -- Caterpillar (CAT), General Electric (GE) and McDonald's (MCD) -- reported earnings before the opening bell.All three stocks fell into the close. Caterpillar, an industrial equipment manufacturer, lowered its revenue outlook for 2016, while describing positive signals out of China as a bright spot.DIA now sits a mere 1% below its May high.Investors in tech-heavy ETFs were less lucky.PowerShares QQQ (QQQ) stumbled 1.5% for the day as well as for the week. The ETF invests in nonfinancial stocks in the Nasdaq.Among its top five holdings, Microsoft (MSFT) tumbled nearly 9%, and Alphabet (GOOGL) lost nearly 6% as earnings disappointed.IBD's Take: How healthy are shares of Alphabet, Microsoft and Starbucks? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupTech giant Alphabet's "Other Bets" segment -- including smart-home device maker Nest, health care segment Verily and high-speed Internet service Google Fiber -- was a soft spot. The company also continues to face foreign-currency headwinds.Energy was the week's best-performing sector, warming up 5.5%. Utilities fared worst, cooling 3.2%.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) fell Friday as the dollar rose against a basket of world currencies. Gold and the U.S. dollar tend to move in opposite directions.GLD, an IBD Leaderboard ETF, finished the week below its 50-day moving average of 118.35.Here's a look at how the major exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), 0%, RS 60PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -1.5%, RS 47SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +0.1%, RS 67IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +0.9%, RS 67IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.0%, RS 52IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +0.1%, RS 38Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.4%, RS 47SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -1.3%, RS 75IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), 0%, RS 47PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.6%, RS 30IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -2.5%, RS 9

Tech stocks took some hard early hits Friday, but action was much quieter in the S&P 500 and the Dow.The Nasdaq lost 0.7%. The S&P 500 and Dow were mostly unchanged.The stock market today slips into Friday's session with slender gains: the S&P 500 is up 0.5% for the week. The Nasdaq holds less than a 0.2% gain. But nearly two-thirds of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD advanced for the week through Thursday, with steel makers, ore miners, enterprise software developers and pipeline operators among those posting gains of 5% or more. On the downside, homebuilders, computer makers and meat producers were among the hardest hit.Friday's few scheduled economic reports include a preliminary manufacturing purchasing managers index estimate from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET. Baker Hughes (BHI) delivers its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m.WTI crude oil futures for June delivery rose nearly 2% to $43.92 a barrel. Gold eased a few bucks to around $1,247 an ounce -- still up more than 1% for the week. Silver and platinum were ahead more than 5% for the week. Natural gas added 1% Friday, nearing a 10% weekly gain. The dollar gained strength, particularly against the yen. Bonds held effectively flat.In stocks, big names were in motion all over the map.Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL) shed 7% and 4%, respectively, in early trading.Late Thursday, Microsoft's fiscal Q3 sales and earnings missed consensus expectations, and management's revenue guidance stopped short of analyst estimates. Alphabet earnings and sales also missed targets in its Q1 report. Analyst chatter was active in both stocks Friday.Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V) dropped 3% in early action following their quarterly reports late Thursday. Visa said spending in the U.S. remained "reasonably strong," but a strong dollar and weak oil prices were creating headwinds in cross-border spending. Starbucks earnings met, but revenue missed analyst projections.McDonald's (MCD) edged 0.4% higher.  Its Q1 earnings jumped 22% and easily topped expectations. Revenue slipped less than expected and global same store sales rose more than 6%, vs. expectations of less than 5%. The stock ended Thursday less than 1% above a 124.93 buy point from a seven-week cup base.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) spiked 24% on news revenue slipped less than expected in Q1, and guidance implied a possible turnaround after seven quarters of revenue declines. Losses for the quarter were also slightly lighter than forecast, and the company announced a $293 million deal to license its processor technology to Tianjin Haiguang Advanced Technology Investment, a unit of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.Hanesbrands (HBI) bolted 6% higher after reporting positive Q1 results late Thursday. The clothing maker's shares have been fighting to regain and hold support at their 40-week moving average since July.

Mkts went into reverse yesterday.....as earnings seasons moves on and investors/traders struggle with how overvalued/overbought the mkt is based on broader macro economic conditions and very mixed earnings reports - ...the dollar ended the day higher sending oil and other commodities lower as investors reconsider the prospect of higher rates here in the US when the FED meets next week. Once again - many are left asking - Could the FED surprise the mkts and hike in April? Let me be clear - in the words of Luis Enrique - "Yo no se manana..." (I don't know about tomorrow)...but I do know that today - the answer to that question is NO WAY!Once again - you got some of the talking heads suggesting that the US economy is so strong that rates need to rise sooner rather than later - the most recent Hawk is Eric Rosengren - Boston's Fed President as he re-iterated 'his' opinion on Monday that the FED'was closer to raising rates than many investors anticipate.... and that the mkt may be underestimating the FED's pace of tightening'Ok sports fans - here we go again.....all the talk of the next FED move just days ahead of their meeting and the end of the month..... Now while I believe that we won't get a move in April - I do expect the FED to leave the door wide open for the June hike (as expected). To add fuel to that fire we heard from Peter Gorra - head of FX trading at BNP Paribas......(Forex - FX - trading is defined as the global decentralized mkt for the trading of currencies - buying, selling and exchanging them at current prices). Currencies are very sensitive to any move in rates so - Peter does sit at the center of speculation.....and he thinks that"U.S. data has actually been pretty good, and there is very little chance of a June move by the Fed priced in,"Ok - first - US data has been pretty good? Really? Let me count thy ways:Yesterday's Philly Fed report - big disappointment, Earlier in this month alone we learned that ISM NY - disappointed, Empire State Manf - disappointed, labor mkt conditions - disappointed, Factory orders - disappointed, Factory orders ex Transports - disappointed, Durable Goods - disappointed, Durables Ex transports -disappointed, Wholesale inventories - disappointed, Wholesale trade - disappointed, Retail Sales - a big disappointment, PPI - oh right - negative, PPI ex food and energy - negative, Construction Spending - negative, Industrial production - another negative.....but so much for the negatives...lets accentuate the positives shall we?Non Farm payrolls - met expectations in terms of 'jobs created' - never mind that they are low wage, temporary (let's ignore that fact), and forget the fact that layoffs hit a 6 month high in January with daily headlines of more 'restructurings' (layoffs) as we move thru earnings season.... US Markit ISM met expectations (positive), ISM Manf -beat, ISM Prices Paid - beat, Oh and the Univ of Mich sentiment survey was 'better than expected', and Earnings reports - yeah - they are missing top line organic growth, yet still beating embarrassingly low earnings estimates - but hey - a beat is a beat and that is positive...so maybe Pete is on the right track.....But as far as the mkt NOT pricing in a June hike - I would disagree - the FED has been quite clear on that point...she has left the June door wide open - if investors have not heard that call of the wild - then they are living under a rock.....Now the real question is not if they have heard the call - the question is Do they believe the call? And that is up for discussion - because here is where I do agree with Peter.....if investors do not believe her and ignore the calls for higher rates and then she in fact moves on rates - then he is right - investors will scream - what the ...?Given Yellen's clear dovish stance, the mkts are not looking for any rate hike this month at all, but we are seeing a small pullback - which reflects just a bit of 'uncertainty' as some investors/traders recede to the sidelines.....but then I expect that next week we will get the usual ramp up when it is clear that rates will go nowhere. Look - the Fed is worried about the both the US and the global economies and feels a bit trapped...... So - next week expect more 'nothing done'.Yesterday's ECB press conference doesn't help.....He (Mario Draghi) did nothing in terms of another policy move but did leave the door open to further negative interest-rate cuts....oh...and that is another sure sign of 'strength'! This morning we wake up to the latest Japanese headline - Hold on this one is good....."BoJ Officials Are Said to Eye Possible Negative Rates on Loans" - Yes - you read that correctly.....the headline suggests that the BoJ may consider offering NEGATIVE rates on some loans (in addition the negative rates on deposits) in order to stimulate their economy....... So the bank will pay YOU to borrow money to invest......Does the word 'desperation' come to mind at all?This morning US futures are once again hovering around the unchanged line...initially lower by 3 pts in early trading - but have now recovered a bit and are slightly positive at 7 am. There are no economic reports today to speak of , but we will get another slew of earnings....Caterpillar (CAT)and McDonald's (MCD) will hit the tape prior to the opening while Alcoa (AA), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), Sun Trust (STI) report post close. Traders will now get a chance to react to last nights announcements from Alphabet (GOOGL) and General Electric (GE)...Alphabet missed on both the top and the bottom line (that was surprising) - the stock sold off 5% in the moments after the announcement and are trading at $722/sh right now.GE on the other hand beat the estimates but is also seeing some profit taking in their stock in early morning trading. Trading at $30.65 down 0.30 cts.As we approach the end of April you would expect to see is a narrowing of market breadth and this is exactly what we are currently seeing. The S&P is testing the November 2015 highs (just over 2100) and hitting a wall......Relative Strength (RSI) which began to roll over in March is suggesting market breadth is narrowing or that fewer and fewer stocks are holding up the indexes as money moves into the largest blue chip companies (think safety) typical of what you would see ahead of an expected correction.Now that being said - there are so many other things to consider......The Fed and the fact that we are in a Presidential election year.....and we are in the 8th year of the current presidency... and historically, the mkts tend to peak in April and then suffer for the rest of the year.Since 1900, the S&P has on average, fallen by 1.2% in the 8th year of a presidential term, with the market rising only 44 percent of the time. This summer will be very interesting.....History shows us (82% if the time) that if stocks rise between July 31 and October 31, then we can expect the incumbent party to win in November (Think Hillary).....BUT If stocks fall, (86% of the time) then the thinking is that a new party will take over. (Think Trump) ....so will history repeat itself or not?I expect the mkt to continue to churn and challenge resistance right here at 2100........I do not expect any major move in either direction until next week's FED announcement. Remember - it is also month end - so expect some window dressing as we move thru next week.
Take good care. Have a great weekend.Take Good Care

Yum Brands (YUM) reported strong first-quarter profit growth Wednesday, with its soon-to-be separated China operations showing marked improvement as bidders weigh an acquisition of the unit.Based on the strong results, Yum raised its full-year core operating profit growth guidance to 12%, up from 10% previously.Yum shares climbed 3.8% in extended trading after closing up 0.5% at 82.53 in regular session trading on the stock market today. Yum had formed a nearly eight-month-long cup-with-handle base and rose above the 82.90 buy point intraday Wednesday. The stock now looks to break out on strong volume Thursday.Companywide earnings per share minus one-time items climbed 19% to 95 cents vs. the same quarter a year earlier, beating estimates by 12 cents a share.Revenue of $2.619 billion was essentially flat vs. last year's $2.622 billion, but it missed forecasts for $2.65 billion. Global sales at stores open at least a year rose 2%.Foreign-currency translation negatively impacted operating profit by $28 million, leading to a 12% rise in operating profit to $564 million.CEO Greg Creed said all four of the company's divisions posted positive same-store sales and core operating profit growth."I’m especially encouraged by the continued turnaround of our Pizza Hut U.S. business, which delivered 5% same-store sales growth," he said in a statement.The China division, which accounts for about half of Yum's business, saw system sales increase 6%, or 11% excluding foreign-currency moves. Same-store sales grew 6%. Operating profit jumped 35%.The growth is encouraging ahead of the unit’s spinoff, following food-safety scares in recent years that sent sales plunging."KFC China had an outstanding Chinese New Year bucket promotion leading to 12% same-store sales growth for the quarter,” Creed said.Yum plans to spin off its China restaurants by the end of 2016 and expects to add 600 stores there this year, pushing its total to 7,800. Yum China has an estimated value of $7 billion-$8 billion.An investor group that includes China's sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corp., KKR & Co. (KKR) and Baring Private Equity Asia is in talks to buy a controlling stake in Yum's China unit, according to reports.Creed said the company's plan to spin off its China restaurants business remains on track to close by end of the year.Meanwhile, KFC's system sales dipped 2%, but they rose 5% excluding forex. Comparable sales edged up 1%. Operating profit fell 4%, but adjusted core profit rose 7%.Pizza Hut's system sales increased 1%, or 4% excluding forex, as comp sales climbed 3%. Operating profit improved 7%.Taco Bell's system sales rose 3%, as comps edged up 1%. Operating profit grew 4%.Yum opened 295 new restaurants worldwide, with 72% of international development occurring in emerging markets.The world's largest restaurant company, McDonald's (MCD), is slated to announce Q1 results Friday before the market opens. Consensus is for EPS to rise 15% to $1.16 on a 2.3% decline in revenue against difficult comps.A resurgent McDonald's beat earnings estimates the prior three quarters in a row. Shares edged down 0.2% Wednesday.Among other large, highly-rated restaurant companies, Domino's Pizza (DPZ) -- which is on the IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks -- rose to yet another all-time high at 140.01, up 1.8% for the day. Popular drive-in restaurant chain Sonic (SONC) fell 0.9%, and food and games restaurant Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) climbed 1.7% to 40.07.

Monster Beverage (MNST) is on track for its biggest gain in over two months as it climbs in heavy volume in the stock market today. The gain comes on the heels of an Evercore ISI report that said McDonald's (MCD) is testing the energy-drink maker's beverages at some of its locations and has seen "positive results."
According to the analyst, Monster could see as much as $1.5 billion in additional U.S. revenue with the new quick-serve restaurant distribution channel.
Shares jumped over 7% intraday to retake the 50-day moving average, which Monster hasn't traded above for eight weeks.
Just last week, the stock breached its 200-day line and closed below that level for the first time in over a year.
Monster is now trading about 11% below its early August peak as it works on the right side of a consolidation pattern.

In June, Monster and Coca-Cola (KO) sealed their deal to transfer all of the energy-drink maker's U.S. and Canada distribution to the soda giant, which now owns about a 17% stake in Monster. Coke and Monster also swapped ownership of several brands.
Coke and McDonald's have been in an alliance for decades, so the testing of Monster's beverages seems logical for the fast-food behemoth.

China on Friday cut interest rates for the sixth time since November, trying to revive flagging growth. On Thursday, European Central Bank President Mario Draghi gave strong indications that the ECB would boost stimulus efforts in December.

The one-two punch has turbocharged stock prices, but it's also lifted the dollar, adding to pressure on U.S. companies such as General Electric (GE), Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Procter & Gamble (PG), 3M (MMM) and McDonald's (MCD).

The dollar had been easing in recent weeks following the Federal Reserve's decision to not to raise interest rates at its September meeting. But with overseas central banks easing or signaling action — and a December Fed rate hike still an option — the greenback is powering up.

Procter & Gamble topped earnings forecasts Friday, but sales fell more than expected. The consumer products giant now says that currency swings will cut full-year sales by 5%-6%, vs. prior targets of 4%-5%. But shares rose 3.3% Friday afternoon as P&G pledged to boost organic sales in the current quarter.
3M on Thursday announced new job cuts as it cited forex. 3M shares popped 4% on Thursday.

General Electric and McDonald's also noted the strong dollar's impact as they reported lower revenue this month. But profits topped expectations, sending GE shares to a 7-year best and McDonald's stock to an all-time high.

Even Alphabet announced a $1.6 billion currency hit — $1.3 billion after hedges — in Thursday night's Q3 report. Google still delivered strong earnings and revenue growth, sending the stock soaring Friday to a record high.China on Friday cut interest rates for the sixth time since November, trying to revive flagging growth. On Thursday, European Central Bank President Mario Draghi gave strong indications that the ECB would boost stimulus efforts in December.The one-two punch has turbocharged stock prices, but it's also lifted the dollar, adding to pressure on U.S. companies such as General Electric (GE), Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Procter & Gamble (PG), 3M (MMM) and McDonald's (MCD).The dollar had been easing in recent weeks following the Federal Reserve's decision to not to raise interest rates at its September meeting. But with overseas central banks easing or signaling action — and a December Fed rate hike still an option — the greenback is powering up.Procter & Gamble topped earnings forecasts Friday, but sales fell more than expected. The consumer products giant now says that currency swings will cut full-year sales by 5%-6%, vs. prior targets of 4%-5%. But shares rose 3.3% Friday afternoon as P&G pledged to boost organic sales in the current quarter.3M on Thursday announced new job cuts as it cited forex. 3M shares popped 4% on Thursday.General Electric and McDonald's also noted the strong dollar's impact as they reported lower revenue this month. But profits topped expectations, sending GE shares to a 7-year best and McDonald's stock to an all-time high.Even Alphabet announced a $1.6 billion currency hit — $1.3 billion after hedges — in Thursday night's Q3 report. Google still delivered strong earnings and revenue growth, sending the stock soaring Friday to a record high.

Stocks took a bold turn Thursday, rising in fast trade and keeping virtually all of the day's sizable gains. The Nasdaq gained 1.6%, the S&P 500 thrust 1.7% higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average booked a 1.9% gain. McDonald's (MCD) had a 8% romp that boosted the Dow after the fast-food king reported better-than-expected quarterly results. Small caps trailed…

Stocks took a bold turn Thursday, rising in fast trade and keeping virtually all of the day's sizable gains. The Nasdaq gained 1.6%, the S&P 500 thrust 1.7% higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average booked a 1.9% gain. McDonald's (MCD) had a 8% romp that boosted the Dow after the fast-food king reported better-than-expected quarterly results. Small caps trailed…
Stocks sprinted out of the starting gate Thursday, riding a storm surge of earnings reports.The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq powered up 1.2% apiece. The S&P 500 jumped 1.1%.
The stock market today rolled out in strong trade, with volume on the Nasdaq rising 8% and NYSE volume up 33% over what were also strong early volume numbers on Wednesday.
Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims rising less than expected and the important four-week moving average declining for a fifth straight week.

Housing news was weak, with the Federal Housing Finance Agency's Housing Price Index rising 0.3% for August. That was half the pace of July's increase and below consensus expectations for a 0.5% gain.
Economic indicators were also soft. The Conference Board's Leading Indicators Index for September slipped 0.2%, down from a flat reading in August below expectations for another month of zero change.

Existing-home sales were more positive, up nearly 5% in September to an annualized rate of 5.55 million, according to the National Association of Realtors. Consensus estimates predicted a mild uptick to 5.35 million.
On the Dow, McDonald's (MCD) soared 7% and American Express (AXP) crumbled 6% after reporting Q3 results.

Big cap eBay (EBAY) swept ahead 12% at the open to lead both the Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500. The online retail/auction site reported late Wednesday its third-quarter earnings topped consensus expectations. Revenue slipped 2% but matched consensus forecasts. Management raised its full-year earnings outlook to meet analyst consensus. The gain punched shares back above the stock's converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, to within 9% of its July high.

Texas Instruments (TXN) left the chute with a 9% gain. The Dallas-based chipmaker reported late Wednesday a third-quarter earnings and revenue beat. Revenue slipped 2%, also better than expected, and management hoisted Q4 earnings guidance above forecasts. The stock is up 30% from a late-August low and back above critical levels of support in a seven-month consolidation.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) spiked 10% on a broad third-quarter beat, with earnings, revenue and guidance all topping expectations. Management also announced after Wednesday's close it had appointed Executive Chairman Robert Calderoni as interim president and chief executive. Citrix CEO Mark Templeton announced his retirement in July. The gain left shares till in buying range, 4% above a 76.28 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Hospital stocks were under significant pressure in early trade. Community Health Systems (CYH) tanked 30% as the hospital operator suffered a flourish of downgrades after warning late Wednesday that its third-quarter earnings and revenue would miss consensus estimates. Tenet Healthcare (THC) tumbled 17%. Universal Health Services  (UHS) down 9% and HCA (HCA) fell 5%.
An important after-hours session includes quarterly reports from Amazon.com (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOGL), as well as Microsoft (MSFT), AT&T (T) and Altera (ALTR).

As restaurant earnings season kicks into high gear this week, one of the hottest stocks in the group — Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) — will be going up against the toughest store-level sales comps in the industry when it reports third-quarter results late Tuesday. Industry giant McDonald's (MCD), which is in the early stages of domestic turnaround efforts, and drive-in…

With the market in a confirmed uptrend, top-rated stocks such as Amazon (AMZN) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) are good prospects for a stock watch list.The Internet giants are among five key earnings reports slated for Thursday, along with McDonald's (MCD), Skechers (SKX) and Under Armour (UA).AmazonAmazon said on Tuesday that it will hire 100,000 for the critical holiday season. Many of those employees will ship packages to Amazon Prime members, who pay $99 a year for free shipping and video streaming. Amazon has around 47 million U.S. Prime users who spend about $1,200 a year each on its site, MarketWatch recently reported, citing Consumer Intelligence Research Partners data.Consensus is for e-commerce leader Amazon to report a 13-cent per share loss, improved from a 95 cent loss in Q3 2014. If Amazon tops estimates, it would be the third time in the last four quarters. Revenue is expected to jump 21% to $24.91 billion. That would be the best sales gain in five quarters.Under ArmourSome analysts project that athletic clothing, shoes and accessories maker Under Armour got a boost from back-to-school sales, continuing its four-year-plus streak of double-digit quarterly sales gains.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Q3 EPS minus one-time items to rise 7% to 44 cents, reversing the prior quarter's 12% decline. Q3 sales are expected to rise 25.3% to $1.175 billion, a bit lower than the 29% pop it saw in Q2 but still a strong gain. Cowen & Co. analyst John Kernan is more bullish, forecasting 45 cents EPS on 26% sales growth, led by a 35% surge in footwear, "in line with management's guidance," Kernan said in a report.AlphabetAs of early October, Google became a unit of Alphabet, an umbrella company that includes the company's future-looking projects such as research into how to improve human longevity and contact lenses that measure glucose levels to relieve diabetics from painful pinpricks.Analysts will look for info on how Google mobile search is faring. Mobile revenue is expected to top desktop search revenue next year, Evercore ISI said in a recent report. Under its new structure, the Google business — search, YouTube, Android and most of the previous company — have become the biggest segment within Alphabet.Consensus is for Alphabet to report $18.5 billion Q3 revenue, up 12% vs. the same quarter a year ago. EPS is expected to rise 13% to $7.20.Skechers USAIBD 50 stock Nike (NKE) has long dominated the athletic shoe market, but Skechers — although much smaller — is gaining acceptance as a top athletic brand, analysts say. BB&T launched coverage on Skechers last Thursday with a buy rating and a 150 price target, citing Skechers' "appealing assortment of lower-price technical footwear."Skechers has also become the category leader in walking shoes, with a 22% market share. Analysts expect a 67% surge in Q3 EPS to 55 cents, continuing a two-year streak of double-digit quarterly increases. Revenue is projected to climb 30% to $876.5 million.McDonald'sShares of the world's biggest restaurant chain hit an all-time intraday high at 105.20 on Thursday, Oct. 15, with shares pulling back modestly since then. McDonald's revamped its menu earlier this year, adding healthier fare catering to the consumer trend toward fresher, more natural foods. It also has started selling breakfast all day.McDonald's is reportedly near a decision on what to do with its extensive real estate holdings amid calls for a spinoff of those assets into a real estate investment trust. Wall Street is looking for a 17% hike in Q3 EPS to $1.27 but expects revenue to fall 8.3% to $6.41 billion amid contraction in China's economic growth, weakness in European markets and the impact of a strong dollar.Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.
