Stocks held solid gains in early afternoon trading Thursday as Wall Street digested news from the European Central Bank and another avalanche of earnings reports.Despite rising distribution in the Nasdaq in recent days, the S&P 500's follow-through day on Oct. 2 is starting to look a whole lot better.The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all rose around 1.7%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Thursday's levels in the stock market today.The ECB left rates unchanged. Comments from ECB chief Mario Draghi fueled speculation that more quantitative easing could be in store for the eurozone.Steel, software security and machinery-related stocks outperformed, but hospital stocks plunged after Community Health Systems (CYH) issued a profit warning.On the NYSE, advancing stocks topped decliners on the NYSE by 4-to-1. On the Nasdaq, the ratio was 2-to-1.In earnings news, Dow component McDonald's (MCD) jumped 7% on news that global same-store sales grew 4% in the third quarter. In the U.S., same-store sales rose 0.9%, halting several quarters in a row of declining growth. Other top performers in the Dow included 3M (MMM), Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT).EBay (EBAY) was the best percentage gainer in the Nasdaq 100, up nearly 14%, after the company reported strong earnings and gave a nice outlook. It was eBay's first quarter without PayPal (PYPL), which started trading in July.After a crummy after-hours session Wednesday, enterprise software name ServiceNow (NOW) righted itself, rising 6%. The high-multiple stock reported adjusted profit of 15 cents a share, up 400% from a year ago and well ahead of the consensus estimate of 8 cents. Sales rose 46% to $261.1 million.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

McDonald's (MCD) touched an all-time intraday high Wednesday of 104.93 after trading in a narrow range since January 2012. Before the open, it was upgraded to buy from neutral by Cleveland Research. On Tuesday, it was initiated with a buy rating from SunTrust. The traditional fast food industry in general and McDonald's in particular have been under pressure in recent…

Investors will get a chance to see how much more sizzle McDonald’s (MCD) can add to its stock price this week when the fast-food king reports first-quarter earnings.The iconic burger chain is already one of the restaurant industry’s top performers this year, with a stock price trading near record highs and an aggressive growth plan that includes a big expansion in Asia.Now all all eyes will be on McDonald’s Q1 results, due Friday morning. Industry watchers expect another strong quarter, at least on the bottom line.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters look for McDonald’s to log a 15% year-over-year earnings gain to $1.16 a share, which would be the third straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth. That hasn’t happened in more than four years.The top-line forecast is a little muddier. McDonald’s overall revenue is seen dipping 3% to $5.8 billion for the quarter, which would be the sixth straight quarter of lower revenue.However, same-store sales growth — a more important industry metric — has been strong. Most analysts see McDonald’s Q1 U.S. comps up 4% to 4.5%.During the 2015 fourth quarter, McDonald’s posted a 5.7% increase in same-store sales, well above consensus. Earnings rose 16% to $1.31 a share, topping forecasts by 8 cents. Sales fell 4% to $6.34 billion, but still topped views for $6.2 billion.The company’s recent financial turnaround is partly the result of success with its all-day breakfast menu, which debuted in the fall. Its McPick 2 for $2 deal, an alternative to the Dollar Menu, didn’t fare as well. It was later replaced by the McPick 2 for $5, which has performed better."While the McPick 2 for $2 and industry conditions were relatively weak in January, McPick 2 for $5, along with ongoing strength from All Day Breakfast, have bolstered sales trends in March," RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer noted in a recent report. "We believe that the McPick 2 value brand will be one of several reasons that McDonald’s can sustain (same-store sales momentum)."Meanwhile, McDonald’s said it will begin selling Johnsonville Brats again after a seven-year hiatus, perhaps in response to a recent move by rival Burger King to sell hot dogs.Starting April 25, brats will return to menus at 125 McDonald’s locations in southeast Wisconsin, according to news reports.Another potential growth driver is McDonald’s big expansion in Asia. It recently announced plans to add more than 1,500 locations in China, Hong Kong and South Korea over the next five years. It already has more than 2,800 locations in those markets, most of which are company owned. This time McDonald’s is looking for "strategic partners" to help in its Asia expansion."This will allow McDonald's to accelerate our growth and scale faster across diverse markets, placing us closer to our customers and the communities we serve," CEO Steve Easterbrook said in a statement. "We're in the midst of transforming our business and taking a strategic and thoughtful approach to enhance our ability to grow around the world. These actions build on our turnaround efforts and will advance local ownership, enable faster decision making and achieve restaurant growth."Wall Street seems happy with McDonald’s direction. The company’s stock price set a new high of 128.90 on Monday and is up about 9% since the beginning of the year. McDonald's ended virtually unchanged Tuesday.That’s part of an overall rebound in fast-food stocks. Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) has risen around 13% for 2016; Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) is up 10%; and Wendy’s (WEN) has risen about 2%.Meanwhile, shares of fast-casual stocks such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Shake Shack (SHAK) and Habit Restaurants (HABT) have struggled.

Optimism among small-business owners slipped 0.3 point in March to a two-year low of 92.6, and the 7.7-point decline in the index over the last 15 months is a flashing warning signal of a possible recession, the National Federation of Independent Business said.April's Index of Small Business Optimism could determine whether a recession alarm should be rung, according to William Dunkelberg, NFIB chief economist.Regulations were small firms' top concern, with 21% listing it as their primary worry, followed by 20% of respondents who cited taxes as their main worry.New York and California are two states that have passed gradual raises of their minimum wage to $15 per hour -- moves hailed by unions but criticized by small businesses.Supporters of the wage hikes have targeted blue-chip companies such as McDonald’s (MCD) and Wal-Mart (WMT), but opponents argue that the pay raises will hurt small firms and their workers more."Arbitrarily raising the cost of labor reduces employment opportunities and raises prices," Dunkelberg said in a statement. "This just gives small firms an incentive to find ways to use less labor."But survey respondents were less pessimistic about whether business conditions will improve during the next six months. The expected-business-conditions reading rose 4 points to -17.The NFIB's overall index hit a post-recession peak of 100.3 in December 2014, but has remained below 100 since that time. Though the March decline wasn't a huge change, it is below the index's 42-year average of 98.

Starbucks (SBUX) should post another quarter of double-digit earnings and revenue gains, analysts project, but will a good second quarter be good enough for investors?The coffee shop chain is expected to post 18% profit growth to 39 cents a share on a 10% revenue rise to $5.03 billion, when it reports results after the close Thursday.Shares have been consolidating since November, largely trading above their 50-day and 200-day moving averages for the last month. Starbucks shares rose 0.6% to 60.89  in the stock market today.IBD's Take: How healthy are the shares of Starbucks and its rivals? Find out at IBD Stock Checkup"We continue to view SBUX as a best-in-class operator and an industry leader in the increasingly important realm of technology-driven consumer engagement," wrote Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh on Monday. He has an equal-weight rating and 56 price target on the stock.Starbucks' rewards program boasted 11.1 million active U.S. members as of January, with its mobile app accounting for over a fifth of all domestic transactions and with its order-ahead feature also picking up steam.Consensus estimates for domestic same-store sales and global comps are 7% and 6.5%, respectively, according to his report.Piper Jaffray, which noted in its semiannual teen survey last week that Starbucks was still No. 1 with young people, said its latest channel checks leave the firm "confident that Starbucks is well-positioned to continue driving strong same-store sales trends in 2016," citing well-received food and drink offerings and targeted promotions.But with expectations high for the coffee titan, a solid quarterly report may not impress."(E)ven if Starbucks reports good results -- based on lofty investors’ expectations -- the shares may still face some added pressure, as good results may not be good enough to support SBUX’s shares at current levels," wrote Deutsche Bank analyst Brett Levy on Friday. He has a hold rating on the stock.Starbucks is a member of IBD's Retail-Restaurants industry group, which includes Dunkin' Brands (DNKN), McDonald's (MCD), Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) and the beleaguered Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).Yum is slated to report Wednesday.

Stocks opened mixed and mostly unchanged Monday as Wall Street readied for another busy week of earnings.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 added 0.1%. The Nasdaq fell a fraction.In the stock market today, early leaders in the Dow included Verizon (VZ), McDonald's (MCD) and Travelers (TRV).Crude oil for June delivery was mostly unchanged around $45.89 a barrel. Gold added 0.6% to $1,297 an ounce.In the energy space, Halliburton (HAL) and Baker Hughes (BHI) called off their $28 billion merger due to resistance from regulators over antitrust concerns. Both stocks added 2% on the news.See who the leaders are in IBD's Oil & Gas-Field Services group with IBD Stock Checkup.Priceline (PCLN) was mostly unchanged ahead of its earnings report Wednesday before the open. The online travel-booking firm continues to show impressive growth for a company with a market capitalization of nearly $67 billion.Tesla Motors (TSLA) lost 1%. It reports Wednesday after the close. Tesla and Priceline were featured in Monday's Earnings Preview column.Inside the IBD 50, Thor Industries (THO) was trading tightly near the top of a long consolidation, paving the way for a possible breakout attempt.

So yesterday at about 3 pm EST the news hit the tape, the twitter sphere and the media outlets.....Headlines screamed:***BREAKING NEWS – SUNDAY APRIL 17, 2016 - ***Failure In Qatar - OPEC ministers unable to come to an agreement - oil mkts began to tremble - investors/traders now had to re-assess the reality of a fractured oil mkt......Oil which has rallied 18% from the early April lows and 30% off of the January lows and are now front and center as Asian mkts prepared to open - initial reactions saw oil plunge 6% as investors hit the sell button first only to ask questions later.....the headlines saturated the web.....who would be first to announce this failure and then the resulting mkt action? The headlines began..."Doha Summit Fails to Agree on Output Freeze""Oil Freeze Talks End in Failure Amid Saud Demands Over Iran""Oil Tumbles 5% on Doha Deal Disappointment""Asia Stocks at Mercy of Post Doha Oil Moves""Oil's Grand Bargain Falls Victim to Saudi Arabia's Iran Fixation"Futures around the globe plunged as day turned to night and the sun began to set in the US just as it began to rise across Asia….US futures were down 11 pts at 8 pm Sunday evening – while futures across Asia pointed in a similar direction as investors dealt with the fallout. News stories began detailing the talks that took place in Doha – the Qatari capital – which dragged on and on – going some 10 hrs past the original scheduled end time – as "Howie Mandel" shouted out –No Deal!Oil ministers from 16 nations, representing 50% of the world's production, gathered in the Qatari capital as they worked towards stabilizing the global mkt with artificial production quotas - the first real attempt at coordinating output among OPEC members and nations outside of the group since 2001. The barriers were numerous - would everyone fall into line? Would Iran come to the table? Could they really commit to restraining production? As we know - the Saudi's made it very clear from the beginning......they wouldn't restrain their production without commitments from other major producers including Iran, which had already made it clear that they had no such intention.The breaking story about a failure to agree on output or production quotas among the world's biggest oil producers now opens the flood gates to what many now expect to be a new retreat in oil prices."Discussions stumbled after Saudi Arabia and other Gulf nations wouldn't agree to any deal unless all OPEC members joined including Iran, which wasn't present at the meeting…"Angus Nicholson – an analyst at IG Ltd in Melbourne, Australia had this to say:"The market has been so heavily positioned for a deal to go through, The change of tone from the Saudis, particularly driven over the last few weeks by Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has been quite a surprise to the market. With Saudi Arabia fighting proxy wars with Iran in Yemen and Syria/Iraq, it is understandable that they had little inclination to freeze their own production and make way for newly sanctions-free Iran to increase their market share."So then what happened? Was there really a change in tone from the Saudi's? Did investors get this all wrong? Once the idea of a freeze was floated (two months ago) – trader types started buying up oil – as it was assumed that any freeze would trim supply just as summer was about to begin and the driving season was about to take off… Oil rallied 30% off the lows as the excitement built…..but hey, buyer beware – remember it was the news sources that reported this ‘cease fire' all while the Saudi's and the Russians never really confirmed or denied the story - they let it play out in the media - they never explicitly committed. ….It all sounded good – but it did require that all members fall into line and Iran had said from the very beginning that they had no intention of ‘playing nice in the sandbox'.Overnight oil suffered a bit - with Brent down 4% and WTI (West Texas Intermediate) down about 4.5% - makes some sense - but equity mkts did NOT follow suit and implode the way many thought they might.....In fact - we have to ask: Is a ‘No-Deal' actually better for the mkts in the long run as it allows for supply and demand to find its ‘natural' level of equilibrium vs. ‘artificial production controls' which will only put off the inevitable? ( I mean look - we all know what artificial controls can do to mkts - think massive QE programs instituted by every central bank)As Asian mkts opened – the pressure came to bear - mkts sold off - but not to the extent that many were prepared for.....…..Japan was the outlier - falling some 3+% - but this had more to do with the major series of earthquakes in the past 3 days – vs. the oil story.... South Korea (Kospi) moved 0.28% lower, Australia stumbled by 0.4%, Hong Kong lost 0.9% and China was off 1.43% by the end of the day.As the sun sets on Asia it rises in Europe and as the clock ticked – European mkts were the next to react.....they too are under a bit of pressure – taking their cue from investor angst in Asia - but again - equities are not getting clobbered by any stretch.......Currently Brent North Sea Crude oil is off by 2% while WTI (West Texas Intermediate) is down by nearly 3% trading at $39/barrel. FTSE - 0.07%, CAC 40 - 0.04%, DAX +0.06%, EUROSTOXX - 0.18%, SPAIN -0.35% and ITALY +0.11%.US futures which were down 11 pts Sunday evening have recovered a bit from the initial ‘knee jerk' reaction trading last night – currently they are lower by 7 pts as the reality of this OPEC decision permeates the psyche. Since the equity mkts did not implode on this news (as many had expected) – we need to ask: Are investors trying to separate action in the oil/energy space from the rest of the mkt. Now while energy names will get hit today – think transports and manufacturers as beneficiaries of lower oil prices.Earnings will continue to ramp up this week as we enter the thick of it. Last week- the message was all about the banks….now while we saw trading revenues decrease and loan loss reserves increase and most reports miss revenue estimates - they all managed to beat the on the bottom line. Uncle Lloyd (Blankfein) released a strategic restructuring plan ahead of his earnings this week - Headlines read:"Goldman's Blankfein Demands Deepest Cost Cuts in Years" -on the chopping block? Travel limits, Entertainment, deferring projects and Layoffs as he"has already adjusted his workforce, relying more on JUNIOR bankers, moving support staff to cheaper locations and investing in technology to improve productivity"(Junior bankers? I mean if you want a Jr banker there are so many other places to go - You don't go to GS for a Jr. Banker)The stock rallied on this news taking it to its down trending 100 dma at $163.... earnings are due tomorrow...so the clock is ticking....did he do a good enough job of acknowledging the disastrous industry environment for the sake of investors?Earnings today include Morgan Stanley (MS) - they beat the estimate - reported 0.55 cts/sh vs. exp 0.46 cts/sh, Pepsico (PEP) - beat reporting 0.89 cts/sh vs. the 0.81 cts/sh expected. HASBRO (HAS)toys also beat 0.38 vs. 0.23 cts/sh.....later in the week we will hear from American Express (AXP), McDonald's (MCD), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), IBM (IBM), Intel (INTC), Cocoa Cola (KO) and Microsoft (MSFT)There is not major economic data points today..so the chatter will be about earnings and oil.....and the 3 FED speakers today....Dudley at 8:30 am, Kashkari at 12:30 pm and Rosengren at 7 pm....Take Good Care

Chipotle Mexican Grill’s (CMG) series of food-borne illness outbreaks may have cost the company three years of earnings growth, according to JPMorgan’s estimates. But the bank sounded bullish as it upgraded the beleaguered restaurant chain to overweight from neutral."In all, our call is based on Chipotle being a highly meaningful brand that with time and expense can regain customer trust," wrote JPMorgan analyst John Ivankoe on Thursday.Shares closed 2.55% higher but remain below their 50-day moving average. The stock has been trading below its 200-day since losing support at the level in late October, and is 40% off its all-time high.The E. coli and norovirus episodes that hit Chipotle locations across the country also hit its brand image, with same-store sales down 14.6% in Q4 and an expected loss in Q1, the latter of which would mark a first for the company’s quarterly results."We expect normal earnings growth to resume by F18 -- after nearly doubling in F17 -- and believe 20%+ EPS growth can be sustained through at least F20," said Ivankoe.He is not the only analyst who sees the light at the end of the tunnel for the burrito chain.Piper Jaffray’s latest semiannual teen survey found that Chipotle still holds major sway over America’s young people. The firm is positive on the company’s long-term story as well, with an overweight rating and 590 price target.The stock is a member of IBD’s Retail-Restaurants industry group, which is at No. 75 among IBD’s Industry Sub-Group Rankings, joined by Starbucks (SBUX), McDonald's (MCD), Yum Brands (YUM) and others.RELATED:Starbucks Is Still Tops With Teens, Chipotle Hangs OnWhy Chipotle Mexican Grill May Have Reached ‘Peak Burrito’

Teenagers love Starbucks (SBUX) and love eating out, according to the results of a new Piper Jaffray poll, which says that restaurant spending is still outpacing apparel spending. The coffee giant is still No. 1 and the only brand to continue to harness double-digit market share preference among teens, according to the firm."Starbucks remains our top investment recommendation based on its proven global brand equity and an accelerating asset-light growth model, both of which generate strong cash flow in support of continued reinvestment into the business and an ongoing commitment to capital allocation," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Nicole Miller Regan following the release of its Spring 2016 Taking Stock With Teens survey results.But Deutsche Bank cooled on the stock, downgrading it to hold from buy Tuesday as it argues that Starbucks' comp and earnings growth are fully priced into shares.Shares rose 1.2% in the stock market today after falling 2.3% Tuesday.Meanwhile, McDonald's (MCD) is still edging up in popularity and remains the top burger choice for America's young people.McDonald's stock fell 0.6% but remains near recent record highs and is still in buy range from a late March breakout.And Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) maintained its position as the second-place favorite among upper-income teenagers, though it unsurprisingly lost some share in the wake of a series of food-borne illness outbreaks at its restaurants.Piper Jaffray remains positive on the brand's long-term story, with a "when, not if" outlook on improvement, an overweight rating and a 590 price target.Chipotle shares rallied to close up 4 cents at 444.66 after falling early. CtW Investment Group urged shareholders not to re-elect directors Patrick Flynn and Darlene Friedman at the company's annual meeting, citing a lack of diversity, and called for more "independent oversight."RELATED:Why One Analyst Is 'Taking A Pause' From Starbucks.

Restaurant Brands International (QSR) shares are looking tastier, while Domino's Pizza (DPZ) is going cold after both companies reported earnings Thursday.The Burger King and Tim Hortons parent earned 30 cents a share, well above views for 22 cents a share, on $918.5 million in revenue, short of forecasts for $932.3 million. That represents a 67% profit tumble on a 1% revenue decline from last year, according to Thomson Reuters data.Burger King same-store sales rose 4.6%, while Tim Hortons comps grew 5.6% in constant currency."It appears as though BK has weathered the storm of competitive discounting during Q1 with its own value platforms, namely 2 for $5 and 10 for $1.49 nuggets, while new innovation including hot dogs likely also contributed somewhat," wrote RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer.The fast-food realm has seen a proliferation of super-cheap promotion deals, including Wendy's (WEN) "4 for $4" deal and McDonald's (MCD) recently ended "McPick 2 for $5" promotion.Restaurant Brands shares closed up 1.1%, nearing buy range after loitering in a broad area of consolidation since last August. McDonald's edged down 0.3%, Wendy's dipped 0.5%, and Jack In The Box (JACK) eased 0.4%.Meanwhile, Domino's Q1 earnings per share grew 10% to 89 cents on 7% revenue growth to $539.2 million, missing estimates for 98 cents in EPS on $545.6 million in sales. Currency headwinds weighed on results.U.S. comps grew 6.4%, while international comps rose 7.9%.Shares nearly 10%, slicing below their 50-day line. Pizza rival Papa John's (PZZA) lost 2.7%, and Pizza Hut parent Yum Brands (YUM) fell 1.3%.Dunkin' Brands' (DNKN) per-share earnings rose 10% to 44 cents, beating by a penny, on 2% revenue growth to $189.8 million, edging above views for $188 million.Demands for breakfast sandwiches and beverages fueled 2% in same-store sales growth at U.S. Dunkin' Donuts, above analyst estimates. Baskin-Robbins' domestic comps rose 5%."As (Q1 same-store sales) results for the Dunkin' U.S. segment were ahead of our expectations, we continue to believe sustained SSS trends is likely" through 2016 and 2017, wrote Palmer in a separate report.Dunkin' reaffirmed full-year guidance for 4%-6% revenue growth and $2.20-$2.22 in per-share profit.Amid the success of Starbucks' (SBUX) mobile-order-and-pay service, in which customers can order ahead and pick up in store, Dunkin' also announced Thursday the rollout of "on-the-go ordering" for loyalty program members in New York City, starting in just a few weeks. The company had started testing the service in select cities late last year.Dunkin' shares closed down 0.8% as they form a wide cup-with-handle base. Starbucks also lost 0.8%.

Stocks rolled out nice gains Wednesday morning as positive input from overseas markets, earnings and analyst reports and economic news all helped add some lift.The Nasdaq strode to a 1.2% gain. The Dow industrials and the S&P 500 rumbled up 0.7% apiece. The stock market today rode rising volume, indicating institutional investors were behind the early action. Trade was up 27% on the NYSE and 13% higher on the Nasdaq, compared with activity at the same time Tuesday.Early producer price data suggested inflation was in check. Retail sales slipped in March, primarily due to a decline in auto sales.Business inventories slipped 0.1% in February, according to Commerce Department data, swinging from a 0.1% gain in January but in line with expectations.The market opened with 29 of the 30 Dow components moving higher. JPMorgan (JPM) led after delivering its Q1 results, up almost 3%. Goldman Sachs (GS) was close behind with a 2% gain.  McDonald's (MCD) was the sole laggard, down 0.1%.China's JD.com (JD) topped the Nasdaq 100, rising more than 4% in very heavy trade. The online retailer is up 9% so far this week and 32% above a February low.Drugmaker Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) spiked 9% on comments from Cowen analyst Ken Cacciatore following a patent case ruling by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. The move lifted shares back above their 200-day moving average and further up the right side of an eight-month consolidation.Tenet Healthcare (THC) punched up 6% to lead the S&P 500. Susquehanna upgraded the hospital operator to positive from neutral. The stock is working on its seventh gain in the past eight weeks.On the IBD 50 list, TAL Education (XRS) surged more than 4% in powerful trade to a new high. The stock is extended after a rebound from 10-week support and sits 3% above a 52.76 buy point from a three-weeks tight pattern.

Hedge funds are loading up with pork.With Americans expected to eat the most pork since 2007, money managers are now the most bullish since 2014 on hog futures, which already are at a nine-month high. Fast-food restaurant owners like McDonald’s (MCD) are selling more bacon, and the price of pork bellies used to make the rashers has surged 30% this year.Demand at home and abroad is rising faster than U.S. farmers are boosting output. Pork remains a cheaper alternative to beef cuts that last year surged to records as supply shrank, government data show. Hog futures for settlement in June are up 16% since mid-November, more than almost every other commodity, including gold.“You have to be bullish in the near term,” said Donald Selkin, chief market strategist at broker-dealer National Securities Corp. in New York, who helps manage about $3 billion. “Exports have been strong, that’s what’s driving this.”The net-long position in hog futures and options jumped 20% to 51,505 contracts in the most recent week, the biggest gain in more than a month, according to Commodity Futures and Trading Commission data. Holdings have surged sixfold since mid-December and expanded in 13 of the past 14 weeks.Futures for June settlement, the most actively traded hog contract, fell 1.9% to 82.275 cents a pound at 11:16 a.m. Monday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Prices are 12% higher than a year earlier. April futures, which had been the most active until March 8, are trading at 69.775 cents a pound Monday, up 18% since mid-November.In a March 16 report, financial services firm Societe Generale SA raised its second-quarter forecast by 16%, predicting that the front-month contract would average 78.9 cents, compared with 69.4 cents so far this year for the April contract.U.S. hog producers have been expanding after futures surged to a record in 2014, when a piglet-killing virus reduced the domestic herd. Pork production last year was the highest ever and is forecast to increase 2.1% in 2016, U.S. Department of Agriculture data show.But people are eating more pork. On average, Americans will consume 50.4 pounds this year, the USDA said on March 9. And more meat is getting shipped overseas.U.S. exports in January were 10% higher than a year earlier, and shipments have averaged 13% above year-earlier levels every month since September, government data show. They exceed the USDA’s full-year increase forecast of 3.2%.Even with the recent rally in prices, beef’s premium to pork is more than 50% above the 10-year average, and wholesale pork is well below its five-year average.More fast-food restaurants are promoting breakfast items all day that feature pork products, said Dennis Smith, Chicago-based senior account executive at Archer Financial Services. As the cost of ground beef slips from recent records, burgers are making a comeback and restaurants are adding bacon as a topping, said David Maloni, principal at the American Restaurant Association in Sarasota, Florida. Wholesale pork bellies are up 88% from a year earlier at $1.3428 a pound, USDA data show.Not all pork items are rallying. Easter hams are priced to sell, dropping 11% since the end of January to 52.05 cents a pound, USDA data show. Bacon fetches a premium to ham that is more than 60% above the five-year average.Rising pork supplies could end the rally, with the increase in hogs overwhelming processing plants later this year. Farmers tend to boost output in the second half of the year.“There’s definitely a good cause to be bullish through the third quarter, but be very careful in the fourth quarter,” said Will Sawyer, an Atlanta-based vice president for Rabobank Food & Agribusiness Research and Advisory. Processing all the hogs “could come at a price that’s less than what futures are showing today,” he said.

The European Union on Tuesday laid out proposed new rules governing how big companies report corporate taxes as it battles to keep billions in euros within its borders.The EU's European Commission on Tuesday proposed to amend rules governing how large companies report corporate taxes. The Commission, the EU's executive arm, estimated that tax avoidance in Europe costs EU countries 50-70 billion euros ($57 billion-$80 billion) a year in lost tax revenue.The new rules could impact U.S. giants such as McDonald's (MCD), Amazon.com (AMZN), Starbucks (SBUX), Apple (AAPL) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), which have all faced, or currently face, EU scrutiny.The proposal would force companies with annual European revenue topping roughly $855 million to be more transparent and to publish key information "on where they make their profits and where they pay their tax in the EU on a country-by-country basis." The proposal was amended to require corporations to reveal taxes paid in so-called tax havens.European Commission member Jonathan Hill said in a written statement that the proposed changes to existing rules aren't a reaction to the Panama papers. Millions of documents were recently leaked from Panama law firm Mossack Fonseca, which specializes in setting up offshore tax havens, mostly for rich individuals.However, Hill added, "I think that they (the Panama papers) have strengthened our determination to make sure that taxes are paid where profits are generated."Last October, the EC ruled that tax deals granted to Starbucks in the Netherlands and Fiat in Luxembourg were illegal state subsidies that the companies must repay.The EU was already investigating McDonald's for allegedly exploiting an agreement with Luxembourg to avoid taxes worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The probe is looking into whether the agreement, under EU rules that prevent taxation in both the U.S. and EU, allowed McDonald's to avoid taxes in both regions.McDonald's has said that it paid its fair share of taxes in the EU, amounting to more than $2.1 billion from 2010 to 2014, Bloomberg reported. The EC is also probing an agreement between Amazon and Luxembourg, centering on whether that country agreed to cap taxes that Amazon pays no matter how much profit it makes there.Alphabet in January agreed to pay $260 million to the U.K. to settle back-tax issues. Many criticized the settlement as peanuts.Apple's Irish tax arrangements also are under EU scrutiny, with a European Commission judgment still pending.The EC statement Tuesday said that the next step is submitting the proposed new rules to the European Parliament and the Council of the EU for discussion, a process that could take months or years, analysts said. If adopted, all 28 EU member states would then have to translate the rules into national legislation.McDonald's, which has a strong 90 IBD Composite Rating -- which means that it's outperformed 90% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth recently -- edged higher in late afternoon trading on the stock market today. It's risen steadily since last fall, advancing about 25% from an Oct. 6 low of 101.98.Amazon, which is on the IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks, may be forming a late-stage cup-with-handle base with a 603.34 buy point. Its shares rose 1% to 601.79 Tuesday.Apple was up 1.2% at 110.31. Starbucks, a stock on the IBD 50 list, fell 2.5%. Alphabet climbed 0.8%.

While much of the media attention in the restaurant industry has focused on the McDonald’s (MCD) financial rebound and Chipotle Mexican Grill’s (CMG) food safety problems, drive-in chain Sonic (SONC) has quietly become one of the sector’s top performers on Wall Street.The company’s shares are up about 7% since the beginning of the year and have risen more than 35% since Feb. 10. In comparison, IBD’s Retail-Restaurant group as a whole has risen about 4% since the beginning of the year and 9% since Feb. 10.Sonic’s stock touched a 52-week high of 36.34 on April 6. The high capped a rally that began a week earlier, when the company beat fiscal second-quarter earnings and revenue views and logged a 6.5% annual gain in same-restaurant sales, or at outlets open more than a year. The latter increase was especially impressive, considering that it came on top of an even bigger gain during the previous year’s second quarter."The clear highlight of the quarter was a better-than-expected systemwide comp of 6.5% against a difficult 11.5% comparison, easily ahead of our estimate of 3% to 4% and consensus of roughly 1.5%," William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia wrote in a research note.Sonic reported results after the close on March 29. The next day, its stock price popped 6%.It was a welcome reaction for a company that has largely flown under the radar in the restaurant sector. Most of the attention has focused on rebounding fast-food stocks such as McDonald’s, Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) and Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR), as well as flailing fast-casual chains like Chipotle, Shake Shack (SHAK) and Habit Restaurants (HABT).McDonald’s has benefited from successful initiatives such as its all-day breakfast menu and its "McPick 2 for $5" promotional deal. Meanwhile, Chipotle continues to feel the fallout from the E. coli and norovirus outbreaks at several of its restaurants.Sonic operates in a kind of middle ground between fast food and fast casual. Like fast-food chains, it focuses on quick service. The main difference is that at some Sonic restaurants, you can have carhops on roller skates deliver your food to your car.Like fast-casual restaurants, Sonic specializes in fresh, made-to-order fare that includes burgers, hot dogs, toaster sandwiches, burritos and various breakfast and side items. It has more than 3,500 locations in 45 states, making it the nation’s largest chain of drive-in restaurants. The drive-in concept separates it from other quick-service restaurant (QSR) brands like McDonald’s, Burger King and Wendy’s (WEN), which offer drive-through but not drive-in service."Sonic represents one of the most highly differentiated QSR brands in the country with a fun, 'retro-future' look that breaks through the clutter in a crowded QSR segment," Jefferies analyst Alexander Slagle noted in a report.Another way in which Sonic differentiates itself is its technology focus. Over the past couple of years, the company has invested heavily in new Point-Of-Service (POS) and Point-Of-Personalized-Service (POPS) platforms, while other chains have focused more on mobile apps.Sonic’s POS platform is designed to improve the order process, cut food and packaging costs, reduce employee waste and theft, and optimize labor so the right amount of staff is on hand at the right time. The POPS platform lets Sonic tailor offers to customers based on their past purchasing history. It also provides on-site redeemable offers to customers.At the end of the second quarter, the POPS platform was in 1,616 locations and was about halfway through its rollout, Zackfia noted. The rollout should be finished by the end of the 2017 calendar year."POPS will facilitate technology and social media initiatives (and) allow for uniquely personalized engagement that we anticipate will be a key driver of future same-store sales momentum, including the systemwide rollout of a mobile app that includes mobile payment," Zackfia said.Although Sonic’s heavy investment in technology has cut into the company’s bottom line, most analysts reckon that it will pay off in the long run."While some investors might have hoped for a little better flow-through to the bottom line given the (same-restaurant sales) upside, the team appears to be making the appropriate investments in the business to continue generating market share gains in the future," Slagle noted.Sonic officials have a similar take. On a second-quarter conference call with analysts, Chief Executive Clifford Hudson said the company’s POS and POPS investments provide an "opportunity to leverage this technology and enhance the customer experience in a way that competitor brands can’t."Even with rising technology costs in recent years, Sonic has done pretty well on the earnings front. It has logged 11 straight quarters of double-digit EPS growth.Earnings came in at 18 cents a share during the fiscal second quarter, which ended Feb. 29. That was up 38% from the prior year and two cents ahead of consensus. Revenue rose 5% to $133.2 million, also topping estimates.Sonic raised its full-year same-store sales growth estimate to a range of 4% to 6% vs. prior guidance of 2% to 4%.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Sonic to post earnings of $1.36 a share for the entire fiscal year, which ends in August. That would represent a 24% year-over-year gain. Earnings are seen rising another 14% in fiscal 2017.

Stocks wrenched into early losses in heavy trade Friday, then eased into mixed trade following a flurry of early economic reports.The Dow backed out of narrow losses into a slight gain. The S&P 500 held 0.2% in the red. The Nasdaq wrestled with a fractional loss.Volume jumped nearly 30% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, compared to trading volume at the same time Thursday.Despite Friday's early slip, the stock market remains in good standing for the week. The Nasdaq is up more than 2% vs. last Thursday's close, and is on track to end its first weekly close above its 200-day moving average since early January.The S&P 500 is fighting to hold its gain to around 1%, but remains comfortably above its 200-day line. Blue chips lagged for the week, with the Dow Jones industrial average below a 1% gain. Small-caps outpaced, sending the Russell 2000 into Friday's session with a 3.2% advance. The entire group opens the second quarter amid a burst of momentum, with the Nasdaq up 15.6%, the S&P 500 up 13.7%, and the Russell 200 up 18.1% off a mid-February low.The Labor Department's March payrolls report showed hiring slowed less than expected and wages rose firmly, although the unemployment rate ticked upward to 5%, vs. consensus expectations for no change.The morning's first read on March manufacturing was mildly disappointing, with researcher Markit putting its Purchasing Managers' Index at 51.5 for the month, up from February's 51.3 but below forecasts for 51.7.A similar gauge form the Institute of Supply Management was more positive, popping to 51.8 in March, up from 49.5 in February and clearing consensus forecasts for 50.5.March consumer confidence also improved above expectations. The University of Michigan placed its final Consumer Sentiment Survey at 91 for the month. Economists had projected an uptick to 90.9, from February's final tally of 90.Oil futures dug deeper, down more than 3% with West Texas Intermediate crude just pennies above $37 a barrel. Prices may see some effect from the Baker-Hughes (BHI) weekly rig count data, due out at 1 p.m. ET.Almost a third of the Dow's stocks posted losses deeper than 1%. Chevron (CVX) slid furthest, down 1.4%. McDonald's (MCD) added 0.7% to top the Dow's few advancing issues.Tesla Motors (TSLA) was center-stage following Thursday evening's introduction of its Model 3 sedan. Shares spiked nearly 8% in heavy trade at the open, breaking out above a 239.98 buy point in a V-shaped cup-with-handle base. The stock quickly pared its gain to 5%, holding just above the pivot.Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Urban Outfitters (URBN) led the S&P 500, up about 4% apiece. Oil and energy-related stocks packed the low end of the index.Airline stocks were taking some hard early hits after Deutsche Bank downgraded United Continental Holdings (UAL) to hold from buy, based on a challenging outlook. United dropped 5% in fast trade. American Airlines (AAL) dumped 4%. Delta Air Lines (DAL) slipped 3%.On the IBD 50 list, U.S. Concrete (USCR) troweled out a 2% gain after announcing it had acquired Haskell, Texas-based Strickland Bridge. Terms were not disclosed, but the company said the deal expands its capabilities in markets in and around Abilene, Texas.

Stock indexes coasted to a quiet close Friday, content to sit on the week's solid gains. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average each eased less than 0.2%, while the S&P 500 trimmed 0.1%. The IBD 50 added almost 0.2%. Volume nudged up across the board. Friday was an expirations day, which normally boosts volume. Bulls had to be reasonably…

Stocks closed slightly lower Friday, but the major market indexes still wrapped up the week with gains of nearly 2% each.The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.2% each, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, slightly higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq vs. Thursday's total, according to preliminary figures. Winners outpaced losers by about a 5-4 margin on the NYSE and by 7-5 on the Nasdaq.Energy, investment banks and computer-related stocks led the downside in today's stock market action. Oil stocks were weighed down by a 3% slide in West Texas intermediate crude prices to $40.36 a barrel, ahead of an oil production meeting this weekend in Doha, Qatar.Super Micro Computer (SMCI) gapped down and sank 20%, slicing its 200-day moving average in hefty trade. Shares are now well below a 33.89 buy point initially cleared March 30. The maker of server systems and other computer gear guided fiscal Q3 earnings lower. It reports April 28 after the close.Apple (AAPL) provided the biggest drag on the Dow, shedding 2% to close back below the 200-day moving average, which it had regained Wednesday. Volume ran about 22% higher than usual. The iPad maker will continue with lowered iPhone production in the April to June quarter, according to the Nikkei Asian Review.Citigroup (C) rose as much as 3.5% intraday but pared its gains to close slightly lower. The big bank reported Q1 earnings that fell less than expected. Shares are 9% above their 50-day line but 9% below the 200-day line.Gold miners, utilities and apparel retailers bucked the downtrend. Among utilities, Aqua America (WTR) rose 2% to reclaim its 50-day moving average. It's been trading mostly in flat-base range since early February.INC Research (INCR) led the IBD 50 with a near 2% gain in above-average volume to extend its win streak for a fifth straight session. The stock is just shy of a 50.50 cup-base buy point. The company provides clinical development services to the biopharmaceutical and medical device industries.Economic news was mixed. Industrial production fell 0.6% in March, well below projections for a 0.1% slip. The New York Fed Empire State Manufacturing Survey for April jumped to 9.6, soaring past economists' forecasts for 3.0. April consumer sentiment fell to 89.7, vs. 91 in March and views for an uptick to 91.8.Reports out Monday include the housing market index for April. The Fed's William Dudley, Neel Kashkari and Eric Rosengren are also scheduled to speak.American Express (AXP), Coca-Cola (KO), Alphabet (GOOGL), McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX) are among companies reporting next week as earnings season ramps up.Image provided by Shutterstock.

With one trading session left in the first quarter of 2016, stocks on Wednesday gave growth investors a little more confidence to wade deeper into the market. The major indexes padded Tuesday's gains with a broad -- albeit mild -- advance. Volume declined. The gains by the Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and even the S&P 100 -- which tracks the…

Shares of burger chains of McDonald's (MCD) and Sonic (SONC) are breaking out, while Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) signals it has a "Better Burger" in mind.McDonald's shares rose 1.5% to 125.83 in the stock market today, rising out of a cup-shaped base with a buy point of 124.93 and hitting a record high. Shares found support at their 50-day line earlier in the month.McDonald's has benefited from a shift to all-day breakfast menus in the U.S. McDonald's also is getting a lift in recent weeks from a weaker dollar, along with several other Dow stocks such as General Electric (GE) and Coca-Cola (KO). General Electric and Coca-Cola, which broke out of their own consolidations in recent weeks, rose to new highs as well Wednesday.Sonic is positioned in buy range after recording better-than-expected second-quarter results and raising full-year earnings and comp guidance late Tuesday. The stock had been building a cup-with-handle base with 33.04 buy point for the last several months.Shares rose 6.2% to 34.58 to a 1-year high, breaking out of a three-month base and moving to the high end of a longer consolidation.Meanwhile, Bloomberg reported that Chipotle Mexican Grill earlier this month filed a trademark for "Better Burger," suggesting it's interested in creating a burger chain. Chipotle, still recovering from food-illness scares, already has a ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen chain. Chipotle stock rose 1.3% to 466.15.Texas Roadhouse (TXRH), meanwhile,  is ascending even higher, edging up 0.9% to a fresh high after popping 3.9% on Tuesday. Texas Roadhouse broke out of a broad area of consolidation last month, rising 12.7% on Feb. 23 following the release of Q4 earnings and revenue results. Shares consolidated for another month or so before Tuesday's jump out of a three-weeks-tight base.Lower beef prices are helping the Southern-style steakhouse chain to eat up market share.RELATED:Sonic Rockets After Hours On Pumped-Up ’16 GuidanceTexas Roadhouse Feeds Wall Street’s Appetite For Tasty Growth.

There's more than meets the eye to California Gov. Jerry Brown's plan to hike the state minimum wage to $15 an hour — about $3.50 more.Including nonwage costs — payroll taxes, paid sick leave and ObamaCare's employer mandate — minimum compensation for a full-time worker could rise as high as $18.52 an hour by 2022, an IBD analysis finds.Social insurance taxes would add $1.15 an hour to the $15 wage. Three days of paid sick leave now on the books in California would add another 19 cents. And the ObamaCare after-tax fine, now $2,160 per uncovered full-time worker and rising each year, will equate to roughly $2.18 an hour in pretax wages. Adding in workers' compensation insurance and unemployment insurance would push the total close to $19 an hour.One big change from a $15 minimum wage has flown below the radar: Many low-wage workers would no longer qualify for Medicaid. For example, a single mom with one child who worked 32 hours per week would earn more than the 138% of poverty cutoff for expanded Medicaid under ObamaCare, though her child would still qualify. A single adult who works just three full days a week also would exceed the income threshold.To no small degree, the $15 minimum-wage movement is asking low-wage employers to lift their workers up closer to the middle class and to provide a full menu of social benefits on top. It looks like a recipe for trouble, and even Brown may be wary about it, insisting that the governor retain authority to delay wage hikes if the state sees a fall in employment or retail sales, or if the state faces a budget deficit. Brown had little room for maneuver because a $15 wage initiative that qualified for the November ballot looked like a sure winner and would have provided no flexibility if the wage hike started backfiring.One early-warning sign for California's wage experiment was Wal-Mart's (WMT) announcement in January that it would shutter stores in Oakland and Los Angeles and cancel two planned stores in Washington D.C., dealing a blow to three cities on the leading edge of the push for a much higher minimum wage.Before Los Angeles put its minimum wage on a path to $15 an hour, the question of how city employers would respond to the simultaneous imposition of a health insurance mandate was simply ignored. An analysis of the wage hike's labor cost impact by the Institute for Research on Labor and Employment at the University of California, Berkeley, explicitly excluded health insurance — or a mandate penalty. The authors explained: "Health benefits are excluded since ... the costs of the benefits will not change if wages are increased." The Congressional Budget Office came to a different conclusion, finding that the ObamaCare employer mandate would exacerbate the impact of a minimum-wage hike. It estimated that a minimum-wage hike to $10.10 an hour could cost 500,000 jobs."(The) additional cost on employers for some low-wage workers who do not currently have employment-based health insurance ... further boosts the likelihood that employers' savings from reducing the size of their workforces would exceed their adjustment costs," the CBO said.Those adjustment costs might include adding labor-saving technology.Wendy's (WEN) CFO Todd Penegor explained in an August earnings call, "We continue to look at initiatives and how we work to offset any impacts of future wage inflation through technology initiatives, whether that's customer self-order kiosks (or) whether that's automating more in the back of the house in the restaurant."Starbucks (SBUX) and Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell are among the restaurant chains promoting mobile ordering, which reduces the need for cashiers. McDonald's (MCD) is about to start testing mobile apps as well.The truth about the ObamaCare employer mandate is that it hasn't been nearly as much of a burden on businesses as feared, so they haven't had to cut workers' hours below 30 per week in a dramatic way. But the reason is hardly cause for celebration: Employers have figured out how to dodge liability by offering "affordable" coverage that costs much more than their modest-wage workers are likely to pay.That's left millions of modest-wage, full-time workers without affordable coverage options. It's possible that California's embrace of a $15 minimum wage will add to their ranks. But the status quo of full-time workers thrown under the bus by ObamaCare may not hold. If the mandate ever becomes something that can't be easily dodged, minimum-wage employers in California will likely cut work hours in a big way, diluting the promise of a living wage.

Stocks whittled away at thin losses Tuesday morning as the market looked toward upcoming comments from Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 dipped 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq backed off a fraction.Volume ticked slightly higher, up 17% on the NYSE and up a fraction on the Nasdaq relative to trade at the same time Monday.A speech scheduled just after midday in New York from Yellen, followed by a question and answer period, provides the centerpiece of the stock market today.In early economic news, home prices popped 5.8% year-over-year in January according to the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Home Price Index. Portland, Ore., Seattle and San Francisco logged the biggest increases.  The gain was in line with economists consensus projections.Consumer outlooks improved in March, lifting the Conference Board's Consumer Sentiment Index to 96.2, a big jump above February's 92.2 reading and easily clearing consensus views for 94.Oil prices continued lower, dropping 3% and putting West Texas Intermediate just above $38 a barrel.  Oil and energy related stocks packed into the low end of the S&P 500.Boeing (BA) dropped nearly 2%, the worst slip among Dow stocks. Chevron (CVX) and 3M (MMM) were also down more than 1%. At the top of the index, McDonald's (MCD) climbed almost 1%.Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) dropped 3% to the bottom of the Nasdaq 100. Citi downgraded the stock to neutral, from buy. The note cited reduced opportunity in carrier aggregation, and said a 20% recovery in smartphone demand expected in the second half of the year was already priced into the stock. Shares are up 36% from a February low.Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) ran up 3% after a solid fiscal Q1 report. The gain lifted shares to a test of resistance at the stock's 200-day moving average.Universal Health Services (UHS) also popped 3% in heavy trade. It is up 22% from a February low and still below its 200-day line.At the extremes on the IBD 50 list, Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) climbed 3% in early action. The stock has been trading wide and loose, but holding support at the 50-day moving average. It is extended above a 15.60 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.LendingTree (TREE) slipped almost 4%. That put the stock below its 200-day moving average, and more than 7% below a 97.85 buy point in a first stage cup-with-handle base.

The stock market received an early assist from economic data Monday, opening mixed and mostly unchanged in early trade.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose fractionally, while the Nasdaq eased 0.1%.The stock market today heads into the final trading week of the first quarter with the Dow up 2.1% and the S&P 500 showing a 1.1% gain this year. The Nasdaq and the small-cap Russell 2000 are tied, down 2.6% each.Premarket futures got an lift from updated Q4 GDP estimates released by the Commerce Department Friday. The report boosted growth to 1.4% from 1%, better than consensus expectations for no change.Today, pending homes sales numbers for February are expected from the National Association of Realtors at 10 a.m. ET.The Federal Reserve jumps back into its war of words on Tuesday, with Fed officials John Williams, Janet Yellen and Rob Kaplan set to speak during trading hours.  Otherwise, the week's economic calendar is only moderately busy.Oil traded a shade higher, but West Texas Intermediate held below $40 per barrel. Gold dipped a fraction to near $1,218 an ounce. The dollar was flat against the euro, up vs. the yen. Bonds eased, lifting the 10-year yield 1 basis point to 1.91%.Deal news was in the air, but not driving much early stock action: Japan-based NTT Data agreed to buy the information technology consulting business from privately held Dell for $3 billion. Meanwhile, Microsoft (MSFT) was reportedly involved in talks with investors regarding a deal over Yahoo (YHOO), but both stocks were  mostly unchanged in the early going.Wal-Mart (WMT), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Walt Disney (DIS) were early leaders in the Dow, up about 0.5% each.Drugmakers were in early motion. Acadia Pharmaceuticals (ACAD) spiked 20 in early trade. Its Parkinson's disease treatment Nupalzid is the focus of a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee meeting set for Tuesday. Alder Biopharmaceuticals (ALDR) surged 50% after reporting positive results from a midstage trial of its migraine treatment ALD403.Marriott International (MAR) jumped 4% and Starwood Hotels (HOT) climbed more than 2.5% to boost the S&P 500. Starwood announced China-based insurer Angbang  has now proposed an $81 per share takeover offer, the latest in a pitched battle between Anbang and Marriott to acquire the worldwide, 1,300-hotel chain.Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) popped 6% after reporting a solid fiscal third-quarter revenue and earnings beat.  The stock has been trying to climb the right side of a consolidation since January, but has been stuck below resistance at its 10-week moving average for the past five weeks.On the IBD 50 list, MaxLinear (MXL) did well, rising 2%. The stock tripped a sell signal by giving up a 16% gain above a 16.29 buy point. It's still holding above its 10-week moving average and trading near an alternate entry at 17.85.Overseas, China's Shanghai composite slipped 0.7%, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged 0.7% higher.  Markets in Europe and Hong Kong remained closed for the Easter holiday.

Here's one data point that doesn't gibe with the complaint that economic gains are increasingly limited to an exclusive club: Minority-owned business ownership has been surging.Among businesses with at least five employees, the percentage with minority owners rose to 13.3% from 9.7% from 2007 to 2012, finds an IBD analysis of the most current data from the Census Department.The rise in minority ownership among businesses operating franchises of established brands has been especially impressive. In 2012, 21.1% of franchise operators with at least five workers had minority owners vs. 15.8% in 2007. Meanwhile, among firms that don't operate franchises, 12.6% had minority owners in 2012, up from 9.3% five years earlier.The jump in minority ownership of franchises helps explain a surge in minority-owned restaurants noted by the National Restaurant Association.The data confirm something that is well understood by many entrepreneurs from diverse backgrounds who have sought to carve out a share of the economic pie: Franchising has provided one of the most accessible and surest paths to business success.Among African-Americans, for example, fully 24% of all businesses with at least 50 workers are engaged in franchising, the new Census data show.Yet this model is increasingly under attack from the political left, which sees franchising as a problem, not a solution. Whereas thousands of minority business owners may see franchising as the best approximation of a golden goose within their reach, the labor movement and its campaign for a $15 minimum wage can't see past their arch-nemesis — the golden arches.In their view, dispersing economic power among franchisers makes it harder to unionize service-industry workers than it would be if labor unions could directly target corporate giants. In that sense, minority-owned franchises are merely an obstacle that must be steamrolled for the greater good.The National Labor Relations Board provided a steamroller suited to the task in designating McDonald's (MCD) a joint-employer of employees who work for franchise-owned locations — about 90% of the restaurant chain's total workforce.McDonald's contends that the designation makes no sense because franchise operators make all decisions involving hiring, firing, pay and work schedules. The company's legal challenge is now being heard by an NLRB administrative judge, but the case may take a few years to play out as it heads next to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and then possibly to the Supreme Court.Beyond facilitating a push to unionize franchises, the joint-employer designation would turn small employers into large ones subject to ObamaCare employer penalties for failing to offer qualifying health coverage to workers clocking at least 30 hours per week. It also would make corporations with deep pockets liable for labor violations of its franchise operators.Together, these factors would put so much strain on franchise operators and their brand-name partners that their agreements — typically 4% of revenue goes to the franchisor in return for training and the benefits of scale and name-recognition — may no longer be viable.That's a risk the left is apparently unconcerned about, as evident in the appeal before the Supreme Court challenging Seattle's discriminatory treatment of franchises. In petitioning justices for a hearing, the International Franchise Association highlighted internal emails among government officials expressing their disapproval of the franchise model.At issue in the case is Seattle's more-rapid phase-in of its minimum wage for franchise businesses, which are considered to be large employers if the chain has more than 500 workers systemwide, even if the franchise operator has a single location.In an email to a fellow city council member, Nick Hanauer explained the reason for treating small-business that operate franchises differently than other small businesses: "The truth is that franchises like Subway and McDonald's really are not very good for our local economy. They are economically extractive, civically corrosive and culturally dilutive."Presumably, one of the reasons that a broad segment of franchising companies has made a concerted effort to increase local minority ownership is to make the business model more of a contributor to local economies.There are other advantages, as well, such as a low cost of capital. In the ObamaCare era, letting others do the hiring also may help limit the cost of the employer mandate.New York, in ordering fast-food companies to pay a $15 minimum wage — phased in by 2019 in New York City and by 2021 statewide — also lumped small franchise operators in with bigger employers.The New York Fast Food Wage Board blasted the franchise industry for a "combination of profits and impoverishment," saying that the industry gets a subsidy in the form of public assistance to its workers.The rule covers a long list of food vendors without table service which have at least 30 locations in the U.S. Among them are Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell, Shake Shack (SHAK), Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN), Jamba Juice (JMBA), Wendy's (WEN) and Subway.Ironically, big franchisors like McDonald's might stand to gain if their franchises raised wages. That's because the typical 4%-of-revenue royalty would rise if the franchise was able to pass along a price hike to customers to cover higher labor costs. Thus, the real gripe with the franchise industry may be a royalty structure that provides an incentive to keep costs down. That's why franchisers may be highly likely to eliminate labor costs by investing in technology if wages rise too high.Image provided by Shutterstock.

High-rated Adobe Systems (ADBE) stock edged up Thursday but closed down slightly for the week of its Adobe Summit 2016 digital marketing conference. That’s a week after shares advanced almost 9% on the strength of Adobe’s first-quarter earnings report and outlook.The Adobe Summit in Las Vegas drew more than 10,000 people -- the company’s largest live event to date. The theme centered around how brands are increasingly interacting with consumers in a wave of “digital experiences” online that leverage social networking.Actor George Clooney spoke at the Adobe Summit on Wednesday, but most presenters were from the tech and business worlds. Executives from major brands were among the featured speakers, from McDonald’s (MCD) and Mattel (MAT) to General Motors (GM) and General Electric (GE) to Comcast (CMCSA) and Charles Schwab (SCHW).That's right. It's George at #AdobeSummit talking experience and creativity. Watch live now: https://t.co/NTBQXucWEM pic.twitter.com/Q0HoYKOw3f— Adobe (@Adobe) March 23, 2016“Adobe’s momentum in digital marketing was demonstrated in record attendance, including by CEOs, at its marketing summit,” Pacific Crest analyst Brendan Barnicle wrote in a research note as the conference kicked off Tuesday. “New products and partnerships increase its strategic value both to customers and the industry, and should drive continued growth and market-share gains.”Adobe Summit Sees World Gone Digital, From ‘Deadpool’ To Sea Of Data https://t.co/wT0S73h5it pic.twitter.com/Qz56otNOGn— Investors.com (@IBDinvestors) March 22, 2016Adobe makes the Creative Cloud suite of content tools, such as Photoshop and Premiere Pro video editing software, along with the Adobe Marketing Cloud array of tools to track online content popularity and inform advertising decisions. This week, the company announced an audience measurement partnership with comScore (SCOR), among initiatives aimed at improving measurement of online video viewing and other forms of content consumption across platforms.FBR & Co. analyst Samad Samana wrote Wednesday about an analyst briefing held in conjunction with the conference that "focused  almost  entirely  on  Adobe’s  technology  and  the  platform  pivot." In recent years, Adobe has moved headlong to host its products in the Internet cloud, using the software-as-a-service (SaaS) model, with platforms that handle content’s entire life cycle from creation through tracking consumer interaction with it. Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen summed up a broad Adobe goal: being able to “make, monetize and measure” the digital experiences that people have."Management highlighted that it is investing around the 'experience business’ wave of disruption and innovating at the platform level, both of which will be important in driving long-term growth for the digital marketing business," Samana wrote. "While it is in the early stages, we see the platform play as strategically smart, as it should enhance the value proposition for Adobe’s entire product suite, making it stickier with customers."Adobe, which is on the IBD Big Cap 20 stock list, closed up 0.4% Thursday at 92.52, down 1% for the week. The stock market is closed on Good Friday, March 25. Adobe gets a high IBD Composite Rating of 96 out of a possible 99. Adobe stock is a few percentage points under a potential buy point, trading above both its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.RELATED: Adobe Summit Sees World Gone Digital, From 'Deadpool' To Sea Of DataImage provided by Shutterstock.

The strong dollar has been a drag on U.S. multinationals for several quarters. But with the greenback turning flabby, investors are betting on better corporate results, pushing Dow stocks General Electric (GE), McDonald’s (MCD), Microsoft (MSFT) and Coca-Cola (KO) near or above buy points.Another Dow component, Nike (NKE), fell Wednesday after reporting weaker-than-expected revenue for its February quarter, in part due to the dollar. The athletic shoe and apparel giant's sales rose 8% but would have climbed 14% excluding currency swings.Yet the currency headwind is waning. The U.S. dollar index, which measures the greenback against the euro, yen and 4 other  currencies, has turned lower vs. a year earlier in the last few weeks -- down 0.9% as of Wednesday, even with a recent upturn. At this time last year, the dollar index was up 21%.The Federal Reserve's decision this month to trim its plans to hike interest rates certainly had an impact. When investors expect U.S. rates to be lower for longer, their view tends to negatively impact the greenback, which becomes less attractive to yield-seeking investors. The dollar has rallied somewhat in recent days on less-dovish comments from various Fed officials.Although companies are still using the dollar as a reason for negative guidance, they're using that reason "a little less than before," said Gregory Harrison, a senior research analyst at Thomson Reuters."It seems like other factors are a little more prominent now -- like the slowing global economy and the slowdown in China," he said.Uncertainty over the U.S. presidential election usually tends to make consumers pull back a bit in spending, he added, noting also that a sagging energy sector has been a much bigger drag on corporate earnings than the dollar."That’s kind of expected to remain the case throughout the year -- at least until the fourth quarter," Harrison said.Meanwhile, central banks in Europe and Japan have gone to negative rates, but their recent moves unexpectedly lifted their currencies against the dollar. The Chinese yuan has erased its early 2016 losses vs. the greenback.And stocks have responded. General Electric saw its stock break out of a cup-with-handle base with a 30.69 buy point on March 17, a few weeks after Coca-Cola cleared a long consolidation to a record high.McDonald's briefly rose to 125 on the stock market today, hitting a record high and just passing a buy point of 124.93. But the below-average volume rise faded to a 0.3% gain at 124.19.Procter & Gamble (PG) stock is on the cusp of retaking a buy point at 83.10. Microsoft also is close to an entry point.Of course, the dollar isn't the only reason for their success.McDonald's decision to introduce an all-day breakfast boosted the fast-food chain in Q4 to its best U.S. quarterly sales in nearly four years after several years of struggling.Coca-Cola is in the middle of selling its U.S. manufacturing and distribution operations by next year. Instead, Coke plans to focus on its concentrate-making business, which is more profitable. Procter & Gamble is moving to focus on more-profitable core brands.GE is transitioning back to its industrial roots, with a strong digital footprint. The company is selling off much of its once-massive GE Capital financial services unit. General Electric is also moving its headquarters from Fairfield, Conn., to Boston, a tech hub located near several major universities that should supply the company with fresh, young tech talent.Despite the market turbulence over the past 12 months, Microsoft has been a top performer, gaining 26% from a year ago; near the end of last year, it eclipsed its dot-com boom peak. The company has finally made a push into mobile, and its Windows 10 operating system has won praise -- especially after the debacle of Windows 8.As for Nike, the athletic brand king had been closing in on a new high but closed down 3.8% Wednesday. Nike reported after Tuesday's market close that fiscal Q3 earnings rose 22% and that currency-neutral futures orders leapt 17%, both results better than expected. But Nike sales fell short, and the company gave cautious fiscal 2017 guidance.A weakening dollar should provide a better business climate for blue-chip giants going forward. But if the Fed turns hawkish and the greenback firms up, investor optimism about profits may fade, threatening Dow breakouts.Those with a more skeptical view say that the window was closing on the tough year-over-year currency comparisons anyway and that the real story was corporate earnings finally catching up to the sluggish revenue environment."Revenue growth has been somewhat constrained for quite some time," said Richard Moody, chief economist at Regions Financial. "That just reflects you can only get so far on the expense side of the ledger and support earnings growth that way. Cost cutting can only take you so far."

Aberdeen U.S. Small Cap Equity Fund (GSXAX) is on a roll. Through March 31, the now-$558 million portfolio was the eighth-best performing U.S. diversified stock fund in the prior 12 months with a 7.58% return, according to Morningstar Inc. And it was No. 1 among small-cap funds. The S&P 500 advanced a more modest 1.35% in that period.At the quarter's end, the fund ranked in the top 1% and 2% of its small-cap growth peers over the past three and five years, respectively.The fund captures an A+ 36-month Performance Rating from IBD, which means that its performance is among the top 5% of all mutual funds in that time.Thirty-two-year-old Ralph Bassett and 47-year-old Jason Kotik, two of the fund's four managers, spoke with IBD from their offices in Philadelphia about how they invest.IBD: Describe key aspects of your research process.Kotik: We have concentrated positions of between 40 and 60 names. We start with meeting a company's management team. Some investors look at screens. We look at a company to understand its business model, to look at its historical margins and returns, the balance sheet, things like that. We build a list of questions for that management team.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Six-Month LeadersThe bigger difference (between us and other funds) is that, while we interview company management like other investors do, we take a three-to-five-year or longer approach to understanding businesses because we'll hold them a long time.Our turnover is 25% to 35% a year, the lower end of the range for most funds. Our approach is really about understanding management's discipline around their capital investments, understanding them and building a relationship with them.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Category PerformanceSo, in the future when things don't go as planned -- and there's always a time when things don't go as planned, always -- we know how they will react, based on their answers to our questions.That's really the most important part of understanding a business.IBD: You recently wrote that volatility can be an opportunity. Was the recent market volatility a buying opportunity?Bassett: In the back half of last year and the first month of this year, I would say there was more opportunity than we'd seen in a long time.We did find some companies of higher quality but linked to less predominant macro themes (than the ones that hurt the energy sector). Things unfairly got discounted around macro contagion and dollar strength. We take a long view and assume dollar strength will subside over time. So we found some good opportunities.IBD: What are some examples?Kotik: We found opportunities to take advantage of names we own. One example in Q4, we were able to top up Canadian Western Bank. When you think of western Canada, you think of oil and gas, the oil sands market. So you'd think their loans portfolio would be filled with damaged goods. But less than 3% of their loans are to oil companies. They had traded down to tangible book and to book value. We took advantage of the marketplace selling off energy stocks and Canadian stocks and anything related to the Canadian dollar, and we added to our position.IBD: What example would you provide, Ralph?Bassett: We initiated a position in WisdomTree Investments (WETF) in February at the depths of the market. Their business is focused on ETFs and specifically those that are bespoke in nature -- bespoke in the sense that they are the only solely-ETF-focused company that is public. They also have been very innovative and quick to market with products compared to their peers. Now they have a wide product menu, and that can capture shifts in client asset allocation over time.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Quarterly LeadersWe had grappled with their valuation for a while. Frankly, we watched it tumbled from 30 to 24 to roughly 10 -- then it got more intriguing. A lot of concerns about their product concentration and competitive forces were, in our minds, diminished.Secondly, they had net cash on their balance sheet and intended to keep it that way, so we weren't worried about financial risk.We will be slow and patient. This is an example of our process patience.IBD: What else besides the housing rebound is driving Gibraltar Industries (ROCK)?Kotik: It sold off in the down market, and we added to it. It's rebounded more than 40% off its bottom.Gibraltar has started to make a strong transition in its business model to diversify its end markets.Its new CEO (Frank Heard) came from Illinois Tools Works (ITW) and brought ITW's tenets of focusing on the parts of the business that provide higher profits.It's a building products company. It sells things like mailboxes to Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's Cos. (LOW). They have a large contract with the postal service for large-scale postal boxes. Apartment buildings need them because of ecommerce and the way consumers now buy products. Apartment managers can't figure out where to put all of this mail and packages. So Gibraltar came up with a plan for a new model.We own it because they use their capital extremely efficiently, and their cash flow is expanding. They're moving to a higher-margin mix of businesses.We look for company-specific drivers. Gibraltar benefits from the housing rebound. But we won't invest in companies that benefit just from volume and cyclical rebounds. We need a specific driver. For Gibraltar, it was about their transition to a more diversified business, driving higher quality profitability, rather than a focus on top-line growth.IBD: OK, what's the driver for Drew Industries (DW), a maker of components for recreational vehicles and manufactured homes?Kotik: The interest is that they've been adding dollar content on products to the RV and manufactured home industries. They've consistently improved their content dollars per vehicle.

Their continued market share gains let them perform well even during tough times. But we're skeptical when everything is going right. We still hold it at an average weight, and we brought it down to capture profits.IBD: You own some stocks that sound like they're in non-sexy businesses. What's their appeal? What's the special catalyst? Start with RBC Bearings (ROLL), please.Bassett: They make highly specialized ball bearings, which range from pen-cap size to several feet. Those big ones go into huge industrial products and reactors.They focus on specialty areas where the ball bearings need to be designed into the product. That reduces competition, so they capture margin along the way. Their business is high-value-added, taking share in programs. They've thought about acquisitions but are being careful. Years down the road, there could be pressure on their aerospace business. We're mindful of the potential cyclicality.IBD: What about Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), an egg distributor?Bassett: They are slowly shifting away from the egg commodity part of their business. About one-quarter of their business is providing specialties like liquid eggs to McDonald's (MCD) and Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN).They're increasing their organic eggs business. And a lot of customers want cage-free eggs. Few companies can afford to provide that. It takes capital for land and structures for organic eggs and cage-free eggs.So Cal-Maine not only picks up business, it consolidates as smaller farmers are forced out.IBD: What's the special driver for MarketAxess Holdings (MKTX), an electronic bond-trading exchange?Bassett: Previously, a lot trades went through large investment banks with huge inventory.
