Earnings reports ruled the stock market again Thursday, with heavy hitters such as McDonald's (MCD), eBay (EBAY) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) scoring big gains on upside surprises.The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 1.9% jump, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq each rallied nearly 1.7% in the stock market today. Volume ran sharply higher across the board, according to preliminary data.The Dow was fueled by McDonald's, which gapped up and soared 8% to a record best after its Q3 results topped views. Apple (AAPL) added 1.5%, and Microsoft (MSFT), due to report after the close, rose 2%. Only four blue chips fell, including American Express (AXP), down 5% after its Q3 profit missed views late Wednesday.Steel, security software and chipmakers were among the day's biggest gainers. Drugmakers and other medical groups got hurt, led by hospitals. Community Health Systems (CYH) gapped down and fell 35% in huge volume to a near three-year low. Analysts downgraded the stock after the Tennessee-based acute-care hospital operator reported preliminary Q3 results well below forecasts.After the close, Amazon.com (AMZN) vaulted 12.5% on blowout earnings, and Alphabet (GOOGL) jumped 10.5% on strong Q3 results.Notable IBD 50 gainers in volume included Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), up 5% in fast trade to break out past a 68.06 handle buy point, and water-heater maker A.O. Smith (AOS), which rose 6%.But LGI Homes (LGIH) reversed lower and sank 6% in big volume. It's still extended from an August breakout and subsequent test of the 10-week line. Homebuilder stocks moved in sympathy with Pulte Homes (PHM), which gapped down and fell 7% after its Q3 earnings missed views.Early Thursday, the Housing Price Index for August climbed 0.3% but came in below views. Existing-home sales for September rose nearly 5% to 5.55 million, topping forecasts.Earnings due Friday include American Airlines (AAL), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL).Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.
Consumer prices fell again in September on cheap energy. That's helped keep real wage gains solid, but they'll shrivel when CPI comparisons get tougher at year-end.

The consumer price index fell 0.2% after August's 0.1% dip. Credit yet another sharp drop in gasoline and other energy prices, as oil prices fell further. CPI was flat vs. a year earlier, in the zero-bound range it's been throughout 2015. Energy prices are down 18.4% year on year.

But core CPI, which excludes food and energy , rose 0.2% in September. Core inflation crept up to 1.9%. That's the highest it's been in more than a year and just below the Federal Reserve's 2% target.

Meanwhile, real weekly wages fell 0.2% in the latest month, reflecting a shorter workweek. Year over year, inflation-adjusted weekly wages are up 2.2%. That's down from 3% in January but still a solid boost for consumers.

But comparisons are about to get tougher. At this time last year, oil futures were still above $80 a barrel vs. about $46 right now. But by the end of 2014, crude prices fell to $53.27 a barrel and briefly undercut $44 in January. That means energy, even if it stays below $50 a barrel for the foreseeable future, will no longer be a huge drag on inflation.
Wage Impact On Holiday Shopping

Real wage gains likely will fade significantly in the middle of the holiday shopping season. While the Apple (AAPL) iPhone and new toys around Walt Disney 's (DIS) "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" movie likely will be hot sellers, consumers may realize they don't have more discretionary income than a year earlier.
Could nominal hourly pay gains ramp up and workweeks lengthen?
Well, Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), McDonald's (MCD), Target (TGT) and some other big employers are raising wages, while many states and local governments are hiking the minimum wage.
But private job growth has slowed to a three-year low, while higher minimum wages could spur businesses to trim jobs or limit hours for low-wage workers.

The world's largest restaurant chain, McDonald's (MCD), is close to deciding what to do with its real estate holdings, amid calls for a spinoff of those assets into a real estate investment trust.Board member Miles White, who is chairman and CEO of diversified medical products maker Abbott Laboratories (ABT), told the Wall Street Journal in an interview that the fast-food giant has done a lot of due diligence but hasn't yet made a final decision.McDonald's shares changed little in extended-hours trading Thursday after rising 0.8% in the regular session on the stock market today.As customers have shifted away from McDonald's to fast-casual chains such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), some investors and analysts have pushed for a REIT.In fact, McDonald's has been mulling taking action on its real estate as part of a broad restructuring undertaken by new CEO Steve Easterbrook, who took the reins in March.In May, Easterbrook said that McDonald's would examine "all opportunities" and might look at spinning off real estate assets or creating a REIT structure.Other companies have faced similar calls to spin off their real estate. MGM Resorts International (MGM) has been under pressure from shareholder Land and Buildings Investment to sell real estate.Sears (SHLD) spun off its property into Seritage Growth Properties (SRG). And several hedge funds asked Macy's (M) to consider options for its real estate.Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.

What a week to go on vacation! The weather was great up on the Cape - and the ocean was the perfect temperature - but that did not stop the markets from convulsing for another week. By the end of last week - the markets suffered another loss - Friday saw the indices give back 1.5+% on the back of that 'stellar NFP report' - taking the S&P to 1921 and the Dow to 16,102…as traders and investors try to make sense out of the recent beating. Despite the volatile action in stocks last week, the selling has not taken prices anywhere near the recent sell-off lows of 1865 and the fact that the selling has not been nearly as bad in the microcap sector - suggests that traders and some investors are using the 'blue chips' as a source of cash, pressuring large cap asset managers to liquidate portions of some positions as the nervousness increases. For the week - the Dow tumbled 3.2%, the S&P was down by 3.4% and the Nasdaq lost 3%.

The selling was the same around the globe with Asian and European markets all under pressure. Mounting concerns over a weaker China, and an indecisive FED, weak energy prices, slowing global growth, weaker Europe, imploding emerging markets, a US gov't bond market under assault (as China sold nearly $100 bil in reserves - treasuries - as they deal with a 'destabilized Yuan and a slowing economy) add in that massive human tragedy out of the Middle East and you can see why global investors are concerned.

So why all the fuss? Most of this is not new news - China? The Fed? Weaker Oil?, Emerging Markets? We have been talking about these issues for months now and what it all may mean for markets....and yet the markets continued to push higher with the Dow making a new high in May, the S&P and Nasdaq making their new highs in July and the Russell ringing the bell in June. So what gives?

Many now point to the collapse in China's stock market which began in June - after an incredible 122% increase in 12 months....or a 53% increase ytd.... China's currency devaluation only exacerbated the concerns....in fact we can point to that event as the catalyst that lit the flame to ignite the fire and by most accounts many would agree.

We have heard all this talk about a slowing China - Current projections still have that economy growing at 7.3% this year or 2x that of the US. Could it be more that analysts and companies had become a bit too bullish on China? Did we put all our eggs in one basket? Was it the herd mentality that got us into trouble again? I'm just sayin.....

Concern over China's market action has dominated the news wires for weeks now....as their market has given back and then some all of their ytd gains.... The gov't - shell shocked - tried in vain to 'control' the action only adding to the angst....Threatening short sellers with a public caning, banning some investors from liquidating positions, imposing new rules on the fly, all while trying to convey a sense of normalcy....How'd that work out? Remember - this is an economy run by a communist gov't, an economy in transition, it is an 'emerging economy'. The imploding stock market - sending the message that they were in trouble - has caused a global rout as investors run for cover and every bear out there is calling for a massive global reset (again) - Think 2007/2010.

But we don't need to worry - because this weekend at the G20 summit in Turkey - PBoC (Peoples Bank of China) Governor Zhou Xiaochuan told the members that "China's stock market has almost completed its correction"

And BOOM! Like clockwork - China rallied some 2.9% overnight..... I just want to know one thing? How does he know that? I mean most gov'ts don't have a clue about what moves the markets - just take a look at Washington.

Which brings us to our own issues..... If our gov't actually understood how to create a vibrant economy that benefits everyone they would employ FISCAL POLICY initiatives to complement the massive MONETARY POLICY initiatives to actually help our economy create long term, well-paying jobs which in turn will help our country and economy get back on track. But case in point - they don't have a clue - Congress and the current administration have done zero to create any real positive economic change. We've got a massive multi trillion deficit, higher taxes, burgeoning entitlement programs and a FED that is caught between a rock and a hard place because legislators have failed them and us. Maybe The Donald IS onto something!

We are sure to hear much more about possible FED moves in the next two weeks ahead of the September 17th announcement.....I can only hope that Janet and her band of merry men consider the implications of any move now......I mean they have had plenty of opportunity to raise rates all year and failed to do so - but now in the midst of all this turmoil - they suggest that the time is right....REALLY?

Friday's NFP report could be used to argue either way....right? Some say it was downright disappointing - missing the projection by 47k - but once you add in the 'revisions' from June and July - then it's a wash……and unemployment - oh right that managed to move lower - 5.1% - as well - putting the country at 'full employment'- Even the analysts were surprised!

Avg hrly earnings are on the rise - climbing 0.3% to $25.09/hr - taking you to $52k/yr - but not if you work at MCD or WMT - There you are making $10/hr or $21k/yr. And speaking of MCD's - did you see their answer to the increase in the minimum wage? They are now installing ATM-like machines - that allow the customer to place their orders directly - no human interaction - and just go to the window and pick it up - eliminating even more jobs.... Pretty soon - there won't be a human being working in the joint...... I'm just sayin….think about what that does to their BOTTOM line!

And Inflation? Not happening...and the culprit? Weaker energy prices! Come on! In fact - at some point - weak oil has to be viewed as a boon to the economies - I mean you can't argue that expensive oil is bad for the economy AND cheap oil is bad for the economy - One of those arguments has to be wrong...... Cheap energy should cause everything to be cheaper - transportation is cheaper so that means that the goods that they move around should be less expensive, Airlines should feel the benefits of cheaper oil, Transportation companies should benefit, consumers should be getting a break at the pump, at the grocery store, and at the clothing store - businesses are getting a break on energy costs, homeowners are getting a break on heating costs etc….so when is cheaper oil viewed as a positive? Just think - the minute it starts to trade higher - then every analyst will tell us how higher prices are negatively affecting the economy!

So what about rates? Is September a Yay or Nay? Futures traders now have it at a 28% chance of a rate hike in September and are now betting on a November rate hike....and the coming eco reports over the next two weeks will only keep the volatility alive. There are also sure to be a number of speeches and articles by major Fed players as they test the market for investor angst....- so listen closely - Watch what they do vs. what they say.

Overnight Asian stocks moved in opposite directions.....China rallies 2.9% ( after being off another 1.5% in early trading) right after the gov't announced an $11 bil railway project.....this after their Aug trade data continues to paint a picture of a slowing economy - exports fell by 5.5% while imports plunged by 13.8%. Japan was down 2.4% giving back all of this year's gains - after they revealed that revised GDP was not as bad as previously thought! That market is now slightly negative on the year, Hong Kong +3.2% and ASX +1.6%.

In Europe - markets are all higher....seemingly able to ignore the latest weak Chinese data points.....M&A in the insurance sector is fueling today's advance in Euro markets. FTSE +1.9%, CAC 40 + 2.2%, DAX + 2.5%, EUROSTOXX + 2.3%, SPAIN +1.8% and ITALY +2.2%.

US Futures are screaming higher - currently up 37 pts or 2% - as they look to pierce the 1950 level here on the opening. The market is clearly trying to find its 'happy place'.....and action around 1950 seems to be it. Much of the action during the past two weeks has revolved around this level.....a move up and thru and a close above would be a better sign. But we remain in a volatile situation....Look for 1920 to be support as we search for near term resistance - which I think is at the 1970 level. There is not much on the Eco data front today, but later in the week - we will get PPI, Wholesale Inv, JOLTS Job Openings.
Take good care
Kp

The weather was great up on the Cape - and the ocean was the perfect temperature - but that did not stop the markets from convulsing for another week. By the end of last week - the markets suffered another loss - Friday saw the indices give back 1.5+% on the back of that 'stellar NFP report' - taking the S&P to 1921 and the Dow to 16,102…as traders and investors try to make sense out of the recent beating. Despite the volatile action in stocks last week, the selling has not taken prices anywhere near the recent sell-off lows of 1865 and the fact that the selling has not been nearly as bad in the microcap sector - suggests that traders and some investors are using the 'blue chips' as a source of cash, pressuring large cap asset managers to liquidate portions of some positions as the nervousness increases. For the week - the Dow tumbled 3.2%, the S&P was down by 3.4% and the Nasdaq lost 3%.The selling was the same around the globe with Asian and European markets all under pressure. Mounting concerns over a weaker China, and an indecisive FED, weak energy prices, slowing global growth, weaker Europe, imploding emerging markets, a US gov't bond market under assault (as China sold nearly $100 bil in reserves - treasuries - as they deal with a 'destabilized Yuan and a slowing economy) add in that massive human tragedy out of the Middle East and you can see why global investors are concerned.So why all the fuss? Most of this is not new news - China? The Fed? Weaker Oil?, Emerging Markets? We have been talking about these issues for months now and what it all may mean for markets....and yet the markets continued to push higher with the Dow making a new high in May, the S&P and Nasdaq making their new highs in July and the Russell ringing the bell in June. Stocks cut their losses following the release of the Fed minutes Wednesday, but sold off again into the close. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.9%, as Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) weighed. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each gave up 0.8%. Volume was higher across the board, according to preliminary data. That would mean another distribution day for the major indexes.Energy stocks led the decline in the stock market today as crude oil prices slid to new lows. In the much smaller list of advancing industry groups, gold miners, Internet content and building stocks eked out gains.D.R. Horton (DHI) added 2% in heavy trade to a new nine-year high. Shares of the Texas-based homebuilder are now 12% extended from a 38.80 cup-with-handle buy point.Lowe's (LOW) rose 2% in fast turnover for its fifth straight advance. The home improvement chain reported mixed Q2 results, with a profit miss and sales beat. It guided full-year earnings a penny higher than Street forecasts.Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, with 35 decliners and 15 advancers. CyberArk Software (CYBR) led with a 4% pop. Nike (NKE) was one of only two Dow components to close in the black. McDonald's (MCD) (not in the IBD 50) was the other.Thursday's economic data include jobless claims for the week of Aug. 15, July existing-home sales and the Philly Fed business outlook survey for August. The Fed's Narayana Kocherlakota and John Williams are also scheduled to speak.Wednesday's Fed minutes indicated a September rate hike is still on the table.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

If there's one thing officials at Chipotle Mexican Grill want you to know, it's that it is not like other restaurant companies.Sure, Chipotle's (CMG) fast-casual Mexican eateries prepare food in kitchens and serve it to guests who pay money for the privilege, just like at other restaurants.And yes, business tends to pick up around lunch and dinner, when folks queue up to order the company's freshly prepared burritos, tacos and salads.And yes, Chipotle needs to keep food, labor and other costs in line if it wants to hit its margins and deliver the kind of profits that make investors tingle with joy.But that's where the similarities end — at least from Chipotle's point of view."Our business is pretty different than others in the category in that we don't rely on some of the things others depend on, such as limited-time offers, merchandise ties and new menu items," said Chris Arnold, the company's communications director.No Smoke And MirrorsChipotle doesn't depend on "gimmicks" to drive customers through its doors, Arnold says. Instead, it relies on the company's "food culture and people culture."On the food side, Chipotle focuses on "finding the best ingredients we can and preparing them using classic cooking techniques," Arnold told IBD.On the people side, the company looks to hire the right workers and develop them into managers.Ninety-eight percent of Chipotle's managers are hired internally from the company's rank-and-file crew, Arnold says. Last year it promoted more than 9,000 people into management positions."This leads to a better customer-service experience and more operational efficiency," Arnold said.It's hard to argue with the results. Chipotle almost always churns out double-digit sales and profit growth and consistently ranks among the top stocks in the restaurant sector.Its financial might was on display during the second quarter, which Chipotle reported after the close on July 21.The company stomped all over earnings and sales estimates despite implementing its first price increase in three years to help cover higher food costs.The next day, Chipotle's stock price soared nearly 12% to 659.77 for the biggest single-day gain since last fall. Shares currently trade near 678.Chipotle logged earnings of $3.50 a share for the quarter, up 24% from the prior year and well ahead of estimates for $3.08 a share.Overall sales gained 29% to $1.05 billion, beating views for $989.55 million. It was the third straight quarter of accelerated top-line growth.Same-store sales climbed 17.3% vs. expectations for a 10.5% gain. Chipotle also raised its full-year same-store sales guidance to the midteens from its prior guidance of growth in the high single digits."It's the best traffic number in the industry," Sterne Agee analyst Lynne Collier said after the earnings report. "Rarely do you see numbers this high. Most of the companies we follow have recently put up flattish to slightly negative traffic numbers."In a report, Citigroup analyst Gregory Badishkanian said there was "no single driver" of Chipotle's strong same-store sales performance, though he did point to a few key drivers.One was a bigger (though still small) contribution from Chipotle's catering business. It represented 1.6% of sales during the second quarter, up from 0.3% the prior year.Badishkanian also says Chipotle benefited from improved marketing during the quarter.Compared with other restaurant operators in the fast-casual and fast-food sectors, Chipotle doesn't spend a whole lot of money on marketing. While most companies spend 3% to 5% of their revenue on advertising, Chipotle spends 1.75%, Arnold says."We are not pursuing the kinds of gimmicks that fast-food companies pursue, such as new products," he said. "Those are very expensive; a lot of R&D goes into developing new menu items, then you have to spend a lot of money on marketing."Instead, Chipotle focuses on non-traditional marketing efforts that range from producing Web videos and sponsoring food and music festivals to partnering with local farmer's markets.While marketing helps drive top-line growth, Chipotle looked to bolster its bottom line with a rare price increase during the second quarter to help offset rising costs of beef, avocados and cheese."We generally try to hold the line on pricing and raise prices as a last resort," Arnold said. "We just felt like we had to do it."Badishkanian, who recently met with Chipotle management, noted after the meeting that the company is not seeing "any impact" from raising prices, and added that Chipotle still feels that its prices are too low in the Northeast.One reason customers aren't terribly concerned about the higher prices is they are confident in the quality and freshness of Chipotle's food, analysts say. That holds true not just for Chipotle, but also for other fast-casual chains such as Panera Bread (PNRA), Qdoba Mexican Grill — a division of Jack in the Box (JACK) — and Baja Fresh, according to a recent report from analysts at research firm Trefis.Top Of The LineFast-casual restaurants provide more "freshly prepared and high-quality food than traditional quick-service restaurants (QSR), all in an upscale and inviting ambiance with meals ranging from $8 to $15," Trefis said, adding, "Big QSR brands such as McDonald's (MCD), Subway and Starbucks (SBUX) have been facing a huge threat by the leading fast-casual restaurants, as the traffic growth in the latter segment surpassed that of every other segment for the fifth consecutive year (in 2013)."To help meet rising customer demand, Chipotle opened 45 new restaurants during the second quarter to bring the total to more than 1,600. That total includes 17 Chipotle restaurants outside the U.S. and seven ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen restaurants.The company also has a stake in one Pizzeria Locale in Denver.In any given year, about 80% of its expansion is in existing markets, Arnold says."We have a pretty good idea of what the returns will be in those markets," he said.

Taco Bell launched home delivery service Wednesday in 90 cities from more than 200 restaurants.
The move comes as restaurants broaden their technologies to include ordering from smartphones and tablets and other ways to order, prepare, distribute and receive food.
Yum Brands (YUM)-owned Taco Bell joins Starbucks (SBUX), which in March said it will try delivery service in its Seattle hometown and inside the Empire State Building.

Taco Bell is partnering with on-demand Silicon Valley-based delivery service DoorDash. Taco Bell will deliver initially in metropolitan areas including Los Angeles, Orange County, the San Francisco Bay Area and Dallas.

"Delivery is yet another example of how we're using technology and innovation to respond to consumers' wants and needs, further evolving the Taco Bell experience for customers," Taco Bell CEO Brian Niccol said.
Despite its new home delivery, Yum Brands shares tanked 3.5% to 86.71 in Wednesday morning trading in the stock market today, before all New York Stock Exchange trading was suspended.

The parent of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut hit an all-time high at 95.90 on May 20 and then consolidated. The stock was forming a flat base with a 96 buy point but dropped below its 50-day moving average Friday, and with Wednesday's drop was about 9% below its high.

Fast food giants McDonald's (MCD) and Burger King haven't made a major push into home delivery yet, but Taco Bell will compete in that convenience with pizza restaurants, such as Papa John's (PZZA) and Yum Brands' own Pizza Hut, which have long offered delivery service. McDonald's shares were down 0.5% Wednesday morning on the Big Board.

Starbucks said in March that its delivery system will debut by the end of this year and is paired with the company's mobile payment technology and extensive customer loyalty program. Starbucks said at the time that its goal is to use new initiatives and global expansion to nearly double its revenue by 2019.

Starbucks stock has easily outpaced the market this year. The stock has a 98 IBD Composite Rating, meaning its has outperformed 98% of all stocks on key metrics including sales and profit growth. It has hit a series of new highs. The most recent was an intraday high of 54.75 on May 26. On the Nasdaq, Starbucks shares were down 1.4% Wednesday morning.
Papa John's, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, was down 0.4% Wednesday morning on the Nasdaq.

Stock futures were off to a neck-wrenching start Thursday, as earnings reports powered a volatile premarket session.

Dow futures were up and down, showing a 4-point gain vs. fair market value 45 minutes before the start of regular trade. S&P 500 futures were up 1.6 points. Nasdaq 100 futures gained 9 points. All were down sharply vs. their hour-earlier gains.

The stock market today gets a chock-full calendar of important quarterly reports. But investors will be looking toward an equally busy after-hours reporting session, headlined by Amazon.com's (AMZN) second-quarter results.

Economic news got off to a positive start, as the Labor Department reported weekly initial jobless claims fell to 255,000 in the week ended July 18. That was down from 281,000 in the prior week and well below consensus estimates for 279,000 claims. The four-week moving average ticked down to 278,500 claims, its first decline in four weeks.

In stocks, some heavyweight names were in serious early motion. American Express (AXP) and Qualcomm (QCOM) were down 2%. Caterpillar (CAT) fell 3%. Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) surged 3% and General Motors (GM) spiked 6%. Others, like McDonald's (MCD), Pulte (PHM) and Raytheon (RTN), barely budged.

Semiconductor plays were getting some early attention, led by SanDisk (SNDK), which vaulted 13% higher after reporting its Q2 earnings fell much less than expected. Revenue also slipped less than expected, and B. Riley upgraded the stock to buy, from neutral, and raised its price target to 75 from 60. The stock has been in a deepening correction since December.

Cirrus Logic (CRUS) soared 10% after clearing revenue and earnings expectations for the second quarter and boosting third-quarter revenue guidance above consensus views. Shares ended Wednesday down nearly 6% for the week, but were paring losses after finding support at their 200-day moving average.

Security software developer Fortinet (FTNT) sparked up 12% after its Q2 earnings narrowly beat but 30% revenue growth trounced analyst expectations. The stock has been in a firm uptrend since December, and ended Wednesday in the fourth week of a shallow consolidation supported by its 10-week moving average.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) rumbled up 4% ahead of the open after reporting its second-quarter results. Revenue and earnings easily topped expectations in Q2. Full-year revenue and earnings guidance was strong, but management guided Q3 earnings below consensus views. Attention is a central component of modern society. Entrepreneurs must reach buyers. Teachers must get students to listen. Musicians have to connect with fans, charities with donors. Here's the problem: Humans have a shorter attention span than goldfish. Or so says a Microsoft (MSFT) study. Seems alarming? Yes. Time to panic? No. Why? Because goldfish don't tend to the complex…
Ronald McDonald's recent makeover couldn't jolt McDonald's (MCD) second-quarter results, as declining appetites for Mickey D's contrasted with explosive demand for Chipotle's (CMG) burritos.
Revenue grew 1.4% to $7.18 billion, missing views for $7.29 billion, and earnings per share rose 1.4% to $1.40, missing analyst estimates by 4 cents.

Comparable restaurant sales fell 1.5% in the U.S. and 1% in Europe. Comps in the region that covers Asia Pacific, the Middle East and Africa rose 1.1%, thanks to Chinese diners and locally relevant product promotions, among other factors.

"Results for the quarter reflected negative comparable guest traffic amid ongoing broad-based challenges," said the company in a release. "Looking ahead, McDonald's U.S. is intent on strengthening the overall customer experience to effectively position the segment for long-term growth. Key areas of focus include service excellence, enhanced marketing, and value, core menu and breakfast."
McDonald's doesn't expect full-year international comp sales to be too different from its June performance, and July global comps are expected to be negative.

That's in spite of the late-April makeover for the iconic Ronald McDonald clown, who traded in his pear-shaped yellow onesie for a hip vest-and-cargo-pant combo. For special occasions, he wears what the firm calls a whimsical red blazer and bow tie. His floppy red shoes remain.
Shares of the Oak Brook, Ill.-based company slid 1.4% in the stock market today.

By contrast, Chipotle wolfed down profit in spite of higher menu prices, reporting late Monday a 17.3% jump in Q2 same-store sales. Earnings topped views as revenue growth accelerated for a third straight quarter.
The company's antibiotic-free proteins and fresh ingredients have made the chain a fan favorite in the fast-casual world.
Making over menu items — instead of mascots — may be the ticket to success with consumers.
Domino's Pizza (DPZ) reported Q2 earnings rose 17.5% to 67 cents a share, topping by a penny, and revenue rose 8.8% to $450.5 million, beating analyst estimates for $442.1 million.
Same-store sales growth of 5.4% in Q2 boosted domestic franchise revenue, and growth in store count and same-store sales abroad punched up international revenue.

In 2010, the Michigan-based company engineered a brand turnaround, overhauling its pizza recipe and trying to reconnect with consumers. A shift to reimaging stores is next up for the global pizza delivery chain, said Domino's in an investor presentation.

News poured out of China on Monday, sending a handful of China-related stocks both up and down sharply.

Yum Brands (YUM) and McDonald's (MCD) received the short straw Monday, as a new food safety scare in China gained momentum. Both companies issued apologies to customers after a TV report led Chinese authorities to shut down Shanghai Husi Food, a supplier of chicken meat and other products to both chains.
The report described unsafe and unsanitary practices among workers at a Husi plant. The company is a subsidiary of the privately held Illinois-based OSI Group.
China's $174 billion fast-food market is Yum's largest, and the third largest for McDonald's. Both companies were working to recover from an earlier food scare in 2012.
Yum shares fell 4% Monday. McDonald's dropped off more than 1%.

On the more positive side, Baidu (BIDU) received an upgrade from Morgan Stanley. Their report boosted China's largest search engine operator to overweight from equalweight and hoisted its price target to 239.30. Accelerating revenue growth — in the 50% range for the past three quarters — was a key element of the upgrade. The note cited acquisitions and improved monetization of both PC and mobile traffic.
The company blew past Q1 consensus earnings expectations. Views call for a 2% gain in Q2. Baidu is scheduled to report results Thursday evening.
The stock rose 3% Monday. It is extended 16% above a 170.89 buy point in a first-stage cup base.

Kandi Technologies (KNDI) skipped up 10% in very heavy trade. The volatile stock dived 52% in the five weeks to mid-April. It carved out a U-shaped bottom through early July, then rocketed 33% higher last week, after reporting a huge quarterly sales increase in Q2, up 174%. Monday's gain left the stock just below the flawed base's potential buy point of 22.50.

The company makes new energy vehicles, or NEVs. Part golf cart, part sedan, the vehicles are designed for short jaunts at slow speeds — not highway travel. A Seeking Alpha article Monday cited estimates that NEV sales in China would reach 50,000 this year — a 200% year-over-year gain. Kandi holds the leading share of that market. Recent sales growth has ramped up sharply after a weak 2013. McDonald's (MCD) and Yum Brands (YUM) are hoping that halting meat shipments from their Shanghai supplier will help offset consumer backlash over a report saying they may have sold outdated meat.
McDonald's, which operates nearly 2,000 restaurants in China, said on a company blog site that it had asked all of its outlets to stop using meat from Shanghai Husi Food Co.

Yum Brands, parent of the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell chains, separately said it also halted purchases from the supplier. Coffeehouse chain Starbucks (SBUX) also removed an item from its menu that reportedly contained meat from the supplier.

Chinese regulators suspended operations at Shanghai Husi the same day that Dragon TV, a local channel, said workers at the meat supplier's plant were repackaging and selling chicken and beef that had expired sell-by dates on them, according to a Bloomberg report.
McDonald's and Yum both apologized to customers, saying the move will result in short supplies of some menu items.
Both companies have faced similar controversies in China in recent years.

Yum, which ended 2013 with 4,563 KFC restaurants in China and more than 6,000 total including Pizza Hut and local branded chains, saw sales plunge in early 2013 as an outbreak of avian flu at Chinese poultry farms scared consumers away. A fresh outbreak last February threatened to scare away consumers again, but there were just a few cases and it quickly subsided.

In December 2012, China investigated claims that some Yum and McDonald's suppliers were injecting growth hormones and other drugs into chickens, violating China's food safety laws. Yum reportedly cut ties with 100 suppliers.
Yum shares skidded nearly 4% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market. McDonald's and Starbucks were both down about 1%.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which doesn't operate in China, was slated to report second-quarter earnings after the market close Monday.
Chipotle, the top-rated company in the 56-company restaurant group, and whose stock is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, was down more than 1%.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) recently hiked menu prices without alienating diners, but Wall Street still expects the trendy burrito chain to report slower earnings growth on Monday. Per-share profit should rise 9% vs. a year earlier to $3.08, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters forecast. Still, that would be slower than the 12% increase that Chipotle saw in Q1…
Stocks began modestly lower Monday, then reversed to small gains.
The Nasdaq was barely above the break-even line while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average was flat. Volume was running higher in the stock market today vs. Friday's sluggish pace.
Blue chips were about evenly split between winners and losers. Dow components Chevron (CVX) and Home Depot (HD) showed the biggest gains, with each up 0.8%. IBM (IBM) took the hardest hit, down 1.5%.
In the IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, chip stocks were in retreat while transportation-related stocks were advancing.
The schedule for economic data is thin, but the Dallas Federal Reserve manufacturing survey was expected to be released this morning.

West Texas intermediate crude oil and Brent crude were each up 1%, crossing the $55 and $60 marks, respectively. Did diners chow down on a lot of burgers, fries and ice cream shakes at Sonic (SONC) in the last quarter? Investors will find out on Monday when the drive-in fast food chain operator reports third fiscal quarter results after the stock market close. The company's business has stayed hot with double-digit profit growth in all but one of the…
McDonald's (MCD) reported a smaller-than-expected drop in May same-store sales, though comps have fallen for 12 straight months.
The fast-food giant said global comps dipped 0.3% last month, less than the 0.9% drop analysts polled by research firm Consensus Metrix were expecting.
U.S same-store sales were down 2.2%, but comps in Europe were up 2.3% on strong sales from the U.K. Asia/Pacific, Middle East and Africa same-store sales were down 3.2%,
The company, which will stop reporting monthly sales after July, said it is working on enhancing the customer experience at its U.S. stores with limited-time menu and value options.
McDonald's shares were up 0.6% to 96.14 in premarket trading in the stock market today.

"Our goal is to be a modern, progressive burger company that is responsive to consumers' evolving preferences, provides a contemporary experience for our customers and drives long-term value for our system and our shareholders," CEO Steve Easterbrook said in a release.
In May, McDonald's announced a restructuring plan to help it compete with fast-causal restaurants like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Panera Bread (PNRA) .

Easterbrook said in a video message that the current structure is too "cumbersome" with layers of bureaucracy. McDonald's aims to make more money from franchising fees, as it looks to have 90% of its restaurants franchised, up from 81% now. The restructuring will account for $300 million in cost cuts, most of which will be by 2017.

Investors have had an insatiable appetite for fast-casual restaurant stocks, evident by a surge in initial public offerings in the past year and big first-day gains.
Another serving is coming. Chicken-wing king Wingstop (WING) is set for an IPO that begins trading Friday.
The Dallas-based company raised the estimated price of its offering Tuesday, suggesting investors are hungry for shares.

Wingstop fits into the popular fast-casual restaurant segment, a type of restaurant that does not offer full-table service but provides a higher quality of food with fewer frozen or processed ingredients.
According to research firm Technomic, annual sales in the fast-casual segment in 2014 increased at more than three times the rate of the total restaurant industry.
Technomic says the fast-casual field boosted annual sales approximately 13% last year to $39 billion.
While that is a small share of the total restaurant industry's $466 billion in annual sales, it compares with a growth rate of 3.8% for the entire restaurant business.
Wingstop follows the May 8 IPO of Bojangles (BOJA), a Southern-style chicken-and-biscuit chain that raised $147 million. Bojangles stock priced at 19 and now trades near 25.

Another is New York burger chain Shake Shack (SHAK), which raised $150 million in its Jan. 30 IPO. Shake Shack priced at 21, above its estimated range, and bolted 119% from there on its first day. It now trades near 74.
California-inspired burger joint Habit Restaurants (HABT) priced at 18, above the estimated range, and popped 120%, raising $90 million. It now trades near 34.
Another winner has been Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES), up 166% from its April 2014 IPO.
Big first-day gains have been common, though not all have shown long-term momentum.
Potbelly (PBPB), the Chicago-based sandwich chain, surged 120% in its October 2013 IPO, ending the day at 30.77. It now trades near 14.
Other early winners in this category that have turned cold include Noodles & Co. (NDLS), which popped 104% in its June 2013 IPO but now trades below the offering price.
Wingstop looks to raise $99 million in its IPO, pricing 5.8 million shares with an estimated range of 16-18.

Restaurant valuations are high, which has attracted investors to the IPO field, hoping they can catch a ride on a fast-growing company, says Larry Miller, founder and CEO of restaurant industry research firm MillerPulse.
Those valuations are high because overall industry performance has been on an upward trend since 2013, thanks to a steadily improving economy.
"Same-store sales and traffic have continued to improve," said Miller. "The restaurant IPO market is benefiting from improving fundamentals and good valuations."
That's been broad-based, with the exception of McDonald's (MCD), he adds.
THE COMPANY

Founded in 1994, Wingstop says it pioneered the concept of wings as a center-of-the-plate feature. It claims to be the largest fast-casual chicken-wing focused restaurant chain, having sold approximately 4 billion wings in the past 20 years.

Wingstop has 745 restaurants in 37 states and six countries. Of those, 726, or 97%, are franchised, with just 19 company-owned stores. Its largest market presence is in Texas and California. It has 27 restaurants in Mexico. International locations also include Indonesia, the Philippines and Russia.

Wingstop offers three versions of chicken wings: boneless, bone-in and chicken strips, with 11 "bold, distinctive and craveable flavors," including mango habanero, Cajun, Hawaiian, hickory-smoked BBQ and mild.
It also offers hand-cut, seasoned fries and sides made fresh daily.
Family packs are on the menu, the largest being a 100-piece package. Carry-out orders constitute approximately 75% of sales.
On top of all that is an online ordering service.
Restaurant industry magazine QSR listed Wingstop among its "Best Franchise Deals" of 2014.
Food & Wine magazine put Wingstop on its list of "Best Chicken Wings" in 2014.

"While other concepts include wings as add-on menu items or focus on wings in a bar or sports-centric setting, we are singularly focused on wings, fries and sides, which generate approximately 90% of our sales," the company said in its IPO prospectus filing.

The small menu that Wingstop offers sets it apart from Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), a giant in the field with sales last year of $1.6 billion. Sales at the sports bar and grill have climbed by double-digit percentages for 19 straight quarters. In addition to chicken wings, Buffalo Wild Wings has burgers, sandwiches, salads and beer — and much larger restaurants.
"Wingstop should not be considered to be another Buffalo Wild Wings," said John Gordon, principal at Pacific Management Consulting Group.
Wingstop says its customers are anchored by the sought-after demographic of 18-34-year-olds, which Wingstop says is a loyal group that dines at fast-casual restaurants more frequently.
RISK/CHALLENGES
The fast-casual restaurant arena is highly competitive.

The all-star in the group is Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which came public in January 2006. Chipotle annual sales have grown by double-digit percentages 14 years in a row, which partly explains the enthusiasm for stocks in the sector.
"There's a tremendous amount of interest among investors to find another Chipotle," said Gordon.
It won't be easy to replicate Chipotle's success, he notes.
The challenge all restaurants face is that the market is saturated. Gordon estimates 1 million restaurants are in America. The plate is overflowing.
"Restaurants have grown faster than the population has grown," said Gordon. "There's a supply and demand imbalance."
But chicken's popularity works in Wingstop's favor.
"Chicken consumption has been tearing the heck out of beef consumption," Gordon said, with chicken getting hot in 1999.
THE RESULTS

Wingstop's same-store sales growth, an important measure of company performance, has been positive for 11 quarters. Domestic same-stores sales rose 10.7% year over year in the first quarter and 12.5% in the fourth quarter.
Revenue of $19 million in the first quarter was up 14% from the year-ago period, with net income of $2.55 million.
Revenue of $67.5 million in 2014 was up 14%, with net income of $9 million. Royalty revenue and franchise fees accounted for 56% of revenue.
Wingstop estimates there is opportunity to grow to 2,500 restaurants across the U.S., with "significant international growth opportunity," saying it has 310 international restaurant commitments.
PROCEEDS

Of the 5.8 million shares being offered, 3.65 million are from current stockholders. Wingstop will not receive any proceeds from that sale. Of the remaining 2.15 million shares, based on an assumed price of 17 per share, Wingstop expects to receive proceeds of $30.9 million after deducting underwriting discounts, commissions and other fees. It plans to use that to repay debt and for other general corporate purposes.
MANAGEMENT
Charles MorrisonPresident, CEO
Morrison, 46, with 20 years of restaurant experience, has held those positions since June 2012. He had been chief executive of Rave Restaurant Group (RAVE), an international pizza chain.
Michael MravleChief financial officer

Mravle, 40, has served as CFO since September. He spent the previous seven years at Bloomin' Brands (BLMN), a casual dining company, in various financial roles. He has more than 15 years of finance and accounting experience in the restaurant industry.
William EngenChief operating officer

Engen, 43, has served as COO since September. He previously served as senior vice president of Eastern operations at 7-Eleven, the world's largest operator, franchiser and licensor of convenience stores.
Wingstop
Dallas, Texas972-686-6500

(NDLS), which popped 104% in its June 2013 IPO but now trades below the offering price.Wingstop looks to raise $99 million in its IPO, pricing 5.8 million shares with an estimated range of 16-18.Restaurant valuations are high, which has attracted investors to the IPO field, hoping they can catch a ride on a fast-growing company, says Larry Miller, founder and CEO of restaurant industry research firm MillerPulse.Those valuations are high because overall industry performance has been on an upward trend since 2013, thanks to a steadily improving economy."Same-store sales and traffic have continued to improve," said Miller. "The restaurant IPO market is benefiting from improving fundamentals and good valuations."That's been broad-based, with the exception of McDonald's (MCD), he adds.THE COMPANYFounded in 1994, Wingstop says it pioneered the concept of wings as a center-of-the-plate feature. It claims to be the largest fast-casual chicken-wing focused restaurant chain, having sold approximately 4 billion wings in the past 20 years.Wingstop has 745 restaurants in 37 states and six countries. Of those, 726, or 97%, are franchised, with just 19 company-owned stores. Its largest market presence is in Texas and California. It has 27 restaurants in Mexico. International locations also include Indonesia, the Philippines and Russia.Wingstop offers three versions of chicken wings: boneless, bone-in and chicken strips, with 11 "bold, distinctive and craveable flavors," including mango habanero, Cajun, Hawaiian, hickory-smoked BBQ and mild.It also offers hand-cut, seasoned fries and sides made fresh daily.Family packs are on the menu, the largest being a 100-piece package. Carry-out orders constitute approximately 75% of sales.On top of all that is an online ordering service.Restaurant industry magazine QSR listed Wingstop among its "Best Franchise Deals" of 2014.Food & Wine magazine put Wingstop on its list of "Best Chicken Wings" in 2014."While other concepts include wings as add-on menu items or focus on wings in a bar or sports-centric setting, we are singularly focused on wings, fries and sides, which generate approximately 90% of our sales," the company said in its IPO prospectus filing.The small menu that Wingstop offers sets it apart from Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), a giant in the field with sales last year of $1.6 billion. Sales at the sports bar and grill have climbed by double-digit percentages for 19 straight quarters. In addition to chicken wings, Buffalo Wild Wings has burgers, sandwiches, salads and beer — and much larger restaurants."Wingstop should not be considered to be another Buffalo Wild Wings," said John Gordon, principal at Pacific Management Consulting Group.Wingstop says its customers are anchored by the sought-after demographic of 18-34-year-olds, which Wingstop says is a loyal group that dines at fast-casual restaurants more frequently.RISK/CHALLENGESThe fast-casual restaurant arena is highly competitive.The all-star in the group is Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which came public in January 2006. Chipotle annual sales have grown by double-digit percentages 14 years in a row, which partly explains the enthusiasm for stocks in the sector."There's a tremendous amount of interest among investors to find another Chipotle," said Gordon.It won't be easy to replicate Chipotle's success, he notes.The challenge all restaurants face is that the market is saturated. Gordon estimates 1 million restaurants are in America. The plate is overflowing."Restaurants have grown faster than the population has grown," said Gordon. "There's a supply and demand imbalance."But chicken's popularity works in Wingstop's favor."Chicken consumption has been tearing the heck out of beef consumption," Gordon said, with chicken getting hot in 1999.THE RESULTSWingstop's same-store sales growth, an important measure of company performance, has been positive for 11 quarters. Domestic same-stores sales rose 10.7% year over year in the first quarter and 12.5% in the fourth quarter.Revenue of $19 million in the first quarter was up 14% from the year-ago period, with net income of $2.55 million.Revenue of $67.5 million in 2014 was up 14%, with net income of $9 million. Royalty revenue and franchise fees accounted for 56% of revenue.Wingstop estimates there is opportunity to grow to 2,500 restaurants across the U.S., with "significant international growth opportunity," saying it has 310 international restaurant commitments.PROCEEDSOf the 5.8 million shares being offered, 3.65 million are from current stockholders. Wingstop will not receive any proceeds from that sale. Of the remaining 2.15 million shares, based on an assumed price of 17 per share, Wingstop expects to receive proceeds of $30.9 million after deducting underwriting discounts, commissions and other fees. It plans to use that to repay debt and for other general corporate purposes.MANAGEMENTCharles MorrisonPresident, CEOMorrison, 46, with 20 years of restaurant experience, has held those positions since June 2012. He had been chief executive of Rave Restaurant Group (RAVE), an international pizza chain.Michael MravleChief financial officerMravle, 40, has served as CFO since September. He spent the previous seven years at Bloomin' Brands (BLMN), a casual dining company, in various financial roles. He has more than 15 years of finance and accounting experience in the restaurant industry.William EngenChief operating officerEngen, 43, has served as COO since September. He previously served as senior vice president of Eastern operations at 7-Eleven, the world's largest operator, franchiser and licensor of convenience stores.WingstopDallas, Texas972-686-6500Wingstop.comMorgan Stanley, JefferiesOffering price: $16-$18Ticker: WING

Wendy's (WEN) announced a massive buyback program Wednesday that's equivalent to a third of its market capitalization, letting it raise its long-term per-share earnings growth forecast. The fast-food chain said it would repurchase $1.4 billion from shareholders, with $211 million coming from top shareholder Trian Group, by the end of 2016. Based on the stock's current price, Wendy's has a…

Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) said it's raising pay for 100,000 more U.S. workers, the next step in its earlier-announced plan to raise wages for about 500,000 of its U.S. workers and reorganize management. The world's largest discount retailer told the Associated Press it will start department managers of some service-oriented departments such as produce and electronics at $13 per hour and…

IBD's Retail-Restaurant group has been on shaky ground of late amid problems involving some of the bigger industry names, but one eatery that continues to produce solid financial and stock price growth is Cracker Barrel Old Country Store (CBRL), which is set to report fiscal third-quarter results on Tuesday.The Lebanon, Tenn.-based Cracker Barrel is due to report fiscal Q3 earnings before Tuesday's open. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings of $1.37 a share for the quarter, which ended in April. That's up 11% from the prior year and would mark the fifth straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth, but would mark a slowdown from 24% in Q2. Revenue is seen climbing 6% to $680 million. That would snap a four-quarter string of gradually accelerating top-line growth.Cracker Barrel, which runs a chain of more than 630 family restaurants in 42 states, boasts a strong IBD Composite Rating of 90. The stock fell 0.9% to 141.08 on the stock market Friday, finding resistance at the 50-day moving average for a third straight session. Shares have been consolidating since peaking at 149.94 on March 20.Cracker Barrel remains one of the better stocks in a group that has fallen to No. 62 out of 197 industries tracked by IBD — down from No. 2 as recently as 13 weeks ago.The restaurant group has been rocked by problems plaguing industry giants such as McDonald's (MCD), which is undergoing a restructuring plan designed to help it return to growth mode; as well as former Wall Street darling Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which has seen shares sag recently amid sales that have failed to live up to historic rapid pace.There are still some tasty restaurant stocks out there, however, including highly rated Starbucks (SBUX), which touched a new high on Friday, as well as Sonic (SONC) and Papa John's Pizza (PZZA).

Visa (V) said it will "reassess" its FIFA sponsorship in light of the massive corruption scandal that has resulted in the arrest of nine officials at soccer's governing body. "Our disappointment and concern with FIFA in light of today's developments is profound," said Visa on its corporate blog Wednesday. "As a sponsor, we expect FIFA to take swift and immediate…
As McDonald's (MCD) continues to lay turnaround plans to become more "modern," the company says it is also making a change to the way it reports financial data.
After June, the fast-food giant will no longer report monthly sales figures, something the Golden Arches has done since 2003.

"Disclosing comparable sales as part of our quarterly reporting is consistent with nearly all retailers and will provide a greater understanding of McDonald's sales results in the context of the company's overall financial performance," CEO Steve Easterbrook said at a conference with analysts Wednesday.
McDonald's shares ticked up 0.1% on the stock market today. The stock is working on a cup-with-handle base with a 101.19 buy point.
Competitors Yum Brands (YUM) — which operates Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut — and Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) do not issue monthly sales figures.
Traditional fast food chains are trying to reinvent themselves to appeal to crowds that flock to restaurants like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which markets itself as serving "food with integrity."

On Tuesday, Yum Brands' Taco Bell chain said it plans to replace artificial colors and flavors with natural alternatives by the end of the year. By the end of 2017, Taco Bell plans to remove additional artificial preservatives and additives.
Pizza Hut says it will take out artificial colors and preservatives by the end of July.
In March, McDonald's announced that it would use only chickens raised without antibiotics important to human medicine. It's also testing dishes with kale in certain markets.

Stocks slumped out of the starting gates Monday, as home sales, Black Friday returns and Chicago manufacturing data put pressure on opening trade.

The Nasdaq slipped furthest, down 0.2%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1% apiece. Small caps ran slightly against the grain, with the Russell 2000 rising 0.1% and the small-cap S&P 600 index up nearly 0.2% in early trade.
Volume was well above Friday morning's levels, no surprise in a lame-duck trading session after the Thanksgiving Day break.
The stock market today received no breaks from the early economic news.

Chicago Purchasing Managers Index dropped to 48.7 for November, Kingsbury International reported. That was sharply below October's 56.2 reading, as well as economist consensus expectations of 54. The gauge is generally taken as a precursor to the more closely watched Institute for Supply Management's PMI index, which is due out Tuesday morning.

Pending home sales ticked up a feeble 0.2% in October, the National Association of Realtors said. The gain was an improvement after two months of declines, but well below forecasts for a 1% increase. Pending home sales have flattened this fall, the NAR said in a release, as consumers face rising prices and a dwindling inventory of homes.

In stocks, Computer Sciences (CSC) jumped 22% as the company divided into two separate publicly traded operations. CSRA (CSRA) combines CSC's government-contractor business and the operations of SRA International, which CSC announced in August it would acquire. It begins trading Monday under the CSRA ticker. CSC's commercial operations continue to trade as CSC on the NYSE. CSRA shares traded up 6% in early action.

Retailers were taking some notable hits as early tallies begin to roll in from the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season. Under Armour (UA) and Urban Outfitters (URBN) each dropped 3%. Ugg maker Deckers Outdoor (DECK) dived 6%. Fashion designer Steve Madden (SHOO) dumped 4%.

Among IBD 50 stocks, TAL Education (XRS) jumped nearly 3%, bumping off another new high. The China-based chain of after-school tutoring clinics has gained in 13 of 15 recent sessions, in the process clearing a 38.75 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Shares are now extended almost 15%.

Another China-based issue, Noah (NOAH), climbed nearly 2% for the group's second best gain. The asset-management firm has failed to decisively clear a 33.10 buy point in a flawed cup-with-handle base.

Nike (NKE) slipped more than 1% to take the IBD 50's worst early decline (also the largest decline among Dow stocks). Stocks slipped in lower volume Monday, but Netflix (NFLX) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) rose after hours following their earnings reports.Chipotle was up sharply in post-session trading after reporting that Q2 profit rose 23% from a year earlier to $3.50 a share, easily beating analysts' expectations. Sales climbed 29%, accelerating its rate of growth for the third straight quarter and also beating views.In extended trading, Chipotle was around 646 a share, which would put the stock firmly above the 602.31 entry of a cup with handle.Netflix (NFLX) was up modestly after the close following a 135% jump in Q2 profit to $1.15 a share. The result was just below Wall Street expectations, but it was the fifth straight quarter of triple-digit profit growth. Sales for the period rose 25%, continuing a general uptrend over the past six quarters.The stock closed the regular session near a 434.99 buy point.The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 fell 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3% Volume was lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today , according to preliminary data.McDonald's (MCD) is scheduled to report quarterly earnings before the market opens Tuesday. Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) will report after the close.Economic reports due Tuesday include the consumer price index for June and existing home sales for June.
Stocks posted small losses Monday, as volume trailed off Friday's pace.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 trimmed 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%

Volume was lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today. Friday was an options expiration day, which can boost volume. It also made it likely that Monday's volume would be lower by comparison.
Companies reporting quarterly results Monday included two stocks representing strong sectors.

Transportation is No. 1 among 33 sectors, and trains are a highly rated group within the sector. Canadian National Railway (CNI) reported quarterly results after the close. Adjusted data were not immediately available. The stock was up 1% in after-hours trade.
The No. 6 energy sector also has been strong.

Halliburton (HAL) reported Q2 results before Monday's open. Revenue was above the Street's consensus number, earnings matched the consensus view and the company announced a $1 billion increase in its $5 billion share buyback program. The stock rose 2% in the first 15 minutes of trade but then gave the gain back.
Halliburton closed up 0.1%. Volume was heavy.
The leisure sector is middle-of-the-pack performer, but Netflix (NFLX) is top-rated. The Street expected $1.16 EPS, but Netflix delivered $1.15. The stock rose almost 2% after hours.

Companies reporting quarterly results before Tuesday's opening bell include McDonald's (MCD). Attention shoppers: Apple on Tuesday unveiled tap-to-pay technology for using iPhones to buy things.
The company said "Apple Pay" will be available in October as a free update to its iOS 8 software.

Apple's (AAPL) push into mobile payments isn't expected to power earnings growth, analyst say. But Apple's digital wallet will likely re-energize the iOS ecosystem's cool factor, amid rising smartphone competition. That, of course, depends on how many iPhone users tap-to-pay, instead of pulling out cash or swiping credit cards in retail stores.

Apple didn't disclose terms with credit-card companies that will support the payment system. JPMorgan speculates Apple may collect a small transaction fee, perhaps pennies, each time iPhone users wave their device to pay at check-out terminals.
Apple is taking on Google (GOOGL), eBay's (EBAY) PayPal, retail consortium MCX, phone companies and others in mobile payments.

U.S. consumers have been slow to embrace digital wallets, partly over security concerns. Worries over credit-card security have been heightened by data thefts at Target (TGT), Home Depot (HD) and others. Apple, stung by last week's celebrity-photo hacking scandal involving iCloud data storage, aims to win over shoppers, retailers and credit-card firms with its approach to protecting consumer financial data and limiting fraud.

"Security is at the core of (Apple) Pay, but so is privacy," Eddy Cue, Apple's senior vice president of Internet software and services, said at Apple's product unveiling event Tuesday, taking a shot at Google. "Apple doesn't know what you bought, where you bought it or any other details about the transaction. And the cashier doesn't even see your name."

Apple's security measures include "TouchID" fingerprint authentication technology to log in and verify users. IPhones will generate single-use, random digital code during transactions, instead of transmitting 16-digit credit-card numbers to store check-out systems. A "secure element" chip stores encrypted data.
NFC Rollout Will Get Boost

Apple Pay uses near-field communications, a short-range wireless technology, to send data to payment readers. Analysts say just 15% to 20% of U.S. retail locations have NFC-equipped sales terminals, but Apple's push into mobile payments could speed NFC adoption.

Aside from its ability to build easy-to-use devices, one of Apple's strengths in the payments field is the more than 800 million credit cards on file in iTunes app store accounts. IPhone users will be able to load eligible credit cards into the Passport app.
IPhone users are prime candidates for ushering in the mobile wallet age, says Jordan McKee, an analyst at 451 Research.

"Not only do iPhone owners earn more than their Android counterparts, they also spend more," McKee told IBD. "IPhone owners are the most advanced users of mobile transaction services across a wealth of categories. An iWallet would simply be a natural extension of how iPhone owners already use their devices.

"The number of iTunes accounts has ballooned from 575 million to 800 million in a year, with many of those accounts having a credit or debit card associated with them. While most vendors are clutching at straws for new ways to increase cards on file, Apple trumps them from day one by a significant factor."
Apple, which acquired Beats Electronics' music streaming service in May for $ 3.2 billion, aims to diversify from hardware into services.

At around a penny per transaction, Apple's payment revenue would amount to a few hundred million dollars annually, analysts estimate. A JPMorgan report says the "impact to Apple's earnings would be immaterial."
McDonald's, Macy's On Board

Apple's biggest benefit would be "significant platform lock-in" amid fierce competition from Google-Android based smartphones and other rivals, JPMorgan analyst Rod Hall said. Mobile payments, said Goldman Sachs analyst James Schneider in a report, will "increase the stickiness of the iOS platform over time."
Apple says its payment system will work with Visa (V), MasterCard (MA) and American Express (AXP), as well as credit cards from six banks.

Apple Pay can be used at McDonald's (MCD), Starbucks (SBUX), Macy's (M), Bloomingdale's, Walgreen (WAG), Walt Disney (DIS), Staples (SPLS), Duane Reade and Subway. Some 22,000 retailers are equipped to accept the payment system, Apple said.

Some speculate that Apple may launch a rewards program with partners to encourage use of the payment system. Analysts say it's unclear if Apple will be able to garner revenue from advertising or special product offers.

Retailers have been testing Apple's iBeacon wireless technology, which provides customer location data in stores. Analysts say retailers hope to whisk coupons or other discounts to shoppers via iBeacon.

Analysts say Apple made a good move in teaming with credit card companies. Visa, MasterCard and American Express have a strong presence in the mobile market. Almost all mobile wallets today rely on credit-card networks to authorize and clear payments, says Goldman Sachs. PayPal, which uses a clearinghouse system set up by banks, has more than half of transactions linked to traditional credit cards.
Apple has taken years to cobble together a digital payments strategy. It bought security firm AuthenTec in 2012 and began testing iBeacon last year. But mobile wallets are off to a slow start.

PayPal has tried to expand its online payment processing business into retail stores. Consumers with PayPal accounts use a plastic card or mobile phone number and PIN combination to make purchases at checkout.
Yet, fewer than 5% of PayPal's nearly 120 million online users are forecast to use its retail payment system by 2015.

MCX, a consortium backed by Wal-Mart (WMT), Best Buy (BBY) and 60 other retailers, might not be ready to launch its smartphone-based digital wallet until 2015, analysts say. MCX members hope long term to reduce the credit-card transaction fees they now pay, analysts say.
A mobile payments joint venture formed by AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and T-Mobile US (TMUS), rebranded as Softcard last week, has struggled to gain traction.

The three firms formed the joint venture in 2011, but early partners Barclays and Capital One (COF) have backed out of the venture.Attention shoppers: Apple on Tuesday unveiled tap-to-pay technology for using iPhones to buy things.The company said "Apple Pay" will be available in October as a free update to its iOS 8 software.Apple's (AAPL) push into mobile payments isn't expected to power earnings growth, analyst say. What do most past winners have in common that helped spur their big advances — besides strong current and annual earnings growth?

It's the N in CAN SLIM, which stands for "New." "It takes something new to produce a startling advance in the price of a stock," IBD chairman and founder William O'Neil wrote in "How to Make Money in Stocks." It could be an innovative new product or service, new leadership or changes within an industry.
Industry changes include shortages, pricing shifts or new technologies. A new condition in an industry may serve as fuel to propel a stock to new price highs.
Or, as O'Neil wrote, "It can be an important new product or service that sells rapidly and causes earnings to accelerate above previous rates of increase."

Think of Apple's (AAPL) huge rally after launching the iPod in the early 2000s. Dell, Microsoft (MSFT) and Yahoo (YHOO) surged in the 1990s as they rolled out build-to-order PCs, Windows operating software and a popular Internet portal, respectively.
"Or it can be a change of management that brings new vigor, new ideas or at least a new broom to sweep everything clean," O'Neil wrote.

For instance, back in the 1960s, McDonald's (MCD), with new owner Ray Kroc at the helm, revolutionized the fast-food industry. And Starbucks (SBUX) has been on a tear since Howard Schultz in 2008 returned to lead the coffee chain.
IBD studies show that the stock price rallies of more than 95% of the past decades' biggest winners were fueled by the N factor.

Restoration Hardware (RH) is a good example. The home furnishings retailer, bought on the cheap in 2008 by private-equity firm Catterton Partners after the business collapsed, has seen its fortunes change dramatically after a major overhaul. With former chairman and CEO Gary Friedman now back at both posts, the company has opened bigger stores and added curated collections of art, antiques and kitchenware. It plans to launch RH Atelier, an upscale brand of apparel accessories and footwear.

The stock went public again in late 2012 at 24 a share and soared 213% in the first eight months. After building a series of bases (1), RH triggered the eight-week hold rule as it rallied 23% (2) from a mid-June breakout this year. While it's pulled back with the market, RH remains nearly 11% above its 76.20 entry.What do most past winners have in common that helped spur their big advances — besides strong current and annual earnings growth?It's the N in CAN SLIM, which stands for "New." "It takes something new to produce a startling advance in the price of a stock," IBD chairman and founder William O'Neil wrote in "How to Make Money in Stocks." It could be an innovative new product or service, new leadership or changes within an industry.Industry changes include shortages, pricing shifts or new technologies. A new condition in an industry may serve as fuel to propel a stock to new price highs.Or, as O'Neil wrote, "It can be an important new product or service that sells rapidly and causes earnings to accelerate above previous rates of increase."Think of Apple's (AAPL) huge rally after launching the iPod in the early 2000s. Dell, Microsoft (MSFT) and Yahoo (YHOO) surged in the 1990s as they rolled out build-to-order PCs, Windows operating software and a popular Internet portal, respectively."Or it can be a change of management that brings new vigor, new ideas or at least a new broom to sweep everything clean," O'Neil wrote.For instance, back in the 1960s, McDonald's (MCD), with new owner Ray Kroc at the helm, revolutionized the fast-food industry. And Starbucks (SBUX) has been on a tear since Howard Schultz in 2008 returned to lead the coffee chain.IBD studies show that the stock price rallies of more than 95% of the past decades' biggest winners were fueled by the N factor.Restoration Hardware (RH) is a good example. It plans to launch RH Atelier, an upscale brand of apparel accessories and footwear.The stock went public again in late 2012 at 24 a share and soared 213% in the first eight months. The stock market takes a lot of flak for being impersonal. Arguments for or against automated trading aside, stocks are bought and sold by people. People manage and staff publicly traded companies that sell goods and services to, you guessed it, other people.In the end, it's all very personal.Many times, successful investors are buying into visionary leaders as much as they are the actual companies. This is true for many when it comes to Facebook's (FB) Mark Zuckerberg, Tesla's (TSLA) Elon Musk or the omnipotent aura of Apple's (AAPL) Steve Jobs. In other cases, the leaders have less star power but carry a solid background with successful companies.That's why every investor's fundamental research regimen should include a look at a target company's executive management. It takes only a few minutes to get a general sense of who you are dealing with.Chase down a company's annual 10-K Securities & Exchange Commission filing. These forms, as well as profiles on the company's website, list executive management and detail their experience. If it's a young company, look for the 424b prospectus filed prior to the initial offering.Do quick searches of the executives by reading past articles in IBD's The New America and Internet & Technology sections. Get some sense of where the executives came from and what their accomplishments and failures are.A search for news on the Web is also important, because 10-Ks won't tell you an executive's failings.Brilliant inventors, creators and visionary thinkers often make lousy executives. In contrast, some of the best managers have climbed the ranks amid difficult circumstances. They understand a company and its markets from the customer level up.Are there any managers to watch today?Consider the new McDonald's (MCD) CEO, Steve Easterbrook. He took the management helm in March and announced a vast restructuring and turnaround strategy at the beginning of May.Easterbrook is a Brit who was an accountant with PricewaterhouseCoopers before shifting to a management position with McDonald's in London in 1993. He earned the company's top management slot, first in the U.K., then in Europe. He left for several years to run London-based restaurant chains PizzaExpress and Wagamama.Easterbrook re-upped with McDonald's in 2013, earning the title of global chief brand officer.McDonald's shares jumped 5% in late January on news of Easterbrook's appointment, then rose another 8% over the next five weeks. They've been basing since early March as investors wait to see whether Easterbrook proves to be a genuine force for change.Yahoo's (YHOO) Marissa Mayer is not a brand-new CEO, but her task is no less Herculean.She joined Google (GOOGL) in 1999 as the company's 20th employee and first female engineer. She helped build the company, had ups and downs, and notched notable successes, but she had no real experience outside the Google cocoon or as the ultimate decider atop the management heap.Yahoo shares have risen 231% since Mayer took the CEO post in July 2012. But the stock is down 15% so far this year.

McDonald's (MCD) April same-store sales fell less than expected, and the fast-food giant reiterated its turnaround plans to become more "modern." The Golden Arches said that its overall comparable sales dipped 0.6% last month, with U.S. comps dropping 2.3%. Analysts polled by research firm Consensus Metrix were expecting global comps to slide 1.8%. The Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa…
Just a few months after McDonald's (MCD) proclaimed of its food, "Nor will that ever be kale" in an ad, the Happy Meal maker is introducing the vegetable to its menu.

The fast-food chain is testing two breakfast bowls in Southern California, one a chorizo-and-egg bowl with hash browns, cheese and pico de gallo, and the other a turkey sausage and egg white bowl that features spinach, bruschetta and kale.
It is also reportedly adding three salads to its Canadian menus that come with the leafy iron-filled green.
Shares fell 0.1% to 96.30 in the stock market today.

As the brand competes with more health-conscious fare for consumer attention, McDonald's said earlier in the week that it had embarked on a turnaround, though it did not provide details about menu changes at the time.

It has, however, provided a look at the newly made-over Hamburglar, who is no longer a redheaded illustrated character but a grown man sporting stubble and a hamburger-patterned tie. The character still sports black-and-white stripes.

McDonald's also started testing delivery in parts of New York City this week through Postmates, the same service that Starbucks (SBUX) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) have called on for similar services.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Restaurant Brands International (QSR) reported first-quarter earnings above analyst estimates Monday as same-store sales rose. The operator of Tim Hortons and Burger King fast-food restaurants said Q1 adjusted earnings were 18 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 17 cents. Revenue was $932 million, under analyst views for $944 million. Tim Hortons comparable sales increased 5.3% and…

Wendy's (WEN) announced plans to divest its bakery operations to focus on its core as the fast-food industry reorganizes to better compete with fast casual restaurants like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).

Wendy's first-quarter earnings rose 20% to 6 cents per share, beating the 5 cents per share analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Revenue fell 11% to $466.2 million, under views for $475.6 million.
Same-store sales rose 3.2% systemwide, above the 2.5% rise Consensus Metrix forecast.
Shares jumped 5.4% to 11.03 in pre-market trading on the stock market today.

Wendy's said it plans to sell its bakery operations in Q2 and that its reduction in ownership of company stores is on schedule. During the quarter, Wendy's sold 240 company-operated restaurants to franchises.

On Monday, McDonald's (MCD) announced a restructuring plan to make more money from franchising fees, as it looks to have 90% of its restaurants franchised, up from 81% now. But McDonald's didn't mention any changes to it's menu.
Restaurant Brands' (QSR) Burger King has also been aggressively franchising locations.
Meanwhile, Wendy's on Tuesday launched a veggie black-bean burger at two of its Ohio stores as consumers tastes shifts towards healthier fare.
