Global hysteria dominated early morning headlines as Dow futures approached a 550 point loss before the market opened, which halted futures trading. Just after the opening bell, the industrials traded down as much as 500 points before see-sawing their way through the day, finishing down 312 points at 8,379.
Broader markets sold off proportionately, as the S&P 500 dipped 31 points to 877 and the Nasdaq lost 52 finishing at 1,552.
Equity indices around the world dropped last night driven by fears of a global recession.  European markets fell anywhere from 3.5% to 6% and the Japanese Nikkei fell almost 10%.

Existing home sales unexpectedly jumped 5.5% in September. Some see it as a sign of a bottoming housing market, as prices driven down by foreclosures are presenting great value for those seeking to purchase a home. The 5.2 million purchases are the highest rate in the past 12 months.

The CBOE Volatility Index, commonly referred to as the fear index, spiked to an unprecedented 89.5 in early trading, about 75% higher than the weeks lows.  The record high for the VIX is twice as high as levels seen during the dot-com crash.

Crude oil continued to slide despite a 1.5 million barrel per day production cut announced by OPEC today.  Oil eventually came off of the lows to settle at $64.15 per barrel.  After shedding $3.69 today, light, sweet crude was down nearly 11% for the week.

Gold rallied to $729.10, up $14.40.  While gold is typically a safe haven during tumultuous markets, global uncertainty is causing the dollar to strengthen, hurting dollar-denominated commodities. Despite the strong finish, the precious metal was down about 7.5% this week.
The Euro finished near a 2-year low against the Euro, 1.2580 USD/EUR. Investors fleeing emerging market currencies are buying up the depreciated greenback.
Zacks Elite Portfolios
The Focus List took a bit of bigger hit than the broader market amid todays bearishness. The portfolio ended Fridays session 5.5% lower. However, most of the holdings were in line with the market.

It was mainly Wabtecs (WAB  -  Free Report) loss of 13% that caused the Focus List to lag todays market. There was no specific news item driving the share price slide and high volume. However, the overall global economy concerns had to have had an impact on Fridays trading action.
We will re-evaluate this position no Monday. Removing this one now may not necessarily be the most prudent move as the company continues to offer stellar fundamentals.

The company just delivered an outstanding third quarter that included year-over-year sales growth of 12% and earnings per share of 68 cents, which topped the consensus estimate by 5% and beat the year-prior total.
WAB also boosted its full-year earnings guidance as did analysts. The consensus 2008 forecast of $2.68 per share is a penny higher than last weeks projection and in line with the companys outlook.
However, well see what the market brings next week and factor that into our decision on how to play WAB going forward.

Another Focus List stock that saw higher estimates recently on a strong third quarter was McDonald's Corporation (MCD  -  Free Report). The fast food giant delivered a year-over-year profit of 11% thanks to a boost seen in worldwide sales.
Analysts increased full-year 2008 earnings expectations from $3.54 per share to $3.57 over the past week.
McDonalds also took 2nd place among the Focus List top performers for the week. First place went to Almost Family Inc. (AFAM), which came in as the second strongest performer last week.

As if its Focus List outperformance wasn't enough recognition, the company recently announced that Forbes ranked it No. 24 in the Forbes' 2008 listing of the 200 Best Small Companies in America, an advance from AFAM's No. 77 ranking in 2007.
The company also recently delivered a record second quarter. Earnings per share of 50 cents jumped ahead of the previous year's 35 cents and exceed the consensus estimate 32%.

Total revenues advanced by 8.4% year-over-year to $30.4 million. Net income jumped 26.8% from last year.
The company also declared a quarterly dividend of 36 cents per share, which is payable on November 21 to shareholders of record as of the close of business on November 6.

The week is going to be about earnings and whether the stock market can sustain its current momentum.

We have confirmed that nearly 800 companies are going to report. Most of the attention from the news media will rightfully be on large-caps with 167 members of the S&P 500 on the schedule. Included in this group are nine Dow components: 3M (MMM  -  Free Report), American Express (AXP), AT&T (T  -  Free Report), Bank of America (BAC  -  Free Report), Boeing (BA), DuPont (DD), McDonald's (MCD  -  Free Report), Merck (MRK  -  Free Report) and Microsoft (MSFT  -  Free Report).
The economic calendar is very light with just a few key reports. The Federal Open Market Committee will meet next on Apr 29-30.
Wednesday: March existing home sales
Thursday: March durable goods orders, March new home sales, weekly unemployment claims
Friday: Revised University of Michigan April consumer confidence survey

Will the market be able to maintain its current upward momentum? All three of the major indexes are testing the upper end of their trading ranges as I write this on Friday morning. An upward breakout will need to be accompanied by strong volume and follow-through.

The shift away from financial earnings could, ironically, hurt the market because less bad news is priced into companies from most other sectors. (Homebuilders, and to a lesser extent retailers, are the notable exception.) Brokerage analysts expect average earnings growth from the S&P 500 companies reporting next week to be 3.5%. (The median growth rate is higher at 8%).
For the nine Dow components on the calendar, the average expected growth rate is -0.9% and the median is 6.3%. Not bad numbers, but also not the stuff that rallies are made of.
Still, if an upside breakout does occur, there is a possibility of an extended upward move. Just be ware that bear markets can have strong, temporary rallies.
First-Quarter Earnings

As of Thursday evening, about 20% of the companies within the S&P 500 have reported first-quarter earnings. Positive earnings surprises are outnumbering negative earnings surprises by a margin of 2.2:1, which is actually worse than the recent sentiment would have investors believe.

Growth remains a matter of perception. Median per share earnings growth is running at a brisk 8.6%. Median net income growth, however, is a nominal 1.6%. Average earnings per share and average net income are both down by more than 27%.

Out of the 20 companies with the biggest declines in year-over-year net income, 16 are either in the financial or construction sector. The four exceptions are Micron Technology (MU  -  Free Report), The New York Times (NYT  -  Free Report), Alcoa (AA) and International Game Technology (IGT). These companies have posted year-over-year declines of 40% or more.
Keep in mind that the sample size remains small and there will be fluctuations over the next couple of weeks.

High commodity prices have taken a big bite out of the restaurants industry.  Stocks were performing well at the beginning of the year, but are currently down -20% to -25% from their 52-week highs, on average.  But a good management team and a hot concept can go a long way even during unfavorable circumstances.  If investors do their homework and consult analysts, the restaurants industry can continue to provide sustenance to their portfolios.  The space enjoys a Zacks Industry Rank of 2.87 at the moment, which places it 73rd out of more than 200 companies.

The restaurants industry is in the business of meeting the primal needs of the public, said 5-Star analyst Dean Haskell of JMP Securities.  If a company is able to meet those needs, it will be successful, even if the industry isnt much help.  For this reason, Haskell believes that a solid management team is the most important aspect of a restaurant company.  Good management is able to give its customers what they want while keeping a sharp eye out for where the industry is moving.  The ability to spot an opportunity or emerging trend, and the resourcefulness to take advantage of it, can make the difference between a solid investment and a risky venture.  One can bet the restaurants that first picked up on the growing obesity concerns and low-carb craze made their investors very happy.

A good management team leads toward another crucial aspect of a solid restaurant company; namely the concept.  In fact, the concept is a direct extension of management, because the team consistently attempts to make sure the concept is working and appeals to customers.  At the moment, Haskell is looking towards companies like Cheesecake Factory (NASDAQ: CAKE ) and Wendys (NYSE: WEN ), among others.  These companies have good menus, clean spaces, and fast, friendly service.  Equally as important, at least to the investor, is their predictable return on capital.

As mentioned earlier, high commodity prices stunted a solid beginning for the year.  Management teams have attempted to combat the problem by raising prices, and luckily the move has not scared away customers.  However, restaurants can only raise prices sparingly; about once a quarter.  Therefore, it often takes several quarters for companies to catch up with food cost inflation.

At the moment, same-store sales are slowing, but remain positive, while operating margin is under pressure and new unit development is accelerating.  Haskell says that these are the three important technical factors to look at in the space.  So while the industry is challenged at the moment, there is opportunity for investors willing to stay selective.  Analysts can help you to find the truly innovative management companies, and also point out some of the emerging trends that can make a particular stock a very good investment.  If your portfolio is starved for profit, you might want to try placing an order with the restaurants industry. What Do the All Stars Recommend?

Zacks tracks the analysts who cover the restaurants industry and ranks them based on the performance of stocks recommended. Some of the top-ranked analysts include: A Brenner  of Roth Capital Partners, Inc.; M. Gallo  of C.L. King & Associates; D. Haskell  of JMP Securities;  H. Penney  of Friedman, Billings, Ramsey, & Company, Inc.; and  P. Westra  of SG Cowen Securities Corporation. In fact, with four recommendations, Panera Bread has more All Stars in its corner than any other company in the restaurants industry.  Earlier this month, the company reported second quarter earnings of $0.21 per diluted share, which was +11% better than last years $0.19.  It also matched the consensus, and marked the 18th consecutive quarter of earnings per share that either met or topped Wall Street expectations.  Company and franchisee revenues advanced +31% and +24% respectively from year-ago levels, while system-wide comparable bakery-café sales rose +1.9%. The company established a development target of 150 to 160 new bakery-cafes in 2005, which would be +20% more than the number expected to be opened this year.  Looking forward to 2005, Ron Shaich, Chairman and CEO, stated, We believe as commodity prices stabilize, and the percentage change in new company bakery-café openings moderates, earnings will once again expand at a faster rate then revenue.  Many analysts believe that as well, and are expecting big things from this unique and growing restaurant company. During the quarter, twelve new Applebees restaurants were opened system-wide, bringing the total to 1,612 by the end of the period.  Over 100 new restaurants are expected to open this year.  To further research Applebees International, Inc., click APPB .Ruby Tuesday, Inc.  (NYSE: RI ) has company-owned, and/or franchise Ruby Tuesday brand restaurants in 41 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and 12 foreign countries.  Ruby Tuesday has put together 28 consecutive quarters of earnings per share at or above Wall Street expectations.  That includes its fiscal fourth  quarter result from mid-July, when the company reported diluted earnings of $0.46 per share.  The result was in-line with the consensus, and +17.9% better than last years $0.39.  Company-owned same-store sales improved by +1.3%.  Ruby Tuesdays Spring menu was rolled out in the quarter, and included some lower pricing along with Phase Two of the Ruby Tuesday Smart Eating initiative.  As we head into fiscal 2005, we now plan to invest money in advertising initiatives affecting the majority of our company-owned locations, said Sandy Beall, Chairman and CEO of Ruby Tuesday.  We believe these initiatives, among others, will enable us to continue to deliver on our longer-term goals.  Ruby Tuesday expects 50 to 55 company-owned restaurant openings during fiscal 2005, and expects its franchisees (including both domestic and international) will open 35 to 40 Ruby Tuesday restaurants during the same period.

Ruby Tuesday is one of the leaders in its industry when it comes to combating obesity and giving its customers healthier options.  The Smart Eating program mentioned above was launched in November 2003, and is a company-wide effort to provide menu items with the tools and information to make healthier and more informed choices.  Since the launch, Ruby Tuesday has made changes such as a switch to cooking with canola oil, and the addition of dozens of Smart Eating choices that are lower-calorie, lower-fat, or lower-carb.  Ruby Tuesday also promotes its signature salad bar.  To further research Ruby Tuesday, click RI .McDonalds Corporation  (NYSE: MCD ) develops, operates, franchises and services a worldwide system of restaurants that prepare, assemble, package and sell a limited menu of value-priced foods. Our results to date reflect the strength of our commitment to enhancing McDonalds brand relevance and improving the operational execution in our restaurants, said Charlie Bell, President and CEO of McDonalds.  As we continue through 2004, we will maintain our intense focus on delivering a superior restaurant experience to our customers.  Analysts like the results from the companys Plan, which includes focusing on People, Product, Place, Price and Promotion.  The company has more work to do, which suggests that its momentum should continue.  To further research McDonalds Corporation, click MCD .Starbucks Corporation  (NASDAQ: SBUX ) is the leading retailer, roaster and brand of specialty coffee in the world, with more than 8,000 retail locations in North America, Latin America, Europe, the Middle East and the Pacific Rim. An analyst at WR Hambrecht & Company stated, We expect the strong comp store sales momentum to continue through the end of the year. For its fiscal third quarter, Starbucks reported diluted earnings of $0.24 per share on consolidated net revenues of $1.3 billion.  That earnings results topped the consensus by more than +9%, improved upon the year-ago result of $0.17, and marked the 28th straight quarter with earnings per share at or above Wall Street expectations.  Net revenues advanced +27% year-over-year from $1 billion.  Same-store sales rose +11%, which was the 150th straight month of same-store sales gains.  These quarterly results were strong enough for Starbucks to raise its full year 2004 earnings per share target.  In fact, the company said its consistently strong performance puts it in a good position to achieve its aggressive goals for fiscal 2005.  Those goals include accelerating its store development plans and opening about 1,500 new stores on a global basis. Starbucks is a popular and growing company, so its easy to see why it has caught the attention of the All Stars.  To learn more about Starbucks Corporation, click SBUX .

Another week, another rate cut. The futures markets are predicting the Federal Open Market Committee (a.k.a "the Fed") will cut rates for the second time this month when it meets on Wednesday and Thursday. As of yesterday, Jan 24, expectations were highest for an additional 50-basis point cut, though the possibility of just a quarter-point cut is gaining steam.

The problems for the economy stem from a lack of available credit, and anything that can be done to encourage lending is a step in the right direction. Therefore, erring on the side of cutting rates too much is better than maintaining the fight against inflation. The stimulus can always be pulled back later in the year. If the economy does regain its footing, it would not surprise me to see rate hikes occur in the fourth quarter of this year. Let's hope that the economy regains enough strength to make my prediction about higher rates come true.
Going back to the week of Jan 28, the following economic reports will be released:
Tuesday: December new home sales
Wednesday: December durable good orders and January Conference Board consumer confidence survey
Thursday: Weekly initial jobless claims, advance fourth-quarter GDP and January PMI

Large-cap stocks will continue to dominate the earnings news with approximately a quarter of the more than 500 companies confirmed to report belonging to the S&P 500. Among these large caps are Dow components 3M (MMM  -  Free Report), Altria Group (MO  -  Free Report), American Express (AXP  -  Free Report), Boeing (BA  -  Free Report), Exxon Mobil (XOM  -  Free Report), McDonald's (MCD  -  Free Report), Merck (MRK  -  Free Report), Proctor & Gamble (PG  -  Free Report) and Verizon (VZ  -  Free Report). Fourth-Quarter Earnings Results

As I expected, the median rate of growth accelerated as results from many non-financial companies were released. As of Thursday evening, median per share earnings growth for S&P 500 companies was 8.6%. The pace of net income growth was slightly less at 5.5%, reflecting the impact of share buybacks.

More companies continue to beat expectations than miss, though the number of misses remains proportionately higher than we have seen in past quarters. A total of 97 companies have beat and 42 have missed, a surprise ratio of 2.3:1.

The sample size remains relatively small with only 159 total reports (20 companies met expectations) and therefore the numbers should continue to change as more companies release their earnings results.

Earnings growth is not much different for the broader S&P Composite 1500 (S&P 500, S&P Midcap 400 and S&P SmallCap 600). Median EPS growth is running at 8.8% and median net income growth is 5.1%. The surprise ratio is 1.74:1 (172 companies beat and 99 missed).

The proposed merger between SAP (SAP  -  Free Report) and Business Objects (BOBJ), announced over the weekend, put the spotlight on the business intelligence software market. Among the independent companies still left standing, Cognos (COGN) is rumored to be a likely takeover target.

Trading on merger speculation is extremely risky, but COGN could see its shares appreciate even without an acquisition offer. The company recent reported fiscal second-quarter profits of 31 cents per share, a penny above expectations and 19% above year-ago levels. Revenues rose 10% to $252.4 million, driven in part by a 12% increase in license revenues. Gross margins widened by 200 basis points to 79.1%. The company is seeing customers standardizing on Cognos 8 and has version 8.3 in beta. (Our software analyst, Abdul Saleh, believes that version 8.3, which is currently in beta, could provide an additional catalyst for the stock.)

Based on the strength of its second-quarter results, COGN boosted its fiscal 2008 outlook. The company now expects revenues to be in the range of $1.075 billion to $1.100 billion and earnings per share to total between $1.66 to $1.76. Previously, the company had forecast revenues of $1.065 billion to $1.085 billion and earnings per share of $1.66 to $1.73. The majority of the covering brokerage analysts raised their full-year profit forecasts in response, sending the consensus estimate four cents higher to $1.79 per share.

Last week, P.F. Chang's China Bistro (PFCB) slashed its third-quarter guidance. The company said that same-store sales at its namesake restaurants and at Pei Wei decreased 1.6% and 1%, respectively, during the third quarter. (The decrease at the Bistro locations included the impact of a 2-3% price increase.) Adding to the downward pressure on the bottom line, the company also said that it incurred higher wages, repairs and restaurant supplies. As a result, PFCB expects third-quarter revenues to have totaled $270.8 million and per share earnings to be within a range of five to seven cents. Previously, the company had guided for revenues of $273 million and per share profits of above 25 cents.
Not surprisingly, brokerage analysts were quick to cut their full-year forecasts. The downward revisions caused an eight-cent drop in the consensus estimate to $1.26 per share.
PFCB's warning follows the fourth consecutive earnings miss by fast-food chain operator CKE Restaurants (CKR) and a warning by Ruby Tuesday (RT).

A few weeks ago, CKR reported second-quarter earnings of 18 cents per share; brokerage analysts had been expecting 20 cents per share. The company was adversely affected by both higher food prices (including beef, cheese and soft drink syrup) and higher occupancy and operating costs. The 0.4% decrease in consolidated revenues did not help earnings either. The majority of the covering brokerage analysts cut their full-forecasts in reaction to the report.

RT said that first-quarter same-store sales at company owned restaurants plunged 4.8% during its fiscal first quarter. The company blamed "continued high gas prices, higher interest rates, and competitive value promotion" for the poor performance. RT now expects fiscal first-quarter profits to total 21 cents per share when it reports this afternoon.

The economy is having an impact on consumer spending and higher food prices are a drag on earnings, especially for restaurant chains that lack the ability to pass along the higher costs to consumers. Although the outlook for restaurants appears to be somewhat mixed overall (over the past four weeks, a total of 44 full-year earnings estimates have been raised and 47 have been cut), the companies that seem to be faring the best in the current environment are the fast food chains. About of the recent positive revisions have been concentrated in just three companies: McDonald's (MCD  -  Free Report), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Yum! Brands' (YUM  -  Free Report).

YUM reported third-quarter earnings on Monday afternoon. The company earned 50 cents per share, six cents above expectations and 20% above year-ago levels. U.S. same-store sales were essentially flat, but company realized strong growth in China. It also announced plans to open Taco Bell restaurants in Mexico with the hopes that its "American" menu will provide an attractive alternative to traditional Mexican food. YUM raised its full-year guidance to profits of $1.65 per share, a penny above then the consensus estimate. Four of the six covering brokerage analysts adjusted their forecasts in response, boosting the consensus estimate to $1.65 per share.

The New York Times reported on Tuesday that New York regulators are proposing a requirement for insurance companies to set aside reserves to cover damage caused by a severe hurricane. The reserves would come out of premium payments. Insurers are unhappy because under current federal tax law, the money set aside in the reserves would not be tax deductible.

Ironically, the lack of a severe hurricane in North America might just help insurance company profits this year. Over the past several days, brokerage analysts have upped their full-year forecasts on multiple property and casualty insurers and reinsurers including AllState (ALL  -  Free Report), Chubb (CB  -  Free Report), Ace Limited (ACE), Travelers (TRV  -  Free Report) and XL Capital (XL  -  Free Report).

The upward revisions likely reflect the relatively calm hurricane season, increased premiums and the rebound in the U.S. equity markets. Investors should note while none of the insurers have changed their third-quarter guidance, three or more brokerage analysts have raised their forecasts on 11 different companies - a bullish sign.

Since the United States is the richest and most powerful country in the world, its only logical that we would be the fattest as well.  As recent court cases attest, Americans love to eat, and obesity has become the newest health concern in the nation.  However, divorcing the public relations aspect from the situation, the restaurant industry is a large, multi-billion-dollar and highly competitive industry here.  Now, recent attempts by companies to change the way they do business, especially from the fast-food franchises, have begun to pay off, giving the industry a Zacks Industry Rank of 2.93.  According to Nick Raichs  Weekly Earnings and Sector Update,  that places 81st out of more than 200 industries.

Restaurant stocks are doing great, said 5-Star analyst Jonathan Waite, research analyst at McDonald Investments, Inc., A KeyCorp Company.  Fast food companies are leading the way, according to Waite, as they have found the benefits of offering higher premium items.  McDonalds is leading the way in this matter, in much the same way it leads the industry itself.  Last year, the companys hottest new menu item was not a quadruple cheeseburger or $10 milkshake, but premium salads.
Companies learned that they could sell a premium item for $3.99, instead of something off of a 99-cent menu, said Waite.

Along with such items, comes a new way a directing business.  In a January press release, Jim Cantalupo, McDonalds Chairman and CEO, said, From the very beginning, we introduced a new level of discipline and focus to all aspects of the business.  In 2003, we eliminated projects not directly impacting our customers' experience, narrowed our non-McDonald's brand activities, aligned our System around a single action plan, and re-established McDonald's marketing leadership through the introduction of our first ever global brand direction, 'i'm lovin' it.  As a result of such actions, same-store sales for McDonalds, and many of its competitors, have been on the rise.

Some casual dining restaurants are also getting into offering more healthy choices.  While these companies are not experiencing the thrust of fast-food franchises, many of them have also reported strong quarterly earnings and sales results.  And as far as obesity claims are concerned, Waite believes such attention impacts these companies mainly on a public relations front.

Given the size of the industry, it can be rather daunting at times to pick one or two issues that are likely to rise from the pack.  Thats where analysts can help you pinpoint the best opportunities.  Waite likes companies that have the potential to be a good national chain.  Also, he looks for a high return on invested capital, and a strong management team.  If handled the right way, the restaurant industry can provide good sustenance to your portfolio.  What Do the All Stars Recommend?

Zacks tracks the analysts who cover the restaurants industry and ranks them based on the performance of stocks recommended. Some of the top-ranked analysts include:  A. Brenner  of Roth Capital Partners, Inc.;  S. Carpenter  of Thomas Weisel Partners;  R. Derrington  of Morgan Keegan, Inc.;  M Sheridan  of Johnson Rice; and  J. Waite  of McDonald Investments, Inc., A KeyCorp Company.  Get their recommendations and those for all others in the industry by clicking  here .  Top Consensus Stocks

Below are some of the top stocks in the restaurants industry recommended by the most  5-Star  analysts.  Unlike other industry reports, you probably are quite familiar with each of these companies, even if youve never eaten at one.  All of them were able to match Wall Street expectations in the their most recent quarters, and all have enjoyed higher sales as well.  Applebees International, Inc.  (NASDAQ:  APPB ) develops, franchises and operates restaurants under the Applebees Neighborhood Grill & Bar brand, the largest casual dining concept in the world.  As of February 22, 2004, there were 1,594 Applebees restaurants operating system-wide in 49 states and nine international countries.  Late last month Applebees reported that comparable sales for company restaurants advanced +8.4% in its February period.  System-wide comparable sales increased +7.8% while comparable sales for franchise restaurants moved forward +7.6%.  In February, Applebees completed one of the best years in its history with fourth quarter net earnings of 41 cents per share, matching the consensus and beating the year-ago total by +14%.  System-wide comparable sales improved +4.6%, marking the companys 22nd straight quarter of comparable sales growth.  In 2003, the company continued to expand its market share as at least 100 new restaurants were opened for the 11th consecutive year.  Furthermore, the new year got off to a good start with solid sales results in January.

In mid-November, Applebees launched a five-market test of a new Weight Watchers menu.  More than 70 restaurants are testing a combined total of 18 potential items.  The most popular eight to 10 items will be selected for the national menu, which will launch in 2004.  Some of the items tested include a Mexican Fiesta Dip, a French Onion Soup, a Grilled Citrus Chicken Salad, a Chicken Fajita Skillet, and a Chocolate Raspberry Layer Cake.  In its quarterly report, Applebees stated that it is pleased with the early results and guest response, and believe the strategic initiative can contribute to its continued success in the latter half of 2004 and beyond.  To further research Applebees International, Inc., click  APPB .  The Cheesecake Factory, Inc.  (NASDAQ:  CAKE ) operates 74 upscale, casual dining restaurants under The Cheesecake Factory® name that offer an extensive menu of more than 200 items with an average check of approximately $16.  The company also operates a bakery production facility that produces over 50 varieties of quality cheesecakes and other baked products for the companys restaurants and for other leading foodservice operators, retailers and distributors.  For its fourth quarter, Cheesecake Factory reported diluted net income of 30 cents per share, which matched the consensus and improved upon the prior year.  Total revenues advanced +23% to $214.5 million while comparable restaurants sales rose +2.5%.  The company attributed the comparable restaurant sales rise to the sustained popularity of its concepts, great operational execution, and favorable weather comparisons in California and Florida.

The Cheesecake Factory opened seven new restaurants in the fourth quarter, and it achieved its goal to open as many as 14 new Cheesecake Factory restaurants during fiscal 2003.  As for fiscal 2004, the company wants to open 16 new restaurants.  CAKEs goal is to achieve a +22% to +23% increase in total restaurant operating weeks during the fiscal year. Compared to a +21% increase during fiscal 2003.  With a popular brand and ambitious goals for the future, theres no wonder why four All Star analysts are recommending this company.  To further research The Cheesecake Factory, Inc., click  CAKE .  Outback Steakhouse, Inc.  (NYSE:  OSI ) is a company that owns and operates Outback Steakhouse units throughout the U.S. as well as Carrabbas Italian Grills and Lee Roy Selmons. The Company also operates through joint venture agreements and existing franchise agreements additional Outback restaurants (including International locations), Carrabbas Italian Grills, and Flemings Prime Steakhouse & Wine Bar. Outback Steakhouse, Inc. has a joint venture development relationship with Roy Yamaguchi, the chef and creator of Roys Restaurants located in Hawaii, the U.S., and Japan. As of February 11, 2004, the company operated 829 Outback Steakhouses, 148 Carrabba's Italian Grills, 22 Fleming's Prime Steakhouse and Wine Bars, 18 Roy's, 39 Bonefish Grills, two Lee Roy Selmon's, and three Cheeseburger in Paradise restaurants in 50 states and 21 countries internationally.  In February, Outback Steakhouse reported fourth quarter net income of 58 cents per diluted share on revenues of more than $718 million.  The earnings result matched the consensus and surpassed the year-ago total, as revenues improved +19.2%.  As for the year ended December 31, 2003, Outback Steakhouses net income per diluted share rose to $2.17 compared to $1.89.  Revenues for the year improved to $2.7 billion from almost $2.4 billion last year.  To further research Outback Steakhouse, Inc. click  OSI .  Panera Bread Company  (NASDAQ:  PNRA ) owns and franchises bakery-cafes under the Panera Bread and Saint Louis Bread Company names.  The company is a leader in the emerging specialty bread/café category due to its unique bread combined with a quick, casual dining experience.  For the four weeks ended February 21, 2004, Panera Bread reported that system-wide comparable bakery-café sales advanced +1.4%.  For its fourth quarter, the company reported earnings of 34 cents per diluted share, which was +36% better than the year-ago result of 25 cents.  The performance also matched the consensus.  For the year ended December 27, 2003, earnings per diluted share of $1.01, before the cumulative effect of an accounting change, which marked a +38% advanced from earnings per share in 2002 of 73 cents.  The company attributed the years earnings growth to development activity and continued very strong average unit volumes.  Panera Bread opened 131 bakery-cafes in 2003, including 45 in the fourth quarter.

We are pleased that we were able to increase annualized average unit volumes while expanding the number of bakery-cafes in our system by +26% in the last year, said Ron Shaich, Chairman and CEO of Panera Bread.  Additionally, we view our rapid growth, while maintaining industry leading average unit volumes, as a testament to the broad consumer acceptance of the Panera concept and a reflection of the depth of development potential that exists for the Panera concept across this country, he said.  To further research Panera Bread Company, click  PNRA .  McDonalds  (NYSE:  MCD ) is the worlds leading food service retailer with more than 30,000 restaurants in 119 countries, serving 47 million customers each day.  The company is one of the worlds most well-known and valuable brands and holds a leading share in the globally branded quick service restaurant segment of the informal eating-out market in virtually every county in which it does business.  Earlier this month, McDonalds announced that systemwide sales for February 2004 jumped +22.6%, or +14.8 in constant currencies.  Comparable sales for McDonalds restaurants worldwide increased +13.9%.  The performance was helped by an extra day in February due to leap year.  The month marked the tenth straight of increased systemwide comparable sales.  While the company knows that some unique factors helped Februarys numbers, the performance was also helped by its Plan to Win strategy.  The plan includes actions to improve the customer experience through better tasting food, improved service, relevant marketing, and enhanced menu variety.  Mid-February saw the company announce that it generated a record $3.3 billion of cash from operation in 2003, thanks to increased sales at existing restaurants.  The combination of increased cash generation and lower capital expenditures allowed the company to pay down approximately $900 million of debt in 2003 while increasing its annual dividend by +70% to about $500 million.  The revitalization work we have done so far has paid off in increased sales and cash flow at existing restaurants and better restaurant experiences for our customers, said Jim Cantalupo, Chairman and CEO of McDonalds.  We will continue to focus on the customer, improve the restaurant experience and exercise financial discipline.

In its fourth quarter, McDonalds reported diluted earnings of 35 cents per share, excluding net charges, which matched the consensus and surpassed the year-ago result.  Revenues advanced +17%, or +9% in constant currencies, with systemwide sales up +16% and comparable sales up +7.4%.  To further research McDonalds, click  MCD .

Over the past several months, the Experts views presented in this column have been predicting and analyzing the recent correction. John Bollingers suggestion to Say Goodbye in July would have been decent advice to take. The strong move off the March lows to the June highs had many concerned that valuations had gotten ahead of earnings growth. Then, stocks suffered a serious sell off in the wake of the yield spike. Many of the top Experts on Wall Street right now, though, believe that the correction is nearing completion and suspect that stocks will begin a new up move shortly. In spite of the near-term down trend, the dominant trend since October is up. Will the 6.8% drop in the S&P 500 since June 17th be the end of the correction? The Experts weigh in on how to prepare for an intermediate bottom, why the expect the next move to be up and how to profit in such a leg.So Those Were the Earnings, Now What?

Wall Street was fairly pleased with the performance of corporate America in the second quarter earnings reporting season. Conservative expectations, low interest rates, and a declining dollar combined with scattered demand strength to produce an up quarter all around. The market had largely discounted good earnings for the quarter, and it would have taken an aggregate earnings surprise on the order of 30% above expectations to drive the market higher on the news. In fact, a good bit of the weakness, according to several Experts, can be attributed to a low threshold for profit-taking.

Richard Moroney, editor of Dow Theory Forecasts believes that a good barometer for buying stocks, though is to look beyond the absolute earnings level vs. estimates. Strictly using the surprise, i.e. the difference between corporate guidance/analyst estimates and the actual earnings reported, can result in jumping on low-quality earnings bandwagons. Cookie jars, and other accounting gimmicks, allow companies to manage their earnings to a point to beat earnings estimates by a couple of pennies. Coupling guidance and analyst estimates with earnings surprises are approaching Moroneys ultimate decision-making process on which stocks to buy.

Further, the record of the company in beating earnings estimates over the last several quarters and its ability to grow earnings consistently are crucial for the editor of Dow Theory Forecasts. Moroney notes that a critical factor in looking at stocks to buy right now is to include an analysis of the markets reaction to the earnings report. This would seem somewhat intuitive, but it bears delving slightly deeper. The market is first and foremost a discounting mechanism. Most stocks recommended by the Experts trade hundreds of thousands of shares a day. Thus, the stocks movement is the exhibition of the interaction of expectations, estimates and assumptions from thousands of people.

As such, simply reading an earnings report citing performance vs. guidance, or press release that compares the report to estimates does not provide sufficient insight or justification to buy a stock. Taking a look at the response of the stocks price reaction to the earnings report provides further insight into the stocks ability to meet true expectations or force those that follow the stock to revise their expectations upward.Theres No Time Like the Present
Moroney brings this up right now because of our proximity to the 2nd quarter earnings period. He profiles several stocks whose stock prices were goosed in the wake of their earnings releases.

Fisher Scientific (NYSE: FSH ) raised its guidance about a month before the company reported earnings for the second quarter. Ben Zacks, editor of the Zacks Advisor added the company to his Focus List in May, after first quarter earnings, since which it has appreciated 21%. The company beat profit estimates by $.04 per share, and the consensus estimate for the 2003 fiscal year moved the same amount. The company expects around 5% sales growth for 2003, which should prove conservative, and profit margins are likely to expand. The company trades at a modest 16x 2003 earnings, and Moroney rates the company a Buy. Fishers stock price jumped a slight bit right after it reported earnings and has come off less than the indices.

Intel Corp. (NASDAQ: (INTC  -  Free Report) ) benefited from improvement in demand for microprocessors throughout the quarter. The company is boosting R&D spending and predicted higher profit margins for the rest of the year, two signs which pleased investors. Since it reported, analysts have raised their earnings estimates by about 11% for the rest of the year. Moroney predicts the companys communication business will remain weak, but its semiconductor billings have been rising of late. The company, though, trades at 35x earnings, so Moroney rates it strictly a Long Term Buy.As For Sentiment

Paul Hauck and John Scherr are in constant communication with a large community of individual and institutional investors. Hauck and Scherr are both contrarians who state, in their August issue of WhisperNumber Earnings Digest that the renewed interest in stocks that begin in March was a rally killer from the start. The lack of pent up demand from a general balance of bullishness in stocks placed an expiration date on the rally in their opinions. Disney (NYSE: (DIS  -  Free Report) ), AT&T (NYSE: T ), and McDonalds (NYSE: (MCD  -  Free Report) ) moved up during the rally due to the fact that theyd been largely out of favor.

The correction, though, in spite of not igniting a new bear leg, marks the waning of some of that bullishness. Hauck and Scherr expect sentiment to drift lower throughout the rest of August. Late-comers who sat skeptically on the sidelines in March, April and May, and then bought in June, were largely forced to sell in July, and will be among those who drive sentiment lower. Hauck and Scherr expect this new dose of skepticism to set the market up for a rally in late August or early September, though dont think it will be as large as the takeoff from the post-Iraq conflict lows.

Hauck believe that Technology has likely had its rally, and that Financials and Health Care have performed too well to take off. If you seek to invest in Technology stocks, they recommend Microsoft (NASDAQ: (MSFT  -  Free Report) ), which hasnt made a significant move lately. Utilities, Energy and Transportation should be a significant part of the concentration of the rally. Hauck and Scherr are also very positive on the Gold sector, and sentiment remains very bearish in that area. Bullishness, they say, would cause them to question their outlook for it.Down Trend Within an Up Market

It has been a long time since a good number of Experts were classifying a particular leg as a correction within a clear up market. Yet, they are making compelling cases right now to find stocks with strong earnings momentum and big cap cyclicals that will benefit from economic strength. Certainly, each of the Experts would concede that the market could turn decidedly bearish and move significantly lower. A positive turn in late August or early September, though, would be clear evidence of market strength and the Experts are hoping and jockeying for the proper positions in their portfolios. What are you doing?
